DOC.HEAD: Earl Wild Gives Carnegie Concert on 75th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Earl Wild celebrated his 75th birthday and lots of people came. Wild strode onto the Carnegie Hall stage and gave a magnificent piano recital on Monday night, the 75th anniversary of his birth in Pittsburgh. A few days before his birthday, Wild said he'd always been known as having expert technique and these days he is thinking about the music more. He began Monday night with Beethoven's ``32 Variations on an Original Theme,'' differentiating the variations with a tiny pause between each. Then he played Chopin's four ``Ballades,'' chosen because they're serious pieces that he has lived with all his life and still is trying to project better. These ``Ballades'' aren't program music. But it's easy for a listener to visualize being in a beautiful maze garden, turning corners and seeing something quite different as Chopin moves between power and delicacy. After intermission, Wild played Liszt's ``Funerailles,'' moving and somehow uplifting, with none of Liszt's well-known bravura, plus two concert etudes and ``Rhapsodie Espagnole.'' Wild composes and makes transcriptions for piano which he considers virtuoso etudes. He played three transcriptions as encores, ``Floods of Spring'' by Rachmaninoff, ``Pas de Quatre'' from Tchaikovsky's ``Swan Lake'' and Gershwin's ``I Got Rhythm.'' Pianist Billy Taylor was seen in the audience smiling broadly during the last one. Wild received a standing ovation, two bouquets and a cake wheeled out from the wings. He was 14, in 1929, when first engaged by Otto Klemperer as pianist for the Pittsburgh Symphony. Trying to build a career during the Depression, his first job was making orchestrations. In 1936 he got hired as staff pianist at NBC. In 1939 he gave the first piano recital on American TV. In 1942, when Toscanini decided to conduct his first ``Rhapsody in Blue,'' he chose Wild, who'd never played it either, as his soloist. Wild was immediately hailed as a Gershwin expert. He taught at the Juilliard School for 10 years and now is distinguished artist-in-residence at Ohio State University.

DOC.HEAD: Expatriate Work Force In Kingdom Changing Face
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The familiar rugged faces and slight builds of the Yemenis, once conspicuous in markets across Saudi Arabia, are slowly disappearing as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis. Instead, Egyptians are showing up in larger numbers, along with more Indians and Pakistanis in a gradual transformation of the lower echelons of the kingdom's labor force. The unique position of up to 2 million Yemenis disintegrated after their government supported Iraq following its invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia retaliated by ending the work and trade privileges which the Yemenis alone enjoyed among scores of other Third World communities, primarily because of the common Saudi-Yemeni border. About half of the Yemenis have already returned home. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, on the other hand, has led the cry against Saddam Hussein from the start of the invasion, and his Egyptian work force is reaping the benefit. Informed sources here expect the Egyptian labor force, already estimated at 750,000, to grow by thousands as the Yemenis depart. One diplomatic source noted that several large companies plan to hire Egyptians and have applied to the Interior Ministry for work visas. ``We've even heard that Egyptian workers whose contracts were renewed in September received generous raises in salary,'' said one informed source. ``It was the private sector showing their appreciation for Egypt's stand.'' The Yemenis' departure has already left some scars, albeit temporary. A trip down Riyadh's Wazira Street reveals scores of empty storefronts, the interiors nothing but rubble and a few remnants of goods sold in haste. ``A Yemeni man used to deliver my newspaper every morning,'' said one executive. ``I haven't seen him for two months. Tomorrow, he's being replaced by a Pakistani.'' Some complain that the Yemeni bakers, known for their delicious Arabic bread, will be sorely missed and impossible to replace. ``Thank goodness the baker I go to is still here,'' said one expatriate. Although the move against Yemen was an angry response to Yemen President Ali Abdullah Saleh's alignment with Saddam, diplomatic sources in Riyadh said the decision probably made sense regardless of politics. ``To have 10 percent of your total population running around without documentation just seems silly,'' said one diplomat. ``It was silly before the invasion, but it was really brought home to them after Aug. 2.'' The authorities had simply decreed that Yemen nationals, previously allowed to work in Saudi Arabia without formal sponsorship, would be treated like everyone else. Except the timing of the measure meant many Saudis would not sponsor them. The majority of Yemenis in Saudi Arabia were shop owners and vendors, semi-skilled and unskilled laborers. Many were mechanics, bakers, merchants, porters, car washers and tea boys. The effect of the new rules on Saudi Arabia's economy has been minimal. A former Saudi government advisor noted: ``There's a lot of underemployment here anyway and the Yemenis contributed to that. I don't think there will be major repercussions from their loss. In fact, I think there will be some benefit.'' Businesses previously in competition with Yemeni merchants would now prosper, he said. A diplomat, however, pointed out that Saudi Arabia may feel the loss of Yemeni spending power. While the average Yemeni salary is 700 riyals (the equivalent of $186) monthly, Yemenis do not remit the greater part of their salaries back home. ``Most of the expatriates can't bring their families with them, but the Yemenis can,'' said the diplomat. ``So they don't send as much money home. It's an important demographic difference - most of the money they earn goes back into the Saudi economy.'' Sources estimate that approximately 1 million Yemenis will remain in Saudi Arabia under official sponsorship. Few expect that number to increase when the Persian Gulf crisis is over. ``I wouldn't like my government to give equal opportunity to those who did not stand with us,'' said the chief operating officer of a major company.

DOC.HEAD: City's Last Family Farm Hangs on in Queens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: John Klein weeds a row of beets and white radishes with a turn-of-the-century, wood-and-iron push hoe. Nearby, tall zucchini plants sprout limp yellow blossoms. His mother, Barbara, sells corn, cucumbers, tomatoes and fruit to passers-by from a stand on the street. This is New York City's last family farm, two green acres in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens, surrounded by small brick apartment houses, an elementary school, paved ball court, and a broad street noisy with buses and traffic from nearby expressways. ``A couple of weeks ago, these guys from Florida got off the Clearview Expressway and came down the street asking directions, and they couldn't believe there was a farm in the middle of Queens. They thought they were in the Twilight Zone,'' said Klein, 25, a fourth-generation farmer. The two acres - slightly bigger than a square city block, with a chain-link fence on three sides and a lawn and tall oaks in front - are all that's left of a 100-acre spread that was sold off piece by piece over the years. The Kleins grow beets, carrots, scallions, radishes, basil, dill, parsley, cucumbers, squash, and kohlrabies - ``stuff that doesn't need that much room to grow,'' Klein explained. The rows are so short, he has to weed them by hand. ``It's too small to use a tractor,'' he said. ``By the time you got there, you'd have to turn it around.'' But the family also grows corn, melons and produce that needs more space on 100 acres in Riverhead, on Long Island's eastern tip. It's trucked in each day to the farm stand. Open July to November, seven days a week from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., the farm stand on 195th Street and 73rd Avenue does a brisk business. ``In Queens, to find a farmer's market, this is really an oasis,'' said Sylvia Ehrlich as she examined tomatoes. ``I come here all the time - the stuff is delicious,'' agreed Michael Morache, who was buying zucchinis. Freshness is key. ``I go out and pick it in the morning and by the end of the day, it's home in their refrigerator,'' said Klein. ``We run out and pick the basil and dill and parsley right away for people because if you leave it out for a half-hour, it gets wilted.'' His great-grandfather, Adam, began farming in Fresh Meadows in the 1890s. His great-aunts, Margaret and Stella, live in two brick houses on the remaining two acres. Why keep the Queens land, when the family owns 100 acres in Riverhead? ``It's definitely a tradition, but it's making a living also,'' said Klein. ``If you go out to Riverhead, on every corner there's a farmstand. But we're the last ones here.'' Certainly Queens is better known as home to the Mets, Archie Bunker and 2 million of the city's 7.5 million residents than as an agricultural community. But Queens, like the four other boroughs, has a rich farming past dating to the 1600s. Only in the 1800s did industry and housing begin to replace open space around the city. Narrow, winding streets in Lower Manhattan recall cowpaths. Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village harks back to the Bleecker Farm of colonial times. In the 1830s, trains chugged ``through miles of rocky wasteland overrun by pigs and goats'' from what is now Little Italy up to Harlem, according to the Works Progress Administration Guide to New York City. Small farms - called truck farms because their produce was trucked into urbanized areas to be sold - remained common in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx until after World War II, when developers gobbled up land to build housing. Henry Ludder, the Queens borough historian, recalled cutting across vegetable fields as he walked home from school in Bayside, Queens, in the early 1940s. ``I can remember pulling a carrot or a beet out of the ground, rubbing the dirt off on my pants and chewing it as I went along,'' he said. About 20 farmhouses dating from 1679 through 1871 around the city are designated landmarks; most are owned by historical societies. Two - the Queens County Farm Museum in Floral Park, and the Decker Farm, owned by the Staten Island Historical Society - remain working farms. But the Klein enterprise is the last family owned farm within city limits. Even the Klein farm in Riverhead is one of a vanishing breed. ``I imagine another 25 years, Riverhead will be like here, and you'll be out there writing about the last farm,'' said Klein's father, also John, 47. After Adam Klein sold most of the Queens property, he bought farmland in Hicksville, Long Island, and then was pushed out further east to Melville, and again out to Riverhead. ``I guess we can't go too much further or else we'll be in the ocean,'' said the younger Klein. ``There's no farms in Hicksville now and there's only four or five farms left out in Melville and property is worth a million dollars an acre out there, so the guys holding it are just dumb,'' his father said. Would he consider selling the two acres in Queens? ``If I didn't want to farm anymore, I'd just plant it with grass, put a big swimming pool in the back,'' he said. ``If you don't have to sell it, why sell it?''

DOC.HEAD: Antique-Loving Teachers Add One-Room Schoolhouse to Collection
DOC.TEXT: Two antique-loving teachers are making a major addition to their collection - a historic one-room schoolhouse. The 96-year-old Lane School must be moved 21 miles to their farm, where Tom Lutzi and his wife, Judy, plan to fix it up. ``One-room schoolhouses are kind of like dinosaurs; they'll be extinct before too long,'' Lutzi said. ``We wanted to save one. You almost have to be a teacher to appreciate it.'' Lutzi and his wife, both second-generation teachers, intend to outfit the schoolhouse with a stove, school bell, desks and slate chalkboards to re-create the classroom as it was when it opened nearly 100 years ago. Lane School was built in 1894, said 82-year-old Leo Taylor, who attended classes at the first- through eighth-grade schoolhouse and later taught there for five years. It closed in 1962. As many as 2,000 pupils attended the school during its 68 years of operation, Taylor said. It won't be the first building the Lutzis have saved. Years ago, they moved an old gas station 35 miles to their farm in southeastern Nebraska. Lutzi said he also has bought a Depression-era outhouse to be placed close to the school.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit-Cutting Lawmakers Know: Keep Your Hands Off Social Security
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers looking for ways to trim the federal deficit can cut defense spending and even raise taxes if they have to. But they have found they'd better not touch Social Security. This year, Social Security will dispense about $265 billion - more than one-fifth of all federal spending. But the program was untouched in the deficit-reduction package enacted last month. And new budget rules make Social Security virtually untouchable in the future. The reason has much to do with the political power of the elderly, but also with the program's overall popularity, analysts and lawmakers say. ``It's a real gut issue,'' said Sen. John D. Rockefeller, D-W.Va. Both Social Security and Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, are ``enormously popular programs,'' noted Henry Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. ``The public opinion polls indicate that people would prefer to cut the deficit in any other way.'' That explains why, as lawmakers were voting billions of dollars in new taxes and defense cuts to cut the budget deficit last month, Social Security recipients being were told their benefits would increase 5.4 percent in January. The Bush administration announced this month it was looking at ways to shift government benefits from the wealthy to the poor, but it specifically excluded Social Security. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., noted that ``members of Congress are still pretty sensitive'' after having to repeal the Medicare catastrophic illness program last year after an outcry by senior citizens who didn't want to pay for it. The program was designed to protect the elderly from financial ruin if they were struck by a devastating illness. A fight over Medicare cuts was one issue that delayed last month's budget agreement. In the final version, Medicare takes a $42 billion hit over five years. About $10 billion of that comes from beneficiaries' pockets. Social Security and Medicare are widely considered the most effective government programs ever to improve the lives of senior citizens. A 1988 Census Bureau report said Social Security benefits lifted 15 million elderly citizens out of poverty in 1986 and cut the poverty rate among the elderly from 47 percent to 14 percent. ``It's done a fantastic job of reducing poverty among the elderly,'' said Robert Ball, former Social Security commissioner. ``About two thirds of beneficiaries get more than half their income from Social Security.'' Social Security and the hospital part of the Medicare program are funded in the same way - with a payroll tax held in a trust fund earmarked solely for that program. Neither program is run like welfare; benefits are given to rich and poor alike. Rather, the criteria are related to age or disability, plus a person's lifetime contributions to the program. ``It's precisely the fact that they're not programs for the poor that gives these programs their unifying force,'' said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at Brookings. ``People think they have paid and now they're entitled'' to benefits, Aaron said. Judy Schub, senior economic lobbyist at the American Association of Retired Persons, said the elderly tend to think of their Social Security benefits as money that was put away for them, ``that there's a piggy bank with my name on it.'' However, the system is an inter-generational plan, with today's recipients receiving far more than they ever paid into the system. Current workers are paying those benefits. After financial troubles in the early 1980s, Social Security benefits were scaled back in 1983 and other changes were made to keep its trust fund solvent. Now there's a large surplus, and Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., tried this year to reduce the Social Security payroll tax so that money from the program would not grow so quickly and be used to mask the size of the federal budget deficit. His effort was unsuccessful, but others in Congress did succeed in removing the program from the calculations used to determine the federal deficit. That means that cutting Social Security won't help the deficit. Medicare, however, is facing mounting pressure, as inflation in medical costs continues to outpace overall inflation. The reserves in the Medicare hospital insurance trust fund are shrinking and the fund faces bankruptcy in 13 to 15 years unless action is taken, according to the 1990 annual report of the program's Board of Trustees. Ball said he is mindful of Social Security's popularity and the political risk in touching it. ``Changes should be made in Social Security from time to time ... to bring it up to date and make it a better program,'' said Ball, a member of the Social Security Advisory Committee at the Department of Health and Human Services. But, he said, ``The changes should be made for sound Social Security policy, not to reduce the deficit.''

DOC.HEAD: The Lovers Keep Their Clothes On in Congressman's Movie Script
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Critics of Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, arch-foe of federal spending on ``obscene art,'' hooted with glee over rumors that the conservative California Republican had written a movie script ablaze with steamy love scenes. But Rohrabacher is having the last laugh. He says he's on the brink of signing a deal with Hollywood producers to film his screenplay, ``The French Doctoresse,'' a World War II drama of romance and intrigue that he predicts will earn nothing worse than a PG rating. ``There's not a single bedroom scene, or people not wearing any clothes,'' he said. ``It's something the whole family could see. I think it's going to be the `Dr. Zhivago' of the 1990s.'' Rohrabacher is a bearded, 43-year-old bachelor, surfing enthusiast and former newspaperman who was a speech writer for President Reagan until he won election to the House in 1988 with a campaign boost from White House buddy Oliver L. North. In the House, where he represents a staunchly conservative coastal district south of Los Angeles, Rohrabacher quickly became the scourge of the National Endowment for the Arts, which he accuses of financing pornography and sacrilegious works. Rohrabacher said he sold everything he owned, except for his car and his typewriter, to finish ``The French Doctoresse'' in the late 1970s, and was reduced to sleeping on his brother's living room sofa. As poor as he was, Rohrabacher said, he never once contemplated applying for a federal grant. Besides, he said, his script was much too tame to interest the arts endowment. ``Who knows what kind of steamy sex scenes would be required for me to get an NEA grant?'' he said with a chuckle. His screenplay is based on the real-life story of Jeanne Varagnat, a wealthy, red-haired, divorced French physician who falls in love with a handsome young French fighter pilot named John Fontaine. Madame Varagnat spends the war years trying to win the release of her lover, who is captured and eventually executed by the Germans. After the war, she is imprisoned on charges of collaborating with the Nazis, but she is acqitted at her trial when she proves she was not a traitor but a spy for the French Resistance. Rohrabacher's screenplay reads more like a Harlequin romance written for the ``Care Bears'' crowd. Even a PG rating might be overreacting. Rohrabacher's story has the lovers meeting on a skiing vacation. The pilot has taken a tumble on the slopes. Cut to the resort's infirmary. ``As Jeanne waits for John to regain consciousness, she can't help noticing his handsome features and rugged, virile body. ...'' ``A whirlwind romance ensues. The couple take sleigh rides through the snow; many nights are spent in front of a fireplace. Against the majesty of the French Alps, they kiss as they ride a ski lift.'' Midnight is tolled at a New Year's Eve party, and ``the lovers kiss as 1940 explodes into reality around them.'' They enjoy a picnic in the countryside. ``The food and wine are consumed with gusto, and the two lovers embrace under the shady branches.'' That's about as hot as it gets. There isn't enough steam to take the Marine Corps crease out of Ollie North's trousers. Rohrabacher envisions Jessica Lange, Meryl Streep or even Jane Fonda playing the ``older woman,'' and said the young lover's role should go to a ``Mel Gibson with a French accent.'' But Rohrabacher warns that once a deal is signed, Hollywood producers will be free to write sex or violence into the final script to enhance the movie's box-office appeal. The congressman said he wouldn't object if the R-rated material improved the plot and wasn't merely exploitative. In any event, he would have little say in the matter. ``If they want to make it steamy, they can do it. They own it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Congressional Staff Shows High Turnover, Low Pay
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Many scholars and commentators speculate on why Congress does what it does, with explanations ranging from partisan theology to personal avarice to group psychology. Fewer have tried to explain, however, why Congress does what it does as poorly as it often does. But a new survey by the Congressional Management Foundation offers some insight with a look into the inner workings of House members' offices. The picture that emerges is not one of an elite cadre of public policy experts as voters might expect. Instead, it's a revolving door where some offices must have higher turnover than fast-food restaurants. ``Work in Congress has become a stepping stone for the young and restless rather than a career for the dedicated and experienced,'' said Rick Shapiro, executive director of the foundation and a coauthor of the study. The foundation, which tries to instill professional management practices in lawmakers, found data that make Shapiro's statement seem quite mild. For example, 52 percent of House legislative assistants, the people who tackle specific issues for the members and recommend solutions, have been at their jobs less than one year. Nearly 40 percent of their bosses - the legislative directors - are in the same category. A congressman's top aide is called an administrative assistant. This is the person who oversees everything, is the keeper of the body, the equivalent of the president's chief of staff. Amazingly, nearly a third of these people have been on the job less than a year. And all House staffers have held their jobs for 15 percent less time than they did in 1987. ``It means that members of the House are generally receiving essential advice and support from staff who have considerably less experience than the staff they worked with just three years ago,'' Shapiro said. To put it more bluntly, there are a lot of people on Capitol Hill tinkering with the nation's laws who may not know what they're doing - and it's not just the people who are elected. The foundation points to salaries as one explanation for the rapid turnover. The average House employee makes $29,542, more than $2,000 less than the average federal worker and $11,000 less than private sector earners. This statistic is misleading, however, since so many House employees are so young. The average administrative assistant is 38; the average legislative assistant is 26. Senior staffers in Congress are quite well paid. The average administrative assistant gets nearly $63,000, and more than 10 percent are above $80,000. Some of them can - and do - turn around and double or triple their salaries by signing on with lobbying firms. All of this suggests that legislative competence is getting short shrift in congressional offices. Just think back to this year's budget-making mangle, and it's hard to argue with that conclusion. So where are congressmen putting their priorities? Toward getting re-elected, of course. This year's elections showed once again that big, national issues weren't the downfall of very many lawmakers. Perhaps that's because the built-in advantages of incumbency are nurtured by the members. The biggest pay raises handed out in congressional offices over the past three years, totaling 18.8 percent, went to press secretaries, the men and women who make sure their bosses get good coverage in hometown newspapers and local television programs. Another reason members are rarely kicked out of Congress is because of the favors they do for the folks back home. Next to the press people, the directors of the lawmakers' home district offices had the biggest salary boosts, at 18.3 percent over three years. They also had more job stability than any other type of congressional office employee, with an average of 5.5 years in the position. Right after them in tenure - with an average 4.7 years - were the caseworkers, the folks who can help straighten out a citizen's problem with Social Security or a businessman's beef with the Small Business Administration. These are the kind of favors that challengers can only dream of delivering to voters. Challengers might be more successful if they could convince voters that those services would continue no matter who holds the jobs, while the issues they are voting on are getting less and less expert attention. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0428, changes format coding
Better Times Slow to Arrive at FmHA
DOC.TEXT: Better times have helped ease loan pressures on the Farmers Home Administration, but a backlog of hard-luck cases has sharply boosted foreclosure actions by the agency. In the 1990 fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, the FmHA tallied 50,803 loan applications, down 13 percent from 58,539 in 1989, according to a year-end report. Overall, the FmHA - traditionally called the government's farm lender of last resort - had a farm loan portfolio of about $24 billion among 210,458 active borrowers. Of those, 31,925 were behind in their payments as of Sept. 30. A year earlier, when there were 230,013 loans outstanding, 41,213 were in arrears, an 18 percent delinquency rate. The FmHA, an agency of the Agriculture Department, makes loans to farmers and others who can't qualify at banks and other commercial lenders. The agency's total portfolio, including farm, rural housing and other programs is around $57.5 billion. Marlyn Aycock, an agency spokesman, said the loan decline is attributable to ``what's happened in the farm economy, generally'' over the last few years. According to USDA economists, cash farm income nationally in 1990 is expected to be at a record level, probably in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up from $55 billion in 1989. That is the money left over in a calendar year from gross cash income after paying cash expenses, according to USDA analysts. The previous high was $58.4 billion in 1988. But the mills grind slowly in FmHA, and thousands of farmers are still being affected by the financial crunch of the early and mid-1980s when debt loads forced thousands into restructuring loans and, for some, into foreclosure proceedings. The number of potential foreclosures is indicated by ``acceleration'' letters sent to delinquent borrowers, a major step toward final closeout of an FmHA loan through foreclosure. Another step is the number of accelerated cases referred to USDA lawyers to await formal foreclosure action by the government. Last fiscal year, according to the report, 5,462 acceleration letters were sent out, representing 2.6 percent of all farm borrowers. In the previous year, notices went t 4,045 borrowers, or 1.8 percent. Aycock said bankruptcy petitions and the number of FmHA delinquency cases sent to the department's Office of General Counsel for foreclosure action also have increased. ``It means that we're working through the old backlog, and more and more of these cases are getting closer to a conclusion,'' he said. Foreclosures aren't the only way FmHA can collect what is owed, nor are foreclosures the only reasons farmers go out of business. Pressure by the agency can result in the sale of property, in which case the debt is often settled, or in the voluntary transfer of property to FmHA as part of a settlement deal. According to the annual report, there were 2,505 FmHA borrowers who left farming ``due to financial difficulties'' in the 1990 fiscal year, representing 1.2 percent of the total number of farm borrowers. In 1989, only 2,066 left farming due to financial difficulties, representing 0.9 percent of 1989 borrowers. Actual foreclosure actions completed by FmHA last year totaled 243 against only 45 in 1989. In addition, there were 179 foreclosure actions completed by banks and other lienholders that share loans with the agency, compared with 258 in 1989. Eight states accounted for three-fourths of last year's FmHA foreclosures: Alabama, 18; Georgia, 18; Minnesota, 26; Mississippi, 12; Missouri, 28; North Carolina, 29; South Dakota, 17; and Texas, 35. Meanwhile, the FmHA has written off in one way or another nearly 40 percent of $8.8 billion in overdue loan payments. The forgivenesses stem from the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, which allowed write-down and write-off of debts in cases where collection costs would exceed the recovery value. Some borrowers, working with FmHA, also are allowed to ``buy out'' their loans at current liquidation rates. Aycock said that as of September, the buyouts of 6,774 loans showed net losses totaling $1.46 billion. Write-downs of 6,580 totaled $1.02 billion. In addition, about $1 billion in old debts, some going back 10 years or more, have been written off completely as uncollectable.

DOC.HEAD: Mercenary Wasps Deployed in War Against Crop-Munching Pests
DOC.TEXT: Mercenary ``killer wasps'' are being deployed in a battle to rescue besieged cabbage, broccoli and other vegetables without resorting to chemical pesticide warfare. Scientists say the wasps cost about the same as pesticides but attack pests on parts of plants that chemical sprays don't reach and can eliminate crop-eating bugs that have developed immunities to insecticides. The wasps also are choosy about their victims. They do not sting humans or animals. Wasps released two weeks ago in the Rio Grande Valley naturally seek out the larvae of the diamond-back moth and lay eggs inside them, ensuring their destruction. ``Our research has shown that the wasps can provid a new way to reduce insect damage to cabbage, broccoli and other vegetables without using insecticides,'' said entomologist K. Duane Biever of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. In previous tests, Biever found only 5 percent pest damage to broccoli fields after releasing 300 to 600 pairs of wasps per acre. In fields without the wasps, 25 percent of the crops were damaged. The strain of wasps was developed at a USDA laboratory in Washington and bred commercially at a private laboratory in Sinton, a town north of Corpus Christi.

DOC.HEAD: Safe Sex Shop Blends Humor With Business of Education
LaserPhoto MA1 of Nov. 24
DOC.TEXT: AIDS is no laughing matter at the Safer Sex Boutique, but the unique shop offers such lighthearted gifts as condom-shaped candy and boxer shorts adorned with smiling condom cartoons that glow in the dark. Shoppers also can buy earrings and key chains that discreetly store condoms inside, or use a computer that calculates a person's likelihood of exposure to AIDS. The unusual store, open this holiday season, is a commercial experiment to market both silly and serious products that promote safe sex and draw attention to the needs of those who have acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``This is designed to talk about and promote safer sex by making it more fun and exciting,'' said Dave Rompa, executive director of the AIDS Support Network in Madison, an advocacy group that helped develop the business. ``Some stores will have a safe-sex corner or cute little condom section, but there's never been a whole store devoted to it,'' he said. Since the boutique opened Nov. 5, it has drawn about 2,000 people - both shoppers and the simply curious - ranging from teen-agers and their parents to divorcees returning to the dating scene, Rompa said. In addition to shelves of books, magazines and videotapes about the dangers of AIDS and ways to minimize exposure, the store sells cards containing condoms, comic books promoting and explaining their use and T-shirts urging contraceptive use because it's ``condom sense.'' There are also pink-and-black boxer shorts dotted with pictures of smiling condoms that glow in the dark. ``Condom-shaped chocolate mints and glow-in-the-dark condoms are also big sellers,'' Rompa said. The store was funded through donations and fund raising by the support group, Rompa said. Many of the products were donated by manufacturers and merchants throughout the United States, Great Britain and Canada, he said. Rompa declined to say how much money the store has earned. It is staffed by volunteers and all profits are returned to the group. The shop will close Dec. 31, but Rompa said the group seeks more funding and hopes to reopen next year. ``If people take safe sex seriously, it could be an ongoing business,'' Rompa said. ``We opened now for two months because these are the best shopping months and we're providing products that are outreach, educational and practical.'' The store sells several types of condoms - barriers against sexually-transmitted diseases such as AIDS - anti-bacterial soaps and other products designed to halt the spread of the incurable virus. It also features a computer that estimates a person's risk of exposure to AIDS based on their sexual practices and another that describes possible treatments for those stricken with the fatal virus. ``We have a huge number of parents coming in and young people - high school-age - who want to know more because they aren't sure what safer sex was all about,'' Rompa said.

DOC.HEAD: RERTRANSMITS a0438, to include writethru designator.
Delaying Tactics Prolong One-Party Rule in Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also serves as writethru to b0170, sent in advance Nov. 19; adds 2 grafs on Sunday's parliamentary election in Ivory Coast.
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Promises have been made a year after Africans braved tear gas and gunfire to shout for democracy in more than a dozen capitals, but not a single one-party government has been unseated. Fifteen regimes have said they would accept multiparty rule, but there is no sign that democratically elected administrations will replace any of them soon. Leaders who could not crush protest movements with troops and arrests have turned to delaying tactics. While paying lip service to democracy with promises of free elections, critics say, they use a bag of dirty tricks to stay in power. Those who mimicked the communist system and told their people to look there for inspiration were taken at their word when East Europeans started demanding freedom. After the collapse of Communist parties in the Soviet bloc, the writing was on the wall for Africa's one-party governments. Western nations that helped corrupt leaders, in order to keep them from the Soviet orbit, found it difficult to justify more support. ``There is no true development without genuine democracy,'' Jacques Pelletier, the French minister in charge of relations with Africa, said recently. France is a staunch advocate of aid to Third World countries, but Pelletier's comments echoed those of African opposition leaders, not governments. At a conference on Africa, Herman Cohen, U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, said governments that resisted their people's demands for democracy would find themselves ``in an increasingly disadvantageous position'' in the competition for aid. Bans on opposition parties have been lifted in six countries: Benin, Cape Verde, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Sao Tome and Zaire. Nine have agreed to move toward ending one-party government, but opposition parties are not yet operating. They are Angola, Cameroon, Congo, Guinea Bissau, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Somalia and Zambia. The first show of unrest came from Benin, where protesters stoned a statue of Lenin. They blamed the nation's bankruptcy on the Marxist-Leninist ideology adopted by President Mathieu Kerekou, who gained power in a coup, and demanded his resignation. Kerekou renounced communism in response and said his government was writing a new constitution to liberalize the economy and guarantee human rights. In a move later copied by President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, he appointed a transition government but set no date for himself to step down. Mobutu shocked Zaire in April when, under intense pressure from the United States and other Western backers, he said he would give in to demands for multiparty democracy. Student unrest continued and Belgium, the former colonial power, accused Zairean commandos in May of killing more than 100 at Lubumbashi University. Mobutu's government claimed only one student was killed and blamed local government officials. In November, six months after Mobutu legalized opposition parties, soldiers still were breaking up their meetings. On Nov. 6, opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi said Mobutu had ordered him prevented from leaving the country to meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in the United States. Other leaders, like President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo and Joseph Momoh of Sierra Leone, have said no to change and often have called out soldiers to enforce the decision. Gabon moved closer to democracy than the others when President Omar Bongo was forced to conduct the first multiparty general election in 22 years. Several rounds of voting had to be held because voters smashed ballot boxes, burned government cars and attacked officials they claimed were rigging the election. Bongo emerged with a bare majority in the National Assembly, but his term as president does not expire for three years. Ivory Coast held its first contested presidential election in October. Police dispersed opposition campaign rallies with tear gas and clubs. On election day, voters smashed ballot boxes and claimed fraud. Government-controlled television and radio denied the opposition access until the campaign was nearly over, then censored their statements. Laurent Gbagbo, a history professor, was the only opposition candidate. Two others could not raise bonds equivalent to $80,000 each, which the government announced as a requirement one week before the 10-day campaign began. Everyone expected the victory of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the octogenarian who has ruled since independence from France in 1960, but many doubt he got the 81.67 percent of the vote his government claims. The country's first multiparty parliamentary election was held Sunday, and opposition leaders claimed it was marred by intimidation and fraud perpetrated by Houphouet-Boigny's Democratic Party. Turnout was light. The Democrats were expected to easily win a majority, reinforcing Houphouet-Boigny's huge victory last month. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Michelle Faul, now based in Abidjan, has covered Africa for 14 years.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Fuel Storage Tanks Catches Fire Near Denver Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with two more storage tanks ablaze, firemen pulled back. Edits to conform. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `There are...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing.
DOC.TEXT: Four storage tanks holding more than 2 million gallons of jet fuel caught fire Sunday near Stapleton International Airport, snarling comings and goings at the terminal as holiday travelers headed home after Thanksgiving. A fire at a holding pond that had collected some of the spilled fuel was extinguished with foam, but authorities feared it might reignite and spread to a nearby 2 million-gallon fuel tank. Firefighters had been trying to cool two 800,000-gallon tanks containing jet fuel throughout the day, spraying them with strong jets of water, but they caught fire about 10 p.m. When the two tanks ruptured, firefighters had to be pulled back. The tanks were designed to rupture, rather than explode, when overheated, officials said. An attempt to snuff that part of the fire with foam failed. ``We didn't have the capacity to provide foam in the amount needed,'' Fire Chief Rich Gonzales said. Three firefighters were treated at Denver General Hospital for dehydration and heat exhaustion and two others were treated for smoke inhalation at the scene, but the fire caused no serious injuries. Smoke from the blaze cast a pall over metropolitan Denver and caused visibility problems on nearby Interstate 70, which remained open. Norm Avery, a Stapleton spokesman, said the airport was open, but United Airlines was forced to delay, cancel and divert flights because of a fuel shortage. There also were traffic jams outside the airport on one of the it's busiest days, when travelers were returning from the Thanksgiving holiday. Stapleton is the nation's fourth-busiest U.S. airport as measured by numbers of passengers traveling through it. Airport officials initially planned to contain the intial fire and let it burn itself out, but they changed their plans when flames altered by shifting winds began to threaten the larger tanks. The fire was reported about 9:30 a.m. at the fuel tank farm about a half-mile north of the Stapleton terminal and just south of I-70. Also threatened were two tanks about 100 yards from the blaze that held 1.5 million gallons of jet fuel each, said Mike McNeill, a Denver Fire Department spokesman. The fire torched nearby utility poles and generated so much heat that firefighters worked in 30-minute shifts near the flames. The blaze apparently was caused by a broken valve leading into one of two 400,000-gallon-capacity storage tanks, and the heat from the first fire ignited the second tank, Avery said. There are no homes or businesses anywhere near the site. The storage tanks were part of Stapleton's fuel storage farm, which supplies jet fuel to most of the airlines at the airport. It is the chief source of fuel for United Airlines. In attempting to control the fire, firefighters shut off the underground pipeline from the tank farm to the Stapleton terminal, and United officials were scrambling to find ways to obtain jet fuel, said Stapleton spokesman Richard Boulware. United Airlines reported flight delays of up to four hours out of Denver, affecting connecting flights at other major hubs, officials said. ``United is virtually out of fuel and trying to make arrangements to get more,'' said Boulware. Some United flights were diverted to Colorado Springs and other nearby airports to obtain fuel, and other flights were delayed or canceled, United officials at the airport said. Boulware said Continental Airlines was forced to shift its refueling operations to a Stapleton concourse, but this had little effect on its operations.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Higher, Share Prices Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against the yen Monday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced moderately. The dollar finished at 127.95 yen, the day's high, up 0.82 yen from last Thursday's close of 127.13 yen. It opened at 127.50 yen, and ranged between 127.45 yen and 127.95 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 362.58 points, or 1.55 percent, closing at 23,762.86. The index posted a 583.29 point gain last Thursday. Japan's markets were closed Friday for a national holiday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 86.81 as of 3 p.m. (11 a.m. EST), up from Thursday's close of 86.11. Their yield fell to 7.310 percent from 7.465 percent. Currency traders said there was no major market-moving news on hand, although reports the United States will seek U.N. approval this week for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq spurred some dollar buying. Tsuyoshi Yamamoto, a dealer with Industrial Bank of Japan, said the trading was rather active on cross trading between West German mark and the yen, affecting the dollar-yen trading. ``As for dollar-yen trading, it moved in a narrow range,'' he said. On the stock market, the index started higher on small-lot buying on a broad front in a favorable reaction to a firmer bond market, securities dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Face Budget Cuts After Passage of Term-Limit Initiative
DOC.TEXT: California lawmakers returning to work next week will be tackling a familiar issue: budget cuts. This time, however, they'll be slashing their own budgets. Voters on Nov. 6 narrowly passed Proposition 140, which limits lawmakers' terms, eliminates their pension benefits and demands cuts of about 40 percent in the Legislature's budget. Analysts say half of the 3,200 legislative staff members could be laid off. The day after the proposition passed, Assembly Speaker Willie Brown spoke to Capitol staffers. ``He said, `Don't worry till after the holidays. Go ahead and try to have a good Thanksgiving and Christmas. We've got 'til July.''' said Michael Reese, Brown's press secretary. Still, most lawmakers returning for the new session Dec. 3 are already pondering prospects of layoffs and lawsuits. Many members of their staffs are looking for new jobs. The session lasts through August. The Senate Rules Committee sent a memo suggesting senators begin planning staff reductions. The committee said it would offer ``golden handshakes'' to encourage long-time employees to retire. ``What's out there permeating the place is the human factor,'' said Bob Forsyth, a spokesman for Sen. David Roberti, chairman of the committee. ``I think most people who came to work for the Legislature came here voluntarily. They do not get civil service benefits. They're anxious about their job futures.'' Proposition 140 passed with 52 percent of the vote. It was backed by anti-tax crusader Lewis Uhler and conservative Republican Los Angeles County Supervisor Pete Schabarum. It limits Assembly members to three two-year terms. Senate members, the governor and other elected statewide officials, and members of a state tax board, can serve no more than two four-year terms. The measure also eliminates legislators' pension benefits, leaving only what had been accrued by Election Day. The mandated legislative budget cuts must be made by July 1, but the proposition does not spell out how. ``I think it's clear then when you have over 3,000 legislative employees, you could probably prune pretty heavily and still get the legitimate legislative business done,'' Uhler said. San Francisco attorney Joe Remcho said he believes Proposition 140 is vulnerable to a legal challenge. The Senate Rules Committee is also reviewing the legal issues involved. Remcho successfully sued on behalf of the Legislature's Democratic leaders and others to overturn a campaign spending initiative approved by voters in 1988. Backers of the measure are appealing that federal court decision. Remcho said lifetime term limits on legislators disenfranchise voters, particularly minorities. Uhler said the initiative was drafted to withstand court challenges. Sponsors reluctantly agreed to give incumbens the same fresh six- to eight-year limits newcomers face, he said. ``That's a long time for those who carry grudges in the Legislature and who seek retribution, a lot of time for that to play out,'' Uhler said.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Shutdowns to Idle About 40,000 Workers This Week
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers are blaming economic uncertainty and dealer backlogs for the temporary layoff of 38,800 employees. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said the layoffs would begin today and run through Dec. 7 at 14 assembly plants in eight states. ``We are watching the marketplace and then we adjust production to meet those needs,'' Kathy Tanner, spokeswoman for GM's Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group, said Sunday. Additional layoffs would be announced five to 10 days before they were to be imposed, officials said. ``I wouldn't be surprised to see more,'' said Joel Pitcoff, Ford's research and analysis manager. ``We've been having shortages of dealer orders for some time,'' Pitcoff said. ``It's clear the dealers are nervous about the recession talk.'' The shutdowns won't put a big pinch on workers' wallets. Contract agreements with the United Auto Workers union provide laid-off workers with up to 95 percent pay during shutdowns. The layoffs are an indication of a slowdown in the industry, with manufacturers possibly wanting to avoid the over-buildup they experienced a year ago when 107,000 Big Three workers were furloughed in January. Ward's Automotive Report, an industry newsletter, reported inventory for the nine major U.S. automakers stood at 72 days Nov. 10, compared with 88 days in December 1989. The largest single layoff will be at Chrysler's Toledo, Ohio, plant, where company spokesman Doug Nicoll said about 4,700 workers are affected. GM announced about 21,900 layoffs, and Ford has furloughed about 12,200 workers.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Panther Genes Diluted, Protection in Jeopardy
DOC.TEXT: Genetic tests show that as many as half the 50 Florida panthers still remaining in the wild may not be true Florida panthers at all, but a hybrid species, biologists said. Scientists warn that if the hybrids found in Everglades National Park and the neighboring Big Cypress Swamp area continue to dilute true Florida panthers' bloodlines, the species could become so watered down it could lose its place on the endangered-species list. ``If the panther were to lose protection, then the entirety of wild Florida is left open to development,'' says Melody Roelke, who studies panthers for the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission. If bumped off the list, the cats would no longer be protected by a federal ban on killing or capturing them. The federal Endangered Species Act doesn't cover hybrid animals. Genetic tests of 26 panthers in South Florida showed only 13 were true Florida panthers. The others were a hybrid of Florida panthers and a South American cousin released into the wild in the 1950s and 1960s. The pure descendants of true Florida panthers are characterized by a kink in the tail and a cowlick, of ruff of spiky hair, on their tawny colored backs. They live mostly in the Big Cypress National Preserve. The others, descendants of Florida panthers and seven captive cats released into the wild between 1957 and 1967, also are tawny colored. Similar cross-breeding has prompted officials to consider removing others from the endangered species list. The federal Farm Bureau has asked the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to take the gray wolf off the list because genetic evidence shows some gray wolves cross-bred with coyotes.

DOC.HEAD: Some Businessmen Uncertain About Free Trade Pact
With PM-Bush-Mexico, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari chose Monterrey for the summit with President Bush because this northern city symbolizes the economic miracle he envisions for Mexico. But as Bush arrives to discuss a free trade agreement, some businessmen fear Mexican industry could suffer under such a pact. ``It's inevitable: Some businesses will fail, others will have to change,'' said Miguel Garza, who owns a ceramics factory. ``It's a new world.'' Because the agreement has not taken form, uncertainty is mixed with the skepticism. Formal negotiations don't begin until next year and could take two years to complete. ``A free trade agreement will not change our situation and could help us,'' said Ernesto Garcia Martinez, director of Cifunsa, an auto parts company in nearby Saltillo. ``The Mexican automotive industry has proven itself for quality and volume.'' Labor leaders predict a free trade agreement will cost jobs by creating a form of economic Darwinism that will choke industries unable to compete with U.S. technology and industrial efficiency. When President Franklin D. Roosevelt visited Monterrey in 1943, it already was on the way to becoming Mexico's industrial capital. ``We are the locomotive that is pulling the nation to modernization,'' Mayor Socrates Rizzo says now. Glass-and-steel towers occupied by businessmen with U.S. university degrees have come to overshadow the colonial buildings and cobbled streets of Old Monterrey. The city glitters with prosperity, but city workers made it over for the summit nonetheless, painting buildings and repairing streets while White House teams checked security arrangements. More than 1,000 telephone lines were installed to accommodate hundreds of journalists. A heliport was built in Monterrey and an airstrip added to Salinas' nearby hometown of Agualeguas for the Bush visit. On a mountain facing Monterrey's 100-acre Grand Plaza, a neon sign flashed ``Welcome'' in English and Spanish. The monument to the meeting between Roosevelt and President Manuel Avila Camacho, a large concrete cross on a street corner, had been vandalized and its plaque was missing. It was cleaned up, repaired and moved to a park. A monument to the Bush visit has a flame that will remain lighted while he is here. Interdependence with the United States has developed in Monterrey through cross-border culture, U.S.-owned assembly plants and travel. The city is 150 miles from Texas, and the U.S. consulate issued more than 200,000 visas last year for travel north of the border. Nuevo Leon state, of which Monterrey is the capital, now has 7,500 businesses. The number is expected to increase with a free trade agreement and completion of new border-crossing facilities and bridges. Monterrey's press is generally recognized as the fairest and most aggressive in Mexico. The newspaper El Norte prepared a 100-page bilingual special section for the summit. In a year, the city plans to open one of Latin America's largest art museums. A 17-mile light rail transit system is to begin service in March and an international business and trade show center will be inaugurated in the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Presidential Election At A Glance
With PM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at Poland's first popular presidential election, which was held Sunday. --- AT STAKE - Presidency of the Republic of Poland, the head of state and commander in chief of the military responsible for internal and external security. Nominates the prime minister, has limited veto power over parliament, can dissolve parliament or declare a state of emergency under strictly defined circumstances. Powers are likely to be redefined in a new constitution expected to be approved in 1991. --- TERM OF OFFICE - Five years. Two terms maximum. --- INCUMBENT - Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, former leader of Communist Party. --- REQUIRED TO WIN - More than 50 percent of the vote. If no candidate receives an outright majority, top two vote-getters contest a second round Dec. 9. --- ELIGIBLE VOTERS - 27,540,933 in Poland plus unknown number abroad. --- POLLING PLACES - 22,209, including 177 abroad, 295 on Polish ships and, for the first time, 130 in prisons. --- RESULTS EXPECTED - Official results expected Tuesday. --- CANDIDATES - Lech Walesa, 47, Solidarity chairman, endorsed by the Center Alliance party and the Solidarity union. Tadeusz Mazowiecki, 63, prime minister, endorsed by Citizens Movement for Democratic Action. Stanislaw Tyminski, 42, Polish-born, Canadian-Peruvian businessman, independent. Roman Bartoszcze, 44, chairman and candidate of Polish Peasants Party. Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, 40, a parliamentarian endorsed by the Social Demorcracy Party, a successor to the Communist Party. Leszek Moczulski, 60, chairman and candidate of nationalist Confederation for an Independent Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov, Karpov Agree to a Draw
DOC.TEXT: The second half of the World Championship between chess masters and arch-rivals Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov began with a draw. They were to return to the table today for the second game of the championship's French phase. The 13th game had adjourned Saturday night after 41 moves in five hours of play with a draw inevitable, according to the experts. Karpov, who is trying to regain the world championship title from defender Kasparov, proposed the draw on Sunday by telephone through the intermediary of Dutch referee Geurt Gijssen, officials said, an option open to either player. Kasparov accepted. Karpov, playing white, would have opened Sunday's play with the 42nd move, which was sealed Saturday night in an envelope. Kasparov, 27, and Karpov, 39, now each have 6{ points. They were tied at six points apiece after the first 12 games in New York from Oct. 8 to Nov. 7 - 10 of which were draws. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. Saturday's match in the main auditorium of the Palais des Congres in this southcentral city was the first in the championship series in two weeks. Karpov moved the queen's pawn to begin play. The players went through a series of moves known as the Grunfeld defense, which was used in Game 9. Kasparov varied it a bit when he castled on the eighth move. The pair traded queens before the 20th move and were reduced to eight pieces each by the 30th. Karpov repeatedly left his chair in the early part of the match. Kasparov stayed at the board, hunched over in deep thought. At the adjournment, Kasparov had just taken a pawn to finish with five pawns, a rook and the king. Karpov had four pawns, a rook and a king but was about to take a black pawn to even things up again. Karpov waited more than 10 minutes as the five-hour time limit drew close before sealing his 42nd move. ``I thought it was reasonable exciting,'' said international grandmaster Mike Valvo of Perth Amboy, N.J. ``It was not a dull 25-30 move draw you would see in other matches.'' Karpov ran into a time problem as the time limit approached, with only nine minutes to complete eight moves. Each player is alloted 2{ hours for his first 40 moves. But Karpov moved eight times in his next seven minutes. ``Most of us who sat and watched thought that white had chances to win,'' Valvo said. ``In time pressure, Karpov seemed to let whatever edge he had slip away.'' Kasparov gained the title in 1985 from Karpov, who had held it from 1975. Their dislike for each other is well-known. The two men differ in temperment, looks, politics and even playing style. Kasparov considers Karpov a product of the Soviet system. ``Normally chess is a battle between two individuals,'' Kasparov has said in an interview. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rebounds Against Yen, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded against the yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose again in thin trading. The dollar closed at 127.95 yen, the day's high, up 0.82 yen from Thursday's close of 127.13 yen. It opened at 127.50 yen and went no lower than 127.45 yen. In the previous three trading days, it had fallen a total of 2.60 yen. Japan's markets were closed Friday for a national holiday. Some $6.94 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, down from $9.95 billion on Thursday. Currency traders said there was no major news to move the market, although reported U.S. plans to seek U.N. approval this week for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq spurred some dollar buying. ``Amid a lack of incentives, the dollar moved gradually up on short-covering,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 583.29 points Thursday, added another 362.58 points, or 1.55 percent, closing at 23,762.86. A total of 250 million shares were traded on the first section, down from 360 million shares Thursday. Securities dealers said the index rose on arbitrage and index-linked buying. In arbitrage trading, investors seek to profit from price differentials between the spot and futures markets. ``The market was encouraged by a firm movement on the bond market,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 86.56, from Thursday's close of 86.11. Their yield fell to 7.365 percent from 7.465 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Plan Detailed 3-D Map of Universe
DOC.TEXT: Scientists eager to create a three-dimensional map of the universe are embarking on a $14 million telescope project aimed at exploring the origins of galaxies. The search of the skies is expected to produce the most detailed charts of the universe to date, according to members of the Astrophysical Research Consortium, a group composed of several universities and the Princeton N.J.-based Institute for Advanced Study. Scientists said they hope to produce a three-dimensional layout of 1 million galaxies, 100,000 quasars and numerous intergalactic gas clouds. A two-dimensional color version of 100 million galaxies also is planned. The survey ``is the cosmic equivalent of a U.S. Geological Survey map,'' said Richard Kron, a professor of astronomy and astrophysics at the University of Chicago. ``It will show the details of galaxy and quasar distribution as well as the large-scale `geography' of the universe,'' Kron said. Quasars are starlike, celestial objects that produce immense quantities of light or powerful radio waves, or both. The University of Chicago is a member of the consortium that includes the Institute for Advanced Study, New Mexico State University, Princeton University, the University of Washington and Washington State University. The consortium voted Nov. 20 to move ahead with the project, which is scheduled to begin in 1995. The University of Chicago, Princeton and the Institute for Advance Study will split the costs, said University of Chicago spokesman Larry Arbeiter. The new telescope and its instruments have been specially designed by astronomer Jim Gunn of Princeton to map the universe quickly. The telescope, combined with digital and robotic technology, will enable astronomers to complete the mapping in five to seven years, the group said. The telescope will be placed on Apache Point in New Mexico's Sacramento Mountains. The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill. is expected to provide the computer equipment needed to store and analyze the survey's estimated 10 million megabytes of information - roughly enough data to fill a telephone directory for 250 billion people, officials said. Scientists say the map could help answer questions about the Big Bang theory, which proposes that the universe was created in a massive explosion 15 billion years ago. The simplest theory indicates the explosion should have scattered matter uniformly across the universe, but galaxies are found in clusters. The survey may show if still unknown sub-atomic forces or particles formed the beginnings of galaxies during the Big Bang, scientists said. Information gathered by the survey may also provide astronomers with an insight into the nature of ``dark matter'' - material that has been detected through its gravity but remains unidentified.

DOC.HEAD: Poles In North America Choose Walesa
With PM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa faces a runoff in Poland's presidential contest, but if it were up to the 36,000 Poles who cast ballots in North America he'd already be in office. ``He is the only man for the job,'' St. Louis cab driver Alexander Gorka said Sunday. ``He can take the country out of the critical situation it's in.'' Walesa, the Solidarity leader who led the revolt against four decades of Communist rule in Poland, got 60 percent of the vote among Poles in Canada and the United States who voted Saturday, said Consul Andrezj Jaroszynski in Chicago. Citing unofficial figures, he said Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki placed second with 33 percent of the ballots cast by 36,006 voters in North America. Upstart emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, who beat Mazowiecki for second in voting in Poland, had about 3 percent of the North American vote. In Poland, Walesa had just under 40 percent of the vote with 44 of 49 provinces reporting. Tyminski, with 23 percent, made a surprise showing by beating Mazowiecki, who had 16 percent of the vote. Three other candidates trailed far behind. Final results were expected later today. A Dec. 9 runoff will be held between the two top vote-getters if neither wins an outright majority. Gorka, who drove from St. Louis to the Polish Consulate in Chicago to vote, said he cried when he cast his ballot for Walesa, who had been favored to win. ``It was such an important day for me,'' Gorka said. ``It was the first time in my life I had the freedom to vote in a truly democratic election in Poland.'' Turnout was lower than expected in Chicago, where only 9,810 of more than 40,000 eligible voters went to three polling places, Jaroszynski said. The metropolitan area has a larger bloc of Poles and Polish-Americans, a total of 800,000 to 1.2 million, than any municipality outside Warsaw. More than 16,000 ballots were cast in New York state, according to the consulate in New York City. Alderman Roman C. Pucinski, a Walesa supporter, said returns in Chicago, especially in the heavily Polish 41st ward he represents, show Walesa ``does get his strength from the blue collar workers.'' In Chicago, Walesa got 76 percent of the vote to Mazowiecki's 18 percent. Unofficial North American results showed Walesa with 21,608, or 60 percent; Mazowiecki with 11,823, or 33 percent; Tyminski with 1,238, or 3 percent; and the remainder for the other three candidates, Jaroszynski said. Poland allows naturalized U.S. citizens to hold Polish passports and vote. Newly arrived immigrants and visitors to the United States also could vote. Balloting was at sites in North America on Saturday; voting by mail was not permitted.

DOC.HEAD: China Charges Two With Sedition, Seeks To Wrap Up Cases
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have charged two prominent figures in last year's pro-democracy movement with plotting to overthrow the government, a crime punishable by death, Chinese sources said today. The charges against Chen Zeming, publisher of the now-banned Economic Studies Weekly, and Wang Juntao, its editor, are the most serious to be brought so far against intellectuals involved in the pro-democracy movement. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said relatives of the two men received formal notices late last week that Chen and Wang had been charged with ``plotting to overthrow the government and counterrevolutionary incitement.'' The Beijing city Foreign Affairs Office said it had not heard about the charges. The government's move, more than a year after the two men were arrested, indicated its desire to wrap up remaining cases from the protest movement and put the controversial events behind it. Other sources have said the government is preparing to hold trials for alleged ringleaders of the protests, which began with student marches in Beijing in April 1989 and spread nationwide. The movement was crushed when the army opened fire on protesters in Beijing two months later, killing hundreds on unarmed civilians. Hundreds of participants in the protests already have been sent to labor camps, a punishment that requires no trial. Dozens of others have been tried secretly, and at least 18 are known to have been executed. However, none of the alleged ringleaders has yet been put on trial. One reason is the Communist Party's fear that trials would require releasing information about the involvement of high-level party officials in the movement. The party has closed its investigation of ousted party chief Zhao Ziyang without announcing any conclusions or punishment for that very reason. Zhao was dismissed as party general secretary last year for allegedly supporting the democracy movement. Chen and Wang acted as advisers to the Beijing student protests, helping plan the strategy of early student marches and formulate demands. Both got their first experience in confronting the government in 1976, when they joined a protest in Tiananmen Square against the radical leftist officials who led the destructive Cultural Revolution. They were arrested then, but were released when the Cultural Revolution leadership was ousted and the protest was officially reappraised as patriotic. Wang became a leader in the Communist Youth League, but continued challenging the official line. He helped found an unofficial journal called Beijing Spring in 1978 during a brief period of open political debate called the Democracy Wall Movement. Many other participants in that movement were jailed. He and Wang were arrested in October 1989, in Canton, where they apparently were trying to flee the country. Family members have not been allowed to visit Wang and Chen in prison, although they have been allowed to send books and clothing. Wang's wife, Hou Xiaotian, also was jailed for several months after the protests. She was recently released from a hospital after being treated for ailments she said were related to her prison stay. The government recently set up a special group of lawyers to defend protesters brought to trial. Sources said the protesters would not be allowed to hire their own lawyers or organize their own defense. Authorities say 355 people remain in jail under investigation in Beijing in connection with the democracy movement, and two in Shanghai. No figures have been released for the rest of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Bus Freebies Near End, Many Want Free Rides to Keep Rolling
DOC.TEXT: To silence critics who suggested selling nearly empty buses and using the money to buy lonely riders cars of their own, officials made bus rides free, but the gravy train is nearing the end of the line. Starting New Year's Day, the buses will cost 50 cents again, meaning riders will have to pay for the first time in 15 months. Under an order approved by the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, the elderly and disabled would remain exempt from the renewed fee. Some downtown express service still won't cost anything and there will be discounted bus passes available, but some say free rides should not end because the move attracted tens of thousands of new riders. City Councilman Max Nofziger, who serves on the transportation oversight panel, wants to keep the no-fare system, pointing to a three-quarter cent sales tax that funds the bus system. ``I don't think they should charge the riders an additional fee to actually get on the buses, because those folks have already paid once through the sales tax,'' Nofziger said. A panel of elected officials must review the decision to reinstate fares, which was approved 4-3 by the Capital Metro board after considering reports of problem passengers and concerns about lost revenue. Capital Metro board members Lyndon Henry and Dennis Garza said the system is losing $3.8 million a year. ``No other transit system in the country is doing what we're doing, and I think for good reason,'' Garza said. ``They can't afford it.'' Dennis Kouba of the American Public Transit Association in Washington said he knows of no other city offering free bus fares. The elimination of fares began as a three-month program in October 1989, when jokes abounded about the number of empty city buses rolling around town. The running gag was that selling the buses and buying riders cars would save money. After fares were suspenced, ridership grew by 82 percent in the first nine months of 1990, compared to the same period last year, said Capital Metro spokesman Howard Goldman. On the average weekday in September 1989, 50,765 people rode the bus. This September, the average was 84,540. The president of the local bus driver's union, Joneth Wyatt, said a big drawback of the free-ride program has been problem passengers. ``People tend to disrespect something that you get for free,'' Wyatt said. He said the city traded ``good passengers for the bad passengers.'' ``We gained the transients, we gained a lot more school kids who would normally walk to school, we gained the gangs, the undesirables,'' Wyatt. Lost, he said, were ``everyday working people.''

DOC.HEAD: Blast On Rail Line Taken By Emperor To Shrine
DOC.TEXT: An early morning explosion delayed service on an express ``bullet train'' line today but did not prevent Emperor Akihito from taking the railroad hours later to an ancient shrine for a rite of enthronement. Police found batteries at the site of the explosion and suspect the bombing was the work of ultra-leftist radicals who oppose the monarchy. A loud explosion was heard at about 6 a.m. near Shin Yokohama Station, about 12 miles west of Tokyo. Pieces of a concrete wall were thrown as far as 110 yards and blocked the tracks, halting the train service for two hours, police said. No injuries were reported. Akihito and Empress Michiko boarded an express train on the line six hours after the explosion, bound to pay their respects to the imperial family's ancestral deities enshrined in Ise in central Japan. They were not delayed. Akihito's enthronement ceremony was held Nov. 12. Last week, he offered sacred rice to the gods in a controversial rite called the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering. Ultra-leftists, who oppose the imperial system as symbolic of Japna's militarist past, have publicly declared their intentions to disrupt enthronement-related rites that continue until early December. Police reported nearly 40 incidents on enthronement day alone, including attacks with homemade mortars and arson at several shrines. One police officer was killed in an earlier bombing at a Tokyo police dormitory.

DOC.HEAD: Driver's License Applicant Arrested for Drunken Driving
DOC.TEXT: A man who drove to a state police station to apply for a license instead found himself charged with drunken driving, police said. Jerry D. Hager of Jeffrey wanted to exchange his out-of-state driver's license for a West Virginia license, police said. He expected tests in vision and driving rules when he got to the station in Madison. Instead, he was given field sobriety tests. ``It was obvious he was drunk when he walked up to the counter,'' said Trooper E.K. Harper.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued its strong gains against the Japanese yen in European trading this morning, and moved higher against several key European currencies. Gold was higher. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.95 yen, the day's high, up 0.82 yen from Thursday's close of 127.13 yen. There was no trading in Tokyo on Friday because of a holiday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.55 yen. Currency traders in Tokyo said there was no major news to move the market, although reported U.S. plans to seek approval this week for a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq spurred some dollar buying. ``Amid a lack of incentives, the dollar moved gradually up on short-covering,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.4890 German marks, up from 1.4860 -1.2645 Swiss francs, u from 1.2583 -5.0190 French francs, up from 5.0075 -1.6745 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6760 -1,116.80 Italian lire, up from 1,115.00 -1.1597 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1592 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9690, compared with $1.9670 late Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $387.05 per ounce at midmorning, from $383.75 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $385.90, up from $383.25 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $7.10 an ounce today, to close at $386.35. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.19 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $4.15.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in West, Warmer Weather in Rest of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell in parts of the West early today, and the weather was mostly dry and unseasonably warm in the rest of the nation. Winter storms were forecast over the mountains of Utah and the White Mountains of Arizona. Storm watches were posted tonight for the mountains of New Mexico and snow drifts were forecast for the Colorado mountains. Accumulations of near 8 inches of snow were likely today in the passes of the Cascades and Siskiyous mountains of Oregon, the National Weather Service said. Wind gusts were expected in southeast California and southern Nevada. Freezing rain was possible in the northern Great Lakes region. Showers were possible over the southern Plains and parts of Missouri and Illinois. Rain also was likely along the coastal Pacific Northwest. Temperatures in the 60s were forecast for much of the Midwest, Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic states. Temperatures in the 40s were expected north of a cold front passing through Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania. The northern Plains and Rockies were to be in the 20s, 30s and 40s, and the Northeast was to have 40- and 50-degree weather. Temperatures in the 60s, 70s and 80s were forecast for the Sun Belt. The nation's high for Sunday was 91 degrees at McAllen, Texas.
