DOC.HEAD: Senior Citizens Have Bedeviled Address Changed
DOC.TEXT: Residents worried that their address at 666 Jackson St. was the sign of the Antichrist have been granted a new street number. More than 100 people at the 140-unit senior citizen's apartment complex signed a petition requesting the change. The Gary Housing Authority will change the address in January to 650 Jackson St. The number 666 is referred to in the New Testament as a sign of the Antichrist. ``There were some religious people who moved out,'' said John Younge, president of the building's tenant council. ``Not that anything bad happened, but they just didn't like living in a building with that address.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Reno, Nev.-dated 3rd item in rdp to CORRECT name of play in 2nd graf to `The Piano Lesson' sted `Piano Player.'
DOC.TEXT: Emmy-award winning actress Alfre Woodard and Jill Clayburgh are co-starring in a film being shot here based on the life of a white girl raised by a black couple. ``Pretty Hattie's Baby'' also stars Broadway actor Charles Dutton, known for his role in ``The Piano Lesson.'' The film depicts the struggle of Fauna Hodel, now 39, to discover her identity during her childhood with the late Homer and Jimmie Faison in Sparks, Nev. The woman suffered ridicule from whites and blacks while growing up. Mrs. Faison was working as a hotel cleaning woman in 1951 when she met a white woman from San Francisco who asked her to take in an illegitimate baby. The film directed by Ivan Passer is scheduled for release in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Students United After Anti-Semitic Violence in Dormitory
DOC.TEXT: Jewish college students who share a kosher kitchen that was defiled with anti-Semitic slurs and human waste said the incident has left them united. ``If we can continue having kosher meals together...then there's still the sense of community, and of Jewish people as survivors,'' student Aline Iskander said Sunday. Police classified the vandalism in a section of Macalester College's Kirk Hall dormitory as a bias crime against Jews. The dormitory section is known as Hebrew House. Ted Leventhal, 21, a former director of Hebrew House, said he and two friends who iive there found an obscene note and a mixing bowl filled with feces in the kitchen Friday night. The note read in part: ``Achtung... Can't you clean up after yourselves? Didn't Hitler teach you nothing? Remember neatness reflects your character? Shape up or ship out!!!'' In signing the note, the vandals claimed to be members of the Aryan Youth Movement. Police officer Larry Sandell said police have no information about the group. The intruders also broke eggs, extinguished cigarettes on the carpet and littered the floor with beer cans and other debris. Hebrew House has its own kitchen so Jewish students in Kirk Hall can prepare kosher meals under strict religious standards. ``I think they knew that striking in the kitchen, defiling the kitchen, would have been significant to the house,'' Leventhal said. The kitchen will be cleaned and blessed before it is used again. ``The message is sickening, and anti-Semitism is sickening,'' said Robert Gavin, president of the small liberal arts college. ``I certainly find it abhorrent.'' Police are investigating the incident. Gavin said access to the kitchen would be restricted. Bernard Raskas, a rabbi emeritus of Temple of Aaron in St. Paul and a Macalester faculty member, called the incident shocking. ``My first reaction is that this is the product of sick and twisted personalities, and they need help,'' Raskas said. ``On the other hand, one is not surprised with the rising tide of anti-Semitism all over the world.'' About 8 percent of Macalester's 1,750 students are Jewish.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Denounces Plans for New U.N. Resolution
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today denounced U.S. plans to seek a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing military force in the Persian Gulf and said it would not withdraw from Kuwait even if such a resolution were approved. ``If anybody believes that this newest resolution will influence our position or force us to abandon our rights, they are completely wrong. We respect U.N. resolutions only when they are just and balanced,'' the ruling Baath party said in its daily newspaper, Al-Thawra. The front-page editorial was the first official reaction to reports that the United States would ask the Security Council to approve military force unless Iraq withdraws its troops by Jan. 1. The proposed resolution was circulated as the council prepared to begin debate on new steps to try to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. If adopted, it would mark the strongest step taken by the council since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Baghdad has refused to abide by previous resolutions demanding that it withdraw from Kuwait. Ten days after the invasion, President Saddam Hussein said he would negotiate about Kuwait if talks were also held on other Middle East problems, specifically the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Iraq has insisted that the Security Council resolution calling for Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian lands must also be implemented if it is to abide by resolutions on the Persian Gulf. Al-Thawra claimed the United States is using ``terrorism, threats and blackmail'' to try to win approval for the resolution. The editorial urged other Security Council members to vote against the resolution, which it said would pave the way for ``an overall American hegemony, not only in the region, but in the world at large.'' ``Nobody should blame us if we say that what's going on in the Security Council is a scandal on a wide-scale level, which violates all international laws and norms,'' Al-Thawra said. ``We wonder how other parties themselves will react to the American attempt to impose their hegemony and tyranny over the whole world,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia-Bound Marine Killed Helping Motorist
DOC.TEXT: A Marine who expected to ship out to Saudi Arabia in January was killed in a hit-and-run accident when he went to the aid of a stranded motorist. Lance Cpl. Reynaldo Martindale, 19, of the New York borough of Brooklyn, was here on a Thanksgiving visit with his family. Martindale and a friend, Steven Morales, 24, were en route early Sunday morning to La Guardia Airport - where Martindale was to catch a flight back to Camp Lejeune, N.C. - when they saw a disabled car on the expressway, police said. Morales told Barbara Perrino, a spokeswoman for Jamaica Hospital, that they stopped to push the car off the road and Martindale was hit by a light green car that dragged him 50 feet. Morales was injured and was listed in stable condition today at the hospital. The people in the car were uninjured, police said. When Martindale died, so did his dream of a career in the military, a dream that began in his native Trinidad, his father said Sunday night. ``He always wanted to join the military since he was a kid,'' said Jeffrey Martindale. ``He was so contented, so happy.'' ``If all kids were like him, you'd have a perfect world.'' Morales said he heard a bang ``and then I looked over to my side and I didn't see my friend. ... I lost a very dear friend. ``He wanted to do one last good deed before going to Saudi Arabia. I thought he'd go over there and maybe die for his country instead of on some highway.'' Reynaldo Martindale was assigned to an engineering battalion at Camp Lejeune, according to his father.

DOC.HEAD: First Women's Tabloid in Japan Seems Unlikely To Forge New Ground
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `Kato believes...' to CORRECT that Lady Kong a newspaper, sted magazine. Pickup 6th, `That will...'
DOC.TEXT: With a shocking-pink picture of Tokyo's skyline gracing its front page, Japan's first newspaper designed for women - Lady Kong - hit the newsstands today with lots of fluff but little feminism. As with virtually all enterprises here, men run the daily tabloid, leading some critics to complain that the publication is not likely to challenge the subservient role of women in Japanese society. ``Everything, even sanitary napkins, has been planned and produced by men,'' said Harueko Kato, a communications professor at Tokyo Women's Christian University. ``And news coverage is not an exception.'' The tabloid's name refers to King Kong's girlfriend. The name apparently is meant to show that women are strong, too. Kato believes the most important aspect of the new daily newspaper will be ``how the opinions of the female employees are reflected in the decision-making and news writing.'' That will depend to a large extent on Masahiro Oshima, the 41-year-old man who is the tabloid's editorial director. Twenty-seven of the 47 editors and reporters on his staff are women, but they are in charge of only the entertainment and city guide sections. The company specifically recruited male writers to work in the news department, Oshima explained, ``to give news stories a serious tone.'' Despite the radical image the tabloid is cultivating with its odd name and its advertisements suggesting greater independence for women, there appears to be little emphasis on feminism and social issues. The leading headline on the splashy front page was a call for Tokyo's commuter trains to extend operations a few hours each night to 2 a.m. for the benefit of people who stay out late drinking and dancing. The rest of the 80-cent newspaper, which describes itself in English as a ``newsy tabloid for Tokyoites,'' reads like a typical fashion magazine with a few pages of news slapped onto the front. The first edition included a series of interviews with female business executives, as well as a soft-porn story titled ``Honest Legs,'' gossip items and entertainment news. Oshima says he had wanted to carry more features on social issues, but a six-month marketing research program led him to reduce stories on politics, business, women's issues and the environment. ``Japanese women are not ready for such a progressive paper ... I was quite disappointed to discover that,'' he said in a recent interview at his office. To achieve its daily circulation goal of 350,000, Lady Kong largely reflects the editorial content of the many popular women's magazines already flooding the market with heavy doses of fashion, cooking and new products. The tabloid says it also is trying to attract female readers by using stain-free print that does not rub off. Young Japanese women often complain that ink from the regular broadsheet newspapers dirties their hands and expensive designer dresses. One kiosk in central Tokyo carried a few dozen issues of Lady Kong along hundreds of existing tabloids that aim exclusively at a male readership - heavy with sports coverage and female nudes. Lady Kong is a joint venture between a Japanese publisher and a British brokerage. Investors include Orient Co., the nation's leading finance company.

DOC.HEAD: `Big Five' Agree on Draft Accord on Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council have reached agreement on a draft accord to settle the Cambodian conflict, U.S. officials said today. The agreement paves the way for reconvening the Paris Conference on Cambodia in the next few months, said Richard Solomon, the assistant secretary of state who represented the United States in the three days of talks that ended Sunday. ``This was an important step forward in the process of a political settlement'' to the 12-year-old Cambodian civil war, Solomon said. The latest talks brought together the five permanent Security Council members - the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, China and France - as well as representatives of Indonesia and the United Nations. France and Indonesia are co-chairs of the Paris Conference on Cambodia, which closed in failure in 1989. Indonesia also agreed to the draft accord. A statement issued by participants in the talks said it is ``urgent'' that the four Cambodian factions resolve differences over leadership of the Supreme National Council. The Supreme National Council is to help guide Cambodia through elections after a truce. It has six representatives from the government and six from the three-party resistance coalition led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The council's first meeting broke down Sept. 17 over guerrilla demands that Sihanouk be its chairman and 13th member. The Phnom Penh government says making Sihanouk head of the council would tip the balance in the coalition's favor. The statement by the five permanent Security Council members said they would welcome the election of Sihanouk to head the council, but that Cambodians themselves should work out a formula for the body's composition. On Sunday, Sihanouk urged the government and the three resistance groups to meet as soon as possible in Paris to discuss their differences. The ``draft comprehensive political settlement'' agreed to after the latest talks in Paris is based on the framework agreement of August and endorsed by the Security Council and the U.N. General Assembly. It contains a draft agreement covering major aspects of the settlement, as well as five annexes to the political settlement dealing with the U.N. role, a cease-fire and withdrawal of foreign forces, elections, repatriation of Cambodian refugees and principles for a new constitution. The five Security Council members also set out a draft agreement on the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity and neutrality of Cambodia and a draft declaration on rehabilitation and reconstruction of the nation. The resistance coalition has been fighting the Hun Sen government since it was installed after the Vietnamese invaded in December 1978 and toppled the Khmer Rouge, which had killed a million people during its reign. The Khmer Rouge is the strongest military arm in Sihanouk's resistance coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Urges Egypt to Tighten Security After Gunmen Kills Four
LaserPhotos NY7,9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to recast, move up Levy comment. Pickup 7th graf pvs, ``The Egyptian...''
DOC.TEXT: Israel urged Egypt today to clamp down on extremists after a lone gunman crossed the lightly patrolled frontier and killed four Israelis in a roadside ambush before being shot and retreating into Egypt. ``We cannot grow accustomed to enduring a peace with Israeli bloodshed,'' said Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy. ``The Egyptian government must understand that everything must be done to end this serious situation, which is intolerable. Israeli blood cannot be cheap in Egypt,'' he said on Israel radio. Twenty-seven people were wounded in Sunday's attack, which occurred about 15 miles north of Eilat and was among the worst ever along the border. The attacker sprayed fire from a Kalashnikov automatic rifle into a bus and three military vehicles before he was himself shot and fled, officials said. A Moslem fundamentalist group called Islamic Holy War-Jerusalem claimed responsibility. Egypt signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, but there have been periodic border incidents. The last attack was on Feb. 4 when gunmen abmushed an Israeli tour bus in Egypt, killing nine Israelis and wounding 20. Despite strong Israeli concerns about the violence, a top Israeli army official said there are no plans to reinforce Israel's most peaceful frontier. ``The Egyptian border is different than the others ... it is border of peace, and I suggest we don't make the mistake of relating to this border as a hot one at war, it would be a real mistake, a psychological mistake,'' said Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron on Israel television Sunday. It was the third attack against Israelis in two days. In a suicide bombing earlier Sunday, a Lebanese woman with a handbag packed with explosives was killed and two Israeli soldiers were wounded in southern Lebanon. On Saturday, at least four Palestinian guerrillas were killed when an Israeli navy gunboat sank a dinghy off the Lebanese coast. A Palestinian group said four of the guerrillas were missing but one swam ashore. It said the guerrillas had planned a raid in Israel. Following the shooting near Eilat, Egyptian soldiers captured a suspect described as an border policeman stationed in the area, a senior Egyptian security source said. Israeli reports said the suspect suffered a head wound after a bus guard shot at him as he fled. The assailant's blood-stained flak jacket was found on the Israeli side of the border, with ``Allah'' written on it, army radio reported. During the half-hour rampage, the gunman killed the drivers of all four vehicles he attacked. Three of the drivers were soldiers, and most of the wounded were civilians, the army said. The assailant had acrossed the border through a dry river bed early in the morning, taking up a position near a gravel shoulder of a road, army and television reports said. Passengers on Egged Co. bus recounted moments of terror and confusion after the gunman flagged down the bus. ``Ten seconds didn't pass before we were showered with gunfire. Everyone hit the floor ... It was a difficult sight. There was blood and glass everywhere, the windshield was full of bullet holes,'' said Nuriel Yehud, 35, of Eilat, a construction worker at a nearby army base. The gunman fled as a guard on the bus returned fire with an Uzi submachine gun. Sunday's attack was claimed in Jordan's capital of Amman by a Moslem group called Islamic Jihad-Beit Al-Maqdes, or Islamic Holy-War Jerusalem. Their statement said the shootings were in memory of Suliman Khater, an Egyptian policeman who shot to death seven Israelis, including four children, in Sinai in October 1985. Khater hanged himself four months later in a Cairo, Egypt, prison hospital, according to the Egyptian authorities. Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the attack appeared to be an outgrowth of ``incitement by many factors in the Arab world like (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein.'' Legislators from right and left-wing parties called for an urgent Parliament debate.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Cold Help Smother Range Fires in Montana, Colorado
DOC.TEXT: Snow and chilly temperatures helped firefighters battle two huge range fires in Montana, and dying winds aided efforts to extinguish a wildfire that destroyed 10 mountain homes in Coloradao. Firefighters in Colorado took advantage of a break in high winds that reached up to 70 mph over the weekend to build a fire line Sunday around the Olde Stage Road fire that consumed 2,200 acres in the rugged foothills northwest of Boulder. Officials said they expected the blaze to be under control today. There were no serious injuries reported in either Colorado or Montana, but several firefighters were overcome by heat, smoke and exhaustion after battling the Colorado blaze since early Saturday morning. In Montana, snow fell Sunday night on two fires that were the largest of a swarm that swept over an estimated 45,000 acres of grass and timber Friday night and Saturday, racing across the central Montana range on winds that gusted up to 100 mph. The smaller of the two huge range fires, a 10,000-acre blaze that reached within a quarter-mile of the tiny community of Bohemian Corners north of Lewistown, was extinguished early today. ``It is out. We had about 2 to 3 inches of snow last night. Any hot spots are well out now,'' Fergus County Deputy Sheriff Ron Rowton said. Several homes were destroyed, and ranches lost numerous outbuildings in the Montana fires. About 280 firefighters worked on the lines Sunday at the Turkey fire, which burned about 32,000 acres near the farming communities of Stanford and Hobson, east of Great Falls, said Jane Weber, spokeswoman for the Lewis and Clark National Forest. Officials said fire lines had been finished around 90 percent of the blaze, and officials expected to have the fire under control by Tuesday, Weber said. Local ranchers said they believed the blaze was sparked by Forest Service ``slash fires,'' or controlled burns designed to clear dead timber and other debris from heavily wooded areas. Jerry Dombrovske, district ranger for Stanford, said several slash fires begun in 8 inches of snow Nov. 6 were still smoldering Friday, the day the fire began raging. But Dombrovske said he dispatched several staffers earlier that day to extinguish any remaining hot spots. In Colorado, two National Guard helicopters continued to drop 250-gallon buckets of water on hot spots on the Olde Stage Road fire, but officials said the blaze may be extinguished today. Arnold Stein, 62, was being held in Boulder County Jail for investigation of felony fourth-degree arson, reckless endangerment and firing woods and prairies. He was arrested Saturday. Authorities said Stein dragged a burning mattress from his home early Saturday, and the fire was spread rapidly by strong winds. It was not immediately known how the mattress fire started. Boulder County Sheriff's Deputy Anthony Matthews said Stein lapsed into an incoherent account of the fire. ``He referred to the ensuing fire as World War III and said he was on a suicide mission,'' Matthews said in a report made available Sunday. ``He also said that it all must be a dream and that it was not reality.'' Stein was scheduled to appear in court today. The fire consumed Stein's home and nine others. Another home was damaged, and five outbuildings were destroyed.
