DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Said To Win Majority in First Multiparty Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with final results, quote from opposition party member. Pickup 11th graf, `Popular Front...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Democracy Delayed, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's party won an overwhelming majority in parliament in multiparty elections that ended 30 years of unchallenged rule, the government said today. Opposition politicians accused the governing party of intimidation and fraud during Sunday's voting. The Interior Ministry said the governing Democratic Party won 163 seats in the 175-member assembly, while the Popular Front, the main opposition party, won nine of 10 seats captured by government opponents. The remaining two seats went to governing party members who ran as independents. Two opposition leaders who both are university professors were elected - the Popular Front's Laurent Gbagbo, and Francis Wodie, head of the Ivorian Workers' Party and dean of Abidjan University Faculty of Law. Wodie, a former president of the Amnesty International human rights organization, beat Gbagbo's top ally and two candidates from the governing party to win the seat for the affluent Cocody suburb where Houphouet-Boigny voted. Wodie said in an interview that, ``it is difficult to believe tese results are correct ... that the opposition is in such a minority.'' He blamed a low voter turnout, which he estimated at between 50 percent and 60 percent, and suggested some Ivorians did not bother to vote believing balloting would be rigged. The Democratic Party had been expected to win, but not with such a vast majority. Its victory reinforced Houphouet-Boigny's re-election last month in the first contested presidential race in this West African nation's 30 years of independence, all under his rule. The president's sole challenger, Gbagbo, has charged that the governing party also rigged that election, in which the octogenarian president was awarded 81.67 percent of votes. About 4.4 million people registered to vote in the contest among 490 candidates from 19 parties. Results are not official until the Supreme Court ratifies the count later this week. Popular Front officials charged that the governing party hired thugs to intimidate voters. In Abidjan's high density suburb of Yopougon, for example, they said thugs drove three cars into a crowd of their followers on Saturday, injuring several. In an ensuing fight, 17 people were hurt and 10 of them were being treated in the hospital, a spokesman said. Yopougon's deputy mayor, Mustapha Doukoure, said Popular Front militants provoked the clash by attacking governing party supporters with sticks and stones to stop them from holding a peaceful march. He said 37 of his supporters were injured. Voting was generally peaceful and policed by armed soldiers. The opposition alleged several irregularities. In Yopougon, for example, reporters found three polling stations closed because electoral lists were missing names of voters. The Popular Front said this was to prevent people voting in an area where it has strong support. Yopougon was the site of the first pro-democracy protests in Ivory Coast in February. Weeks of strikes and violent riots followed, forcing Houphouet-Boigny to legalize political opposition. Opposition parties were handicapped by a nationwide network the governing party has built up over 30 years of single-party rule and its large funds from compulsory contributions exacted from civil servants' salaries. Also against them was the government's insistence that non-Ivorian Africans working in the country be allowed to vote. Such foreigners comprise at least a third of the 11.2 million population, and almost all support Houphouet-Boigny. A security guard from neighboring Burkina Faso said he and his brother were beaten up by Popular Front supporters when they lined up to vote. He said they fled their polling station in Adjame suburb without voting. The guard requested anonymity, saying he feared repercussions.

DOC.HEAD: First Widespread Strike in United Germany Halts Some Rail Lines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, `The warning ...' with union spokesman saying strike not aimed at gulf deployment.
DOC.TEXT: More than a quarter-million railroad workers in eastern Germany were on strike for higher pay today in the first widespread job action since the two Germanys united seven weeks ago. The strike started Sunday evening in Berlin, halting inter-city rail traffic from the main stations in the eastern and western halves of the city, and it spread to 26 other cities in eastern Germany this morning, union spokesmen said. Pay levels in the former Communist part of the country for almost all lines of work are about a third of western pay scales, and most industries plan to raise eastern scales gradually over several years to levels in the west. In another job action related to German unification, 10,000 civilian workers at NATO bases staged warning strikes today. Their union, the Public Service and Transport Union, said the workers need higher pay, job protection or retraining because NATO troop reductions are expected to cut 23,000 of the 100,000 civilian jobs at NATO bases. The warning strikes hit such major U.S. bases as Ramstein Air Base in southwest Germany and Rhein-Main Air Base just outside Frankfurt, union spokesman Rainer Hillgaertner said. But there was no immediate indication of possible impact on U.S. troop movements through the bases to the Persian Gulf, U.S. spokesmen said. The strikes ``are for better contracts for the workers. They are not politically motivated and are not directed at slowing down movement of soldiers,'' to the gulf region, Hillgaertner sad. NATO troop strengths in Germany are to be reduced as Soviet troops withdraw from eastern Germany over the next four years as part of the international agreements that permitted East and West Germany to unify. The eastern and western rail companies in Germany are to be gradually unified by 1992, but the eastern rail workers joined the western Union of German Rail Workers months ago. They demand immediate raises to 50 percent to 60 percent of levels in western Germany and protection against the layoffs expected in many eastern industries. Last week management said it anticipated laying off 68,000 eastern rail workers. The union says western rail workers get about $675 a month more than their eastern counterparts, whose pay ranges from $675 to $945 a month. Commuter trains and subways were unaffected by the strike, but its impact extended to western Germany and neighboring countries to the east. Trains from western German cities such as Frankfurt and Hamburg to Berlin and other cities in the east were canceled, and hundreds of passengers were put on buses instead. Trains from Hungary and Romania were stopped at the border in Czechoslovakia, according to the Czechoslovak news agency CTK. Though the strike affected freight as well as passenger traffic, the German news agency ADN reported that the rail workers were still permitting aid shipments for Poland and the Soviet Union. Negotiations between the union and management broke down Thursday and another round of talks is scheduled for Wednesday. A poll of Eastern rail workers ended Sunday with 97 percent voting to strike. There have been scattered strikes in eastern Germany since unification of the Germanys on Oct. 3, but the job action by the 260,000 eastern rail workers was the first major strike in unified Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Dark-Horse Emigre Candidate Predicts He'll Beat Walesa
With PM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stanislaw Tyminski, the political unknown whose strong showing in presidential elections shocked observers, apparently struck a responsive chord among voters disenchanted with difficult economic reforms. Tyminski, 42, who returned to his homeland this fall after 21 years in Canada and Peru, finished second in Poland's first popular presidential elections on Sunday, giving him a spot in the Dec. 9 runoff with Lech Walesa. Walesa finished first in the six-person field with 40 percent. But Tyminski won an estimated 23 percent of the vote, enough to shut out Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who took only 16 percent in unofficial returns. In his campaign, Tyminski promised Poles a quick cure for their economic woes, a pledge he repeated today. ``I want to make this country rich and prosperous ... It will be better within a month,'' he told a packed news conference today at his headquarters. Tyminski said he was undaunted by the prospect of facing Walesa, who won first fame a decade ago as the leader of Solidarity. ``I will win these elections, otherwise I would not have come back,'' Tyminski said. ``I am not afraid of Walesa, I am not afraid of anyone.'' Opponents claim Tyminski's economic policies are wildly unrealistic. Critics have also questioned his qualifications, his Canadian and Peruvian citizenships, his business dealings and his leadership of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, and even his mental stability. For the first month of the campaign, Tyminski was not treated as a serious contender, thus escaping media scrutiny and criticism from rivals. He finally got his opponents' attention with his accusations that the Mazowiecki government is selling off the national property to foreigners at cut-rate prices in its bid to privatize floundering state-owned companies. Tyminski also spent liberally on campaign advertisements, served refreshments at some events and campaigned hard. His appeal may have been bolstered by dissatisfaction with both Mazowiecki and Walesa, onetime Solidarity allies turned political foes. But after the polling, both the Mazowiecki and Walesa camps agreed on one thing: they were alarmed by Tyminski's showing. Walesa strategist Lech Kaczynski, Solidarity's deputy chairman, called Tyminski a ``dangerous phenomenon.'' Andrzej Wielowieyski, a senator allied with Mazowiecki, called Tyminski ``an opportunity for escape'' whose showing was ``an alarming signal.'' ``Tyminski has revealed a black hole in Polish society,'' said Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, a chief Mazowiecki campaigner. ``It is the result, to put it bluntly, of darkness, stupidity, a lack of experience in democracy.'' A state television exit poll suggested Tyminski garnered strong support among the farm and small-town population. Political analysts said the discontent of the Poles who voted for Tyminski has to be taken seriously. ``I want to warn about making light of this electorate,'' said Stefan Bratkowski, a well-known commentator. ``It is not an electorate of stupid people. It is an electorate of disappointed people.'' Polish election law, drafted in the year since Communism was toppled, allowed any candidate who could gather 100,000 signatures to appear on the ballot. It did not, for example, require that a candidate live in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate White Attack on Black Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for 6th pvs, `About 25...' to fix typo in `whites.' Pickup 7th, `The report...'
DOC.TEXT: Police today investigated reports that white men with whips attacked a group of black children on a Sunday school trip who tried to used a public park. Meanwhile, police and news reports today said 19 people were killed in clashes in various parts of the country over the weekend. Most of them died in fighting between rival black groups. A police statement gave few details. Among the incidents, the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. reported on Monday that nine blacks were killed late Friday near Harding in Natal Province when two vans were ambushed. The report gave no details on who may have been responsible for the attack. Natal Province has been the scene of fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and the conservative Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party. The two sides are divided by leadership claims and plans for a future South Africa. The independent South African Press Association said several children were injured Saturday in Louis Trichardt in the far north of the country. The party tried to use the local park while on a church-sponsored outing. About 25 white men told the children that blacks were not allowed to use the park and ordered them to leave, SAPA said. As the children were leaving, the whites attacked them with whips and sticks, it said. The report did not say how many children were involved or how many were injured or the seriousness of the injuries. Rev. George Mohali, who was leading the Sunday school trip, said police were in the area, but did nothing to stop the attack. He said he complained later to police and was told to come back with the children who had been assaulted. Police Lt. Werner Voigt said authorities would not tolerate such incidents and senior officers were investigating the incident. The government recently scrapped apartheid laws that segregated parks and other public facilities. Some right-wing local governments and their supporters refuse to accept the changes and have attempted to stop blacks using facilities previously reserved for whites. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. The pro-apartheid opposition Conservative Party refuses to accept the reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Iraq Broke Agreement on Allowing Soviets to Leave
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry said today Iraq's failure to free 1,000 Soviets could lead to a ``tougher attitude'' toward Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin demanded the immediate release of the Soviets. He also told reporters Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze met with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq for four hours today to reiterate the demand that Iraq withdraws its troops from Kuwait. Churkin said Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia would meet with Shevardnadze on Tuesday to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. He said Iraq agree to allow 1,000 Soviets, mostly contract workers, to leave during November but that only about 350 were permitted to do so. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, there were about 8,000 Soviets, including several hundred military advisers, in Iraq. About 3,000 Soviets, including women and children, were allowed to leave shortly after the invasion and about 1,000 left during September and October. Churkin said Iraq agreed to allow another 1,000 to leave in November, but is not living up to its promise. ``Iraq is not keeping its agreement that our citizens will not be prevented from leaving,'' he said. ``This is totally abnormal and unacceptable.'' He added, ``If Iraq does not immediately remove obstacles and allow our citizens to leave, this will complicate the present situation even further and force us to take a tougher attitude.'' Churkin said that to his knowledge, no Soviets were being detained at potential military targets. ``All (Soviet) nationals are still where they were before the crisis,'' he said. Iraq has prevented hundreds of foreigners from leaving Iraq and Kuwait since Saddam Hussein's troops overran the emirate four months ago. It has been slowly releasing some foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Adjust as Bald Eagles Take Food Where They Can Find It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `A tiny...', to fix misplaced word `that' in phrase `plankton salmon that eat'.
DOC.TEXT: The annual fall gathering of bald eagles at Glacier National Park, once a natural wonder that awed thousands, has disappeared, a victim of man's tinkering with nature. While human blunder destroyed the birds' feeding on salmon at Glacier, 200 miles to the south another attempt to modify nature has provided a new food source and a new eagle gathering area. Just a few years ago, the ark in northwestern Montana was considered one of the best places in America to view bald eagles in the fall. Salmon swarmed upstream to spawn in the park's Lake McDonald, and migrating eagles by the hundreds paused to perch in trees and feed on fish. Tourists jammed viewing areas where it was common to see six of the threatened birds per tree just 100 feet away. But in 1986, the salmon run collapsed after an attempt to enhance the salmon population backfired. A tiny creature called the mysis shrimp was introduced about 20 years ago by the state Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks into nearby Flathead Lake, with the idea that it would be a new food source for the salmon. Instead, the mysis competed for plankton that salmon eat, and the salmon population dwindled. Once there were more than 100,000 spawning salmon in the creek every fall, park officials say. This fall, there were only about 200. As the salmon disappeared, so did the eagles. In 1981, the peak count was 639 bald eagles in the Lake McDonald area. Last year it was 25. Last week it was 13. The bald eagle's are protected nationwide, except in Alaska, where populations thrive. Federal officials estimate there were 2,660 nesting pairs in the Lower 48 states last year. ``Eagles are opportunistic feeders,'' said Glacier park spokeswoman Amy Vanderbilt. ``If there aren't salmon, they're not going to hang around. They're going to go where there's food.'' Riley McClelland, a park research biologist, said many of the birds still fly over, ``but none of them are stopping. Most of them are simply passing through.'' The birds are migratory and many are believed to spend part of the year in Canada and part in Mexico. The loss of the eagles has cost the area tourists. McClelland said 46,500 people used to come and watch the eagles in October and November. Last year, only 1,000 people visited during the same period. Meanwhile, at Canyon Ferry Reservoir just east of Helena, an experiment with kokanee salmon also went awry - but with beneficial results. Salmon stocked for fishermen escaped from the reservoir and made their way into the Missouri River below, where they began spawning. The booming salmon population has attracted so many eagles that officials have closed part of the river to protect their nests and feeding ground. More than 200 bald eagles are there now. Five years ago, observers say perhaps half a dozen stopped there. The new group don't appear to have come from Glacier, McClelland said. Only a few banded Glacier eagles have shown up at Canyon Ferry. Whatever their origin, the majestic birds attracted tourists as word of the new gathering spread. Pat Gubbins, a regional manager with the state wildlife and parks department, said more than 600 people have flocked to the site nearly each weekend this fall, plus hundreds more during the week.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Officials Lose Appeal For Immunity From Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that state officials may be sued for shutting down a day-care center without giving the owner a chance to respond to charges of child abuse and overcrowding. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Arizona officials seeking immunity from a lawsuit by a Tucson day-care center. The Arizona Office of Child Protective Services investigated the Chalkboard Inc. center after Tucson police received a complaint in 1985 that a young girl was sexually abused by a teacher there. The investigators said they discovered at least one other complaint of sexual abuse against the same teacher, learned of several complaints of physical abuse of the children and found overcrowding despite an earlier warning to Chalkboard. The investigators also said the teacher accused of sexual abuse had been suspended, and that there was evidence the physical abuse had been halted two months earlier. Within a week of the preliminary investigation and eight days before a scheduled hearing on the charges, officials suspended Chalkboard's license to operate. The center's owner, Karen Hoyt, sued the state officials for violating her due-process rights by shutting down the center without a hearing or a court order. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in May refused to kill her suit. The appeals court rejected arguments by the officials that they are entitled to immunity because they acted swiftly to protect the children. The appeals court said the officials ignored state law that required due-process for the day care center in such circumstances. ``Arizona has provided procedures ... requiring notice and hearing in the absence of a showing of actual emergency,'' the appeals court said ``In ignoring these procedures ... reasonable officials would have known that their actions were not lawful.'' The appeals court sent the case back to a lower court for further proceedings that could lead to an award of monetary damages against the officials. Twenty-two states urged the justices to hear Arizona's appeal and give state officials broader protection against being sued. The states are Alabama, Arkansas, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Idaho, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, Vermont, Washington, and Wyoming. The case is Brandt vs. Chalkboard, 90-270.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Group Claims Responsibility for Iraqi Unrest
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem group has claimed reponsibility for what it said were violent student protests in Iraq against Saddam Hussein. The statement by the Lebanon branch of the Supreme Council of the Islamic Revolution in Iraq was published today by the Middle East Reporter, an English language daily newsletter based in Beirut. The group is believed linked to the Dawa party, an opposition group formed by Imam Mohammed Baqr Sadr, the Shiite spiritual leader of Iraq who was executed by Saddam 10 years ago. The statement said ``selected units of martyr Sadr's cubs waged as of November a widespread campaign of resistance against Saddam's aggressive policies.'' The campaign included distribution of anti-government leaflets in schools in Baghdad and the Iraqi cities of Kofa, Basra, Amara, Kirkuk and Irbil, the statement said. It said the leaflets urged Iraqi troops to ``rebel against the regime.'' Iraq's official news agency has referred recently to student unrest and arrests, but given no details. The statement published in Beirut was the first to claim responsibility for recent Iraqi unrest. The statement claimed more than 4,500 people, most of them students, were arrested after ``bloody clashes with knives and daggers on Nov. 7 and 15 in Baghdad and several other parts of Iraq.'' It asked international humanitarian organizations to intervene to prevent Saddam from executing the detainees, who the statement said were tortured. The Dawa party is Shiite. Saddam is a Sunni Moslem. The 17 bombers who were jailed in Kuwait for blowing up the U.S. and French Embassies in the emirate in 1983 belong to the Dawa party. Two of the 17 were released last year. There has been no word on the others' fate following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The release of the bombers has been sought by Shiites holding most of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon, including six Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Kill Florida Affirmative Action Program
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill an affirmative action program in Florida aimed at awarding more public works contracts to businesses run by minorities and women. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by companies that said the Tampa-area program is unconstitutional because it condones reverse discrimination against white men. The affirmative action program was adopted in 1984 by Hillsborough County, Fla. The county set a goal of awarding 25 percent of the value of all annual construction contracts to businesses owned by women and minorities, primarily blacks and Hispanics. The program, in effect, calls for county officials to favor contractors who have lined up companies run by minorities and women as subcontractors. If the contractor submitting the low bid on a project has met the county's affirmative action goals, that company is likely to win the contract. The low bidder may lose the contract if it fails to convince officials it has at least made a good-faith effort to meet those goals. After a group of white-owned construction companies sued, a federal judge in 1989 ruled the program was unconstitutional and barred the county from enforcing it. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled the judge last August and reinstated the program. The appeals court said the program, at least on its face, does not violate equal-protection guarantees. But the appeals court did not throw out the suit, but instead sent it back for a trial at which the white-owned companies will have a chance to prove their allegations. The appeals court said the Hillsborough plan appears to be significantly different from a so-called set-aside program adopted by Richmond, Va., that was overturned by the Supreme Court last year. The Richmond plan established a quota that required 30 percent of the value of annual public works contracts to be awarded to minority businesses. In striking down that plan, the high court said local governments must narrowly tailor affirmative action plans to remedy proven past bias. The 11th Circuit court said Hillsborough County acted only after a six-year, wholly voluntary plan failed to do enough to help minorities and women in the building industry. ``Unlike Richmond, Hillsborough County decided to implement its law based on statistics indicating that there was discrimination specifically in the construction business commissioned by the county,'' the appeals court said. It noted that the county shunned rigid quotas and only adopted flexible goals for awarding contracts to minorities and women. Another plus for the county program is that most of the contracts are intended to go to struggling, smaller companies, the appeals court added. The companies that challenged the plan said it is designed to achieve racial balance without proof of past discrimination against women and minorities in the construction industry. The case is Cone Corp. vs. Hillsborough County, 90-587.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Power Industry Loses Effort to Scuttle Training Rules
DOC.TEXT: The nation's nuclear power industry today lost a Supreme Court effort to scuttle anticipated federal rules for the training of nuclear plant workers. The justices, over one dissenting vote, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that forces the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to issue such binding rules. Only Justice Byron R. White voted to hear arguments in the case. Four votes are needed to grant such review. The appeals court said Congress intended to have binding rules imposed when it enacted the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. The law requires ``regulations or other appropriate commission regulatory guidance'' for training nuclear power plant workers. But lawyers for the nuclear power industry contend the commission complied with the 1982 law when it issued a ``policy statement'' in 1985 endorsing the industry's self-improvement safety program. The dispute has its roots in the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania. A presidential commission appointed to investigate the accident concluded, among other things, that inadequate training of nuclear plant employees increased the risk of future accidents. The nuclear industry created an independent organization to bring about self-improvement. According to the Nuclear Management and Resources Council, comprising all utilities holding operating or construction permits for nuclear plants, the industry spent ``hundreds of millions of dollars to expand and refine ... (the) training and accreditation program.'' A coalition of groups sued the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in 1986, seeking to have binding rules imposed on the nuclear industry's training efforts. The industry's Nuclear Management and Resources Council was allowed to intervene as a defendant. The original lawsuit was dismissed for having been filed too late. But after the commission revised its policy statement in 1988, the coalition of groups again sued over the commission's failure to impose binding rules. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last April that the commission had not complied with the 1982 law's provision for ``regulations or other appropriate regulatory guidance.'' The full appeals court later refused to reconsider the April decision, but several judges noted that the commission could ``devise regulations that preserve most if not all of the flexibility the commission sought'' in its 1985 policy statement. The nuclear industry's council then sought Supreme Court review, arguing that the appeals court ruling threatens nuclear safety. ``This is not a case ... in which an industry is simply attempting to evade wholesome regulations,'' the appeal said. ``Uniform adherence to the highest safety standards ... must involve the industry in setting and policing its own standards of excellence.'' Lawyers for the coalition of groups that pressed for binding rules urged the justices to reject the appeal. The federal commission, which did not appeal the appeals court ruling to the Supreme Court, told the justices it did not oppose the nuclear industry's appeal. The case is Nuclear Management and Resources Council vs. Public Citizen, 90-360.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Retirement Issue for State Judges
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether state judges may be forced to retire at age 70. The court said it will hear arguments by two Missouri judges that their state's mandatory retirement age violates federal law and unconstitutionally treats them differently than other Missouri employees. The St. Louis-based 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last March that a federal law banning age discrimination in employment does not apply to state court judges. The appeals court, upholding a ruling by U.S. District Judge William Hungate, said Missouri's state court judges fall into the anti-bias law's exception for ``appointees on the policymaking level.'' The appeals court also ruled that the state's mandatory retirement age is constitutional because it is a rational way to ensure a vigorous and healthy judiciary and to increase opportunities for younger people to serve as judges. The 8th Circuit court's ruling appears to conflict with a decision announced two months later by the New York-based 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that allowed a 71-year-old state judge from Vermont to remain on the bench. The 2nd Circuit court ruled that appointed state judges are not ``appointees on the policymaking level'' and therefore are protected by the federal anti-bias law. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Missouri judges Ellis Gregory Jr. and Anthony Nugent Jr. urged the justices to resolve the conflicting rulings. The Supreme Court has never ruled on the issue, but in 1988 left intact New York's policy of forcing elected judges to retire at age 70 even though no such mandatory retirement is imposed on appointed judges in the state. Lawyers for Gregory and Nugent contend that forcing judges, and no other state employees in physically undemanding jobs, to retire at age 70 violates judges' constitutional right to equal treatment. The case is Gregory vs. Ashcroft, 90-50.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Visit to Mexican President Begins in Hometown's Friendly Setting
With PM-Bush-Mexico, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `The large...' to ADD dropped word. Pick up 8th graf pvs, ```They are...'
DOC.TEXT: Don Geronimo Vela, 73, hitched up his pants a notch, pulled down his cowboy hat and said, ``We are going to be proud to have President Bush here, but President Bush will be proud to be in Agualeguas.'' Welcome, President Bush, to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's northern Mexico hometown: fiercely regionalist, friendly and open as the skies it shares with the U.S. southwest. Bush was to arrive this afternoon for talks with Salinas and travel to nearby Monterrey in the evening for more discussions. Nearly 5,000 people live in this farming and cattle community of stone homes. Some are from families that arrived in the mid-1600s. The town's name comes from the Gualeguas Indians, one of a few groups of semi-nomadic tribes that lived in the region when the Spaniards came. The Salinas and Lozano families, the two sides of the president's lineage, are believed to have settled in Agualeguas with a group of 12 Spanish families in the late 1700s. The large, old one-story Salinas home sits across the street from Don Geronimo's home. Just around the corner from the main plaza, the location indicates that the owners were among the town's first families. ``They are good people,'' said Don Geronimo. ``Don Raul (the president's father) always has been a very decent man, a man of the people who came here to rest and visit whenever he had a chance, even when he was a high government official.'' Raul Salinas served as a senator, congressman and commerce secretary. ``He always brought his children with him. I remember the president being a rather quiet, shy boy at the time,'' Don Geronimo said. President Salinas was born in Mexico City, but he always comes back to his family roots and spends long holidays and vacations in Agualeguas. ``We are proud of him,'' said Ernesto Vazquez, who owns a small grocery story and claims he sells some of the best home-made beef jerky in northern Mexico. ``Someone from a town nearby said the other day Salinas was not even born here and we should not brag about him, but I think there is even more merit in the fact that he wants to be from here,'' Vazquez said. ``I think the visit here is like when you invite a friend to your home. Then they go to Monterrey to talk about serious matters,'' Don Geronimo said. ``I am going to sit on my porch and watch it all. I hope everything goes well. Bush has too many things to worry about now, but we want him to feel at home here.'' It will be close. Agualeguas is like a lot of Mexican towns near the U.S. border that have a constant interchange with their northern neighbor country. ``We understand the United States and we understand Americans,'' said Mauro Martinez, high school teacher and city chronicler. Vazquez offered U.S. brand beer at his grocery store, while on the sidewalks outside his young nephews and nieces, in town on a short visit, chatted in English. Many Agualeguas residents work or live temporarily in the United States but come home regularly for visits, Martinez said. ``They are not unlike the Salinases,'' he said. ``They want to come back to their roots. It is an emotional thing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ban on High-Level Exchanges Ends As U.N. Gulf Vote Approaches
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Only days before a U.N. Security Council vote on the use of force in the Persian Gulf, the United States has effectively ended a moratorium on high-level exchanges with China. Chinese officials today announced that the United States had invited a Chinese vice minister of trade to visit next month. He will be the highest-ranking Chinese to make an official visit to the United States since the June 1989 crushing of China's democracy movement. Word of the planned visit came as the U.S. Embassy in Beijing announced that Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen will travel to New York to cast China's vote on a U.N. Security Council resolution allowing the use of force against Iraq. U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan W. Bell said today the Chinese government had notified the embassy of Qian's plans to come to New York for the U.N. vote. The Chinese Foreign Ministry, asked for confirmation, did not immediately respond. The United States has been engaged in an intensive international lobbying campaign to win support for the resolution, which would authorize the use of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, which it seized Aug. 2. China, as a permanent Security Council member, could veto the measure. A vote on the resolution is expected sometime this week. Bell refused to discuss details of talks between Beijing and Washington on the resolution. ``We are in regular contact with the Chinese on a whole range of diplomatic issues,'' he said. ``To my knowledge, we still don't know how the Chinese are going to respond'' to a vote on the resolution. In keeping with China's longstanding opposition to superpower intervention in regional issues, Chinese officials have urged exhaustive efforts for a peaceful solution. They have refused to say publicly how China will vote on the resolution. However, U.S. officials have said they do not expect China or the Soviet Union, which is also a permanent member of the Security Council, to block the measure. Moscow also has been reluctant to allow force. China's international standing has improved greatly since the Persian Gulf crisis began because of Beijing's support for resolutions against Iraq. This has spurred the Bush administration's efforts to resume normal relations with China. The United States had joined other Western countries and Japan in imposing sanctions to punish China for its June 1989 army attack on student-led protesters for democratic reform. Among other things, the sanctions halted high-level exchanges. The forthcoming visit was announced today by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade. It said its vice minister, Gu Yongjiang, will visit the United States from Dec. 10-14 at the invitation of Commerce Department Undersecretary J. Michael Farren. Although there was no formal U.S. announcement, by inviting Gu the Bush administration effectively ends its own moratorium. Gu's trip falls in the category of those banned since June 1989. Japan and the European Community already have sent ministerial-level officials to Beijing, but Washington has not announced any such plans. Washington had violated its own ban once, when it sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to Beijing in November 1989. Otherwise, the only high-level contacts since June 1989 have been at the United Nations and in third countries. Secretary of State James A Baker III met Qian in Cairo in early November, for example. Washington said such meetings were not covered by the sanction. Other sanctions also have eroded. The United States has resumed import-export bank loans to China, and dropped its opposition to World Bank loans. The EC and Japan have resumed low-interest government loans. A ban on arms sales remains the only clear-cut Western sanction against China.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Participate in General Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to move up size of work force, translation of Podkrepa and background; Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The Socialist ...'; minor editing thereafter to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of workers walked off their jobs today, responding to an appeal by the opposition trad union for a general strike aimed at forcing Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov to resign. There were conflicting reports about the extent of the protest. But the walkout called by the Podkrepa labor federation was apparently limited to about 10 percent of the nation's work force of 4.5 million. ``The political tension in this country has reached threatening dimensions, and its further escalation is impermissible,'' Valentin Stoyanov, spokesman for President Zhelyu Zhelev, said on Bulgarian Radio. Zhelev called on the Socialists - formerly the Communists - and the opposition to meet today to negotiate a plan to bring the Balkan country out of its political and economic crisis. Lukanov's government had said the strike would be illegal. The action started at 6 a.m., but it was unclear how long it would last. Podkrepa announced the strike last week as demands intensified for the resignation of Lukanov and his former Communist associates. Bulgaria's main trade union organization, the Socialist-backed Confederation of Independent Unions, said Sunday it would not back the strike. Both unions claim hundreds of thousands of members. The opposition alliance in Parliament, the Union of Democratic Forces, said it would hold a rally Tuesday in support of the strike. Podkrepa, which means support, is a non-active, non-voting member of the Union of Democratic Forces, to counter Socialist charges that it is a political organization rather than a trade union. The Socialist Party, successor to the former Communist Party, won June elections. But the continuing economic decline and shortages of basic foods and consumer goods have led to growing demands for Lukanov's resignation and daily protests against the government. Lukanov and his government narrowly survived a no-confidence vote in parliament on Friday. That capped months of wrangling between the governing Socialists and the opposition over how to revive the economy. The state news agency BTA, some of whose staff joined today's strike, said that about half a million people walked off the job. Podkrepa's deputy chairman, Toncho Ivanov, said earlier the strike was strongest among miners and health workers throughout the country. He claims his union has 350,000 members. Podkrepa members were on strike in 30 enterprises in Sofia and in 40 in Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second-largest city, BTA said. It quoted Krustyu Krustev, chairman of the Podkrepa national strike committee. Symbolic or full strike actions were in progress in many other Bulgarian cities, BTA said. Deputy Premier Nora Ananieva told Bulgarian radio that ``by and large,'' economic enterprises were functioning normally, and that strikes were isolated to individual cities and enterprises. She denied reports that a main petrochemical combine in Burgas on the Black Sea and a metallurgical plant near Sofia were on strike. Rail, air and maritime traffic were working normally, Ananieva said, adding that with the exception of several bus lines, city transport in Sofia was also in operation. In a television appearance Sunday, the leader of the Podkrepa trade union, Konstantin Trenchev, said the government must resign if it cannot achieve a minimum standard of living for its population. In a seprate televised statement, Lukanov warned that a strike would hurt the economy even more and could lead to further unrest. He urged citizens ``not to support the adventurers who, in their greed for power, are prepared to push Bulgaria onto the fatal path of civic conflict.'' ``God won't fill the shops, but the strike will certainly empty them,'' Lukanov said. Many basic foodstuffs are scarce or beingrrationed. An energy crisis has led to periodic power cuts.

DOC.HEAD: British Women Say Thatcher Set Good Example But Little Else
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to restore dropped first name and reference to Ms. Hawkins.
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher set the example of what a woman could achieve in British society, but her critics say she did little else to help women along. For some, it was enough that her political career reached the heights. One woman wrote to The Independent newspaper last week that her 7-year-old daughter wondered what title Mrs. Thatcher's successor would hold, since ``he couldn't be called prime minister, that's a girl's name.'' Emma Nicholson, a Conservative Party lawmaker, said it was once unthinkable that a woman would ever be a British prime minister. ``She has broken the mold once and forever,'' Ms. Nicholson said in an interview. Mrs. Thatcher, who trained as a chemist before studying law, said she viewed herself as prime minister, not as a woman. She believed the battle for women's rights had been largely won and was no believer in feminism. ``What has it ever done for me?'' she once asked. Mrs. Thatcher, who stepped down on Thursday, urged women to get involved in politics, but did little to pull them up the ladder. Several female lawmakers were appointed to junior executive posts in various ministries, but the only woman to serve in a Thatcher Cabinet was Baroness Young, leader of the House of Lords from 1981 to 1983. ``The truth is that although Mrs. Thatcher is a woman, she doesn't believe in the advancement of women,'' Clare Short, a Labor Party lawmaker, said last month. Edwina Currie, a former junior health minister, said any other prime minister would have had several women in and out of the Cabinet. ``It's Margaret's fault that the only people standing (to succeed her) wear trousers,'' Mrs. Currie said last week. Trree men are vying to succeed her as Conservative Party leader and thus prime minister in a vote by party lawmakers set for Tuesday. Traditional male attitudes remain strong in Britain, from the upper-crust, all-male clubs of London to the topless women pictured daily in the tabloid press. Women are paid less than men and are poorly represented in management jobs and in Parliament. However, campaigners for women rights say there are encouraging signs at the grassroots. ``The critical mass of women have entered middle management in government and business,'' said Lesley Abdela, a founding member of the 300 Group. The group seeks equal representation for women in the 650-seat House of Commons, which now has 43 female members. Women represented 43 percent of the British labor force in 1988, compared with 40 percent in 1979 when Mrs. Thatcher became prime minister. Britain has a higher proportion of working women than other European Community countries. Though Mrs. Thatcher never made a priority of women's issues, she did introduce some helpful legislation: tax concessions for workplace nurseries; independent taxation for married women; and legislation to compel absent fathers to pay child benefits. But as prime minister, she angered feminists by often emphasizing women's traditional roles of homemakers and care-givers. Angela Rumbold, the Conservative Party's minister for women's issues, contends that an ``enormous amount'' has been done for women during the Thatcher years. ``I'm not sure what she could have gone beyond promoting people who were there just because they were women,'' she said in an interview. ``Margaret Thatcher is a great meritocrat. She believes in getting people to succeed on their merits.'' Jo Hawkins of the 300 Group, which is seeking equal numbers of women in the House of Commons, believes Mrs. Thatcher's extraordinary abilities made it difficult for her to understand the needs of the average woman. ``She would say that anybody can do it, just stick to your principles and get up and do it,'' Ms. Hawkins said. ``I think because of her character, her personality and her amazing self-confidence, she isn't aware of how the normal person struggles.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Consider Curtailing Federal Courts' Review Power
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to consider curtailing dramatically the power of federal courts to review criminal defendants' state court convictions. The justices, without comment, turned away a Florida case in which prosecutors asked them to bar most convicted defendants from going into federal court with claims that their so-called Miranda rights were violated. In its famous Miranda vs. Arizona decision in 1966, the high court said criminal suspects in police custody may not be interrogated unless told of their rights to remain silent, to have a lawyer's help, and to have a lawyer appointed for them if they cannot afford one. Confessions or other evidence obtained in violation of the Miranda ruling, which was based on the Constitution's Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination, cannot be used at trial. Florida prosecutors urged the court to rule that defendants given a full and fair chance in state courts to mount a Miranda challenge to the use of incriminating evidence be barred from carrying such challenges to federal courts. The court in 1976 shut down such federal court access for convicted defendants given a fair and full chance in state courts to challenge evidence allegedly obtained unlawfully by police. The Fourth Amendment bans unreasonable police searches and seizures. Over the past decade, the justices several times declined invitations to extend the 1976 decision, reached in a case called Stone vs. Powell, to criminal law areas outside the Fourth Amendment context. But in a 1989 case decided on other grounds, two justices - Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia - voted to extend the ban on federal court access to such Miranda challenges. In the case acted on today, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last April threw out Jack Towne's state court conviction and the 22-year prison sentence it drew. The appeals court ruled that Towne's confessions had been obtained in violation of his Fifth Amendment right because police continued to question Towne without trying to clarify ``an equivocal request for an attorney.'' Towne was arrested Dec. 4, 1984, for loitering and prowling at an apartment complex near his home in Gainesville, Fla. At the police station, an officer questioned Towne about several rapes and burglaries that had occurred recently in the same area. After Towne made some incriminating statements, the officer called in a detective who questioned Towne for an additional three hours. Towne subsequently pleaded ``no contest'' to charges of battery, sexual battery, armed robbery and armed burglary. But he reserved his right to appeal a state judge's refusal to suppress his confessions as evidence. After state appeals courts ruled that Towne's confessions were obtained in compliance with his Miranda rights, he turned to the federal courts for help. A federal trial judge ruled against him, but the 11th Circuit court threw out his conviction. The appeals court noted that at one point Towne said to the police officer who first questioned him, ``What do you think about whether I should get a lawyer?'' ``Questions such as the one posed by Towne are equivocal requests that require clarification before investigating officers initiate any further questioning,'' the appeals court ruled. The case is Dugger vs. Towne, 90-345.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling On Wisconsin Campaign Finance Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that a state may limit how much money a candidate receives from political committees. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that such a Wisconsin campaign financing law violates free-speech rights. The constitutionality of the law was challenged by John Gard, a Republican state assemblyman who was fined $500 for violating its limits in 1987. Other GOP officials in the state joined his challenge. Gard received $18,820 from committees in his campaign that year, $7,607 over the limit. The law places a cap on the total a candidate may receive from all committees, including political action committees (PACs) run by special interests and party-related committees. Gard and his allies said the law violates the free-speech rights of committees that may be barred from making even symbolic contributions to candidates who have reached the limit. They also said the law violates the candidate's free-speech rights by, in effect, limiting the amount of money he or she may spend. The Supreme Court in 1976 upheld federal campaign financing regulations limiting contributions to candidates. But the high court struck down provisions restricting campaign expenditures. The Wisconsin Supreme Court in June relied heavily on the 1976 ruling in upholding the state law. ``There is a compelling state interest in placing an aggregate limit on the contributions that an individual candidate may receive from allccommittees,'' the state court said. ``The purpose ... is to limit the impact of huge special interest contributions on a candidate and to encourage a broad and diverse base of support in order to prevent either actual corruption or the appearance of corruption.'' The state court said it is necessary to apply the limit to all committees, not just PACs, to prevent special interests from ``laundering'' contributions by funneling them through party-related committees. ``The aggregate limit encourages candidates to seek contributions from a greater number of sources and to compel people who would otherwise contribute amounts greater than the statutory limits to expend such funds on direct political expression,'' the Wisconsin court said. It said laws in at least five other states - Hawaii, Montana, Arizona, Louisiana and California - impose similar restrictions. The case is Gard vs. Wisconsin Elections Board, 90-536.

DOC.HEAD: Former Florida Congressman Loses Supreme Court Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Richard B. Kelly the former Florida congressman who served 13 months in prison for his Abscam bribery conviction in 1981, today lost a Supreme Court appeal in which he said new evidence shows he was denied a fair trial. The court, without comment, left intact rulings that threw out Kelly's latest appeal. Kelly, now 66 and living in Stevensville, Mont., was one of seven members of Congress convicted in the FBI's Abscam undercover operation. Kelly represented the Tampa area for three terms but lost a 1980 re-election bid after he was indicted. The jury that convicted him had watched a videotape of Kelly stuffing his pockets with $100 bills given to him by an FBI agent posing as an aide to a non-existent Arab sheik. Kelly said he accepted $25,000 from phony Arabs who said they had immigration problems because he was conducting his own investigation of ``shady characters.'' Kelly was imprisoned from Nov. 1, 1985, to Nov. 28, 1986, at the minimum-security federal prison camp on Eglin Air Force Base in the Florida Panhandle and at the Suncoast Rehabilitation Center in St. Petersburg. In the appeal acted on today, Kelly contended that a former FBI informant, James Davenport, stole key defense documents from his Capitol Hill office in August 1980 and gave the documents to federal prosecutors. Kelly said the new evidence about Davenport's theft entitles him to a new trial. A federal trial judge and the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here previously rejected Kelly's appeal. The case is Kelly vs. U.S., 90-682.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Challenge To Customs Agents' Seizure of Magazines
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected a challenge to the seizure by U.S. Customs agents of some 2,700 allegedly obscene magazines shipped from Cleveland and denied entry into Canada. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that the magazines could be treated as imports from a foreign country once they were headed back to Cleveland. Trans World News Co. of Cleveland shipped, on three occasions in 1987, some 0,000 magazines to Canada for North American News in Toronto. About 10,000 of the magazines were rejected at the Canadian border by officials who deemed them too sexually explicit and offensive to Canadian standards. When those magazines were returned, Customs agents in western New York seized and confiscated 2,703 of them after determining they probably were obscene under the standards of that part of the country. The magazines were seized under a federal law banning the import of obscene materials. U.S. District Judge John T. Curtin in Buffalo upheld the seizure and confiscation despite arguments by Trans World News lawyers that the magazines were not imports because they never had reached their Canadian destination. The 2nd U.S. Circuit upheld Curtin's ruling last July. ``Whether the magazines were accepted into Canada or denied entry and held by Canadian Customs is irrelevant,'' the appeals court said. It added: ``Regardless of their fate in Canada, the objectionable publications were presented at the United States border for entry into the United States from without when they were seized.'' The case is 1903 Obscene Magazines vs. U.S., 90-642.

DOC.HEAD: France Selling Arms To Kuwaiti Government-In-Exile
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: France is selling weapons - including Exocet and anti-tank missiles - to the Kuwaiti government-in-exile, a French newspaper reported today. The arms are being shipped to Saudi Arabia from an air base in France aboard Lebanese aircraft, the daily Nouvelle Republique du Centre-Ouest said. The Defense Ministry would not comment on the report. The French news agency Agence-France Presse quoted a source as saying the shipments were essentially spare parts for French-made aircraft. Kuwait's rulers fled because of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of the emirate, and set up a government-in-exile in Taif, Saudi Arabia. Kuwaiti pilots have been training in Saudi Arabia with Saudi and American forces. The Kuwaiti pilots flew 15 Mirage F-1 fighters, 20 A-4 Sky Hawks, six Hawk trainers and 15 French-made Gazelle helicopters - about 80 percent of the Kuwait air force's planes - to Saudi Arabia, officials have said. The Nouvelle Republique said the French arms deliveries began Nov. 6 and include anti-tank Hot missiles and airplane motors. Twenty-two flights carrying the arms left the airport at Chateauroux-Deols, 140 miles southwest of Paris, last week and three more are scheduled this month, the newspaper quoted sources as saying. The shipments are being carried out under a contract worth $180 million between France and the exiled emir of Kuwait, it quoted the sources as saying. It said the planes belong to Trans Mediterranean Air Cargo System, the cargo affiliate of Middle East Airlines of Lebanon. A spokeswoman for Middle East Airlines in Beirut who identified herself only as Mrs. Saadeh denied the airline was involved. Iraq freed all French nationals in Iraq and Kuwait on Oct. 30, but Paris has maintained there were no negotiations or conditions for their release. France has stressed its solidarity with the U.S.-led multinational force assembled in the Persian Gulf after the invasion of Kuwait. Argentina used a French-made Exocet missile to sink a British warship during the war over the Falkland Islands. Exocet missiles were used with less success during the Iran-Iraq war.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reinstate New York Parental Rights Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate a New York parental rights law that barred many men from vetoing the adoptions of their illegitimate children. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling by New York's highest court that the law violated fathers' constitutional rights. Until a 1979 ruling by the nation's highest court, fathers of children born out of wedlock had no parental rights. But in a series of decisions since, the court has said an unwed father may challenge a mother's putting the child up for adoption if he has ``manifested a significant paternal interest in the child.'' Under the invalidated New York law, a ``significant paternal interest'' had to be proved in three ways: -The father had to have lived with the mother or the child during the six months before the child was placed for adoption. -He had to openly acknowledge his fatherhood. -He had to have paid for pregnancy and birth expenses. In striking down the law last July, the New York Court of Appeals said, ``The ... requirement that the father openly live with the mother before a child's placement for adoption neither legitimately furthers the state's interest nor sufficiently protect that father's, and (the law) must therefore be declared unconstitutional.'' The July ruling cast doubt on the proposed adoption by a Nashua, N.H., couple of a girl born out of wedlock in White Plains, N.Y., two years ago. Lower courts had ruled that the adoption could be finalized without the consent of the child's biological father. The little girl, Raquel Marie, was born May 26, 1988, to a woman identified in court documents only as Louise N. The child's biological father is identified only as Miguel T. When Raquel Marie was 2 months old, her mother consented to the girl's adoption by the New Hampshire couple, identified as Robert and Ana C. Raquel has lived in Nashua ever since, but in November 1988 Louise N. and Miguel T. reconciled and were married. They opposed the as-yet completed adoption. Louise and Miguel had met while students at Eastchester High School in the suburban New York City area. They had their first child, a girl named Lauren, in 1986, but the couple lived together only a brief time in 1987. According to court documents, they had a stormy relationship, and Miguel T. on several occasions had been so physically abusive that Louise N. needed medical treatment. Since challenging Raquel's adoption, Louise N. and Miguel T. have separated. The case is Robert and Ana C. vs. Miguel T. and Louise N., 90-597.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Get Involved in Getz Divorce Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to become involved in a bitter divorce dispute between jazz saxophonist Stan Getz and his wife of 32 years. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments by Monica Getz that New York's divorce law violates the rights of women. Getz, 63, sued for divorce in 1981, after Mrs. Getz, 56, went to court alleging her husband - suffering from alcoholism and drug addiction - abused her. She sought a court order for family support payments and protection against Getz. The couple later made attempts at reconciliation before the divorce became final in 1987. A state jury ruled in Getz's favor in granting the divorce. He had accused his wife of infidelity and trying to poison him. Mrs. Getz said her husband had been repeatedly unfaithful and unpredictably violent, but said she stood by him when drugs and alcohol could have cost him his life. A state judge ruled that Mrs. Getz is entitled to half her husband's royalties from the beginning of their marriage in 1956 to 1981. That ruling was not at issue in the case acted on today. In her appeal to the Supreme Court, Mrs. Getz said the divorce decree against her is unfair. She said the case should have been resolved in New York's family courts rather than by trial courts that handle corporate disputes and other matters. She said the state law favors men by permitting them to wage ``legal wars of attrition'' against their wives, who often lack equal financial resources. Family courts are designed to expedite resolutions of divorce cases and spare the couple excessive legal fees, she said. Mrs. Getz said she has spent more than $600,000 in legal fees and will be forced to use the proceeds from the couple's mansion in Irvington, N.Y., where she still lives, to pay off the bills. In a legal brief in her behalf, Mrs. Getz's lawyer, Whitney North Seymour Jr., said, ``The wife's entire life has been left in shambles by this case. She has been branded an adulteress. She has become obligated to pay legal fees of many hundreds of thousands of dollars. She is being forced out of her home and to give up her old-age security.'' The case is Getz vs. Getz, 90-562.

DOC.HEAD: Torture and Killings Charged in Papua New Guinea
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said today that soldiers and riot police tortured and killed scores of people on Papua New Guinea's Bougainville Island during anti-rebel operations in the past two years. The London-based human rights organization warned such violations could be repeated on a wide scale if the troops and police in the Pacific island nation are allowed again to take the law into their own hands. Papua New Guinea, with a population of 3.6 million in an area slightly larger than California, has been an independent member of the 50-nation Commonwealth of Britain and its former colonies since 1975. It consists of the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and nearby islands, including Bougainville. Amnesty International said accounts of violations emerged soon after the government launched a counterinsurgency operation against the opposition Bougainville Revolutionary Army in early 1989. A state of emergency was imposed in June of that year. ``They bombed and raided more than 40 villages, burning houses, beating and sexually abusing villagers and killing dozens of people, including children as young as three months,'' said the group's 50-page report. ``Soldiers killed dozens of unarmed civilians they suspected of supporting the armed opposition and tortured scores of others,'' before government security forces were withdrawn from Bougainville in March of this year, the report said. The human rights group called for an impartial authority to investigate the allegations. Amnesty International also said the Papua New Guinea government took few steps to stop or investigate the human rights violations on Bougainville. There were frequent violations during states of emergency imposed in different parts of the country, which gave sweeping powers and immunity from prosecution to troops and police, the report said. It said journalists, religious workers, politicians, doctors, government workers and villagers were among the victims during the counterinsurgency operation on Bougainville. One politician was forced to lick the blood of a slain police officer; another man was beaten so badly he had to have a leg amputated and he later died, and a pastor and five of his congregation were seized on the street, beaten, stripped and shot to death, the report said. It gave details of ill-treatment, torture and killings and identified a number of victims. The group said it had well-documented evidence that 19 people died in apparent extrajudicial executions or after torture. The report said its findings were supported by medical records, autopsy reports, testimony from victims and eyewitnesses, press accounts and government documents. The group said it knew of only one soldier who was brought to justice for the abuses in the two years since they first became known. Amnesty International campaigns for freedom of non-violent political prisoners and against torture and capital punishment. It was awarded the 1977 Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEAD: One Boat Sinks, Others in Trouble in Severe Storm Off Alaska
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs with weather still causing problems, boats standing by to provide help, Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `The Seattle-based ...' DELETES last graf pvs., `At least ...' as outdated. Deletes `BRF' designation from slug.
DOC.TEXT: One fishing boat sank, two were abandoned and at least seven other boats were endangered by a severe winter storm east of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea, the Coast Guard said. Seas were cresting as high as 45 feet today, and other fishing boats were standing by to provide assistance. ``The weather is still pretty crummy. But there have been no injuries or deaths. That's phenomenal,'' Petty Officer John Germain said today. The Seattle-based crabber Winter Hawk sank Sunday morning about 150 miles east of the Pribilof island of St. George, said Lt. Sue Hargis at the Coast Guard's Rescue Coordination Center in Juneau. All five crewmen were rescued by other fishing boats, the Coast Guard said. The Shannon Marie, based in Portland, Ore., and the Pisces, believed to be based in Bellingham, Wash., were abandoned and left drifting Sunday after 30-foot waves and winds gusting to 90 mph battered them and other boats fishing for crab between the Pribilofs and Port Heiden in the Aleutian Islands, about 600 miles southwest of Anchorage, Coast Guard officials said. The Pisces' five crew members and the six crewmen aboard the Shannon Marie also were rescued, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Americans Can Take Relatives Home
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with more Trundy quotes, ADDS that he spoke with Mrs. Trundy by telephone. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The Baghdad..'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today told a group of Americans visiting Baghdad that they were free to take their detained relatives home at any time, Baghdad Radio reported. The report did not say how many hostages were involved, or give their names. However, the husband of a Massachusetts woman who is in Iraq to seek the release of her brother said his release had been promised. Mary Trundy of Brockton, Mass., is in Iraq with her brothers, Jame Stevenson and Bill Stevenson of Panama City, Fla. Their brother, John Stevenson, is a computer specialist who worked in Kuwait for 11 years. Mrs. Trundy's husband, Dennis, said Saddam himself had told them her brother would be released. ``She and her two brothers met with Saddam Hussein sometime this morning and he said `sure, take him,''' said Trundy, who spoke with his wife by telephone from Massachusetts. ``It was getting kind of dragged on there. They didn't know what was going on. But things moved kind of fast the last day or two,'' he said. The Baghdad Radio report, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Saddam as telling the relatives the United States did not have the right to appoint itself to police the world, and said Iraq wanted peace and a solution to the Palestinian conflict. A number of Americans are in Baghdad seeking their relatives' freedom. Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash., has a son, Vala Fouroohi, who is seeking his release. Briton Nigel Nightingale's wife Jean, an American, also traveled to Baghdad to seek his freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Refuses to Yield; Saddam Says Some Americans Can Go With Relatives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam saying Americans can take their relatives home, oil prices up. Pickup 2nd graf pvs, ``The Soviet Union...''
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today accused the United States of using blackmail to win U.N. backing for a military strike to free Kuwait, and Saddam Hussein met relatives of some American hostages and told them their loved ones were free to go. Baghdad Radio, which reported on the meeting between Saddam and the Americans, did not say how many hostages would be allowed to leave. The report did not name the hostages or their relatives. However, Dennis Trundy of Brockton, Mass., said Saddam promised to free his brother-in-law, John Stevenson. Trundy's wife and her two other brothers are in Baghdad and called with the news. ``She and her two brothers met with Saddam Hussein sometime this morning and he said `sure, take him,''' Trundy said. Also today, oil prices - which have fluctuated wildly since Iraq seized the oil-rich emirate - rose about $2 a barrel on the futures market, as traders speculated the United Nations was about to authorize the use of force against Iraq. By late morning, light sweet crude was up $2.05 at $33.95 on contracts for delivery in January. Contracts for delivery in later months were sharply higher. The Soviet Union, meanwhile, which has advised patience in dealing with Iraq, today threatened to take a ``tougher attitude'' because Saddam failed to allow 1,000 Soviets to leave in November. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin spoke at a news briefing that coincided with a four-hour meeting in Moscow between Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and the Iraqi foreign minister. Churkin said Iraq allowed 350 Soviets to depart this month, adding: ``If Iraq does not immediately remove obstacles and allow our citizens to leave, this will complicate the present situation even further and force us to take a tougher attitude.'' In other developments: -The Iraqi parliament voted to free the 58 Swedes remaining in Iraq, the Swedish Embassy in Baghdad reported. The vote requires approval from Saddam, the embassy said. Iraq freed more than 100 Germans and 10 Greeks on Sunday. Iraqi officials said 70 Italian hostages would be allowed to leave Tuesday. -Saddam warned that if the U.S.-led force attacks, he will unleash his missiles on Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf Arab states. -Iraqi authorities took steps Sunday to make sure any shortages caused by a U.N.-mandated trade embargo are felt in Kuwait. The official Iraqi News Agency said food rationing would begin soon in the oil-rich emirate. -Kuwait's government-in-exile, citing reports from escapees, said Kuwaiti resistance fighters recently wounded the Iraqi-appointed governor of Kuwait. The report could not be independently confirmed, but Iraq did announce the appointment of a new governor earlier this month. The proposed U.N. resolution authorizing military force against Iraq unless it withdraws from Kuwait by Jan. 1 was circulated as the Security Council prepared for this week's debate on the Persian Gulf crisis. The resolution was given to the other permanent members of the Security Council - Great Britain, France, Chia and the Soviet Union. Any one permanent member has the power to block it. U.S. officials have said they did not expect the Soviet Union and China to veto such a resolution, but raised the possibility they would seek softer language. The Soviets and others who counseled more diplomacy have urged the Bush administration to be patient for at least two more months. Iraq said the proposed U.N. resolution will not force it to give up any of the land it seized Aug. 2. ``If anybody believes that this newest resolution will influence our position or force us to abandon our rights, they are completely wrong,'' the ruling Baath party said in its daily newspaper, Al-Thawra. The newspaper said the United States is using ``terrorism, threats and blackmail'' to try to win approval of the resolution. The United States is seeking a U.N. vote this week because its one-month presidency of the council ends Friday. Taking over is the Red Sea state of Yemen, which has supported Iraq in the past. The United States wants international legitimacy behind any military action to liberate Kuwait. It also wants unanimity in issuing the strongest warning yet to Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Army Sets Call-Up Date For Two National Guard Combat Brigades
DOC.TEXT: The Army said today it ordered National Guard combat units from four states to report for active duty Friday. They will be the first Army reserve combat forces to be activated for Operation Desert Shield. The reservists are to undergo desert warfare training at Fort Irwin, Calif., before the Pentagon decides whether to send them to the front lines in Saudi Arabia. An Army announcement being prepared for release by the Defense Department said Guard combat brigades from Georgia and Louisiana would be activated Friday, but no mention was made of a Mississippi Guard brigade that had been expected to get activation orders. Besides the 48th Infantry Brigade(Mechanized) of Georgia and the 256th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Louisiana, the Army also said a battalion of the 152nd Armor of Oneonta, Ala., and the 1st Battalion, 263rd Armor of Mullins, S.C., were being called to active duty to support the Persian Gulf operation. Those units, plus the 155th Armored Brigade of Mississippi, were among National Guard forces alerted Nov. 16 for possible activation. Last Wednesday the Army said all three combat brigades, plus three smaller combat units, would be put on active duty soon but that no firm date had been established. An Army spokesman, Maj. Joe Padilla, said he had no immediate information on why the 155th of Mississippi was not included in the units ordered to report for duty Friday. ``There are no plans to take them off the alert list,'' Padilla said. The Army had said last week that about 5,000 members of the 48th of Georgia would be put on active duty, along with about 5,500 members of the 256th of Louisiana, 3,700 members of the 155th of Mississippi and about 900 members of smaller combat units from Alabama, South Carolina and Texas. Today's announcement made no mention of a Texas unit being among those reporting for duty Friday, and no official estimate of the total number of forces being activated was immediately available. Here are the units ordered to report for duty on Friday: GEORGIA

-48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) headquarters, Macon. -848th Engineer Co., Douglas. -Troop E, 348th Armored Cavalry, Griffin. -1st Battalion, 230th Field Artillery, Waycross. -148th Combat Support Battalion, Forsyth. -1st Battalion, 108th Armor, Calhoun. -1st Battalion, 121st Infantry (Mechanized), Dublin. -2nd Battalion, 121st Infantry (Mechanized), Albany.
