DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Buys MCA in Biggest Japanese Purchase of U.S. Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CLARIFY that deal values MCA at nearly $6.6 billion, including value of stock in TV station, UPDATES stock price and that Matsushita valued at $37.8 billion in 1990 revenue figures. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: In the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. announced today that it is buying MCA Corp., owner of Universal Studios, in a deal worth $6.6 billion. Matsushita, a $37.8 billion giant known for such brand names as Panasonic, Quasar and Technics, is Japan's biggest manufacturer of consumer electronics equipment. By buying the maker of such box office hits as ``Jaws'' and ``Back to the Future,'' Matsushita seemed to be trying to keep pace with archrival Sony Corp., which bought Columbia Pictures for $5 billion a year ago, analysts said. Universal is the fourth Hollywood studio to come under foreign control. The deal seems likely to heighten fears in the United States that too many major U.S. companies are falling under Japanese control. Asked how the purchase would affect U.S.-Japan relations, Matsushita's president, Akio Tanii, said jokingly that he hoped ``MCA will make a movie called `Japan-Bashing.''' Under the agreement, Matsushita is to start a cash tender offer of $66 a share for MCA's about 92.8 million shares of common stock by Nov. 30. MCA shareholders will also get stock in a television station that cannot be sold to Matsushita because federal rules prohibit foreign-based companies from owning U.S. broadcast stations. The deal calls for MCA shareholders to get one share in a new company that will own MCA's New York-area television station, WWOR, for every five shares of MCA stock they own just before the tender offer is completed. Company officials have estimated the new shares will be worth about $5 for every share of MCA stock. Adding that to the $66 per share in cash brings the per-share value to $71, or nearly $6.6 billion, for MCA's fully diluted shares. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, MCA was the most actively traded issue, slipping 25 cents a share by late morning to $65.12{. MCA Corp.'s chairman and chief executive officer, 77-year-old Lew Wasserman, stands to earn about about $355 million from the deal. Wasserman had personal holdings of 5 million MCA shares, or 7 percent, and controlled an additional 6 million through trusts and charities. ``Matsushita is a great international company,'' Wasserman said. ``This combination assures the structural integrity of MCA and its worldwide operation. MCA will continue to operate under its own name and will be run by its existing management.'' The purchase, which followed two months of intense, sometimes frustrating negotiations, is seen as Matsushita's attempt to dominate the growing merger of technological hardware and entertainment industries. ``Software and hardware have been developing simultaneously - they are like wheels of the same car,'' Tanii said at company headquarters in Osaka. ``We intend that excellent works made by MCA will be distributed all over the world through a variety of media.'' Analysts say Matsushita will now have a ready stock of high-profile movie and television programming to use for its high definition television, considered the next generation in home entertainment. Nonetheless, several analysts said the much-touted ``natural'' linkup between hardware manufacturers and movie, video and TV entertainment companies is still an unproven strategy. For one thing, digitalizing older movies and TV programs for high definition TV is very expensive. ``It looks like they're doing it and trying to figure out strategy afterward,'' said Mike Jeremy, an analyst in Tokyo for Baring Securities. In Japan, Matsushita is jokingly called ``Maneshita,'' or ``copycat,'' for its custom of introducing products only after its competitors have tested the market for them. But some people envision a future of integrated home entertainment consoles that would include high definition TV, a personal computer, stereo and other gadgetry. And that future may accrue to the company with the most prominent image, analysts said. ``Sony has a strong image. People in most countries would automatically know what a Walkman is,'' Jeremy said. ``Matsushita has Panasonic, Quasar and Technics, but they need to rationalize themselves into one image.'' But in an atmosphere of trade friction between the United States and Japan - not to mention the potential of a further downturn in the U.S. economy - Matsushita is taking a big risk, analysts say. ``The biggest problem is the negative image of Japanese buying up everything in the U.S.,'' said Rodney Harada, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. ``One of the biggest reasons I was surprised by the deal was because Matsushita has always been careful to improve its image before.'' Apart from Universal Pictures, which also produced such hits as ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' MCA's holdings include a robust television division featuring winners like ``Murder, She Wrote'' and ``Quantum Leap.'' MCA Records carries the popular teen vocalist Tiffany, as well as the sultry star Sheena Easton. MCA, which earned $191 million last year on revenues of $3.4 billion, also owns a book publishing division, theme parks and real estate. In addition to Universal and Columbia Pictures, the other two Hollywood studios to come under foreign control are 20th Century Fox, now under Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. based in Australia, and MGM-UA Communications Inc., now owned by Italian-controlled Pathe Communications Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Poet's $2,200 Trust for Elderly Home Grows to $215,000 After 72 Years
DOC.TEXT: A $2,200 gift by a farsighted poet 72 years ago has swelled nearly one hundredfold and will be used to establish a home for the elderly retarded. Henry C. Burns, who died in 1918 a childless widower, left $2,207.21 in trust along with a collection of his poetry and prose. He directed that the trust be used to fund housing for the elderly retarded once it reached $175,000. The account, held at Pittsburgh National Bank, passed that amount about a year ago, bank officials said, and now stands at almost $215,000. In accordance with the terms of the trust, bank officials began soliciting proposals for the home when the account surpassed the $175,000 point, said John D. Culbertson, a bank vice president. The bank, named Fidelity Title & Trust Co. at the time of Burns' death, was instructed in the will to give the money to city, county or state authorities, ``whichever shall give the best assurance'' of establishing such a home. City and state officials deferred to Allegheny County, which already contracts with agencies for services for older citizens. The county began site searching this month. A gift from a trust ``happens occasionally, but not in this order of magnitude,'' said Raymond Firth, deputy director of the county's mental health program. County officials said they may seek funds from private foundations to add to the trust, and may establish more than one group home, Firth said. Advancements in medicine have increased the life span of retarded people and the need for housing, Firth said. Burns' will instructed that the home be named ``Our Father's Relief Accumulated Fund Home for Aged and Infirm People.'' He also stipulated that bound copies of ``Musings of a Blind Man,'' a collection of his poems and prose writings, were to be kept at the home ``for general use and reading.'' But residents of the home will not be able to read Burns' books. Officials of Pittsburgh Nationl Bank don't know what happened to the volumes, which were last referred to in records in March 1924. Culbertson speculated that the books may have been stored in the bank's downtown vault, which was swamped in a 1936 flood.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut's Son Promoting Space Trading Cards
DOC.TEXT: Move over, Jose Canseco. Shove aside, Barry Bonds. Make room for Gus Grissom, Ed White and Roger Chaffee. The booming trading card market, already crowded with baseball, hockey, football, basketball, bowling and golf cards, has a new contender: astronaut cards. They are the idea of Ed White III, whose father was one of three astronauts who died in the launch-pad fire of the Apollo I spacecraft in 1967. The others were Grissom and Chaffee. White has paid tribute to the three Apollo astronauts in series No. 1 of SpaceShots, which he bills as The Trading Cards of The Future. He says the cards are drawing the attention of card collectors and space buffs. ``We're advertising in several space-oriented publications with a mail-in form and a toll-free telephone number,'' said White, who lives in Houston. He was on Mississippi's Gulf Coast to visit relatives. White said he was a baseball card and coin collector in the 1960s, and when he read a newspaper column about three years ago describing the value of old cards, he pulled his collection out of the attic. ``I was surprised,'' White said. ``The baseball card collection was worth five times the coin collection.'' That is when the idea came to him. He was in the telecommunications business at the time, and the space card project was a hobby. He sold his business earlier this year so that he and a friend, Jim Roettger, could devote their full attention to the cards. SpaceShots are produced by their Dallas-based company, Space Ventures Inc. White said he and Roettger hope to put out four sets a year, with each set containing 110 cards. ``Eventually, we will also package them in smaller sets like baseball cards,'' he said. White said 25 percent of the proceeds will be donated to the Astronaut Memorial, which is under construction at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The monument will honor those astronauts who lost their lives aboard Apollo I, the space shuttle Challenger and four who died in training before 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Forcing Jerusalem Shopkeepers To Fire Arabs
With AM-Israel-Borders, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bands of Jewish zealots are burning shops and threatening Jerusalem merchants to force the firing of Arab workers, and the intimidation campaign is drawing angry comparisons with racist treatment of Jews. On Monday, police arrested four followers of slain extremist Rabbi Meir Kahane on suspicion of involvement in the incitement. Politicians ranging from the left to the right joined in protesting the violence. ``For anyone familiar with Jewish history, it brings to mind difficult pictures from our past,'' Justice Minister Dan Meridor of the right-wing Likud bloc said on Israel radio. ``Such things must be uprooted. ... We should not tolerate expressions of racism.'' He pointed particularly to efforts to force shopkeepers to display signs saying ``I don't employ Arabs'' - chillingly similar to signs disavowing employment of Jews that appeared in German shops before the Holocaust. Six million Jews were killed by the Nazis. ``I can remind you where and when it appeared on storefronts, `Jews Don't Work Here,''' said lawmaker Yossi Sarid of the liberal Citizens' Rights Movement. Jerusalem Police spokesman Aharon Elhayani said four suspects, all followers of Kahane's Kach movement, were arrested on charges of threatening shopowners, incitement and causing damage. He identified three as Kach spokesman Noam Federman, and activists Tiran Pollack and Baruch Marzel. The fourth was not identified. Israel radio said police were conducting an intensive investigation of the threats and violence. The anti-Arab campaign plays on Jewish fears following a series of revenge attacks on Israelis for the deaths of 17 Palestinians in police gunfire during stone-throwing riots on Jerusalem's Temple Mount in October. The attacks spurred calls to replace the thousands of Palestinians from the occupied territories and annexed east Jerusalem who work in Israel, often as trash collectors, restaurant workers and at other low-paying jobs. Federman told Israel radio prior to his arrest that the party was not using violence. But he admitted Kach was trying to persuade shop owners to fire Arabs. ``We have approached shopkeepers, including one whose shop was burned, and asked them to fire (the Arabs). He did not fire them so it's reasonable to believe that angry citizens did it, and I understand them,'' Federman said. The campaign against employing Arabs began shortly after the shooting death of Kahane in New York on Oct. 5. The suspected gunman is an Arab-American. Groups of young Jewish men have paid visits to shopkeepers in the predominantly Orthodox Jerusalem neighborhoods of Beit Israel and Geulah, urging them to dismiss Arab workers. Slogans were spray-painted on the walls of stores, saying: ``A warning to the employer of the Arabs.'' In Beit Israel, walls were plastered with posters that said: ``Employing Arabs in our midst is dangerous to life. We are not ready to live in danger and permanent fear just because the merchants who employ Arabs want to make some extra money.'' The posters were signed by ``residents and rabbis of the neighborhood.'' Although dozens of Arabs still work in Beit Israel, only a few of the original 40 remained at the nearby Bukharian Market, newspaper reports said Monday. About two weeks ago, a butcher shop was set ablaze in Beit Israel. A grocery store was burned in the neighborhood Sunday night, and the writing on its wall said: ``Death to the Arabs.'' ``This month, they started to threaten with slogans painted on the walls outside. ... We fired the Arabs and still they came and burned the shop,'' said the grocery's owner, Aryeh Moshe. Another shopkeeper, Mordechai Mizrahi, was stabbed in the arm earlier this month by a Kach supporter while trying to defend his Arab employee. The Arab, Amad Abu Sina, suffered serious wounds. Now, Mizrahi's butcher store features a sign: ``No Arabs employed here.'' ``We defended the Arab as we would defend anybody who is attacked in the store,'' Mizrahi told the daily Maariv. ``But when we speak of income, it's another matter. We have no choice, if we employ Arabs we starve. People are not ready to buy the goods when they see than an Arab had touched them.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns Saddam: Anti-Iraq Unity Unshakable
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev forcefully warned Saddam Hussein Monday that the unity of those nations allied against Iraqi aggression cannot be broken. Another Soviet official, meanwhile, accused Baghdad of breaking a promise to allow the departure of 1,000 Soviets still in Iraq and threatened a ``tougher attitude'' by Moscow if they were not permitted to leave. As the United States sought United Nations approval this week of a resolution authorizing the use of military force if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 1, the Soviet Union embarked on a new round of meetings with officials from Iraq and Saudi Arabia. Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in the Kremlin Monday to reiterate the Soviet demand that Iraq withdraw troops from Kuwait. Shevardnadze will meet with Saudi Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal on Tuesday. Gorbachev told Aziz to ask Saddam to rethink the Iraqi position because Baghdad's destiny is in the hands of its leadership and time is slipping away, the official Tass news agency reported. The Soviet leader told Aziz that if Iraq wants to avoid the worst, it must leave Kuwait, free Western hostages and permit all foreigners to leave, Tass said. Saddam's arguments that Kuwait is Iraqi land and that Iraq was threatened by its neighbor are not taken seriously, the news agency quoted Gorbachev as saying. Aziz replied he would take Gorbachev's message to Saddam, and he indicated that a ``bureaucratic accident'' had resulted in the delay of the departure of the Soviet specialists, Tass reported. Answering questions from legislators in the Supreme Soviet parliament about the possibility of a conflict in the Persian Gulf involving the United States, Gorbachev said the crisis was a test of the new post-Cold War cooperation. ``Our position remains based on principles and it includes the following: Aggression is inadmissible. It should be punished, and the pre-aggression state should be restored,'' Gorbachev said, his voice booming. ``We are in favor of preserving a unity of action in the framework of the United Nations ... and the Security Council. That's important,'' he said. ``And we are reaffirming that we are going to cooperate with everybody - the United States, the permanent members of the Security Council, all the members of the Security Council and the United Nations organization, Arabs, Europeans, etc. - so as to leave no pretext and no hope for the Saddam Hussein regime that it can break this unity,'' Gorbachev said, pounding the lectern. He said Saddam's aggression could not be allowed to prevail ``because we are just moving away from the Cold War, when everything was decided from a position of force.'' Gorbachev said the Soviet Union would discuss with other U.N. Security Council members whether a new resolution needed to be adopted. The Soviet Union has given its qualified consent to the use of force in the gGulf, but is pushing for a diplomatic settlement. It has urged the Bush administration to be patient for another two months. Also Monday, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Iraq had agreed to allow 1,000 Soviets, mostly contract workers, to leave during November, but only about 350 people were permitted to do so. There were about 8,000 Soviets, including several hundred military advisers, in Iraq when it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 3,000 Soviets, including women and children, were allowed to leave shortly after the invasion and about 1,000 left during September and October. Churkin said Iraq had agreed to allow another 1,000 to leave in November, but was not living up to its promise. ``Iraq is not keeping its agreement that our citizens will not be prevented from leaving,'' he said. ``This is totally abnormal and unacceptable.'' He said, ``If Iraq does not immediately remove obstacles and allow our citizens to leave, this will complicate the present situation even further and force us to take a tougher attitude.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Keeps Alive Fair-Housing Suit Over Condo Ads
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to kill two fair-housing lawsuits stemming from newspaper real estate advertisements showing only white models posing as homeowners. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that forces developers of a Virginia condominium community to defend themselves in a jury trial against allegations they violated federal law. The suits center on ads that appeared in The Washington Post over a 17-month period beginning in 1985 for Colonial Village, a condo community in Arlington, just across the Potomac River from the District of Columbia. The suits were filed by Girardeau Spann, a black resident of Washington who is a professor at Georgetown University's law school, and two advocacy groups - the Metropolitan Washington Planning and Housing Association and the Fair Housing Council of Greater Washington. Named as defendants are Colonial Village Inc., and its parent firm, Mobil Land Development Corp., a subsidiary of the oil company. The lawsuits allege that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by featuring only white models in ads that appeared in the Post. The suits said the ads were racially preferential and discriminatory, and they sought an injunction and monetary damages. A federal trial judge in 1987 threw out the suits, ruling they had been filed too late. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here reinstated them last March 13, and sent the dispute back to U.S. District Judge Harold Greene for trial.

DOC.HEAD: Court Revives Suit Over Use of Monkeys in Research
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court revived a longstanding legal battle Monday in which animal rights groups are trying to save four monkeys used for medical research. The justices said they will decide whether a federal agency should have been allowed to transfer the groups' lawsuit against it from state to federal court, where the suit was killed. If the animal rights groups win in the high court, their fight will be sent back to a Maryland state court. If the justices had rejected the groups' appeal, their legal fight would have ended. The controversy dates back to 1981. Alex Pacheco, then a George Washington University student, said the research business for which he worked as a volunteer did not provide sufficient food and water, sanitation or veterinary care for 17 macaque monkeys. Only four of the original group of 17 are the subjects of the legal fight. Five have been moved to the San Diego Zoo and eight have died or been killed. In a federally funded project at its Silver Spring, Md., laboratory, the Institute for Behavioral Research was studying the ability of monkeys to use limbs after nerves were severed. Maryland police seized the monkeys in late 1981, and the National Institutes of Health, a federal agency, assumed custody of the animals. They eventually ended up at Tulane University's Delta Regional Primate Research Center in Covington, La. NIH was sued in 1988 by Pacheco and the group he founded, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, and two other animal rights groups - International Primate Protection League and Louisiana In Support of Animals. The groups filed their lawsuit in a state court, but the NIH had the case transferred to a federal court. Eventually, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ordered the lawsuit dismissed. The issue to be decided by the Supreme Court is whether the federal agency should have been allowed to remove the lawsuit from the state court.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Legislators Propose Lip-Syncing Concert Disclaimers
DOC.TEXT: Two state lawmakers filed a bill Monday to prevent singing groups like the pop duo Milli Vanilli from giving the audience nothing but lip service in Massachusetts. ``If you pay `real' money for a concert, you ought to get `real' live music in return,'' said Rep. Kevin Poirier. The bill would require promoters to disclose whetherany part of a performance consists of pre-recorded vocals. Ticket agents would also be required to notify concertgoers of plans for the headline performer to use pre-recorded vocals. Under the bill, ticket agents could be fined up to $5,000 and promoters up to $50,000 for violations. Similar legislation has been proposed in New York and New Jersey. Both were introduced before the revelation two weeks ago that the Milli Vanilli duo of Fabrice Morvan and Rob Pilatus did not sing in concerts or on their album. No action was taken on the legislation in either state. New York's bill would have gone further than the proposed legislation in Massachusetts and New Jersey, requiring disclosures in advertisements. ``It's time to stop the phoney road shows,'' said Rep. William Vernon, co-sponsor of the Massachusetts legislation. Carl Freed, executive director of the North American Concert Promoters Association, said lip-syncing has become more prevalent in live acts because performers are expected to do complicated dance routines. In a recent concert tour, Madonna performed a duet with a dancer who lip-synced a song that Warren Beatty sang on her album. Instead of forcing promoters and ticket sellers to disclose lip-syncing, Freed said the artists should tell their fans what they do in performance. The music industry may not be inclined to take action unless ticket sales drop off at concerts where the singing is staged, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Reinstate N.Y. Parental Rights Law
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused Monday to reinstate a New York parental rights law that barred many men from vetoing the adoptions of their illegitimate children. The justices, without comment, left intact a ruling by New York's highest court that the law violated fathers' constitutional rights. Until a 1979 ruling by the nation's highest court, fathers of children born out of wedlock had no parental rights. But in a series of decisions since, the court has said an unwed father may challenge a mother's putting the child up for adoption if he has ``manifested a significant paternal interest in the child.'' Under the invalidated New York law, a ``significant paternal interest'' had to be proved in three ways: -The father had to have lived with the mother or the child during the six months before the child was placed for adoption. -He had to openly acknowledge his fatherhood. -He had to have paid for pregnancy and birth expenses. In striking down the law last July, the New York Court of Appeals said, ``The ... requirement that the father openly live with the mother before a child's placement for adoption neither legitimately furthers the state's interest nor sufficiently protect that father's, and (the law) must therefore be declared unconstitutional.'' The July ruling cast doubt on the proposed adoption by a Nashua, N.H., couple of a girl born out of wedlock in White Plains, N.Y., two years ago. Lower courts had ruled that the adoption could be finalized without the consent of the child's biological father.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``Cheers'' star Kirstie Alley said her whole life changed when she broke free of drug addiction. ``It changed my relationship with my family,'' she said. ``I started telling the truth, which was a big difference for me. I started having real relationships. I married a really hot-looking guy. I started a career rather late in life from what most actors and actresses start their careers.'' Alley, who spent the Thanksgiving weekend with relatives in Wichita, said she has been drug free since entering the Narconon program in Los Angeles in 1979. On Sunday, she and her husband, actor Parker Stevenson, visited Narconon Chilocco, the group's new drug rehabilitation center outside Newkirk, Okla. Alley portrays self-conscious ``Cheers'' manager Rebecca Howe on the television show and stars in the current film comedy ``Sibling Rivalry.'' She said she turned to cocaine when her life took a series of wrong turns while she was working in Wichita as an interior designer in the late 1970s. ``I wasn't an actress, like I wanted to be,'' she said. ``It was sort of hard in Kansas to say, you know, `I want to be a movie star.' You don't get a lot of validation for that.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The former wife of jazz saxophonist Stan Getz lost a Supreme Court appeal alleging New York's divorce law violates the rights of women. The justices, without comment, on Monday rejected arguments by Monica Getz that the state law favors men by permitting them to wage ``legal wars of attrition'' against their wives, who often lack equal financial resources. Getz, 63, sued for divorce in 1981, after Mrs. Getz, 56, went to court alleging her husband - suffering from alcoholism and drug addiction - abused her. She sought a court order for family support payments and protection against Getz. The couple later made attempts at reconciliation before the divorce became final in 1987. A state jury ruled in Getz's favor in granting the divorce. He had accused his wife of infidelity and trying to poison him. A state judge ruled that Mrs. Getz is entitled to half her husband's royalties from the beginning of their marriage in 1956 to 1981. In her appeal to the Supreme Court, Mrs. Getz said the case should have been resolved in New York's family courts, which are designed to expedite divorce cases to save legal fees, rather than by trial courts that handle corporate disputes and other matters. Mrs. Getz said she has spent more than $600,000 in legal fees and will be forced to use the proceeds from the couple's mansion in Irvington, N.Y., where she still lives, to pay off the bills. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Bo Schembechler doesn't coach here anymore, but his $12 million legacy at the University of Michigan is being criticized as sexist. Schembechler Hall, named after the football coach who resigned in January, opened this fall as the home of Michigan's football program. But the Center of Champions is off limits to Michigan athletes who don't play football. ``This is the 1990s. People (of both sexes) can work in the same space. This would have been the perfect time for equality,'' said Tricia Maran, a Michigan field hockey player. The criticism probably won't make any difference, officials said. ``It's pretty hard for me or anybody else on the Board of Regents to say Bo can't build a building for football, especially if he raises the dough for it,'' trustee Philip Power said Sunday. ``You have to be realistic.'' Schembechler, who ended his 26-year career at Michigan with a 234-65-8 record, is president of the Detroit Tigers baseball team. --- LONDON (AP) - Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, will make an overnight visit to Paris on Dec. 17-18, Buckingham Palace said Monday. The informal visit had been scheduled for the summer, but was postponed after the prince broke his arm while playing polo June 28, said a press officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. Prince Charles' wife, Princess Diana, will not accompany him. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Science fiction writer Ray Bradbury says the heart should always rule the head, even if it means jumping off a few cliffs. The 60-year-old author of such books as ``Fahrenheit 451'' and ``The Martian Chronicles'' said he succeeded because he learned to ignore naysayers. ``If we listened to our intellect, we'd never have a love affair. We'd never have a friendship. We'd never go into business because we'd be cynical,'' Bradbury said in a recent interview. ``Well, that's nonsense. You've got to jump off cliffs all the time and build your wings on the way down.'' Bradbury, who shunned college in favor of independent reading, has published more than 500 short stories plus several successful novels and screenplays, including a 1954 adaptation of ``Moby Dick.'' Two of Bradbury's books have been published this year. ``A Graveyard of Lunatics,'' is a murder mystery based on his experiences as a screenwriter. ``Zen and the Art of Writing,'' is a nonfiction work.

DOC.HEAD: Plan Calls For Tolls, Other Fees to Visit Florida Keys
DOC.TEXT: Visitors would have to pay to play in the Florida Keys under a state proposal to raise money to protect what's left of the fragile marine environment there. The biological slide of the Keys has pushed the stat Department of Natural Resources to create the state's first marine reserve, funded by a 50-cent road toll on the Overseas Highway, a $1 flight fee at county airports and a $5 snorkeling charge. ``Like it or not, Keys waters - that are not owned by the people in the Keys but by the state as a whole - are the most important national and international resource that we have,'' said Edwin Conklin, the agency's director of marine planning. But independence-minded Keys residents - who once staged a mock secession from the union and declared themselves citizens of the Conch Republic when they became fed up with federal policies - aren't exactly buying into the proposal, which goes before Gov. Bob Martinez and the Cabinet on Tuesday. ``I just don't think we need this level of bureaucracy,'' Monroe County Commissioner Doug Jones said. If the fees are adopted, the state expects to collect $10 million a year to fund enforcement, research and education projects in the reserve, which would cover state waters roughly three miles into the Atlantic and 10 miles into the Gulf of Mexico. The 50-cent toll would require congressional approval because U.S. Highway 1, which stretches south to Key West, is a federal road. The airport fee would be paid by anyone flying into the Keys' commercial airports in Key West and Marathon, and the snorkeling fee would be in the form of a $5 annual stamp similar to existing fishing license fees. ``Divers are a big user of the Keys,'' Conklin said. ``It is unfortunate that we have to ask for money but a few bucks, which is what we're asking for, is not going to kill the industry.'' Access would be limited or barred in some threatened portions of one of the world's prime coral reef tracts, which drew 1 million visitors last year. An operating license would be required for Keys boaters even though legislation for a statewide boating license failed this year.

DOC.HEAD: Rapid X-Ray Test Developed for Detecting Coronary Artery Disease
DOC.TEXT: Computer-enhanced X-rays are showing promise in rapidly detecting coronary artery disease in people under 60 without requiring the insertion of tubes or other equipment into the body, radiologists said Monday. A technique called ultrafast computed tomography that uses such X-rays to detect calcium in arteries could be highly accurate and cost-effective in detecting coronary artery disease, the doctors reported. ``Ultrafast CT appeared to be able to rule out significant coronary artery disease in 100 percent of the cases we studied,'' said Dr. Jerome Breen of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He presented his findings at the 76th annual meeting of the Radiological Society of North America, which began its five-day run Monday in Chicago. Ultrafast CT was performed on 100 patients ages 23 to 59 who were sent to specialists for coronary angiograms, primarily because of symptoms such as chest pain or chest tightness that suggested coronary artery disease, Breen said. An angiogram requires that an artery, usually in the groin, be punctured and a tube threaded up into the chest arteries that feed the heart. An X-ray dye is then injected into the heart arteries and X-rays are taken of them. The accuracy of the ultrafast CT was determined by comparing its results to the results of angiograms taken on each of the patients, Breen reported. ``In every case in our study, if no calcium was detected on CT, there was no significant coronary disease seen on the angiogram,'' Breen said. Significant disease was defined as at least one coronary artery blocked by 50 percent or more. ``Ultrafast CT is exquisitely sensitive at detecting the presence of calcium in the arteries, a sign of atherosclerotic disease,'' Breen said. Atherosclerosis is a buildup of patchy deposits that can clog arteries and may eventually lead to heart attacks. ``Detecting calcium on ultrafast CT does not necessarily mean serious disease, but the more severe the calcification, the more likely it is that significant disease is present,'' he said. Dr. Daniel Mark, a cardiologist at Duke University Medical Center, said the test sounds promising but will require further study. ``It does not seem to me they've come out with something totally, radically new,'' he said, noting that calcium deposits in arteries have long been linked with heart disease. Also, many, if not most, heart patients are over 60, when calcium begins to appear in the arteries as a normal sign of aging, limiting the test's usefulness, he said in a telephone interview Monday from Durham, N.C. Because calcium is increasingly present as elderly people age, the researchers limited their study to people under 60, Breen said. He said ultrafast CT is non-invasive, painless and virtually risk-free. The procedure is expected to compete in cost with conventional heart-stress tests and to be performed in a few minutes, he said. However, he emphasized that his results were preliminary, and he said researchers should study more patients before the test's usefulness is established.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Decide on Mandatory Retirement Age for State Judges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to clarify that state judges are asking for same rights as other state employees, not federal judges.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will decide whether states may force judges to retire at age 70 if those states impose no such requirement on virtually all other employees in desk jobs. The high court voted to study arguments by two Missouri judges that their state's mandatory retirement age violates federal law and unconstitutionally treats them differently from other state employees. The justices, four of whom are over 70, are expected to announce their decision by July. The court's nine members, like all federal trial and appellate judges, are appointed for life. In another case, the court left intact a ban on poor and homeless people begging for money in New York City's subways. The justices, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the ban on ``begging and panhandling'' throughout the subway system violates free-speech rights. A federal judge had ruled that the ban was unconstitutional but a federal appeals court reinstated the ban by a 2-1 vote last May. In other matters Monday, the high court: -Refused to kill two fair-housing lawsuits that stem from newspaper real estate advertisements showing only white models posing as homeowners. Now, developers of a Virginia condominium community must defend themselves in a jury trial against allegations they violated a federal anti-bias law. -Revived a long legal battle from Maryland in which animal rights groups are seeking to save four monkeys used for medical research. The court said it will decide whether a lawsuit against a federal agency, already thrown out of federal court, should return to a state court. -Rejected the appeal of Richard B. Kelly, the former Florida congressman who served 13 months in prison for his 1981 bribery conviction in the FBI's Abscam undercover sting operation. -Agreed to decide in a Michigan case how far states can go to shield victims of sexual assaults from unfair treatment without violating defendants' fair-trial rights. -Agreed to decide in a Wisconsin case whether divorced people awarded ownership of the family home may use federal bankruptcy law to avoid a divorce court's order to pay their ex-spouses one-half of the home's value. -Refused to kill an affirmative action program in Hillsborough County, Fla., aimed at awarding more public works contracts to business run by minorities and women. A lawsuit filed by white men who say they are victims of reverse discrimination is pending before a federal judge. -Refused to revive a New York parental rights law that barred many men from challenging the adoptions of their illegitimate children. The court's eventual decision in the Missouri dispute over a mandatory retirement age for judges likely will affect many states with similar laws. If the justices reach the constitutional issue - whether such a law violates equal-protection guarantees - both appointed and elected state judges will be affected. If limited to a federal law banning age bias, the ruling would affect only appointed state judges because the federal law does not apply to elected officials. The St. Louis-based 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last March that Missouri's judges fall into the anti-bias law's exception for ``appointees on the policymaking level.'' The appeals court also ruled that the state's mandatory retirement age is constitutional because it is a rational way to insure a vigorous and healthy judiciary and to increase opportunities for younger people to serve as judges. The 8th Circuit court's ruling appears to conflict with a decision announced two months later by the New York-based 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that allowed a 71-year-old state judge from Vermont to remain on the bench. The 2nd Circuit court ruled that appointed state judges are not ``appointees on the policymaking level'' and therefore are protected by the federal anti-bias law. Lawyers for Missouri judges Ellis Gregory Jr. and Anthony Nugent Jr. urged the justices to resolve the conflicting rulings. The Supreme Court has never ruled on the issue, but in 1988 left intact New York's policy of forcing elected judges to retire at age 70 even though no such mandatory retirement is imposed on appointed judges in the state. The court's four oldest justices are Thurgood Marshall, 82; Harry A. Blackmun, 82; Byron R. White, 73, and John Paul Stevens, 70.

DOC.HEAD: Range Fires Smoldering, But Officials Warn Of Dangerous Conditions Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Snow smothered two large Montana range and timber fires, but authorities warned Monday that the warm, dry, windy weather that nurtured the blazes could return by midweek. ``The potential for this thing to blow back up is really not much affected by this snow,'' said Dave Turner, a Forest Service information officer. He said it would take ``a lot more snow and lot more moisture'' to snuff Montana's unusually late fire season. In Colorado, firefighters took advantage of a break in high winds that reached up to 70 mph over the weekend to build a fire line Sunday around the Olde Stage Road fire that swept across 2,200 acres in the rugged foothills northwest of Boulder. Officials said they expected to control the blaze Monday. Boulder County sheriff's deputies arrested a man Saturday who was accused of starting the fire by dragging a burning mattress from his home. The two Montana fires, fanned by hurricane-force winds, charred more than 40,000 acres of central Montana over the weekend, killing cattle and sheep and destroying houses and ranch buildings. No one was injured. The Turkey Fire burned across 32,000 acres near the ranching-farming communities of Stanford and Hobson, southeast of Great Falls, and continued burning in some timbered areas Monday. Officials said some 433 firefighters and support personnel were called in. The second, 10,000-acre blaze reached within a quarter-mile of the tiny community of Bohemian Corners north of Lewistown, officials said. It was extinguished early Monday. The Bohemian Corners fire was blamed for the loss of buildings on two ranches. Losses in the Turkey Fire included 175 cattle, 50 sheep, stacks of hay, miles of fence, two houses and 13 other outbuildings.

DOC.HEAD: Three Americans Kidnapped in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped three American and two Colombian engineers at an oil field in northeastern Colombia over the weekend, the state-run oil company Ecopetrol said Monday. The Americans were working on a pilot project for a new way of extracting oil, an executive at a private oil company said on condition of anonymity. Al Smith, personnel director at NATCO, a Tulsa, Okla.-based company, said the three Americans were employees of NATCO and that two of them come from Tulsa and one from Bakersfield, Calif. ``As we understand it, it was a non-violent taking of these gentlemen from the site where they were working,'' Smith said, adding that there had been no demands for the men's release. He declined to release their names, but Ecopetrol spokesman William Giraldo identified them as as Robert Hogan, Larry Sands and John Bagbey. He said he could not confirm the spellings of their names. More than 1,000 people have been kidnapped in Colombia so far this year, officials say. Most of the blame falls on leftist guerrillas, drug traffickers and common criminals looking for ransom money. Two men and a woman belonging to the pro-Cuban National Liberation Army abducted the American and Colombian engineers Sunday afternoon near the town of Tibu, in North Santander province, Giraldo said in a telephone interview. The rebels subsequently released one of the Colombians, who delivered the news of the abductions, Giraldo said. The Colombian engineer who was not released, Ignacio Alonso, was taken by the guerrillas to act as a translator, Giraldo said. The National Liberation Army, known by its Spanish acronym ELN, has been attacking Colombia's oil infrastructure for years. Since 1986, the group has bombed the country's main oil pipeline scores of times, causing an estimated $700 million in losses. The ELN is trying to pressure the government to reduce the presence of U.S. and other foreign oil companies in Colombia. The Medellin cocaine cartel, meanwhile, on Monday freed one of nine journalists it has kidnapped. The cartel recently offered to surrender to Colombian authorities in exchange for deals with prosecutors. Drug traffickers released magazine editor Juan Vitta because of a heart problem that required medical attention, former Medellin Mayor Juan Gomez said in a live radio interview. Gomez said he talked briefly with Vitta after Vitta was freed in the northwestern city of Medelin.

DOC.HEAD: United States Presses Resolution To Authorize Military Strike
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States consulted with other Security Council members Monday about a proposal authorizing military force to liberate Kuwait. It sets a Jan. 1 deadline for Iraqi withdrawal. The resolution would mark the second time in U.N. history that the Security Council has authorized the use of force to counter aggression. The first time was in 1950 in the Korean conflict. Kuwait, meanwhile, was preparing a presentation - including a videotape - for the Security Council on Tuesday to describe Iraqi atrocities since the Aug. 2 invasion, including the murder of children and the looting of hospitals. The resolution would authorize ``member states cooperating with the government of Kuwait, unless Iraq on or before Jan. 1, 1991, fully implements the foregoing resolutions (calling for withdrawal), to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council resolutions passed in response to Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait, and to restore international peace and security,'' according to the proposed text. The text of the resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, says that despite all U.N. efforts ``Iraq refuses to comply with its obligation'' to implement U.N. resolutions demanding withdrawal from Kuwait ``in flagrant contempt of the council.'' It cites Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes the use of military force to counter aggression, if sanctions and other steps fail. Foreign diplomats sai they expect the proposal to be amended before the vote later this week, noting some member states are opposed to imposing a deadline for the withdrawal of Saddam Hussein's troops from Kuwait. U.S. officials said Sunday the United States favors a Jan. 1 deadline but could be flexible about a later date to ensure broader support. Other Western diplomatic sources said a later deadline might be imposed to allow more time for negotiations. Judith Kipper, an associate at the Brookings Institute, a Washington research group, said it would be a mistake for the Bush administration to try to set a deadline. ``To put a date is to put his (Saddam's) back to the wall and make things impossible,'' said Ms. Kipper, who just returned from Baghdad where she met with the Iraqi president. ``If we go public,'' she said, ``it's a guarantee that we'll have to go to war.'' The United States has the nine votes it needs to ensure passage by the 15-member body, and the vote is likely to be held Thursday or Friday. Opposition by any one permanent Security Council member - the United States, Britain, China, France, or the Soviet Union - could block the resolution, but a veto is considered unlikely. On Monday the United States consulted with the other four permanent council members in an attempt to agree on final wording of the resolution. Informal talks also were held with the other council members. The United States is president of the council for the month of November and U.S. officials want to secure a resolution on the use of force before turning the presidency over to Yemen, which has favored Iraq in the past. Council presidents have the power to bring issues forward for votes or to suppress debate. Beside the five permanent members, the current Security Council members are Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: War Criminal Klaus Barbie Allegedly Stricken with Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Convicted Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie has cancer and needs special treatment from a French specialist, his lawyer said Monday. Deputy Justice Minister Georges Kiejman said the request by lawyer Jacques Verges amounted to an ``appalling media operation'' - a public relations ploy - and was unlikely to lead to Barbie's early release from prison. Barbie, 77, was convicted of crimes against humanity in July 1987 and sentenced to life in jail following a lengthy trial in Lyon, where he had served as Gestapo chief during the World War II Nazi occupation. ``A sentence of life in prison is not a death sentence for lack of care,'' said Verges, who defended Barbie in his trial. Verges said Barbie had suffered from cancer of the blood the past three months, but did not specify whether it was leukemia. Verges said Barbie, serving his sentence in Lyon's St. Paul Prison, had been undergoing chemotherapy treatment the past month. Verges asked that top cancer specialist Leon Schwartzenberg examine Barbie. Members of Schwartzenberg's family died in Nazi concentration camps. The Justice Ministry said Verges had been sent a response ``of a medical nature'' to his request that Barbie be examined by Schwartzenberg. The ministry said the choice of doctor was up to his treating physicians. ``I totally disagree with the principle of this operation,'' Kiejman said of Verges' effort to get Schwartzenberg to examine his client. Kiejman said it was unlikely Barbie could now benefit from an early release because of the reported illness. ``Medical pardons are always distributed with great parsimony,'' he told reporters. ``The only thing admitted is to put the dying in contact with his family. According to the information I now have, I don't believe we are in such a situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Chairs Hearings on U.S. Role in Post-Cold War World
DOC.TEXT: U.S. foreign relations have long been based on a state of ``permanent crisis,'' but with the end of the Cold War, the United States needs to reconsider its place in the world, Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan said Monday. ``We have very little preconceived thoughts,'' Moynihan, a New York Democrat, said as he opened the first of three hearings on the enr. ``We want to make a record and keep this issue before the Senate.'' Moynihan, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said that the U.S. government has been shaped by three factd of the Cold Waors: the emergence of the president as commander-in-chief; the secrecy system, in which much of what the executive branch does is unknown to Congress and the public; and the so-called permanent crisis, which began with the world wars and extended through the Cold War. Norman Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said he was dismayed that there has been no significant public debate on what role the United States should play in the post-Cold War world. ``The world and the American position in it is different now and we have to respond to that,'' he said. Geo-economics will have a greater influence than geopolitics in the future, and, as a result, we won't be choosing our alliese were 160 Italians in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. About 270 remain in Iraq, with 70 expected to be allowed to leave soon. There are six with dual nationality in Kuwait who do not want to leave.
JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion, and 231 are still in Iraq, more than 100 as human shields, and eight in Kuwait.
LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in pre-invasion Kuwait, about 5,000 have left. None of the aproximately 10,000 in Iraq have been reported leaving.

NETHERLANDS - There were 200 Dutch nationals in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, and 150 remain. More than 100 were working on dredging project in southern Iraq and Baghdad has said they are free to leave.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in more than two years. The Treasury Department sold $10.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.02 percent, down from 7.08 percent last week. Another $10.1 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.96 percent, down from 7.05 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 6.94 percent on Aug. 8, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 6.71 percent on July 5, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.24 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,822.60 and 7.31 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,648.10. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.29 percent last week, down from 7.30 percent the previous week.

DOC.TEXT: NEW ZEALAND - Nine New Zealanders remain in Iraq and Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36.
NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and 10 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of about 46.
PAKISTAN - About 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and about 90,000 remain.
PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq before the invasion. About 2,300 remain in Iraq, with an estimated 2,000 to 3,000 in Kuwait.

POLAND - There were 3,300 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now there are about 470 in Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling industrial project contracts, with 90 refused exit visas. Four remain in Kuwait voluntarily.
PORTUGAL - More than 40 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, mostly stonemasons who had worked on Saddam's new palace in Baghdad. About eight Poles remain in Iraq.
ROMANIA - There were 3,055 Romanians in Iraq before the invasion. About 640 remain.
SOUTH KOREA - About 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq, with 140 left in Iraq and nine in Kuwait.

SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. There are now around 2,900 in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and 206 military advisers. There are none in Kuwait.
SPAIN - There were 183 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Six diplomats remain in Baghdad.
SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq. About 65,000 remain in Kuwait, including 20,000 women. There are 125 Sri Lankans in Iraq.
SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total of about 200, 56 remain in Iraq with a few in Kuwait. The parliament voted Nov. 26 to allow them to leave, but Saddam must approve the measure.
SWITZERLAND - Before the invasion, there were 97 Swiss in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait and about eight are in Iraq.
THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and about 1,150 in Iraq before Aug. 2, with 874 still in Iraq and 20 in Kuwait.

TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait at the beginning of the gulf crisis. Almost all have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis.

UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of about 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, about 600 remain in hiding or are held in Kuwait, and around 330 are in Iraq, including 104 men held as human shields.
VENEZUELA - There were 38 Venezuelans in Kuwait and Iraq Aug. 2. Twenty-eight remain.
VIETNAM - There were an estimated 15,000 Vietnamese in Iraq before the invasion. Around 1,000 have left and the others are trying to get out. There are no figures available for Kuwait.
YUGOSLAVIA - There were about 9,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and about 1,000 in Kuwait Aug. 2. About 300 remain in Kuwait and about 1,000 in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Mick Jagger Marries Longtime Girlfriend Jerry Hall in Bali
DOC.TEXT: Mick Jagger has married his longtime girlfriend, Texas model Jerry Hall, on the Indonesian island of Bali, the press agent of the Rolling Stones singer said Monday. The wedding took place last Wednesday, said a spokesman for the London public relations firm Laister Dickson. The couple are on vacation in the Far East, he said. Few details of the ceremony were available, except that it was a traditional Indonesian wedding, and the couple's two children, Elizabeth, 6, and James, 5, attended, the spokesman said. ``Even we didn't hear about it until today, so they have clearly managed to keep the wedding very secret,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Alan Dunn, Jagger's longstanding friend and the Rolling Stones' tour director, was the best man, the spokesman added. British-born Jagger was divorced from first wife, Bianca, in 1979. They have one daughter, Jade, 19. Miss Hall has not been married before. The couple have been together for more than 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Political Newcomer Suddenly in Spotlight
With AM-Poland, Bjt
LaserPhoto WAR51
DOC.TEXT: Stanislaw Tyminski found out Monday that becoming a real contender for Poland's presidency had one immediate result: chaos. Journalists packed his press center, clamoring for specifics about his economic program. Bodyguards tried to keep order. A staffer painted her fingernails. His Peruvian wife, who speaks almost no Polish, was near tears. Tyminski, who left his homeland 21 years ago and returned only this fall, scored a stunning election upset on Sunday when placed second in balloting for the presidency. He will face Solidarity leader Lech Walesa in a runoff on Dec. 9. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki finished a humiliating third, behind Tyminski, and resigned Monday. Tyminski, a 42-year-old millionaire businessman, is an incongruous sight in economically strapped Poland, with his aviator glasses and fancy Italian suits. But the secret of his campaign success may have been his promises that the wealth will rub off. ``After this victory I will roll my sleeves up, go to work and make this country rich and prosperous. It will be better within a month,'' he boasted at a news conference. ``My candidacy is not a political candidacy, it is an economic one,'' he added in an interview. Tyminski - who holds Polish, Canadian and Peruvian citizenship - says he left Poland penniless, going first to Sweden as a tourist and then emigrating to Canada. He started a cable television outfit and a restaurant in the Amazon port of Iquitos, Peru, and then returned to Canada, where he runs Transduction Ltd., a computer automation firm near Toronto. He leads the Libertarian Party of Canada, a tiny party that has no representative in Parliament. For all his personal wealth, Tyminski is hard-pressed to outline his solution to Poland's economic woes. ``Capitalism will start when people have disposable income,'' he said, fidgeting. ``We must change the banking system, which is Stalinist. We need to have better division of the budgets, like the famous pie drawings.'' Tyminski raised eyebrows in Poland with his free-spending campaign, which he financed himself. Asked how much he spent, he said he did not know. ``We have two boxes packed with receipts,'' he said, adding that his wife, Graciela Perez, handled the campaign finances. On Monday, Mrs. Tyminski appeared distressed and distracted, frequently blinking her eyes. She did not leave her husband's side. Asked what she thought of the campaign, Mrs. Tyminski said in English: ``It's interesting.'' The couple have three children, and Tyminski also has a son by a first marriage. In the course of the campaign, Tyminski became the subject of a state prosecutor's slander investigation after accusing Prime Minister Mazowiecki of treason for his economic policies. Tyminski assailed what he said were unfair press reports about him during the campaign. He denied he was refused service into the army as a youth because of mental illness, and dismissed reports he traveled to Libya in the 1980s. The candidate also denied that he has called for the development of nuclear weapons for Poland. ``I do not want the atom bomb in Poland,'' he said, adding cryptically: ``But it saved my mother's life.'' He was apparently referring to radiation treatments his mother received for cancer. He expressed confidence about facing the popular Walesa. ``I will win these elections,'' he said. ``I am not afraid of Walesa, I am not afraid of anyone.'' He said he looked forward to the next phase of the campaign, but added that he wanted to concentrate on ``the country's future and not my past.''

DOC.HEAD: Educators Support National Math Standards
DOC.TEXT: A federal advisory panel won qualified support Monday for setting mathematical standards for students in specific grades but was urged to measure achievement in ways that avoid ``invidious comparisons.'' The National Assessment Governing Board heard testimony from educators representing both public and private schools on its plan to define what students in grades four, eight and 12 must know in math to obtain one of three levels - basic, proficient and advanced - when tested by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, NAEP. Mandated by Congress, NAEP is the only nationally representative and continuing assessment of what American students know and can do in various academic subjects. The 24-member board sets policy for NAEP, popularly called the Nation's Report Card. Normally NAEP tests simply describe how students perform without judgement. If the proposed standards are approved, results of the 1990 NAEP test will be the first to measure students' actual performance against established achievement standards. Frank Betts of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development said the public must be cautioned against inappropriate use of NAEP test results, which are based on sampling. ``Such comparisons, or rank ordering based on these data, are at best misleading and at worst positively dangerous from the statistical viewpoint,'' he said. Betts added, ``I believe there is a very real potential for further harm in reporting three levels of achievement. My fear is that the inappropriate use of ... data will lead to invidious comparisons.'' The 1990 math exam, to be released next year, is the first NAEP assessment to provide state-level data on a voluntary basis in eighth grade only. Each of 37 states in the trial state program will have the option of using achievement levels to report results in addition to the previous scoring system. Mary Johnson of the District of Columbia Public Schools questioned the use of the terms ``basic, proficient and advanced'' in describing the achievement levels. If renamed proficiency levels one, two and three, Johnson said, students might feel more positive about their achievements at each level. Roy Truby, executive director of the board, acknowledged that the ``board struggled with the notion that the three levels'' were, in essence, tracking. Tracking is a controversial process in which students are grouped based on academic performance. He added, however, that ``the proficient level is the level we hope all students will achieve.'' Joyce McCray of the Council for American Private Education noted a concern ``about the relationship between test content and curriculum,'' but said the concept of three levels ``allows flexibility and we all agree that appropriate achievement goals are probably more easily defined in mathematics than in other areas of the curriculum.'' According to the board's resolution, ``proficient'' level for each grade represents ``solid academic performance,'' while the ``basic'' level denotes ``partial mastery of fundamental knowledge and skills. The ``advanced'' level signifies ``superior performance,'' such as that needed at 12th grade to ``show readiness for rigorous college courses.''
