DOC.HEAD: British Military Leaders Predict Swift Defeat of Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The two top British commanders in the Persian Gulf on Monday predicted allied forces would defeat demoralized Iraqi forces in ``days or weeks'' if war breaks out. Lt. Gen. Sir Peter de la Billiere and Air Chief Marshal Sir Patrick Hine said the allies already have air and naval superiority and will be able to match Iraq's ground forces once reinforcements arrive. ``I think it will be a swift war ... days or weeks,'' de la Billiere, the commander of British forces in the gulf, told a news conference here. ``By removing the imbalance in ground forces ... we can win this operation if it comes to it in the days and weeks that Gen. de la Billiere has referred to,'' added Hine, the British-based joint commander of the force. The commanders provided the first insight into allied thinking since President Bush announced this month he was sending 200,000 more U.S. troops. De la Billiere said he meets daily with the U.S. commander, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf. The fresh U.S. soldiers and 14,000 British reinforcements now heading to the gulf will bring the multinational troop strength to more than 500,000 by mid-January. Iraq currently has about 430,000 troops in and around Kuwait, plus 250,000 reinforcements Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said he was dispatching. De la Billiere said Saddam will be taking ``a very severe risk'' by weakening his other borders to deploy more troops to Kuwait. ``If he were to take that risk and redeploy that number, then I believe we will still have the forces in theater to fight a decisive battle and bring it to a fairly speedy conclusion,'' the general said. Iraq has sizable troop deployments along its borders with Turkey, a NATO member, and with Iran, its foe during an eight-year war that ended 1988. The British commanders said the allies hope to minimize casualties by ``softening-up'' Iraqi ground forces with air and artillery strikes before sending troops and tanks across the border into Kuwait. ``I'm confident the softening-up process will be effective and will enable any offensive operations, if we're asked to do them ... to be conducted with a degree of initiative on our side and assurance that we are not battering our head against a castle wall,'' said De la Billiere. Some Iraqi defenses ``will certainly need tackling and dealing with,'' he said, but barriers such as tank trenches filled with gasoline aren't ``the sort of stuff that you stop armies with.'' Hine said he hoped an operation could be done not to endanger Western hostages, including some being kept as human shields at strategic sites. But he added, ``It's not a driving consideration.'' ``I think they will look after these hostages well with an eye to events after a war is all over,'' he said. The British commanders said they didn't want to underestimate the fighting capability of the Iraqi army, especially its regular forces, or the quality of some of its equipment. But de la Billiere said he wondered whether the Kuwaiti occupation hadn't severely blunted the motivation of the Iraqi troops because it has ``brought them nothing but deprivation at home and distaste and dislike by the rest of the world.'' ``I think many of them will feel they are fighting for a lost cause - indeed they are,'' the general said. Hine said Saddam seems to be making policy week-by-week, in response to reactions from various countries, with the aim of dividing the allies and delaying any military action. ``When he can see that military action against him is perhaps inevitable, then we may see some movement in terms of withdrawal or partial withdrawal or something of that nature. At the moment, it seems there's been no real force put on him ... to withdraw now,'' he said. Hine said a U.N. resolution with a deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal might help focus Saddam's attention. At the United Nations on Monday, the U.S. consulted with other Security Council members about a proposal authorizing military force if Iraq has not withdrawn from Kuwait by Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Millie's Sales Top Ron's
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``Millie's Book,'' to note Millie's publisher, Morrow
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan's autobiography is a best-seller, but sales of the former president's memoir are lagging those of ``Millie's Book,'' the dog's-eye-view of life inside the Bush White House. ``Millie's Book,'' ghostwritten by Barbara Bush, was No. 3 on this week's New York Times non-fiction best-seller list, five notches ahead of the weightier Reagan book. The light-hearted canine narrative held down the No. 5 spot on the Washington Post's best-seller list, while the former president's 748-page memoir came in at No. 7. ``Millie's Book'' was brought out in September by William Morrow & Co. and has been perched on the best-seller charts for nine weeks. ``An American Life'' by Reagan was published just three weeks ago. ``It's a bit of an unfair comparison,'' Jack McKeown, publisher of Simon & Schuster's trade division, said Monday. ``We certainly don't begrudge any success to `Millie's Book,' but they are appealing to quite difference audiences.'' Simon & Schuster is the publisher of the $24.95 Reagan autobiography. ``Millie's Book'' lionizes the president's English springer spaniel, wrapping a droll narrative of White House life and lore around scores of full-color pictures of Millie in the Oval Office, Millie in the Lincoln Bedroom and Millie mingling with celebrities, George, Barbara and assorted grandchildren. All the royalties from the $17.95 book are going to Barbara Bush's literacy foundation. Mrs. Bush penned a similar book about an earlier pet dog, C. Fred Bush, to raise money for charity when her husband was vice president. Sales of the Reagan book are accelerating at the major book chains and ``all the vital signs'' point to big sales of ``An American Life'' as a Christmas gift book, said McKeown. But ``Millie's Book'' is winning the race at the bookstore nearest the White House, a Crown Books outlet on G Street, one block away. ``Millie's the hottest item in the store,'' said assistant manager Larry Hoffer. ``It's out the door. People come in and buy 10, 15 each - and then come back and buy more. It's a really cute gift idea.'' Some of the mega-purchases are by people with White House connections who can get the books ``signed'' by the first lady and Millie, via a paw-print stamp. The Reagan book, which has received lackluster reviews, is selling well at Crown, ``but not as fast as Nancy Reagan did,'' said Hoffer. The former first lady hit the best-seller lists last year by lashing back at critics and ungrateful children in her life story, ``My Turn.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Sanctions Will Need Time to Work, Kuwaiti Minister Says
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.N. sanctions against Iraq will take a long time to work because the country's centralized economy allows Saddam Hussein to shift needed resources easily, Kuwait's finance minister said Monday. Sheik Ali Khalifa Al-Sabah also said Saddam has no compunction about putting the needs of his military before those of the general population. ``In a centralized economy, you can shift resources,'' Al-Sabah said in a speech at the National Press Club. As a result, the sanctions will succeed only ``over a very long period.'' Sanctions virtually cutting off Iraq from the rest of the world were imposed after Saddam invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Al-Sabah said the sanctions are also hurting Iraq neighbors - countries that traded heavily with Baghdad in the past such as Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, he said. Moreover, the world's less-developed economies are suffering because the gulf crisis has produced an increase in the price of oil, he said. ``The rest of the world is also suffering from sanctions,'' he said. Al-Sabah's pessimism about the effectiveness of the U.N.-imposed sanctions came as the United States prepared to ask the U.N. Security Council to adopt a resolution that would authorize the use of force against Iraq if necessary. U.S. officials have said a draft resolution sets a Jan. 1 deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait. The council's five permanent members, who have veto power, are discussing the measure in New York. A vote could come Thursday after debate this week. Al-Sabah said Kuwaiti officials are planning to recount to the Security Council some of the atrocities that are occurring in their country. Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait have shot and killed young men in front of their families and raped the women, he said. The troops have pilfered the country of medical and factory equipment and stolen goods of every kind, including food, he added. Visitors to Baghdad have reported that stores in that city are filled with canned goods from Kuwait, one of the reasons that sanctions have yet to bite hard on the Iraqi people. So far, Iraq has shown little willingness to heed the U.N. or Arab League resolutions that have called on Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. ``That leaves very little choice,'' he said. Al-Sabah's pessimistic remarks about sanctions underscored those make Sunday by Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

DOC.HEAD: US, Cuba Consult on Persian Gulf in Rare High-Level Meeting
With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. concern over the Persian Gulf crisis has produced the highest-level meeting between the United States and Cuba since the two countries opened diplomatic offices in each other's capitals 13 years ago, U.S. and Cuban officials said Monday. Under Secretary of State Robert Kimmitt, the third-ranking official at the State Department, met Sunday with the chief of Cuba's diplomatic mission here, Jose Arbesu. Previously, the most senior U.S. official to meet with Cuba's chief diplomat here has been the assistant secretary for Latin American affairs. A spokesman at the Cuban mission said the Sunday meeting was limited to a discussion of the consultations on the gulf at the U.N. Security Council, of which Cuba occupies one of the 10 non-permanent seats. A U.S. official said Kimmitt extended an invitation to Cuba to attend a Security Council meeting on the gulf set for Thursday. The United States has been pushing hard for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Cuba has expressed support for the restoration of Kuwaiti sovereignty but also has called for efforts to find a peaceful solution. The United States and Cuba consult periodically on immigration and other issues but the Bush administration has ruled out the possibility of normalizing relations with the island, accusing Cuba of human rights abuses. The two nations broke off full diplomatic relations 30 years ago this coming January.

DOC.HEAD: American University President Wants to Remain on Faculty
DOC.TEXT: Former American University president Richard Berendzen, who resigned after being charged with making obscene telephone calls, said Monday he wants to remain on the faculty. Berendzen said Monday the controversy over a reported $1 million buyout of his contract as president and as a tenured professor of physics has caused him ``great anguish.'' ``I am seeing the fabric of this family torn by rumor and innuendo,'' Berendzen said in a statement issued through his attorney. ``I have initiated steps that I hope will bring harmony to the university I love so dearly.'' He pleaded guilty in May to two charges of making obscene phone calls in Fairfax County, Va., and received two 30-day jail sentences, which were suspended on the condition that he remain in psychiatric treatment. Berendzen said he was hopeful the board of trustees will approve his return to teaching ``after an appropriate period of leave.'' Last week, acting president Milton Greenberg asked the trustees to rescind the buyout offer. He cited ``serious rifts'' which the arrangement had caused between the trustees and the rest of the university.

DOC.HEAD: Lord Home, Former British Prime Minister, Suffers Stroke
DOC.TEXT: Lord Home of the Hirsel, who as Sir Alec Douglas Home was Britain's prime minister in 1963-64, was in satisfactory condition Monday in a hospital after suffering a stroke, his family said. Lord Home, 87, was taken to the Sarum private hospital in Winchester, 66 miles southwest of London, on Monday. His nephew, Mark Douglas-Home said the statesman suffered a ``small stroke'' over the weekend. Last week, a memorial service was held in Westminster Abbey for Lord Home's wife, Lady Elizabeth Home.

DOC.HEAD: Court Backs Chiropractors
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday left intact rulings aimed at prohibiting the American Medical Association from boycotting chiropractors. The justices, without comment, rejected arguments by the AMA that its tactics did not violate federal antitrust laws. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals based in Chicago last February upheld a federal judge's order aimed at making it clear that AMA members may associate professionally with chiropractors without violating AMA ethical standards The case stems from a complaint filed by four licensed chiropractors against the AMA in 1976. The chiropractors accused the AMA of trying to drive them out of business by branding them as quacks. Over the years, the AMA has settled other antitrust suits brought by chiropractors and recently adopted a resolution that it is ethical for members to associate professionally with chiropractors. But a judge in the case of the four who sued in 1976 ordered the AMA to take steps to eliminate ``lingering effects'' from the AMA's boycott. The judge said the AMA must make its members aware they are free to associate with chiropractors. The 7th Circuit court upheld the judge's ruling that the AMA failed to prove it was acting in the interest of patients when it conducted the boycott. The case is AMA vs. Wilk, 90-542.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Testifies Police Beat, Threatened, Deceived Him
DOC.TEXT: A defendant in the Central Park jogger trial testified Monday that police hit, coached and deceived him to make him confess to attacking a female runner who was gang-raped and almost beaten to death. Kharey Wise, 18, also said detectives took him to a blood-covered spot in the northern end of Central Park and told him to dip his fingers into the woman's congealed blood and smear it on his clothing. Defense lawyer Colin Moore said he called Wise as a witness to try to convince the jury that police and prosecutors used ``Hitlerian tactics'' to make his client incriminate himself. Wise testified that Detective Robert Nugent slapped him and called him a liar after the teen told of his whereabouts the night of April 19, 1989. Wise said he had told police he left the park with another teen-ager and had not attacked anyone. He said he gave police an incriminating statement after Detective John Hartigan told him to lie to Nugent. ``Tell him that you were there. Put yourself in it,'' the defendant quoted Hartigan as saying. ``I said, `If I tell him a lie, can I go home?' He promised me I could.'' Wise said he told Nugent he had seen the attack on the woman. ``Then I asked him, `Can I go home now?''' ``He looked at me and laughed,'' Wise said. ``He said, `You're going straight to jail.''' In the second of two videotaped statements that have been played in court, Wise implicated himself and others. He told police, ``This was my first rape, and it will be my last.'' Wise and co-defendant Kevin Richardson, 16, are the second set of teens to be tried on charges of rape, attempted murder, sodomy, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the female jogger and two men. Thee others were convicted Aug. 18. All were sentenced to five to 10 years in prison. Another youth will be tried early next year. The 30-year-old jogger, who testified at the trial, has recovered from most of her injuries and has returned to work as an investment banker. She said she still suffers vision and balance problems and cannot smell.

DOC.HEAD: High Wind Batters Utah; Floods in The West
DOC.TEXT: High winds whipped parts of Utah early Monday, causing power outages in three communities, while snow blanketed mountains and valleys. Snapped power lines darkened Snyderville, Summit Park and Kamas, all east of Salt Lake City, for up to five hours late Sunday and early Monday. The wind led off a fast-moving storm that brought snow and colder temperatures to much of Utah. By noon Monday, the storm dropped up to 2 inches on the valley floors, with at least 6 inches in the mountains. High winds also blasted Arizona and California with gusts to 63 mph during the late morning at Show Low, Ariz., and 67 mph at Daggett, Calif. Flood warnings remained in effect over the St. Joe and Coeur D'Alene Rivers in northern Idaho, where several bridges and roads were under water from previous flooding. Flood warnings also remained in effect for the Snoqualmie, Snohomish, Skagit, Chehalis, Cowlitz, Cedar and White Rivers in western Washington. At midday, rain extended over south central Arizona changing to snow from central Arizona across northern Arizona, the mountains of Utah, southeast Idaho, Wyoming, southeast Montana and northwestern North Dakota, and over northwest Montana. Freezing rain fell over parts of Minnesota reaching into South Dakota, changing to rain across southeastern South Dakota and moving northeast to southern Wisconsin and northern Illinois. Rain was scattered over central Indiana and central Alabama. Showers and thunderstorms fell over Oklahoma and northern Texas. Monday morning's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 11 degrees below zero at Cutbank, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 1 below zero at Cutbank, Mont., to 88 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Finding Hitler's Art: One Woman Tries Classifieds
DOC.TEXT: Here's an advertisement that practically jumps off the page: ``Want to purchase any art work by artist Adolf Hitler.'' Hitler's name is in bold type, as if it needed to be. Betsy Gainey, a Wrightsville Beach real estate broker, placed that ad in last Friday's Wall Street Journal as part of her international search for Hitler's art. The German dictator was struggling to make it as an artist when he began his political career. Ms. Gainey, who said she's working for an investor who doesn't want to be identified, said she's already had ``quite a few'' calls to her toll-free line - most of them from the curious. ``Very honestly, bluntly put, they're very nosy,'' she said. ``I have had a couple people say they think they may know where some is. Whether or not they can deliver, I don't know.'' Ms. Gainey, who said she often takes such assignments, said her investor wanted Hitler paintings for their artistic value. ``It's just someone who has the money who wants to invest for the art value itself, not for the philosphy or whatever,'' said Ms. Gainey, who professes no particular expertise in art. But Billy F. Price, a Texas compressor manufacturer who has made an avocation of identifying Hitler artworks, says: ``Buyer beware.'' He said it's not too difficult to find watercolor landscapes being sold as the late German dictator's creations. The problem is detecting the real from the fake. ``It will be very, very unwise for a person to buy a (Hitler) painting who doesn't check with some authorities,'' he said in a telephone interview. Price published his own book in 1984, ``Adolf Hitler: The Unknown Artist,'' in which he cataloged authentic and fake Hitler paintings. Price says he often sees advertisements placed by people seeking to buy or sell Hitler art and that many of them contact him. ``I got a fax the other day from Venezuela. This man wanted $3 million for a Hitler painting and said he would wait 48 hours before he sold it to the Japanese,'' Price said. Price doesn't give such offers much credence.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Won't Testify at Congressional Hearings Until After UN Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 5 grafs, Powell to testify Monday as well, picking up in 5th graf pvs, After a
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's top military officials - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell - will be conspicuous by their absence Tuesday when the Senate begins hearings on the buildup toward an ``offensive military option'' in the Persian Gulf. The hearings, scheduled after President Bush decided to send an additional 200,000 troops to the gulf, get under way with members of Congress pressing for closer collaboration on gulf policy. However, Cheney and Powell will delay their appearances before the Senate Armed Services Committee until next week, after U.N. action on a resolution authorizing military force against Iraq. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the panel, said Monday that Cheney is ``quite willing to testify before the committee and will do so on Monday.'' Powell also is scheduled to appear before the panel. After a meeting with the committee's chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., Warner said Cheney had delayed his testimony until next Monday ``to have a report from Secretary of State Baker on the U.N. resolution.'' Secretary James A. Baker III is in New York to press the United Nations Security Council to approve military force to free Kuwait if Iraq refuses to withdraw its troops. Baker is to testify on Wednesday of next week before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Meanwhile, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., asked that the House be called back from adjournment to discuss the U.N. resolution, lest war be raging by the time Congress returns as scheduled in January. Several congressional leaders, including Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, asked earlier this month for a special session, but that idea quickly died. And there was no indication of action on Schroeder's request. The absence of Cheney from this week's witness list - and the lack of any guarantee he would testify at all - had been portrayed as a part of struggle between Nunn, a possible 1992 Democratic challenger for Bush's job, and the White House. Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., a member of the committee, said in an interview that the hearings were ill-timed and the administration had every reason to wait before testifying. The timing, he said, ``is what you do when your purpose is more political than policy. Not partisan politics, national politics. The chairman is opening a presidential campaign,'' Wallop said referring to Nunn. Nunn invited Cheney and Powell to appear before the panel nearly two weeks ago to discuss the administration's policy since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The military leaders have had prominent roles in defending Bush's decision to send the additional troops to the gulf to provide a potential attack force. And many in Congress have said the administration has yet to justify such a strategic shift. With Baker, Cheney and Powell unavailable until next week, the witness list for this week's Armed Services sessions reads less like a high-level policy consultation than like the lineup for recent television talk shows. On Tuesday, former Defense Secretary and CIA Director James Schlesinger will testify during a morning session with a closed briefing by intelligence officials scheduled in the afternoon. Former Joint Chiefs of Staff chairmen William J. Crowe Jr., and David C. Jones will appear on Wednesday morning and former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger is scheduled to appear that afternoon. Thursday's hearing includes former Navy Secretary James Webb, former assistant Defense Secretary Richard Perle and Edward Luttwak of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Bush's announcement that he was greatly increasing the U.S. deployment in the Persian Gulf - and adding the offensive capability - touched off criticism by lawmakers, including Nunn who said the administration had failed to justify a policy shift from a defensive to offensive stance. Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee sent a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., urging him to call back the House to debate the U.N. resolution. Rep. Schroeder, who contended two weeks ago that it would be useless for Congress to return in a special session to debate a hypothetical action, said Monday a possible resolution makes a session necessary. ``All of a sudden the time has come,'' Schroeder said in a telephone interview. ``It would look awfully silly if we come back and this thing is raging.'' Congress included in its adjournment resolution in late October a provision giving the Democratic leadership, in consultation with the Republican minority, the authority to call Congress back in an emergency. Schroeder said she did not think Congress would oppose the U.N. resolution but ``we have to at least debate it.'' Meanwhile, a delegation of 19 House members left on Sunday for a weeklong visit to the Persian Gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Announces 45 Water Quality Projects
DOC.TEXT: Some additional projects to help improve water quality in farming areas were announced Monday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. The 45 projects in 34 states were designated for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. These are in addition to 45 projects begun last year under the administration's water quality initiative, he said. No funding level was announced. When last year's projects were announced, officials said the assistance provided farmers would be provided cooperatively by several agencies from existing programs. The new announcement said the five-year projects will be implemented under the leadership of the Agriculture Department's Soil Conservation Service, Cooperative Extension Service, and the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. ``Funding beyond fiscal 1991 will be contingent upon subsequent appropriations,'' the department said. The areas designated are: Alabama - Ryan-Crooked-Rock Creeks. Arizona - West Maricopa. Arkansas - Millwood Lake. Arkansas - Long Creek. California - Morro Bay. California - West Stanislaus. Colorado - Patterson Hollow. Colorado - San Luis Valley. Connecticut - Scantic River. Florida - Karst Cropland. Florida - Lake Apopka Drainage Basin. Georgia - Gum Creek. Georgia - Little River-Rooty Creek. Hawaii - Kaiaka-Waialua. Idaho - Snake-Payette Rivers. Idaho - Snake River Plain. Illinois - Little Vermilion River. Indiana - Upper Kankakee River. Iowa - Northeast Iowa River. Iowa - Three-Mile Creek. Iowa - Sny Magill Creek. Kansas - Webster Creek. Kentucky - Taylorsville Lake-Upper Salt River. Maryland - German Branch. Massachusetts - Wachusetts Reservoir. Michigan - Wolf Creek. Michigan - Saginaw Bay. Missouri - Upper Niangua. Nebraska - Central Blue Valley. New Hampshire - Upper Connecticut River. New Jersey - Great Swamp. New York - Wallkill-Rondout. Ohio - Darby Creek. Oklahoma - Peacheater Creek. Oregon - Tualatin River-Dairy-McKay. Pennsylvania - Pequea-Mill Creeks. South Carolina - Lake Bowen. South Dakota - Big Sioux Aquifer. South Dakota - Lower Rapid Creek. Tennessee - Beaver Creek. Texas - Seymour Aquifer. Texas - Lake Fork Creek. DOC.HEAD: With Moving Men and Flowers: The End Comes Swiftly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 2 grafs SUB for 4th graf `Mrs. Thatcher' to UPDATE with party for staff, Thatcher quote. Picks up 5th graf, `Her precedessor.. .'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moving men were hauling Margaret Thatcher's belongings out of 10 Downing St. on Monday and the Western world's longest-serving leader was shopping around for office space. Such is the banality and the swift brutality of the fall of a British leader. ``I think she will write her memoirs, but at the moment I think she could write the guide to fast house moving,'' Carol Thatcher, 37, said in a television interview after helping her mother pack over the weekend. On Monday night, Mrs. Thatcher gave a party for the 200 staff at Downing Street, ranging from cleaning people to her topmost advisers, and declared, ``Life begins at 65 and I shall be working for the future.'' The party was possible because Mrs. Thatcher has longer than most to vacate 10 Downing St. - the six to eight days it takes to elect a new leader of the governing Conservative Party following her decision last Thursday to step down. Her predecessor, James Callaghan of the Labor Party, had to get out with less than a day's notice after Mrs. Thatcher led the Conservatives to victory in a May 3, 1979, election. Within hours of the result being declared early on May 4, the moving men arrived and Callaghan was gone shortly after midday. Then Mrs. Thatcher moved in. The furniture, the silver plate, the chandeliers, the oil paintings and most else at No. 10, a 17th century row house near the Houses of Parliament, belong to the nation. But after 11{ years, the occupant gathers things besides clothes. In Mrs. Thatcher's case they include boxes of personal documents that may form the basis of a publisher's dream: the Iron Lady's memoirs. There also are 1,000 bouquets of flowers sent by well-wishers all over the world following Mrs. Thatcher's ouster as leader by the Conservatives. Personal letters are coming in at more than 1,000 a day, aides say. Speculation about Mrs. Thatcher's future range from tongue-in-cheek suggestions that she run a European bank to becoming a countess and sitting in Britain's unelected and often somnolent upper house. Her memoirs will be hot property and offers abound for lecture tours. Aides say her priority is to find an office in central London from where she may operate some kind of foundation to promote the free-market political philosophy of Thatcherism. ``I don't think she has decided anything,'' a close aide said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Her preoccupation at the moment is to get moved out of here into Dulwich and to get an office.'' Michael Gerson, head of the moving firm Mrs. Thatcher and her husband, Denis, called in, estimates he can get most of it into one large truck for the seven-mile journey to Dulwich, a southeast suburban district. The Thatchers bought a double-storey house there in 1985 for about 400,000 pounds, now the equivalent of $800,000. Mrs. Thatcher, whose political tenets include home ownership, said it was a hedge against the then-rapidly rising house prices in southeastern England. Neighbors are ducking reporters and police are patroling the suburban road. The security will remain a part of life for the new resident, a permanent target of the Irish Republican Army. The Thatcher offices will be under guard, too. For now, her only office is one of the cramped rooms, sometimes shared, allotted to a rank-and-file member of Parliament. It is not a role likely to suit her for long. ``She won't do a Heath and stay there in sullen discontent,'' said a Thatcher aide, referring to Edward Heath, now an ordinary MP, whom Mrs. Thatcher ousted as party leader in 1975. Last week, the same party election rules that Mrs. Thatcher turned against Heath brought her own career to an end. If Tuesday's vote is inconclusive among the three contenders for the leadership, there will be a final ballot on Thursday. Mrs. Thatcher will move out the day after the winner is declared. Meanwhile, it's farewell parties, flowers and some business as usual. When President Bush telephoned Saturday to report on his visit to the Persian Gulf, he caught Mrs. Thatcher sorting out the main sitting room, her daughter said. An aide hastened in, Miss Thatcher added, saying, ``Drop that packing case, prime minister, the White House is on the telephone.''

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Farmer Named to Head Soil Conservation Service
DOC.TEXT: William J. Richards, an Ohio farmer, was named Monday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter as head of the Soil Conservation Service. The post has been vacant since last summer with the resignation of Wilson Scaling. The agency has nearly 14,000 employees and has offices in all states, working with farmers to carry out soil and water conservation programs. Richards, a graduate of Ohio State University, was named as one of the nation's outstanding young farmers in 1967 by the U.S. Jaycees. Richards has a family farming operation in Circleville, Ohio, the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos: College Is Still Affordable
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos, upset by predictions that four years of college soon may cost several hundred thousand dollars, urged colleges and universities Monday to make ``tough choices'' to cut costs. Cavazos insisted that colleges still are affordable, although tuition increases during the 1980s averaged about 8 percent a year. Average tuition and fees for fall 1990 ranged from $884 at two-year public colleges to $9,391 at four-year private colleges. Escalating costs of higher education have some analysts predicting that ``four years of college early in the next century may cost several hundred thousand dollars,'' said Cavazos. Cavazos stressed that the predictions are based on ``misperceptions about both the true cost of college and the availability of student financial aid.'' Yet he released a handbook, entitled ``Tough Choices,'' to help colleges examine institutional goals and priorities and make decisions to control spending. ``If we are to keep higher education affordable, colleges and universities are going to have to make serious efforts to control costs,'' he told reporters. ``Each institution must identify its central mission and focus, and then allocate resources accordingly, with the understanding that no single institution can do everything well.'' For example, Cavazos said colleges should consider merging duplicative services or programs and possibly eliminating programs, including certain athletic or sports programs. Institutions also might consider coordinating services with nearby schools, he said. The handbook also advises school presidents to take the lead, think long-term, involve the entire institution and communicate well with all members of the institution's community. Cavazos also released a survey of college financial officials, who said they could control expenditures more easily than they could raise revenues. The college administrators cited as reasons for raising tuition increased academic expenditures, declining state contributions and the desire to improve the institution's quality. According to the survey, institutions usually control expenditures by delaying or modifying new construction, using more part-time faculty or freezing hiring, imposing budget cuts and cutting services.

DOC.HEAD: Poland's Election Bitter Lesson for Quarreling Solidarity Camps
AP News Analysis
With AM-Poland
DOC.TEXT: An outsider's surprise second-place showing in Poland's first popular presidential election has provided a lesson in humility for the two quarreling camps of Solidarity. Commentators conceded Monday they underestimated the depth of public unhappiness with Western-prescribed economic reforms begun during 15 months of non-Communist rule, and the credulity of a public, most of whom were voting in their first democratic election for president. Stanislaw Tyminski did not underestimate those factors. Now the emigre Toronto businessman, who spent 21 years in Canada and Peru and returned to his homeland only three months ago, is a step away from being president. While the two halves of Solidarity represented by Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki were trying to bury each other in an acrimonious battle for the presidency, a fresh-faced unknown from abroad slipped in and nearly stole the electorate. ``The dark horse took advantage of a fight in the family,'' said Dariusz Fikus, editor of the government paper Rzeczpospolita. ``It is a defeat both for Walesa and Mazowiecki.'' Walesa - founder of the East bloc's first independent trade union, Poland's only Nobel Peace laureate and creator of the first non-Communist government between the Elbe and the Pacific in 40 years - eked out 39.96 percent of Sunday's vote. Mazowiecki - who created a non-Communist government that began the dismantling of the hated former system and won Poland respect and praise abroad - drew only 18.08 percent. Tyminski won 23.10 percent based on his claim to be free of politics and to be a millionaire and therefore an expert in economic matters. Election returns showed he did best in rural areas and small towns, where the benefits of a freer economy have so far been negligible. Young people waiting for housing and miners worried about their jobs also rallied to him. Voters new to democracy seemed to trust him because he looked the part, with the sheen of a successful, self-made North American executive. In the countryside, people were surprised to learn from reporters that Tyminski is an unknown in his adopted country of Canada, or that his Libertarian Party has no one in the federal or provincial assemblies there. They distrusted last-minute criticisms of him in the press, saying it reminded them of Communist propaganda campaigns. Tyminski was willing to articulate the rage felt by that part of the population most immediately affected by the radical economic reform program generally endorsed by both Solidarity candidates. Commentator Piotr Pacewicz wrote in Monday's Gazeta Wyborcza that these people constituted a ``second Poland'' who found no place for themselves in the Poland run by Solidarity. ``Had it not been for Tyminski, they would probably have stayed home,'' he said. ``In Tyminski, this `second Poland' found a man who embodied their hostility to the Solidarity state, someone clean, coming from outside the alignment in which Communist memories are blending with the hardship of radical reform.'' Walesa told reporters after the election he had sensed a growing anger and feared it would be exploited by ``a third force.'' He said that's why he launched his campaign of ``acceleration'' so that this disaffected bloc would not become alienated from Solidarity forever. In its postmortems, the prime minister's camp was still pointing a finger at Walesa - blaming him for fanning the anger. ``The `war at the top' unleashed by Walesa has led to this,'' groused Mazowiecki's election committee Monday in a half-hearted recommendation to its supporters to oppose Tyminski. But in some ways, Mazowiecki was trapped in a vise between the demands of Poland's foreign creditors and the limited patience of his own people. Mazowiecki's tough economic reform policies were drafted last fall in close cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, which for years refused to unlock the door to desperately needed new foreign credits until Poland got its economic house in order. The plan mandated a wage cap and a government-induced recession that caused real wages to plummet 35 percent. Unemployment climbed from almost zero at the start of 1990 to over 1 million today. Tyminski pledged a fast turnaround in the economy and accused Mazowiecki of treasonous mismanagement of the economy - and wound up collecting 1 million more votes than the prime minister. The returns and Mazowiecki's resignation Monday night as prime minister may contain a cautionary lesson to the IMF and Western countries who want to see democracy succeed in Eastern Europe: There is only so much austerity the West can realistically expect the new democratic governments of Eastern Europe to impose, and still remain the government. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - John Daniszewski has been The Associated Press correspondent in Warsaw since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Leona Helmsley Donates $300,000 To Help Alzheimer's Victims
DOC.TEXT: Leona Helmsley, who has been trying to change the public's perception of her as the mean hotel queen, presented a $300,000 check Monday to the New York City chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. With the donation, the association is establishing the Helmsley Alzheimer's Alert Program, a regional network to locate, identify and return people with Alzheimer's who wander from home and become lost, according to Howard J. Rubenstein Associates Inc., the public relations concern that represents Mrs. Helmsley. Carolina Edwards, a Rubenstein spokeswoman, said Mrs. Helmsley became interested in efforts to find a cure for the disease through her lawyer, Alan Dershowitz, whose mother suffers from the progressive, irreversible disease characterized by degeneration of the brain cells. ``She hooked into it personally with the Dershowitz family and then Howard Rubenstein knew of her interest in Alzheimer's and matched her up with this program,'' she said. The alert program is immediately available for the estimated 225,000 Alzheimer's victims in the New York City area. The program will eventually expand to Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington D.C. Participants in the alert program will wear a bracelet and clothing emblem that will identify them by code and provide a tollfree hot line number that anyone who spots them can call to alert police. Mrs. Helmsley, 70, was convicted in August 1989 of billing personal expenses to the Helmsley business empire. She is free on bail pending her appeal.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Operator Asks Court To Allow Thrift Failure Suit Against Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix `hundreds' to `scores'; SUBS last graf to CORRECT number of lawsuits to 132.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration asked the Supreme Court on Monday to kill a Texas businessman's lawsuit that alleges government regulators caused the collapse of his healthy savings and loan. Assistant Attorney General Stuart M. Gerson said in oral arguments before the court that allowing the lawsuit to be heard could open the floodgates for scores of similar claims. In earlier written arguments, the government said that allowing the case to go forward could also restrict regulators' options ``at a time of urgent need for swift and flexible intervention.'' Thomas M. Gaubert of Dallas alleges in his suit that negligence by federal regulators who took over day-to-day operations of his savings and loan, Irving-based Independent American Savings Association, caused its financial ruin. The regulators forced Gaubert out of management in 1985 and replaced directors in 1986. State authorities closed the thrift in 1987. ``They (regulators) just came in and lied to us, misled us and for all practical purposes extorted us,'' Gaubert said following the hearing. ``We had no right to have any say in it.'' Gaubert, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser who persuaded former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Fort Worth, to intervene with federal regulators on his behalf, is seeking compensation for $25 million worth of real estate he lost when his S&L failed. ``We have not had our day in court,'' said Gaubert's attorney, Abbe David Lowell. When the case is heard, he claimed, ``the facts will show these people (regulators) took unbelievably negligent actions.'' The high court is expected to rule on the case by July. The government contends that regulators seeking to restore a thrift to safer and sounder management practices are immune from such claims. While the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that Gaubert can pursue is claim for $25 million, it did not let him continue his bid to collect from the government the $75 million lost value of his Independent American shares. Gerson told the court that the Justice Department has 132 cases stemming from the savings and loan crisis that seek damages from the government. But Lowell said only one is actually in the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Army Sets Call-Up Date For Combat Units; Marines Sending More Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops 3 grafs new to include Army announcement of additional reservists alerted for possible callup; CORRECTS in 2nd graf that combat units alerted Nov. 16 sted last week. Picks up 4th graf: ``Separately, the,''
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Gulf-Reserves-List
DOC.TEXT: The Army on Monday ordered 10,567 National Guard combat troops to report for active duty Friday in support of Operation Desert Shield, and it said dozens of other reserve units have been alerted for possible noncombat duty. The combat forces called up, which were alerted Nov. 16 that they would be activated, are the first units among the Army's reserve combat forces to be activated in the Persian Gulf crisis. More than 45,000 other Army citizen-soldiers put on active duty since August are in non-combat roles such as transportation or medical services. The Army said Monday it had alerted an unspecified number of National Guard and Army Reserve members from 30 states and Puerto Rico that they may be called up soon for non-combat duty in Desert Shield. Separately, the Marine Corps disclosed that it is sending to the gulf the 6th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, a regular unit of about 15,000 Marines based at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Three Marine expeditionary brigades already are in the gulf area and the Pentagon announced Nov. 8 that the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade of Camp Pendleton, Calif., was heading there. Maj. Nancy J. LaLuntas, a spokeswoman at Marine Corps headquarters, said the 6th Brigade would link up in Saui Arabia with a squadron of ships carrying equipment and 30 days of supplies from Norfolk, Va. The Army said the 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Georgia and the 256th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Louisiana were ordered to report for active duty Friday. Also reporting will be two smaller combat units, the 1st Battalion of the 263rd Armor from Mullins, S.C., and a battalion of the 152nd Armor from Oneonta, Ala. The Army gave no other details, but officials said last week that the Georgia brigade and the Mullins battalion would form an ``independent'' unit for possible deployment with the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized), a regular Army division from Fort Stewart, Ga., already is in Saudi Arabia. The Louisiana brigade and the Oneonta battalion are to bring to full strength the 5th Infantry Division (Mechanized) of Fort Polk, La., a regular Army division that the Pentagon last week said may be sent to Saudi Arabia. The announcement made no mention of the 155th Armored Brigade of Mississippi, a National Guard combat unit that the Army last week said would be ordered to active duty and be made part of the 4th Infantry Division (Mechanized) of Fort Carson, Colo., a regular division that has not yet been deployed to Saudi Arabia. About 130,000 Army troops already are deployed in Saudi Arabia as part of a 230,000-strong U.S. military force that President Bush has said may be used to try to liberate Kuwait. Additional U.S. forces of up to 200,000 are heading to the gulf. Bob Harper, spokesman for the Mississippi Army National Guard, said the 155th was told by the Defense Department last Friday to expect to be activated about Dec. 7. Harper speculated that the 155th was not activated at the same time as the two other Guard brigades because the Army's National Training Center at Fort Irwin, Calif., cannot handle all three brigades at the same time. The brigades are to undergo desert warfare training at Fort Irwin before the Pentagon decides whether they are proficient enough to be deployed to Saudi Arabia. The 141st Infantry Battalion of McAllen, Texas is expected to be activated with the 155th of Mississippi, although it was not included in Monday's announcement.

DOC.HEAD: Polluter Gets Five Years' Probation
DOC.TEXT: A woman known as the ``Dragon Lady'' of New York Harbor was sentenced to five years' probation Monday for fouling the harbor with sewage sludge. Evelyn Berman Frank had pleaded guilty in July to unlawful abandonment and release of the sludge - some of it toxic - in New York Harbor in 1987 and 1988. Superior Court Judge Anthony J. Iuliani ordered the 75-year-old Frank family matriarch to cut all ties with the web of family-owned sludge-hauling companies she has run for 25 years. Mrs. Frank could have been sentenced to up to 10 years in prison, but the judge said he declined to incarcerate her because of her age and medical problems. Iuliani also ordered Mrs. Frank to perform 500 hours of community service each year for the next five years, a total of 2,500 hours. One of the Frank companies, General Marine Transport Inc., presented a check to the state at the hearing for $500,000, half of a $1 million fine levied on it as part of the plea agreement. For decades Mrs. Frank has controlled a complicated marine empire of more than 45 interlocking concerns. Competitors and employees dubbed her the ``Dragon Lady'' for her sharp tongue and aggressive management style. She, in turn, christened one of her tugboats The Dragon Lady. The Frank family's environmental violations date back to at least 1970, but drew widespread attention only in September, after the decrepit Sarah Frank barge dumped more than 40,000 gallons of waste oil into the Kill Van Kull near Staten Island.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
Mick Jagger Marries Longtime Girlfriend Jerry Hall in Bali
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of Jagger-Hall relationship, quotes, CORRECTS Jade's age from 19 to 17. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mick Jagger has married his longtime girlfriend, Texas model Jerry Hall, on the Indonesian island of Bali, press agents for the Rolling Stones singer said Monday. The couple were married Wednesday in ``an Indonesian wedding ceremony,'' after a six-week vacation touring the Far East, said spokeswoman Lori Somes of the New York publicity firm Rogers and Cowan Inc. She said Jagger and Hall's two children, Elizabeth, 6, and James, 5, attended the wedding. The couple's best man was Alan Dunn, a friend of Jagger's who has been a Rolling Stones tour director. ``Even we didn't hear about it until today, so they have clearly managed to keep the wedding very secret,'' added a spokesman for the London public relations firm Laiser Dickson, speaking on condition of anonymity. British-born Jagger was divorced from first wife in 1979. Miss Hall has not been married before. It was not immediately clear whether Jagger and Hall were joined by Jagger's other two daughters, Jade, 17, from his marriage to former model Bianca Perez Morena de Macias of Nicaragua, and Karis, 18, by U.S. actress Marsha Hunt. Jagger, 47, and Hall, 34, have been together 12 years, sharing homes in New York, France and the remote Caribbean island of Mustique. There long has been speculation over their marriage plans. As long ago as 1983, Jagger announced they would be tying the knot ``any day now.'' But in February, Jagger laughed off questions about his intentions. ``My marital status will not be changing in the near-future,'' he said in an interview. Around the same time, Hall made her West End acting debut, playing a nightclub singer in a revival of ``Bus Stop,'' the part Marilyn Monroe made famous in the 1956 movie. Hall, who has been a successful model, was quoted in British newspaper reports at the time as saying: ``We have agreed (on marrying), only the time and the place have to be set.'' She was reported to have said that during the years they had put off marrying, she and Jagger had watched friends marry and divorce. ``We say, `OK, even though we didn't get married, we've lasted longer than most,''' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Collapses, Floodwaters Batter Washington State
LaserPhoto SE6
DOC.TEXT: The water went back where it came from Monday but hundreds of people stayed away from the homes they fled over the weekend after heavy rains caused the second ruinous floods in two weeks. One man was presumed dead in the deluge. A pontoon bridge linking Seattle and its eastern suburbs sank. Many residents had just managed to return home and start cleaning up earlier damage when the new rainstorms hit. At least 2,600 people were evacuated as 20 rain-swelled rivers spilled their banks, authorities said. Most of the flooding occurred west of the Cascade Mountains, which form the north-south spine of the state, inundating much of western Washington. Hardest hit were rural areas. More rain but in less quantity was forecast for Monday night and Tuesday. ``Except for the Chehalis River, the worst is over,'' said Dick Milne, spokesman for the state Division of Emergency Management. A flood surge was moving down that river toward Grays Harbor on the coast, and officials feared more evacuations downstream would be necessary. At least six rivers set records for high water. State officials, who already tallied more than $40 million in flood damage earlier this month, said that figure would soar. They had no new figures yet. A storm that dumped a record 3{ inches of rain on Seattle in two days was blamed for the collapse of the old Lake Washington floating bridge, which was being renovated into the new eastbound lanes for Interstate 90. About 2,100 feet of the four-lane, 8,600-foot-long bridge sank in 200 feet of water Sunday morning. Bridge debris severed some cables anchoring the new, seven-lane I-90 bridge, 60 feet north of the old structure. State engineers closed the year-old bridge and said it would be reopened only after temporary replacement cables are installed. The bridge is a chief artery linking Seattle to populous suburbs to the east, handling 110,000 vehicles a day. On Monday, drivers accustomed to a 12-mile commute between Bellevue and Seattle were forced to endure a clogged, 30-mile detour. King County police said Scot Alan Scott, 28, of Duvall, was missing and presumed drowned Sunday after he drove past a barricade on a county road, left his stalled car and tried to walk through high water. He was swept into the Snoqualmie River. His wife and their 6-month-old son were rescued from the river by firefighters.

DOC.HEAD: Former Regulator Says He Was Threatened for Years
DOC.TEXT: The nation's former chief S&L regulator testified Monday that his 1987 meetings with five senators, now subjects of an ethics investigation, capped ``years of private threats'' designed to stop banking officials from curbing high-flying thrift institutions. Edwin J. Gray only had time to read a 13-page opening statement at the Senate Ethics Committee hearings into the five senators' ties to former S&L operator Charles H. Keating Jr. But he immediately set the stage for confrontation with the senators by declaring that he was trying to stop risky investments by instutitions like Keating's failed Lincoln Savings and Loan - while powerful politicians were trying to stop him on Keating's behalf. Gray did not go into details on the conduct of the senators: Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. But his testimony starting Tuesday will be crucial in determining whether the senators made improper demands of regulators on behalf of Keating, a political contributor to all five. Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said that his meetings with the five senators in April 1987, when they intervened for Keating, ``capped years of private threats and public vilification designed not just to change particular decisions by the bank board but to render us unable to carry out our central responsibilities.'' ``No one in Washington with the slightest knowledge of this issue can have been ignorant of this situation or the effect it would have on the way the regulators received and interpreted messages from senators and congressmen.'' Gray is a crucial witness because because of his House Banking Committee testimony a year ago that DeConcini offered a deal on Keating's behalf when he, Cranston, Glenn and McCain met with him on April 2, 1987. DeConcini has vigorously denied proposing a deal. Earlier, an aide to DeConcini said her boss once asked her if there was a way to ``bring heat'' on Gray. Nearly four months later, the aide said, she told DeConcini it could be politically disastrous for him to intervene on Keating's behalf with Gray, but he ``thanked me for my suggestion and said he was going to go ahead anyway.'' DeConcini's aide on banking issues, Laurie A. Sedlmayr, testified on the fifth day of Ethics Committee hearings. Sedlmayr said she was aware Keating wanted Gray out of office and that DeConcini also wanted him replaced. DeConcini wrote her a memo on Dec. 11, 1986, citing press accounts of potential financial and ethical problems facing Gray and asking, ``Anything we can do to bring heat?'' She said she responded five days later saying it was ``probably unnecessary'' for him to take action and suggesting the senator ``stay out of this.'' Sedlmayr said Keating was more aggressive than many other businessmen she dealt with. ``I found him to be something of a zealot and I wasn't comfortable with that,'' she said. ``I think the senator probably thought I was overstating the case,'' she added. Keating contributed $1.3 million to the campaigns and favorite causes of the Keating Five senators, much of it while he was battling thrift regulators during an intense examination of his Lincoln Savings and Loan. The institution was seized by regulators in April 1989 and it could cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses. Asked by committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett what advice she gave her boss before the April 2, 1987, meeting with Gray, Ms. Sedlmayr said: ``I told him I didn't think it was a good idea ... politically it was a mistake.'' The aide said she was concerned that word of the meeting would leak to the news media - a prediction that came true - and that ``Mr. Gray would misrepresent that meeting.'' Ms. Sedlmayr also was the second senatorial aide to back Bennett's assertion that Riegle was far more involved than he acknowledged in organizing the April 2 meeting with Gray - and a meeting April 9, 1987, between all five senators and the regulators examining Lincoln. McCain aide Gwendolyn van Paasschen said last week she believed Riegle was involved in setting up the meetings. While Riegle has denied organizing the meetings, Sedlmayr said she understood from DeConcini that the first one meeting with Gray was Riegle's idea. She described herself as disturbed that DeConcini told her to write Riegle a letter inviting him to the April 9 meeting. ``It was sort of, why are you doing this - he is just as interested in this issue as we are,'' she said. Ms. Sedlmayr wrote in a chronology she prepared in December 1988 that each of the meetings was ``the brainchild of Sen. Riegle'' and he had asked for the letter of invitation to ``cover himself'' to explain his attendance on April 9. Riegle said he went to the April 9 meeting with the San Francisco-based regulators because of his expertise on the Banking Committee, of which he is now chairman. Under cross-examination by Riegle attorney Thomas Green, Ms. Sedlmayr said ``I was being flip'' when she wrote that the meetings with regulators were the brainchild of Riegle. When Green asked her whether Riegle's suggestion that senators concerned about Lincoln meet with Gray was ``rather conventional,'' she responded that it was. Ms. Sedlmayr also told Green she had no reason to doubt that DeConcini wanted Riegle at the meeting with Gray because Riegle was an expert on banking matters.

DOC.HEAD: US Sends Mission To Beirut To Check on Security Situation
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has sent a survey team to Lebanon to determine whether it is safe for American diplomats to return to that country, the department said Monday. A spokesman said the administration hopes to return diplomats ``when we can be reasonably assured of their safety and effectiveness.'' The survey team arrived Sunday. It will not conduct diplomatic business. Former U.S. Ambassador John McCarthy closed the embassy more than a year ago. A new ambassador, Ryan Crocker, was sworn in recently but has remained in Washington. The State Department began re-evaluating the security situation in Lebanon last month after Syrian forces crushed the 11-month rebellion of Gen. Michel Aoun, who opposed a peace plan approved by the Lebanese National Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Broadens Tapes Issue, Wants Hearing on Frozen Funds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0701, to ADD writethru designation. SUBS 11th graf, ``How the ...' to RESTORE first reference to Rubino.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge broadened the constitutional issues in the CNN-Manuel Noriega tapes case Monday, saying basic fairness could allow him to block broadcast of the defendant's prison phone conversations. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler cited fairness again in warning prosecutors to either persuade foreign governments to free $20 million in frozen Noriega-linked bank accounts to pay defense lawyers, or appear before him for a hearing aimed at proving the money was drug-tainted. ``I am deeply concerned about the image that this case seems to be acquiring - that the defendant is not going to be able to get a fair trial,'' Hoeveler said. ``There's an obvious need by all of us in a case like this to show that our system, in fact, does work from top to bottom.'' On the tapes issue, the judge said transcripts of tapes handed over by Cable News Network last week were expected to be completed by late Monday, and will be discussed by all sides in a closed hearing Wednesday morning. Hoeveler said he would rule by Thursday on whether to maintain his order preventing the network from broadcasting the tapes made of calls the former Panamanian leader made from his prison cell outside Miami. The judge emphasized he would review all CNN's tapes, not just those between Noriega and his lawyers. He said an 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals opinion upholding his original gag order allowed him to consider ``broader questions'' than attorney-client privilege. CNN attorney Terry Bienstock protested, saying the issue should not include matters such as pretrial publicity because the defense had not asked for such a ruling. Outside the court, he said he was alarmed by the judge's comments. ``It's bad enough that the court's engaging in this process of pre-publication review,'' he said. ``But it's more disturbing that the court is going broader than even the litigants are seeking.'' Noriega's lawyers were pleased with the handling of the tapes, however. ``How the devil can he ever receive a fair trial ... if CNN's going to play his innermost, private discussions with his lawyers planning his defense strategy,'' said Frank Rubino, Noriega's lead attorney. In the second part of Monday's hearing, the judge said he would postpone appointment of government-paid lawyers to replace Rubino's defense team to give the government another chance to unfreeze Noriega's foreign bank accounts. Prosecutors agreed in June to free the money, but later said foreign governments had stepped in by filing their own confiscation orders against the 27 accounts. Hoeveler said he would order a hearing on the frozen accounts within 10 days to determine if the money was illegally earned. Noriega is facing up to 145 years in prison on a February 1988 indictment accusing him of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to protect and facilitate their U.S.-bound cocaine shipments. He is being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Protest Over Fare Hike Ends at Easter Island, Air Strip Cleared
DOC.TEXT: Easter Island's only landing strip was cleared by protesters Monday after the sole airline operating there temporarily agreed to end a fare increase to mainland Chile, the government reported. LAN, the privately owned Chilean carrier, announced it was postponing its fare hike until Jan. 1. The protesters had blocked the remote Pacific island's only runway on Friday night, preventing the takeoff of a LAN Boeing aircraft with 108 passengers aboard just before it was to fly on to Tahiti. LAN President Jose Luis Moure said the fare increase would be frozen until the new year, and then would be gradually implemented. LAN, the only airline operating to the volcanic island 2,300 miles west of Santiago, had announced it would increase its roundtrip fare for residents from $206 to $410. The fare is 40 percent lower than that applied to visitors coming to see the island's huge stone carvings and famed hieroglyphs. Interior Minister Enrique Krauss said the landing strip at Mataveri airport was cleared by midafternoon Monday, allowing the LAN plane to take off. An air force plane landed from Santiago carrying a group of government officials for further discussions with the islanders, Krauss said. The island has about 1,900 residents.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven-Year-Old Murder Case Ends With Guilty Plea Bargain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to include killer's quotes, judge's acceptance of plea bargain; DELETES 3rd graf pvs. Picks up 7th graf pvs: ``We settled ...
DOC.TEXT: A former school administrator has confessed that he killed his ex-girlfriend, ending an 11-year-old murder mystery. Francis Malinosky, 45, appeared in Chittenden Superior Court Monday and told a judge what police and the victim's family had long suspected: He killed schoolteacher Judith Leo-Coneys in November 1979. ``I am ashamed of myself right down to the very center of my being,'' Malinosky said, admitting his crime to District Judge Frank Mahady. As part of a plea bargain, Malinosky last week led police to Leo-Coneys' body, which had never been found. The corpse, covered in plastic, was located in a 2-foot-deep grave off a logging road in Cabot. An autopsy showed Leo-Coneys had been shot. In return for Malinosky's cooperation, the state reduced its charge against him from first-degree murder to voluntary manslaughter. The plea agreement called for a 10- to 15-year prison sentence, with all but five of those years suspended. He could be released from prison as early as late 1993. Mahady weighed whether to accept or reject the plea agreement for more than an hour. ``The penalty contemplated in the agreement simply doesn't fit the offense,'' the judge said on returning to the bench. But he said he accepted it because ``it accomplished important goals that could not have been accomplished in any other way. It resolved what happened 11 years ago.'' ``We settled for half a loaf but half a loaf is much much better than none,'' said Chittenden County State's Attorney William Sorrell. ``There was enough uncertainty about what might happen at the hands of a court or the hands of a jury that it made sense on both sides to try to reach an agreement.'' Malinosky was arrested in April in a Los Angeles-area motel, where he had been staying under an alias. He claimed then that he was the victim of a ``small-town witch hunt.'' Malinosky was an assistant director of special education for the Burlington schools and Leo-Coneys was a Milton special education teacher when their two-year relationship ended in the summer of 1979. The breakup reportedly left Malinosky distraught, his attorney said. Leo-Coneys, 32, disappeared Nov. 5, 1979, after going to Malinosky's home to pick up her personal belongings. Malinosky had been a suspect from the beginning, but police were never able to connect him with Leo-Coneys' disappearance, police said. Several diggings around his house failed to uncover any evidence. As the investigation accelerated, Malinosky disappeared in December, and wandered the country using a host of aliases, police said. In 1989, Sorrell took over as state's attorney and, after reading the case file for three days, reopened the case. ``I was convinced when I looked at the file that he had murdered her,'' Sorrell said. ``It bothered me that this guy was getting away with murder.''

DOC.HEAD: Son Charged with Marijuana Possession, Foreign Minister Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister of this small South American nation resigned Monday after one of his sons was charged with marijuana possession. A government statement released Monday said Rashleigh Jackson resigned his ministry post after learning his son Martin and a female companion were charged with possessing four grams of marijuana. The statement said President Desmond Hoyte ``accepted his resignation reluctantly'' and would temporarily take over as foreign minister. Jackson, who had been minister more than a decade, has been beset by personal problems since his British-born wife drowned two years ago. Friends said the death had a devastating effect on Jackson. His son faces a mandatory four-year jail sentenced if found guilty. He has pleaded innocent.

DOC.HEAD: `Home Alone' Cleans House at the Box Office
With AM-Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``Home Alone,'' the lightweight story of an abandoned offspring, is crushing the competition at movie theaters nationwide, appealing to children and adults from big and small cities alike. The family comedy's stunning box-office haul - $28.7 million over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend - is all the more remarkable because many of the admissions are discounted for children. As of Monday, the film has grossed $48.3 million in two weeks of release. In a movie season loaded with adult fare such as ``Predator II,'' ``Jacob's Ladder'' and ``Reversal of Fortune,'' ``Home Alone'' appeals to all audiences, its box-office revenues indicate. Over the holiday weekend, parents wanting to take their children to the movies chose ``Home Alone'' overwhelmingly, 20th Century Fox said. The movie stars Macaulay Culkin as 8-year-old Kevin McCallister, accidentally left behind at Christmas when his family leaves for a Paris vacation. While at home, the youngster defends the residence from two bumbling burglars. ``Home Alone'' was written and produced by John Hughes and directed by Chris Columbus. ``Everyone seems to be coming and we're getting a lot of repeat business,'' said Tom Sherak, head of marketing and distribution for Fox. ``It doesn't matter where you are. There's not a weak spot in the entire country - small cities or big cities,'' Sherak said. ``We look at some of the (box-office) grosses from some of those small cities and wonder where the audiences will come from the next day.'' The movie can be seen in 1,284 theaters nationwide, and more theaters may be added this week, Sherak said. To build an audience for ``Home Alone,'' Fox screened the film in sneak previews Nov. 10. Originally set to open on Nov. 21, its release was moved up four days so it would not compete head-to-head with the family-oriented ``Three Men and a Little Lady.'' CinemaScore, a movie testing service, says ``Home Alone'' has scored as high as the year's hits ``Ghost'' and ``Pretty Woman.'' A survey of about 450 patrons of ``Home Alone'' in Las Vegas and St. Louis found that 82 percent said it deserved an A grade. The majority of moviegoers under age 25 said ``Home Alone'' merited an A-plus, said CinemaScore's Ed Mintz.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Brothers, Soviets End World Bike Tour
DOC.TEXT: Two Minnesota brothers and their two Soviet companions pedaled up to the state Capitol Monday to complete a 13,000-mile round-the-world bicycle tour that began eight months earlier. ``We couldn't be happier,'' 30-year-old Dan Buettner of Minneapolis told family members, supporters and reporters who turned out on a cold, drizzly morning to welcome the team. ``We went through a hurricane and earthquakes and floods, and we had the salmonella sicknesses. At times we didn't think we were going to make it, and we knew a lot of folks back here were watching us and rooting for us, and that's really what kind of kept us going.'' His brother Steve, 25, of Roseville, said: ``I feel fantastic. This is the happiest day of my life.'' The Buettners and Soviet bikers Vladimir (Volodya) Kovalenko, 32, and Alexander Razumenko, 31, began their journey April 1. The foursome's goal was to circle the globe, following as closely as possible the 45th parallel, and to get credit in the Guinness Book of World Records as the first people to cycle across the Soviet Union. The trip took the four to Novosibirsk, Siberia, the Soviet bikers' hometown. The 7,353-mile stretch across the Soviet Union took 125 days. A spokesman for the team said Guinness is going over the documentation to verify the record. Dan Buettner already holds a Guinness record for cycling from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego. Buettner said the most challenging part of the trip was in the far eastern part of the Soviet Union. ``The roads came to an end,'' he said, ``and we had about 800 miles where we pushed our bicycles along footpaths and through the mud and knee-deep bogs. When things got really bad, we went up to the trans-Siberian railway and pushed our bikes along it. That was probably the toughest part. We were drinking water out of mud puddles and we were eating buckwheat and Chinese pork fat.'' Physically, the trip was ``not so difficult,'' said Razumenko, although Dan Buettner disagreed. ``It's easy for Alexander to say it wasn't so tough because he's been to Antarctica and the North Pole and for him bicycling is probably easy,'' said Buettner, who lost 18 pounds during the journey. The Buettners met Razumenko and Kovalenko through a suburban Minneapolis group called CONNECT U.S.-U.S.S.R., which arranges visits and business transactions between the two countries. The largest sponsor of the $30,000 trip was 3M Co. of St. Paul. Raleigh Bicycle Corp. of America donated the off-the-rack mountain bicycles.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Draft Resolution Agreed on by UN's `Big Five'
With AM-UN-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Following is text of draft resolution agreed upon Monday night by the `Big Five' permanent members of the United Nations, which include the United States. `The Security Council, Recalling and reaffirming its Resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 666 (1990), 667 (1990), 669 (1990), 670 (1990), and 674 (1990), Noting that, despite all efforts by the United Nations, Iraq refuses to comply with its obligation to implement Resolution 660 (1990) and the above subsequent relevant Resolutions, in flagrant contempt of the Council, Mindful of its duties and responsibilities under the Charter of the United Nations for the maintenance and preservation of international peace and security, Determined to secure full compliance with its decisions, Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, 1. Demands that Iraq comply fully with Resolution 660 (1990) and all subsequent relevant resolutions and decides, while maintaining all is decisions, to allow Iraq one final opportunity, as a pause of goodwill, to do so; 2. Authorizes member states cooperating with the Government of Kuwait, unless Iraq on or before January 1 (15), 1991 fully implements, as set forth in Paragraph 1 above, the foregoing Resolutions, to use all necesary means to uphold and implement Security Council Resolution 660 and all subsequent relevant Resolutions and to restore international peace and security in the area; 3. Requests all states to provide appropriate support for the actions undertaken in pursuance of Paragraph 2 of this Resolution; and 4. Requests the states concerned to keep the Council regularly informed on the progress of actions undertaken pursuant to Paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Resolution.'

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Quits; Walesa Faces Dark-Horse Candidate
LaserPhoto GDA50,51, WAR51
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional Walesa comments, background on election, prime minister resignation. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki resigned Monday along with his government a day after a political neophyte dealt him a humiliating defeat in presidential elections. ``Poland's painful but necessary program of getting out of economic catastrophe can only be realized with the understanding of the majority of the nation,'' said Mazowiecki, the first non-Communist prime minister in the East bloc. ``Society made its choice.'' He had come in third in presidential elections Sunday, failing to qualify for a runoff with Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who finished first. Mazowiecki was knocked out of the race by Stanislaw Tyminski, a wealthy businessman who returned to Poland this fall after 21 years in Canada and Peru. ``I will win these elections,'' an optimistic Tyminski told supporters and the curious at his Warsaw headquarters. ``I am not afraid of Walesa, I am not afraid of anyone.'' Walesa said Tyminski's success was an ``accelerated lesson in democracy.'' Mazowiecki, 63, took office in August 1989 and spearheaded Eastern Europe's most ambitious economic reforms and won international acclaim for his historic role in the democratization. But the election results made clear his inability to head off discontent among ordinary Poles, particularly those in the countryside, suffering through inflation, unemployment and widespread uncertainty after four decades of Communism. ``The vision of creating a Polish democracy and a healthy economy that my government served has been questioned,'' Mazowiecki said. He told state radio he and his government could not be responsible ``for promises made by the other candidates.'' Mazowiecki announced he will submit his government's formal resignation to Parliament. The government will continue only in a caretaker role until a new one is formed following the Dec. 9 runoff, Mazowiecki said. It was the first time Poles voted for a president by popular election. In the past, both under Communist rule and before World War II, presidents were elected by the Parliament. News of Mazowiecki's resignation drew an angry reaction from Walesa, who had tapped him for the post of prime minister, then split with him over the pace of reforms in the post-Communist era. ``That's great responsibility,'' Walesa said sarcastically, contacted at home by The Associated Press. ``Now, let the Poles see this responsibility, this patriotism and this democracy of Mazowiecki.'' He later told state television that the resignation would be ``complicating things,'' but he hoped ``calm will prevail and everything will end up well.'' He added he would try to ``sew up'' Solidarity. Tyminski, 42, who was not taken seriously by other candidates until polls indicated a late surge of support, promised to make Poland prosperous and assailed the Mazowiecki government as incompetent. Tyminski's promises of wealth were particularly alluring to voters worn down by economic reforms launched by Mazowiecki. With Mazowiecki's resignation, a new prime minister presumably would be nominated to Parliament by the new president. Both the Mazowiecki and Walesa camps expressed shock at Tyminski's showing. Walesa, at his Solidarity union office in Gdansk, called Tyminski ``an accident in Polish democracy'' and said he was not ``a serious man.'' With all 49 provinces reporting, Walesa had nearly 40 percent of the vote, Tyminski 23 percent and Mazowiecki 18 percent; three minor candidates split the rest, according to election commission results collected by the official news agency PAP. Turnout was put at 61 percent. Walesa, the shipyard worker who marshaled the forces that ended Communist rule, had hoped for a huge mandate in Sunday's vote. He had said earlier it would be ``horrible'' to face Tyminski in the second round of balloting. ``I must say I am hesitating,'' he said Monday, but added: ``One has to think over what is good for Poland.'' One newspaper commentator attributed Tyminski's strong showing to support from ``a second Poland'' of disaffected rural and small-town voters who are looking for quick answers to their country's difficulties. The major candidates and the press underestimated their numbers, Piotr Pacewicz wrote Monday in the country's largest newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza. He said Tyminski profited from being an outsider ``who came from the world of success, from the Americas, and who was not a part of the world of politics.'' Tyminski was also the beneficiary of a split in Solidarity, which held together and battled Communism for more than a decade but then broke into separate camps supporting and opposing Walesa and differing over the pace of economic reforms.
