There was no indication whether Mazowiecki would throw his support to Walesa, or what his backers would decide. Mazoweicki vowed to continue the ``the struggle for a democracy as we want it,'' but added: ``I am afraid I expect a period of chaos.'' The head of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, Tyminski has sometimes puzzled reporters with odd statements. He promised Poles again on Monday he would quickly cure their economic woes. ``I want to make this country rich and prosperous,'' he said. ``It will be better within a month.'' Tyminski has said a routine business trip to Warsaw in September turned into a campaign for the presidency. He said he had been denied entry to Poland in the 1980s. ``I just want to help my country, and I couldn't before,'' he said. The new president will take over from Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist general who ordered martial law to crush Solidarity but now is retiring early to complete the democratic transformation. The election was the first in Eastern Europe tofocus not on defeating communism but on choosing between visions for the post-Communist future. The new president will serve a five-year term.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Sets Date for Jane Pauley and Second NBC News Series
DOC.TEXT: NBC said Monday it is putting Jane Pauley into the Sunday night ratings wars opposite ABC's to-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and CBS' durable ``Murder, She Wrote.'' The battles will start Jan. 6 at 8 p.m. EST when her ``Real Life With Jane Pauley'' starts, followed by another NBC News series, ``Expose,'' an investigative program anchored by Tom Brokaw. Each will be a half-hour series for three Sundays a month, with Pauley's show getting a full hour on the fourth Sunday and Brokaw's``Expose'' getting that night off, NBC said. The two programs, the first NBC News series since the division's low-rated ``1986'' newsmagazine, will take over the time slot currently occupied by the medical series ``Lifestories,'' which will appear monthly after Sunday's broadcast. NBC also said it is bringing back its ``Amen'' comedy series, which had been axed from its fall lineup after four seasons, as a midseason replacement beginning Saturday. ``The Fanelli Boys,'' a new situation comedy now on Wednesdays, will move to Saturdays starting this week.``Working It Out,'' another new sitcom, will move from Saturday to Wednesday. Pauley's series began last summer as five one-hour specials. The shows - and a new NBC contract - came after her controversial replacement as ``Today'' anchorwoman by Deborah Norville. In becoming Sunday night regulars, Pauley and Brokaw will be part of NBC's midseason bid to overcome the low ratings the network has suffered during the first two hours of that evening. Last month, NBC axed its new ``Hull High'' series, which had led off the network's Sunday night schedule against CBS' powerhouse ``60 Minutes'' and ABC's ``Life Goes On.'' NBC has since has filled the ``Hull'' time period with specials and movies, a spokesman said. A permanent replacement for ``Hull High'' will be announced later.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Frank Out of Hospital After Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Barney Frank, who recently suffered a mild heart attack, was released from the hospital Monday. He had been hospitalized for nine days after suffering chest pains while exercising. Tests showed that his coronary artery was blocked and doctors used balloon angioplasty to restore blood flow in the artery, according to by Beth Israel Hospital. The 50-year-old Democrat won re-election in the Massachusetts Fourth District on Nov. 6. He said Monday he would return to Washington to recover further and to attend organization caucuses for the new Congress beginning next week. Dr. William Grossman, the hospital's chief cardiologist, said he is optimistic Frank will recover fully. National attention focused on Frank last summer when the House reprimanded him for actions stemming from his relationship with a male prostitute.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Launches 10th Satellite; Will Aid Gulf Operations
DOC.TEXT: The U.S Air Force launched a new, more powerful Delta rocket Monday carrying a $65 million Navstar navigation satellite that will help troops stay oriented in the Saudi Arabian desert. The loss of wind data from a weather balloon caused a brief delay. But at 4:39 p.m., the $45 million, 128-foot Delta 2 - boosted by an improved main engine and nine new, larger solid rockets strapped around its first stage core - lifted off. The 10th Navstar satellite launched since February 1989 separated from its booster 25 minutes after launch. It is scheduled to reach its final 11,000-mile orbit above Earth on Wednesday. The Navstars allow U.S. and allied troops inthe Middle East to use telephone-sized, hand-held receivers to determine their position within 35 feet in the nearly featureless desert of Saudi Arabia. The troops were deployed to the Persian Gulf after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. More than 1,000 receivers produced for civilian use have been distributed to the troops in the Persian Gulf, said Lt. Gen. Thomas Mooreman, Jr., chief of the Air Force Space Command. Another thousand are on order. The Navstars also contain atomic clocks, the most accurate time pieces in the world. They allow soldiers to synchronize their watches and carry out split-second timed secret operations, the Air Force said. Besides providing navigational and positioning data, the 3,675-pound satellites carry nuclear detection devices designed to pinpoint the location of nuclear explosions. The new Navstar circling Earth is part of the $8.5 billion Global Positioning System that eventually will have 24 satellites, including three spares, in six orbital planes. The remaining spacecraft in the series are to be launched by the end of 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Official Invited to America As U.N. Vote on Iraq Nears
DOC.TEXT: China said Monday that Washington had invited a Chinese vice minister of trade to visit next month. The report came days before a major vote on Iraq by the U.N. Security Council, of which China is a permanent member. A senior State Department official insisted the United States had not changed its policy of barring high-level exchanges with Beijing, a moratorium imposed after soldiers crushed the Chinese democracy movement in June 1989. The official, speaking in Washington on condition of not being identified, said the ban precludes ``large, formal ceremonial exchanges,'' and that the visit of Vice Trade Minister Gu Yongjiang does not fall into that category. He said meetings have been held since June 1989 at the vice minister level, and next month's meeting is consistent with what has gone on before. At U.N. headquarters in New York, China and the Soviet Union on Monday joined America, Britain and France in agreeing on a U.N. draft resolution authorizing use of military force unless Iraq withdraws by January from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. Washington has pushed hard for such a resolution. Word of Gu's planned visit came as U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan W. Bell announced that Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen will travel to New York to vote on that Security Council resolution. Bell said the Beijing government notified the embassy of Qian's plans. The Foreign Ministry here did not immediately respond when asked for confirmation. As permanent council members, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France each has veto power over any resolution. China's longstanding policy is one of opposition to superpower intervention in regional issues. China has pressed for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. The Beijing government's world standing has greatly improved following China's support for resolutions against Iraq, prompting efforts by the Bush administration to resume normal relations with China. The Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade said that Vice Minister Gu will visit the United States from Dec. 10-14 at the invitation of J. Michael Farren, Commerce Department undersecretary. The only clear-cut Western sanction on China still in effect is a ban on arms sales.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE AGUALEGUAS
Bush Holds Talks With Salinas; Trade Issues Touchy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with Monterrey speeches, Fitzwater comments on Monday talks, minor editing throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying U.S.-Mexican relations ``have never been better,'' met with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Monday for talks the White House said focused on negotiating an end to trade barriers. ``Let's commence a new era for both our nations,'' Bush said, addressing tens of thousands of people at an evening welcoming ceremony in a plaza in this industrial city in northern Mexico. Bush was here for two days of talks. ``Viva Mexico!'' Bush declared to cheers that filled the large plaza. A prospective U.S.-Mexican free trade agreement, similar to one the United States negotiated with Canada two years ago, headed the agenda. But the president also cited ``challenges in the world beyond our borders,'' particularly reconstruction in Central America ``and restoration of stability in the Persian Gulf region.'' Salinas has supported Bush's Persian Gulf policy and has hinted he might send troops to fight along with U.S. forces if the United Nations agrees to a U.S.-backed resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Mexico has also increased its oil production to help offset oil lost from Iraq and Kuwait, boosting its exports to the United States by 100,000 barrels a day. There are 42 gallons in each barrel. ``I've come to Mexico tonight with a message of respect... and hope for a brighter future shared by our two countries,'' Bush said. He called the ending of trade barriers vital to both nations. ``I believe that U.S.-Mexican relations have never been better,'' Bush said in his first official visit as president. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that, at their first session, the two leaders focused on the proposed free trade agreement. ``Both presidents are interested in pursuing the agreement as fast as possible and attach high priority to its successful conclusion,'' Fitzwater said. He said Bush and Salinas also talked about increasing cooperation in the war against drugs and working more closely to end border violence. Bush and Salinas discussed the situation in El Salvador and agreed ``to press for a cease-fire and a negotiated settlement to the situation,'' Fitzwater said. Despite warm greetings the two presidents paid one another, Salinas signalled difficult trade talks ahead, accusing the United States of trade protectionism even before his guest arrived. ``Today, American products can enter the Mexican market without restriction,'' he told the Monterrey daily El Norte. ``But ours are detained at customs, and there are always many restrictions.'' Bush got a red-carpet airport greeting, then travelled with Salinas by helicopter to Salinas' hometown of Agualeguas, a small farming and cattle community about 60 miles northeast of Monterrey. Salinas took Bush to a charro, or rodeo, where the two presidents were tieless while their wives wore light suits under a glaring sun. They watched Mexican dancers before walking through the packed streets of the town square to a luncheon and talks. It was the sixth time Bush and Salinas have met since they were both elected in 1988, but Bush's first trip to Mexico as president. Salinas, introducing Bush at the rally, hailed what he said was ``a new relationship between our countries'' as Mexico assumes its ``new place in the world.'' ``Geography made us forced neighbors, history made us wary neighbors, may our will and vision of the future make us respectful and progressive neighbors,''Salinas said. ``Mexico has changed, faithful to its principles and traditions but looking to the future with liberty and sovereignty to become a modern, competitive and just nation,'' said Salinas. On Tuesday, the two were to meet for more talks and Bush was to address a group of Mexican business leaders in Monterrey, a manufacturing city of more than 3 million only 143 miles from Laredo, in Texas, Bush's adopted homestate. Preliminary discussions on the free-trade pact have been under way since Salinas visited Washington in June. Bush notified Congress in September of his plans to negotiate such an agreement, possibly by 1992. But even as the United States and Mexico worked toward achieving such an accord, trade frictions remained. Salinas has resisted Bush administration suggestions that the state-run oil industry be opened up to U.S. investment as part of the free-trade negotiations. Mexico also wants any free trade agreement to make it easer for Mexicans to enter the United States. In the newspaper interview, Salinas said he was concerned that protectionist attitudes in the United States were making it hard for Mexico to ship agricultural products and fish. Mexican fruits and vegetables are periodically barred from the United States for not meeting quality standards, restrictions that Mexicans contend favor U.S. growers and fishing interests. A recent U.S. ban on Mexican tuna, which environmentalists said was caught in nets that kill dolphins, caused an outcry here. The ban has since been overturned by a federal court.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov, Karpov Adjourn in Game 14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS grafs 6-7 `Monday's 14th ... queen's pawn' to `moved the king's pawn' sted queen's pawn in graf 6, `his king's pawn' sted `queen's pawn' in graf 7. Picks up 8th, `Kasparov used...'
DOC.TEXT: Defending champion Garry Kasparov and his fellow Soviet rival Anatoly Karpov adjourned their 14th game of the World Chess Championship on Monday after both players encountered time troubles following five hours of play. The rapid-fire finish ended when Kasparov sealed his 41st move. Both had three pawns, a rook, a queen and king left. They also adjourned after Saturday's 13th game, which led to a draw. Kasparov and Karpov each have 6{ points. They were tied at 6 after the first 12 games in New York, 10 of which were draws, between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. Monday's 14th game, and second of the French phase of the championship, started when Kasparov walked on stage and sat behind the white pieces. He thought a few minutes and moved the king's pawn. Karpov arrived and matched it by moving his king's pawn. Kasparov used an opening that Karpov has seen before in top-level competition known as the Scotch game. Until the eighth move, the game matched two contests that Karpov played with black against Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman in the mid-1980s. Karpov won one game in 28 moves and drew the other after 57, so experts noted that he was acquainted with this line of play. He played black at least seven times in major competition against the Scotch opening, winning three and drawing four. But when Kasparov moved a queen's bishop's pawn, a new game developed. After almost two hours and 17 moves of the game, Karpov already had an hour more in playing time than Kasparov. Karpov used almost 20 minutes to decide his 18th move, moving his queen in a position to apply some central pressure. By now, Karpov had less than 48 minutes to do 22 moves. Each player is allotted 2{ hours for his first 40 moves. Saturday, in the 13th game, Karpov also ran into time trouble but got out of it with eight moves in seven minutes. But on Monday, Kasparov wasted away his time advantage on the 19th move. He thought for 53 minutes before he decided to move the queen's knight. On the 21st move, Karpov brought up a knight to add more pressure and grandmasters were saying that Karpov could be threatening mate quite soon. But Kasparov battled back after being in check on the 23rd move. After a flurry of exchanges, Karpov had just five minutes left for 14 moves but moved quickly to use just three minutes for six moves. But Kasparov was under pressure, too, and realized he had just eight minutes left after move 32. From then on, both players made moves in a series of rapid decisions that left them both flirting with the time limit after five hours. Karpov put Kasparov into check three consecutive times but Kasparov kept moving his king out of danger. The two played almost exactly the five-hour limit for the first 40 moves before Kasparov sealed his 41st move. Experts again were divided on who had the better posiion. Another draw could be agreed upon before play resumes Tuesday. After Saturday's adjournment, Karpov offered a draw Sunday morning, six hours before the restart.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Comes Out of Hiding for Brief Taped TV Interview
LaserPhoto LON14
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie came out of hiding briefly Monday to tape a television interview in which the author said he wants to put together ``bits of my life'' and talk to Moslems about threats on his life, the BBC reported. Rushdie has been in seclusion since February 1989 when the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered Moslems to kill him for blaspheming Islam in his book ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie went to the BBC's Lime Grove studios in West London for an interview on the arts program ``The Late Show,'' which was broadcast Monday night, the BBC said. The BBC refused comment on why Rushdie decided to go to the studio instead of being interviewed at a ``safe'' house as he has in the past. ``I want to slowly begin to pinch back bits of my life and to continue to work as hard as I can to bring the temperature down,'' he said. ``That involves talking to Moslem leaders to try and find a common ground and it seems to me there is a lot of common ground but the point is to make it more solid.'' He again denied that ``The Satanic Verses'' was an incitement to religious hatred. Asked what he would like to be doing in a few months, Rushdie said, ``I would like to spend it on a beach, but I can't see it happening. I am not looking too far ahead.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Storage Tank Fire, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0685,0615
DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Gain Ground Against Jet Fuel Tank Fire
LaserPhotos DX4, DX5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATES fire burning more than 1.9 million gallons, include computer tracking of smoke plum; picks up 4th graf pvs: The fire at ...; ADDS 4 grafs at end on computer tracking. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Patience, and a quarter of the water Denver uses in one day, helped firefighters rein in a fire Monday that burned more than 1.9 million gallons of jet fuel at a tank farm near Stapleton International Airport. The strategy of the 150 firefighters was to let the fire that began Sunda consume fuel in the ignited tanks and prevent it from spreading by drenching nearby tanks with water and foam. ``We, at this point in time, feel like everything is under our grasp,'' said Denver Fire Department Capt. Nick Nuanes. ``Things are going real, real good. The intensity has dropped dramatically.'' Meanwhile, the black smoke from the fire that darkened the sky and caused potential health problems was tracked with help from a crew of computer scientists at Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant. The fire at the Ogden Allied Services Corp. tank farm began when a valve on a 400,000-gallon storage tank broke and jet fuel began to leak. The flames eventually spread to three other tanks. The facility has 12 storage tanks with a capacity of 12.5 million gallons of fuel. They include the primary fuel source for United Airlines, which was forced on Sunday to delay and cancel an undetermined number of its 186 flights into and out of Denver. But the carrier was nearly back on schedule Monday after finding alternate fuel sources, said Joe Hopkins, a United spokesman in Chicago. The fire caused few problems for other airlines at Stapleton because most had alternate sources of fuel on hand. Stapleton is the nation's fourth-busiest airport in passenger volume. By midday Monday firefighters had used 15,000 gallons of foam. About 24 million gallons of water had been poured on the blaze, about one-fourth the water used in the city system on an average fall day. Temperatures near the fire reached 3,500 degrees Fahrenheit, well beyond the melting point of iron. By Monday, the fire that consumed fuel in two 400,000 gallon capacity tanks left them blackened, crumpled masses of metal. But flames continued to burn in one tank containing about 350,000 gallons of fuel and in an 800,000-gallon tank. Officials said the latter held enough fuel to burn until about midday Wednesday. Authorities decided to let the fuel burn, rather than attempt to smother the fire and face potential ground contamination, Nuanes said. ``We'd like to see the fuel burn itself off,'' he said. ``We're not going to attempt to extinguish the fire. We don't want a contamination problem on our hands.'' Rocky Flats scientists helped Colorado health officials by using a computer model to forecast the path of the fire's smoke. The plume of black, billowing smoke twisted in several directions across Denver as a storm front traveled through the city, but was headed southwest late in the day, said Reed Hodgin, manager of emergency assessments for EG&G Inc., which operates the weapons plant north of Denver. ``The (computer) model has been very accurate as far as what we've seen the plume do,'' said Steve Arnold, manager of the technical services program at the Colorado Department of Health. The Rocky Flats team helped state health officials determine whether the plume will affect the population and which it might affect most, Arnold said.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: RETRANSMITS a0689 to fix category code
DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Visits Quilt Exhibit In Northern Mexican Town
With AM-US-Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush visited a quilt exhibit and chatted with residents Monday during an afternoon stroll through the main plaza of this small town in northern Mexico. Earlier, Mrs. Bush joined President Bush, Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his wife Cecilia Occelli for a private lunch at the Salinas home in Agualeguas, 35 miles from the U.S. border. After the lunch, Mrs. Bush, guided by Mexico's First Lady, walked to the town hall a block away to see the handicrafts exhibit. They were accompanied by Mrs. Bush's daughter-in-law Columba, wife of Jeb Bush. The Bushes began their stay by watching a rodeo and Mexican folk dancing.

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Moved to Baghdad; More Hostage Releases Indicated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with relative saying third American hostage to be freed. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `The Swedish...'
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Americans, Britons and other Europeans held at strategic sites in Kuwait have been moved to Baghdad, diplomats reported Monday. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, meanwhile, said three American hostages can go home, and the Swedish Embassy announced more than 50 Swedes in Iraq have also been given permission to leave. U.S. and British diplomats said the Western hostages in Kuwait - including five Americans and 70 Britons - were brought to the Mansour Melia Hotel in the Iraqi capital. The diplomats, however, were unsure if the Westerners would replace Germans allowed to leave strategic sites inside Iraq or were brought to Baghdad to be released. They also said that Iraq has not allowed any Iraqis to enter Kuwait for a week and has been encouraging those in the country to go home. Britons are largest group of Westerners in the two countries, with about 400 hiding in Kuwait, another 400 not allowed to leave Iraq but free to move within Baghdad and 330 hostages, the British Embassy said. The U.S. Embassy has said there are more than 900 Americans in the two countries, including 104 held at strategic sites. A broadcast on Iraqi television Monday included footage of Saddam meeting with a group of Americans and their relatives, who were told they would be allowed to leave together. The official Iraqi News Agency said three American hostages will be allowed to leave. Some U.S. government officials have criticized relatives' trips to Iraq, and said the broadcast was a propaganda exercise by Saddam. ``If you feel that hospitality has come to an end, you can travel to the United States of America, or anywhere else in the world at any time you deem appropriate,'' the report quoted Saddam as saying. Those in the meeting shown on TV were Fred Harrington, 59, of Bellevue, Wash., whose son, Vala Fouroohi, has been seeking his release; and Bill Stevenson and James Stevenson of Panama City, Fla., and their sister Mary Trundy of Brockton, Mass., who sought the release of their brother, John, 44, a computer specialist who worked in Kuwait for 11 years. ``I believe I'm coming home,'' Harrington said in a telephone call to his wife, Najmi, at their home in Bellevue. He did not to give her details on when he or other hostages could be freed. Harrington, founder and president of the Redmond, Wash.-based American Pulp and Paper Co., is a native of Iran. He changed his name after emigrating to the United States. He became a U.S. citizen in 1986. The daughter-in-law of hostage Clyde Jesse, 55, a U.S. citizen who was living in Kuwait, said Monday that Jesse has also been promised he can leave Iraq. Kim Nickel of Yuma, Ariz., said her mother, Honey Jesse, 54, appeared before the Iraqi parliament last week and pleaded for Jesse's release. Ms. Nickel said Jesse and his wife were at a Baghdad hotel Monday. The Swedish Embassy announced a group of Swedish parliamentarians and peace activists secured the release of 56 Swedes as well as a non-Swedish dependent and a citizen of Iceland. According to the embassy, the National Assembly, or parliament, decided to release the Swedes after the Swedish group met with Iraqi officials. The embassy said no date has been fixed for the hostages' departure, and a diplomat said the parliament action would have to be ratified by Saddam. Also in Parliament on Monday, a letter from Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson was read condemning Israeli policy in the region and pointing out that Kuwait was not the only country occupied in the region, a reference to Palestinian lands controlled by Israel. He also said Sweden would not back a military settlement to the crisis. Two Finnish delegation members were also meeting with Iraqi officials in an effort to win the release of nine Finns in Iraq. But Iraqi Deputy Premier Taha Yassin Ramadan criticized a recent Finnish statement implying the nation would approve a U.N. resolution backing the use of force in the gulf, Finnish radio reported. Saddam has offered to free foreigners beginning Dec. 25 in exchange for U.S. guarantees he will not be attacked. The release period from Dec. 25 to March 25 coincides with the time considered best to launch a military operation since temperatures are lower and there are frequent stretches of calm weather. Western governments and others have said they will not negotiate releases because they believe Saddam is trying to divide the anti-Iraq coalition. He has freed several hundred people, mainly Europeans, after mercy missions to Baghdad by former prime ministers and other non-government figuers. In Milan, Italy, an Italian who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage while held in Iraq arrived Monday and was placed in a hospital. A medical plane of the Europe Assistance group flew Maurizio Rossetti, 53, from Baghdad, where he had been hospitalized, the Italian news agency AGI reported. In Moscow, Foreign Minister Eduard Schevardnadze sought clarification on why only 350 of a promised 1,000 Soviet citizens had been allowed to leave this month.

DOC.SECOND: Defendant Seeks New Trial, Claims Prosecutor Bias
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of sexually assaulting a woman with 46 personalities requested a new trial Monday because prosecutors failed to disclose the woman was having a sexual relationship with a key witness. Mark A. Peterson, 29, was convicted Nov. 8 of second-degree sexual assault and faces a 10-year prison sentence. Prosecutors argued he manipulated the woman's mental illness, called multiple personality disorder, to have sex with her. Wisconsin law forbids sexual contact with mentally ill people who cannot understand the consequences of their action. Peterson filed an appeal in Winnebago County Circuit Court, citing information disclosed last week by a former counselor to the woman. The counselor was fired for trying to profit from book and movie contracts about the case. The counselor disclosed to the court the woman has had a sexual relationship for a year with a neighbor who was a key prosecution witness against Peterson. The woman admitted to the relationship.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Set at $100,000 for Man Accused of Aiding Bambi's Escape
DOC.TEXT: A judge Monday set bond at $100,000 for the man accused of helping convicted murderer Lawrencia Bembenek - popularly known as ``Bambi'' - escape from prison and flee to Canada in July. Dominic Gugliatto, a 35-year-old suburban Milwaukee factory worker, was returned to Wisconsin last week, about a month after he and Ms. Bembenek were captured in Thunder Bay, Ontario. He is charged with aiding and abetting Ms. Bembenek's escape, a felony carrying up to five years in prison. Fond du Lac County Circuit Judge Henry Buslee said he ordered a large bond because authorities may question Gugliatto about other crimes, including a homicide. The judge and District Attorney Peter Grimm would not explain further. Ms. Bembenek, 32, a former Playboy club waitress and policewoman, was serving a life prison sentence for the 1981 murder of her then-husband's ex-wife when she escaped July 15 from Taycheedah Correctional Institute near Fond du Lac. Ms. Bembenek and Gugliatto were captured in October after a visitor to Thunder Bay recognized them from a recent segment of the television show ``America's Most Wanted.''

DOC.HEAD: Deaths Over 370 on Nation's Roads During Thanksgiving Weekend
DOC.TEXT: At least 386 people died on the nation's roads during the Thanksgiving weekend and California suffered the most deaths with 67, according to figures tabulated Monday. Florida had the second most holiday road fatalities, with 39, while Pennsylvania had 18 and Ohio, Michigan and Missouri each had 16. The state agency in Texas that usually compiles such figures didn't do so for the past weekend. The Chicago-based National Safety Council projected between 380 and 480 deaths because of traffic accidents for the period between 6 p.m. Wednesday and midnight Sunday. Over last year's Thanksgiving weekend, 406 people died in highway accidents.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Big Five Agree on Gulf Military Force Draft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with U.N. developments on gulf crisis, Saddam quotes, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2 MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the Security Council agreed Monday on a U.N. draft resolution authorizing military force against Iraq by January unless it quits Kuwait. Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned Iraq its aggression will be punished. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said on Monday a ``great number'' of Iraqis were dying because U.N. sanctions were depriving them of medicine, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Diplomatic sources discounted previous Iraqi claims it was short of medicine. Medical shipments qualify as humanitarian aid, not barred under the U.N. trade embargo imposed to make Iraq leave Kuwait after its blitz invasion on Aug. 2 following disputes over oil, land and money. The draft agreed Monday by the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France would be the 11th U.N. resolution aimed at Iraq since the Persian Gulf crisis began. It would authorize ``all necesary means'' - meaning military force - unless Iraq withdraws by Jan. 1 or Jan. 15. A firm date will be decided before the 15-member council votes this week, diplomats said. The measure is expected to be adopted at an extraordinary council session of foreign ministers. As Soviet President Gorbachev pledged in an address to the Supreme Soviet parliament that the alliance against Iraq would not be broken, the Bush administration called up combat reserve troops from four states. Oil prices jumped $2 a barrel amid speculation about war in the gulf. Saddam blamed the United States for the alleged shortage of medicine in his remarks to the relatives of three American hostages released in Iraq on Monday, INA said, monitored in Cyprus. Saddam said no foreigners had died as a result of not being allowed to leave Iraq, the report said. Iraq has held hundreds of Americans trapped by the Kuwait invasion, among other foreign hostages. He said Monday that in holding them, ``we only intended to add factors that might make some of those who seek war hesitate a little to think better.'' President Bush and other leaders have said the hostages will not be a factor in deciding whether to attack Iraq, and called for their immediate release. Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in the Kremlin to demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. Answering questions from legislators in Moscow, Gorbachev said the gulf crisis was a test of the new post-Cold War cooperation. ``Our position remains based on principles and it includes the following: Aggression is inadmissible. It should be punished, and the pre-aggression state should be restored,'' Gorbachev said. He said Saddam could not break the alliance assembled against Iraq and that Iraq's aggression could not be allowed to prevail ``because we are just moving away from the Cold War, when everything was decided from a position of force.'' In the Iraqi capital, U.S. and British diplomats said more than 100 Americans, Britons and Europeans held in Kuwait were brought overnight to a Baghdad hotel. The group included at least 10 Americans and 60 Britons. The diplomats said they were unsure if the new arrivals would be used to replace Germans allowed to leave strategic sites in Iraq or were being brought to Baghdad to be released. They also said Iraq had not allowed any Iraqis to enter Kuwait for a week and had been urging those in the country to go home. The Swedish Embassy said nearly 60 Swedes, the last remaining Swedish citizens in Iraq, will be allowed to leave. However, the Soviet Union complained Iraq reneged on a promise to free 1,000 more Soviet citizens this month. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Iraq's actions were ``totally abnormal and unacceptable.'' The official Soviet news agency Tass said Aziz attributed the Soviets' delayed departures to a ``bureaucratic accident.'' Dennis Trundy of Brockton, Mass., said Saddam told his wife in Saddam's meeting Monday with relatives of hostages that her twin brother, John Stevenson, would soon be allowed to go. ``She and her two brothers met with Saddam Hussein sometime this morning and he said `sure, take him,''' said Trundy, who spoke with his wife by telephone. Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash., also apparently was among those promised freedom. ``I believe I'm coming home,'' Harrington said in a telephone call to his wife, Najmi, at the family's Bellevue home. The family of Clyde Jesse, an American living in Kuwait, said Jesse was also to be freed. In other developments: -Six hundred Kuwaiti volunteers completed six weeks of basic training in Saudi Arabia. Some will join the regular Kuwaiti army serving near the border with their homeland, while others will serve in support positions. Some 3,000 to 5,000 Kuwaiti troops are part of the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. -An Indian cargo ship will unload its remaining 4,700 tons of rice for foreigners trapped in Iraq, Indian reports said. Iraq had refused to let the cargo ship leave the port of Umm Qasr with the rice. The ship arrived in Iraq in early September with food and supplies for Indians in Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Five Permanent Members in U.N. Agree on Use-of-Force Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 5th graf `Monday's accord' to RECAST language on abstention, ADDS that all five voted on earlier resolutions. Picks up 6th graf, `The broad...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and China joined the United States, Britain and France on Monday in delivering an ultimatum that gives Iraq until January to withdraw its troops from Kuwait or face a military strike. The nations - the five permanent Security Council members with veto power - agreed Monday on a draft resolution that allows use of ``all necessary means'' to liberate Kuwait and restore its government. The draft contains optional deadline dates - Jan. 1 or Jan. 15. It gives Iraq one last chance in ``a pause of goodwill.'' The deadline in the final resolution, to be adopted Thursday, will be decided in consultations among the 15 council members, diplomats said. Monday's accord ends speculation the Soviets and Chinese might abstain. Previously, the Kremlin and Beijing indicated only they would not veto the measure. Now a positive vote by the Soviet Union and China seems assured on the proposed resolution. All five permament members voted on the 10 earlier resolutions passed against Iraq. The broad coalition against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait now has passed its toughest test - authorization of military force. The resolution demands that Iraq withdraw and authorizes ``all necessary means'' - meaning military force - to drive Iraqi invaders from Kuwait. But it decides ``to allow Iraq one final opportunity, as a pause of goodwill,'' to leave the sheikdom it invaded Aug. 2. The measure is expected to be adopted at an extraordinary session of foreign ministers. It would mark the second time in U.N. history the Security Council authorized military action to counter aggression. The first was in 1950 during the Korean conflict. The council also authorized military action to enforce the maritime embargo of Iraq and the blockade against Rhodesia - now black-ruled Zimbabwe - in 1966. British Ambassador David Hannay told reporters the January deadline, whether the first or 15th ``is not a pause for good offices.'' ``It is a pause in which we all are making clear that no new measures will be taken against Iraq prior to the end of that period, after which the authorization to use all measures ... which includes the use of force, would become available,'' he said. The envoy said Britain supports a Jan. 1 deadline because that would mean ``nearly six months that Iraq has been in illegal occupation of Kuwait and long enough to realize the world is united against it.'' The United states also favors Jan. 1, but U.S. officials in Washington indicated the resolution and date were negotiable. Kuwait was preparing a presentation for the Security Council on Tuesday - including a videotape - to portray what it describes as Iraqi atrocities since the invasion, including the murder of children and looting of hospitals. Soviet Ambassador Yuliy M. Vorontsov told reporters Monday as he entered consultations ``there is broad agreement'' among the five. He did not specify the deadline for Iraqi troop withdrawal, but Western and other diplomats said the Soviets favor more time for peace efforts. The draft resolution would authorize ``member states cooperating with the government of Kuwait, unless Iraq on or before Jan. 1 (15) 1991, fully implements the foregoing resolutions (calling for withdrawal), to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council resolutions passed in response to Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait, and to restore international peace and security.' The resolution text, obtained by The Associated Press, says that despite all U.N. efforts ``Iraq refuses to comply with its obligation'' to heed U.N. resolutions demanding withdrawal from Kuwait ``in flagrant contempt of the council.'' It cites Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes use of military force to counter aggression, if sanctions and other steps fail. Foreign diplomats said they expect the proposal to be amended before the vote this week, noting some member states are against imposing a deadline for withdrawal of Saddam Hussein's troops from Kuwait. Judith Kipper, an associate at Brookings Institute, a Washington research group, said it would be a mistake for the Bush administration to try to set a deadline. Ms. Kipper, who just returned from Baghdad where she met the Iraqi president, said: ``To put a date is to put his back to the wall and make things impossible. If we go public, it's a guarantee that we'll have to go to war.'' The United States has the nine votes needed to ensure passage, and the vote is likely Thursday or Friday. Any permanent member could block the resolution, but a veto is considered unlikely. The United States consulted with the other four permanent members Monday in an attempt to agree on final wording of the resolution. Informal talks also were held with the other council members. U.S. officials want to secure a resolution on use of force before turning the December presidency over to Yemen, which has favored Iraq in the past. Other Security Council members at present are Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Many Die in Iraq Because of Medicine Shortage
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said Monday that many Iraqis were dying because United Nations sanctions were depriving them of medicine, the official Iraqi news agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted him Monday as telling relatives of three American hostages about to be freed that the United States - in the forefront of the effort to push Iraq out of Kuwait - was responsible for the deaths. ``But do you know, ladies and gentlemen, how many children and people died as a result of the United States denying medicine to the people of Iraq?'' INA quoted him as saying. ``Go to the hospitals and ask them to supply us with lists, we will find out what great number of people are dying as a result of being deprived of medicine.'' Diplomatic sources have discounted previous Iraqi claims it was short of medicine. Foreign hospital staff leaving Iraq have not reported any gaps in drugs, although they said Iraq lacked medical personnel in some specialized fields like pediatrics. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, noted that tons of medicine have been flown in weekly from European nations seeking hostage releases. The latest large shipment was 25 tons from Italy on Saturday. Medical shipments qualify as humanitarian aid, not barred under the U.N. trade embargo. Kuwaiti officials have said they had a six-month stockpile of medicine for almost 2 million people in Kuwait that Iraq seized after its Aug. 2 invasion. The diplomatic sources said Iraq was claiming a shortage of medicine to stockpile supplies for the military in case the Persian Gulf confrontation erupts. Saddam said no foreigners died as a result of not being allowed to leave Iraq, INA reported. He told the American families that Iraqis were also unhappy that hundreds of foreigners were barred from leaving. ``But our only excuse lies in the intention, we do not intend to harm anybody or deny anybody his rights,'' he said. ``We only intended to add factors that might make some of those who seek war hesitate a little to think better.'' President Bush and other leaders have said the hostages will not be a factor in deciding whether to attack Iraq, and called for the immediate release of all hostages. Saddam repeated his call for peace by alluding to Iraq's 1980-88 war with Iran. ``We know very well what war means because we have been through it. We also know that should this war take place, it will be very horrifying, both for humanity in general and for the interests of mankind,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Second Mistrial Frees Man Accused of Shooting Ex-Wife, Killer Her Lover
DOC.TEXT: A man whose ex-wife awoke from months in a coma and accused him of shooting her and killing her boyfriend walked free Monday after the second mistrial in his case. George Gurney won his freedom when a lone juror's dissent led to a mistrial. It was the second hung jury in five months. The Rockingham County Superior Court jury had deliberated 14 hours since early last week before telling Judge Douglas Gray they were deadlocked with 11 votes to convict and one to acquit, Assistant Attorney General Michael Ramsdell said. Prosecutors had decided not to seek a third trial if the jury couldn't reach a verdict. Miriam Stoltz-Gurney, 48, was found in woods near her Windham home in February 1989, shot in the head and left for dead. Nearly five months passed before she regained consciousness. But when she did come around, Stoltz-Gurney identified her ex-husband as her assailant. Neither the jurors nor Gurney, 54, would speak to reporters. Defense lawyer Albert Scherr said Gurney was relieved and felt good. Gurney of Newburyport, Mass., was a newspaper advertising salesman when he was arrested last year. He had been behind bars ever since. Stoltz-Gurney told authorities that she and her boyfriend, Roger Whittemore, were surprised the night of the assault by a man wearing camouflage fatigues who burst into her home and beat, stabbed and shot Whittemore. Whittemore, 52, was found dead at the scene. Gurney was charged with first-degree murder, attempted murder and kidnapping. Stoltz-Gurney is now in a rehabilitation center in Boston. Last June, a mistrial was declared in Gurney's first trial after jurors deliberated 19 hours and failed to reach a verdict. Half voted to convict him, half to acquit him. The testimony by Stoltz-Gurney was all the prosecution had to put Gurney at the scene. The defense hammered at the reliability of her memory, calling experts who testified that people with her kind of head injury sometimes create memories to fill in gaps in their actual recall.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan President Says Proposals Made to End Civil War
DOC.TEXT: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said Monday he has received proposals from the exiled king and Moslem rebels that could help end the 12-year-old civil war. Najibullah said the proposals from former King Zahir Shah and the mujahedeen guerrillas were made last week during his four-day trip to Geneva. He did not give details of the plans. ``We talked with a number of opposition leaders and exchanged views for a political settlement,'' the 43-year-old president told a news conference in the Afghan capital of Kabul. His remarks were broadcast later by state Kabul Radio on a program directed toward the more than 5 million Afghan refugees living in neighboring Iran and Pakistan. ``I can say that I am pleased and satisfied with the results of that meeting. It could be the real foundation for future meetings,'' he said. The Afghan president also said he stopped briefly in Mashad, Iran, en route to Geneva for talks with government officials. About nine guerrilla groups are headquartered in Iran. Najibullah and his government have repeatedly claimed to have had contacts with the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, over the past two years. However, they have refused to disclose the names. Najibullah again on Monday refused to give details of the meetings, saying it could damage the peace process. But guerrilla leaders based in Pakistan have accused the Kabul government of concocting stories about peace talks to try to undermine and further divide the resistance. One guerrilla leader also accused the fundamentalist guerrillas of launching a smear campaign to link the more moderate leaders who favor the return of the former king with Najibullah. The fundamentalist have threatended to kill the former king if he returns from exile in Rome. At least two Pakistani English-language newspapers carried front-page stories Monday, claiming the two most moderate guerrilla leaders had met this month with Najibullah. The Muslim and The Frontier Post said Pir Sayed Ahmed Gailani, leader of the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan, met Najibullah in Geneva and that Sibghatullah Mojaddidi, leader of one of the smallest guerrilla groups, met the Afghan president earlier in Iran. Both newspapers based their reports on Afghan News Agency, run by fundamentalist leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and often criticized for its highly exaggerated reports and erroneous information. NIFA spokesman Azim Nasser-Zia denied reports. ``It was physically nt possible,'' he said. For more than 12 years, the guerrillas headquartered in Pakistan have been fighting to topple successive Communist governments in Afghanistan. After the Soviet army intervened in Afghanistan in 1979, Washington sent billions of dollars to the resistance. Pakistan has served as the conduit for U.S.-supplied weapons, but Western diplomats said Washington has little control over the allocation of arms. It is widely known that Hekmatyar's Hezb-i-Islami, or Party of Islam, receives the lions' share of weapons even though it is the most anti-Western of the seven guerrilla groups.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vietnames Premier Nguyen Van Tam Dead at 97
DOC.TEXT: Nguyen Van Tam, prime minister to former Vietnamese emperor Bao Dai, has died, his family said Monday. He was 97. Nguyen died Friday, family members said. Cause of death was not given for Nguyen, who had lived in exile here the last 35 years. Nguyen was president of the Vietnamese Council from 1952-53 after holding several ministerial posts from 1946. He was nicknamed the Tiger of Cai Lay for eliminating communist Vietnamese resistance groups in the Cai Lay region of the Mekong Delta. Named chief of criminal investigations in Saigon in 1950, he put an end to a series of assassination attempts by the communist resistance. Nguyen had French nationality since 1927 and was awarded several decorations by the French government including commander of the Legion of Honor. Details on surviving family members were not available.

DOC.HEAD: State Abandons Effort to Evict Elderly Squatter From Beach-Front Home
DOC.TEXT: Decades of stubbornness paid off - at least temporarily - for Doris Gagnon Monday when the state abandoned its effort to evict the 73-year-old squatter from her makeshift beachfront home. The state had until Friday to evict Gagnon from her compound of shacks and trailers in Milford on Long Island Sound so it could proceed with plans laid 19 years ago to build a park. Attorney General Clarine Nardi Riddle said she wouldn't enforce the order because the the state Department of Environmental Protection decided it didn't immediately need Gagnon's land. For two decades Gagnon refused to sell her house and half acre and stood fast when the state marshaled its legal forces against her. On Monday, Gagnon was as steadfast as ever. She said she'll never give up her sandy plot bordered on three sides by tall marsh grass. Nevermind that she has no electricity, running water or telephone - this is home, with a family of cats, dogs, chickens, geese and ducks. ``They met somebody that wasn't afraid of them,'' she said, standing outside the combination chain-link and chicken-wire fence that surrounds her property. ``For 39 years I give it right back,'' she said. ``Thank God. With God's help I've been able to take it and I'll take it until this case is over. I won't give them the satisfaction of dying.'' Gagnon's battle with the state began in the mid-1960s, when about 100 cottages in her neighborhood were torn down to make way for a state park. She refused to sell. The state seized her house and land under the right of eminent domain and her house was demolished in 1971. Gagnon was to get $15,000 for her land. She refused to take the money. Instead, Gagnon stayed as a squatter. The state sought an eviction order in 1988, after Milford health officials expressed concern about squalid conditions including bags of human waste piled behind her living quarters. In her battle with the state, Gagnon argued she was never fairly compensated for her property, and that she should receive an amount equal to its current market worth. Riddle also said she had been assured by Milford health officials that sanitary problems cited in the original court action had improved. ``There are times when circumstances change,'' Riddle said. ``We are dealing with changed circumstances here.'' Riddle said the decision doesn't mean Gagnon can stay indefinitely. Eviction efforts could resume in two to three years, when the land is more likely to be needed, she said. ``This is only a postponement,'' Riddle said. ``If it becomes necessary because the state needs the land, the state will be prepared to go forward with evicting her.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Flee Camp Under Rebel Attack
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebel fighters are hunting down government soldiers who fled a beseiged military camp into the swampy jungles in northern Sri Lanka, a guerrlla leader said Monday. The government statement said 150 soldiers were missing and more than 100 of them were feared dead. It also claimed 196 rebels were killed in the clash before government troops retreated Saturday. The rebel militia said its fighters found 158 bodies of soldiers in the camp, and 30 guerrillas were killed. The reports could not be independently confirmed. Both sides are known to make exaggerated claims. Military officials said the troops made a ``tactical withdrawal'' after Tamil forces stormed a military encampment in Mankulam, about 160 miles northeast of Colombo. ``We regard the capture of Mankulam camp as a great victory,'' a rebel leader, Sathasivam Krishnakumar, said in a telephone interview from London. The fall of the camp is one of the worst setbacks suffered by the government since rebels resumed their separatist campaign in June this year. In September, the Tiger rebels killed 60 soldiers when they overran the Kokavil army camp, 10 miles north of Mankulam. Krishnakumar said at least 250 soldiers have fled into the jungles. ``They have split into small groups or individuals and are lost. Our cadres are hunting them down,'' he said. The nearest military garrison is Vavuniya, 30 miles south of Mankulam. ``The troops will never make it there,'' Krishnakumar said. The Tamil guerrillas seek an independent nation, claiming they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese majority in jobs and education. More than 14,000 people have been killed since Tamils started the separatist campaign in 1983. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people. Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of Sri Lanka's population, control the government and military. With the fall of Mankulam, the government now controls only five isolated military bases in the predominantly rebel-controlled north. President Ranasinghe Premadasa called an emergency government meeting Monday to discuss the Mankulam attack, senior government officials said. Details of the meeting were not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Vice President Steps Down from Dual Education Ministry Job
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's communist regime has replaced Vice President Jose Ramon Fernandez as education minister with educator Luis Ignacio Gomez Gutierrez, the Mexican official news agency Notimex reported Monday. Fernandez, whose formal title is Vice President of the Council of Ministers, has held both jobs for more than two decades, and the decision to replace him in the education slot was taken by the Political Bureau of the Cuban Communist Party, Notimex said. A Notimex dispatch from Havana quoted in a party news release as saying this was the third change in the council this month, but gave no reason for Fernandez's replacement. Gomez Gutierrez was rector of Central University at Las Villas Province. The dispatch from the Cuban capital, monitored here, said Fernandez will continue to serve as president of the Organizing Committee of the 1991 Pan American Games in Havana.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Officials Back Off Restart Date for Savannah River Site Reactors
DOC.TEXT: Just weeks before the scheduled restart of the first Savannah River Site reactor, the Energy Department said Monday it doesn't know when the plant's three reactors will begin operations. A top agency official Monday also said the Energy Department might not need to restart all three reactors to continue meeting the nation's needs for nuclear weapons materials. Deputy Secretary Henson Moore said the Savannah River reactors aren't ready to be restarted because they still fail to meet Energy Department standards. In an interview with The Augusta Chronicle, Moore refused to be specific about when the reactors might be restarted. Moore was in the Augusta area Monday to present a grant to the South Carolina Universities Research and Education Foundation. The reactors, located in South Carolina about 30 minutes east of Augusta, are the nation's sole production source of plutonium and tritium, two key elements in nuclear weapons. Tritium, a radioactive gas used to boost the explosive power of nuclear weapons, decays at the rate of about 5.5 percent a year and must be replenished in warheads periodically. All three reactors have been shut down since August 1988 for safety improvements. In May, Energy Secretary James Watkins said the first reactor would be restarted in December or January, and the other two reactors would restart by six months later. Nuclear experts, including Watkins, previously have said that a delay in the timetable could result in a dismantling of some nuclear weapons because enough of the tritium in them would have decayed to render them useless. But Moore said Monday such time pressure no longer exists. ``The Soviet Union is changing, and the pressure on us to have a certain amount of nuclear materials by a certain date is changing to where we are not under any bind in the foreseeable future,'' Moore said. Moore said the previously scheduled restart dates were simply an estimate by the department made at Congress' request. He said the department never intended to restart the reactors until they met department standards. ``Our schedule has always been that when they're ready, they will operate. Our standards still haven't been met, and so therefore, those reactors aren't going to run,'' Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Fire Forces Down U.S.-Supplied Government Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels shot down an air force helicopter in eastern El Salvador on Monday, three days after downing a jet fighter. The armed forces said the pilot and co-pilot sustained minor injuries when the UH-1M crash-landed after being hit by guerrilla ground fire. The rocket-equipped helicopter went down near Jiquilisco, 50 miles east of San Salvador. Air force mechanics were on the scene at midday, salvaging the turbine engine of the U.S.-supplied copter as well as munitions and avionics. The fuselage and rotors of the U.S.-made helicopter were damaged beyond repair, and officers on the scene said the stripped hulk would be left where it crashed. The helicopter was hit by ground fire while providing air support to government forces battling guerrillas along the coastal highway. The rebels downed an A-37 Dragonfly jet fighter last week with a surface-to-air missile. It was their first successful use of the missiles in the 11-year-old civil war. In other fighting Monday, commandos from the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front ambushed an army infantry patrol in the western sector of the capital. The armed forces press office said six soldiers were wounded. It also said the FMLN bombed five bank offices during the night in El Salvador. There were no injuries, it said. So far 91 people have died and 309 have been wounded in the military campaign launched last week by the FMLN. The rebel high command said the push is aimed at pushing the government into making concessions at the negotiating table on sweeping reforms in the armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Kill 7 Hindus, 10 Others
DOC.TEXT: Sikh militants forced a Hindu man inside his home in a Punjab town and fatally shot him, his parents and a sister on Monday, police said. Press Trust of India said the gunmen shot three neighbors while fleeing after the attack in Ludhiana, 96 miles south of Amritsar, the center of a Sikh secessionist movement. Senior police superintendent Paramjit Singh Sandhu said four Sikh militants drove in a car to the shop of a HIndu youth and led him at gunpoint to his home next door. Inside, the gunmen fired indiscriminately with Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, killing the man, his 60-year-old father Ram Lubhya, his mother and a sister. The names of the other victims were not immediately available. The slayings were the latest in a series of organized killings by Sikh extremists in the northern state where they want to set up an independent nation. On Sunday, Sikh gunmen raided a shopping center and a residential neighborhood in another Punjab town and killed 16 Hindus in indiscriminate gunfire. The attack occurred 56 miles east of Amritsar. Police said Sikh militants killed three Hindus in separate attacks on Monday in Tarn Taran district outside Amritsar. Elsewhere in the state, a rich farming district on the Pakistani border, seven people were killed by the militants, Press Trust of India said. Sikh extremists have killed 231 people the past two weeks in ambushes, bombings and massacres in the state. Victims have included Hindu passengers pulled out of buses, shoppers, residents, policemen and Hindus doing morning exercises. At least 2,975 people have been killed in Punjab this year in the Sikh insurgency. Sikh separatists began their campaign for independence in 1982, complaining of political and economic discrimination by the majority Hindus. Sikhs are in a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab, but nationwide they comprise 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Resigns, Handpicked Successor to Take Over
DOC.TEXT: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of this island republic for 31 years, submitted his resignation on Monday to make way for his handpicked successor. Lee, who had been expected to step down, gave his letter of resignation to President Wee Kim Wee. Lee's chosen successor, Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, 49, is to be sworn in on Wednesday. Lee, 67, is to remain as a senior minister in Goh's Cabinet and also continue as secretary-general of the ruling People's Action Party, which holds 80 of the 81 elected seats in Parliament. Goh recently appointed Lee's eldest son, Trade and Industry Minister Lee Hsien Loong, 38, as one of two deputy prime ministers. Political analysts say that Lee's retention of the party leadership and the ascendency of his son will ensure that no fundamental changes will take place. Goh himself has said his administration plans no major policy initiatives. Goh has been first deputy prime minister of Singapore since 1984. Currently minister of defense as well as deputy prime minister, he served a 13-year apprenticeship in Lee's Cabinet. Goh said the current session of Parliament would end about two months after he takes over, following enactment of a bill to change the office of president. Parliament is to amend the constitution to elect and give executive powers to the now ceremonial and appointive presidency. Lee suggested the changes in 1984, but insists he is not interested in the revamped presidency. Goh has a master's degree in economics from Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., and was a shipping executive before entering politics.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Nov. 19-26:
DOC.HEAD: Daily News Sues Strikers, Loses Major Advertisers
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News, fighting to keep advertisers and circulation in the midst of a strike by union employees, sued 11 people for allegedly burning a delivery truck, stealing bundled papers or attacking replacement drivers. Each of the three lawsuits filed in state court Nov. 20 seeks $100,000 in punitive damages and unspecified compensatory damages. They claim the defendants have hurt the paper's ability to do business. On Nov. 23, one of the News' biggest advertisers, Macy's department store, said it had dropped its ads in the paper. The News' two tabloid rivals, the New York Post and New York Newsday, have reported large advertising and circulation gains since the strike began Oct. 25. ``This is obviously all strike-related,'' Newsday spokeswoman Chiara Coletti said. Newsday's Nov. 23 paper had 192 advertising pages, 24 more than a year ago. The Post on the same day had 90 ad pages, 40 more than last year's. The Daily News, which declined to comment on the departure of advertisers, had 47 pages of advertising. Nine unions are striking the newspaper over what they term unfair labor conditions. The Daily News has published every day since the strike began, but many vendors have declined to sell it. It had a daily circulation of 1.09 million before the strike. The newspaper said it is now printing 600,000 papers a day and getting 400,000 to customers. New York Newsday officials said their paper's daily circulation has risen from about 150,000 before the strike to about 340,000. The paper's Long Island edition has a circulation of about 600,000. Post officials said their newspaper's circulation is up from about 500,000 before the strike to between 700,000 and 750,000. The News' lawsuits filed in connection with the strike include videotapes made by management, said John T. Sloan, vice president for human resources. One lawsuit claims that a member of the striking drivers union set fire to a truck outside the paper's Brooklyn printing plant. Another claims two Wall Street Journal drivers stole bundles of the News that had been left off at a drop-off point by non-union drivers. The third lawsuit accuses eight people of attacking non-union drivers and independent distributors at a paper drop-off point. In a separate court action, strikers won a victory when U.S. District Court Judge Jack B. Weinstein issued a temporary restraining order Nov. 20 permitting striking pressmen to expand pickets outside the Brooklyn plant. The pressmen complained management and police infringed on their rights by confining pickets to side streets on either end of the block-long plant. Strike leaders have complained that police have taken the company's side in the dispute. On Nov. 19, union officials presented Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown with a letter asking that the department investigate ``growing hostility by police officers against Daily News workers.'' Daily News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson called the union allegations outrageous. ``The police are just trying to preserve peace and justice,'' she said. ``They're out there trying to do their job. All around them crimes are happening at the hands of the union.'' A spokesman for the department said the cost of police staffing plus overtime since the strike began was estimated at more than $5.6 million. Police have recorded about 195 strike-related incidents and made at least 89 arrests, said Officer Scott Bloch, the spokesman. He said most of the incidents reported have involved attacks on Daily News trucks and allegations of harassment of vendors.
DOC.HEAD: CNN Hands Over Noriega Prison Tapes to Judge
DOC.TEXT: CNN has turned over its tapes of Manuel Noriega's jailhouse phone calls so that a federal magistrate can help determine whether Noriega's right to a fair trial has been jeopardized. The network handed over a briefcase full of tapes Nov. 20 after the U.S. Supreme Court refused to lift U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's temporary order barring CNN from airing the recordings. U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff will make and study transcripts and report to Hoeveler, who will preside over Noriega's trial on drug trafficking charges and will weigh a defense request to dismiss the case. Hoeveler assigned Turnoff to listen to the tapes to avoid being ``tainted'' by having learned details of Noriega's defense strategy. No time limit for reviewing the tapes was set, but Noriega's lead attorney, Frank Rubino, said the judge guaranteed it would done ``with dispatch.'' Rubino also asked Hoeveler to set a contempt hearing against CNN for airing a conversation in alleged violation of the judge's order. The judge did not immediately set a hearing, saying he must await a decision by the chief judge of his judicial district on a CNN request to remove him from the tapes case. CNN attorney Steven Korn wouldn't say how many tapes were turned over. He would not discuss their contents or origins but said he was confident that the judge will rescind the order not to broadcast the tapes. He said CNN believes it never violated the judge's order because the telecast conversations did not deal with matters protected by attorney-client confidentiality - in part because Rubino tacitly agreed to broadcasting them when he identified them on the air. Noriega has asked that the case against him be dismissed because of the taping, the freezing of his assets, and other alleged government misconduct. The fallen dictator is jailed near Miami on charges of taking bribes to protect the cocaine trade. His trial isn't expected to begin before the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Town Bracing for Journalists Covering Quake Projection
DOC.TEXT: Despite a controversial projection about a massive Midwest earthquake, some residents along the New Madrid Fault are more worried about getting knocked down by a TV truck than a temblor in early December. ``We've got reporters running out our ears,'' New Madrid Police Chief Jim Helms said. ``They've been here from Washington, Michigan, Kansas City, Oklahoma and as far south as Houston, Texas. We've had them every day.'' New Madrid, a town of about 3,300 in southeastern Missouri, has become earthquake central for much of the media zeroing in on Iben Browning's projection and the accompanying anxiety in the region. Browning is a New Mexico scientist-business consultant who says his research shows conditions will be right for a major earthquake along the New Madrid Fault about Dec. 2-3. He has projected a 50-50 chance. He based his projections on tidal forces, which will be particularly strong at that time. Most scientists discount his tidal theory but say that eventually there will be a powerful earthquake along the fault. Browning's projection nevertheless has led school officials in communities in at least four states to call off classes. It also has renewed attention to earthquake preparedness in a region that experiences several hundred tremors a year that range from minor to imperceptible. The New Madrid Fault zone runs roughly from Marked Tree in northeast Arkansas, across the Missouri Bootheel and up to near Cairo in southern Illinois. Since reports of Browning's work came to light earlier this year, the media have focused increasing attention on the New Madrid zone. Television stations from throughout the region have done ratings-month series on the projection, the fault zone and earthquake preparedness. Reporters have descended from Detroit, Minneapolis, Baltimore and Tampa, Fla. People magazine and the television program ``Unsolved Mysteries'' also have been to town. Although New Madrid residents have become used to being interviewed, the town is bracing for Monday, Dec. 3, when the reporters, photographers, engineers and producers are expected back en masse. Helms said three blocks may be roped off to accommodate the television satellite trucks that will roll into town. Motel rooms have been snatched up. Maor Dick Phillips is understanding. He'll have to work as usual at Phillips Fertilizer Co. on Dec. 3 and then conduct a city council meeting that evening, but he'll also try to be available for interviews. The situation raises questions for the media: Is the possibility of an earthquake, discounted by most experts, a story? Do you send a reporter just in case, or do you ignore it and hope you don't miss what could be the region's biggest story of the year? Editors across the country are deciding. ``We're going mainly expecting nothing to happen,'' said Susan Okie, acting science editor at the Washington Post. ``This is a story because of the excitement it's generated.'' The feeling is the same at the Baltimore Sun, said National Editor Ed Goodpaster. ``It's like any other prediction. There are those that you really have to pay attention to to see whether anything does happen,'' Goodpaster said. ``If it does happen, you're in a good position to report on it, and if it doesn't happen, it's a good story, too.''
DOC.HEAD: Kids Dress Up Magazines for Troops in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: American teen-agers in Germany have launched a ``cover-up'' mission for Persian Gulf soldiers yearning for reading material. Using marking pens and an eye for what may offend Saudi sensibilities, the teens have been drawing over pictures of scantily clad people and advertisements for alcohol and tobacco products. ``The original plan was that they were just going to cut out the pictures, but after the first three magazines they had edited out, there was nothing left,'' said U.S. Air Force 2nd Lt. Bryan Stokstad, who organized the magazine drive. Stokstad said he got the idea after reading an article in the unofficial military newspaper Stars and Stripes ``that the morale down there was just a little bit low'' because troops didn't have enough current publications. ``They were receiving the Stars and Stripes, but they were getting issues a week late, and just for them to circulate around it would take even longer,'' Stockstad said Nov. 22. Since the project was started in mid-October the volunteers have sent out 2,500 pounds of magazines to Saudi Arabia through the military postal system.
DOC.HEAD: Cave-In Forces UPI To Evacuate Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: United Press International had to evacuate its headquarters after a cave-in at an adjacent construction site Nov. 20. The news service continued to operate with help from Reuters and from National Public Radio. A 100-foot-long section of sidewalk and part of a downtown street slid into the four-story-deep hole as workers tried to shore up the construction site from an earlier collapse. No injuries were reported. The cave-in forced other businesses to evacuate and threatened to cut power to portions of downtown. UPI moved some of its operations to its computer headquarters in Vienna, Va., and to the Senate press gallery at the Capitol. The staff began returning to the headquarters building the following day. Spokesman Milt Capps said Reuters helped UPI distribute photographs to its clients, and National Public Radio was helping maintain its broadcast and audio network services.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Changes Policy in Abuse Reporting After Court Threat
DOC.TEXT: The Sheridan Press was threatened with a contempt of court citation for a story written about a pre-trial hearing in a child abuse case. In the story, the victim was reported to be the defendant's daughter. The newspaper did not name the victim, but did report that she was the daughter of the accused, who was named. District Court Judge James Wolfe said the daughter was implicitly identified. ``In the story you identified the victim,'' the judge wrote. ``In the court file is an order restricting information that would identify the minor victim.'' Sheridan Press Managing Editor Bruce Moats said after talking with the counselor involved in the abuse case - and before he received the judge's letter on Nov. 16 - he changed newspaper policy and will no longer identify the relationship of victims in pre-trial hearings.
DOC.HEAD: Sunday Grit Shutting Down, National Grit To Remain
DOC.TEXT: The Sunday Grit weekly newspaper will stop publishing at the end of the year, Executive Editor Michael R. Rafferty said. Rafferty said the newspaper's owner, Stauffer Communications Inc., decided to close it after the daily Williamsport Sun-Gazette announced plans to launch a Sunday edition. ``Stauffer doesn't feel this market can support two Sunday newspapers,'' Rafferty said Nov. 20. Sunday Grit has a staff of 16, half of them editorial employees. The company said some of them will be offered jobs at Grit magazine, a national, general-interest weekly that Stauffer publishes from Williamsport. Stauffer bought Grit from Advo Systems in 1983, which had bought it two years earlier from the Lamade family of Williamsport. The newspaper was started in 1884.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editor Accused of Impersonating Prosecutor Cleared
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed all charges Nov. 20 against the former chief editor of the Johnstown Tribune-Democrat, accused of impersonating a state prosecutor and pressuring a man suing his brother to back off. Theodore N. Beitchman won the dismissal after he and a former subordinate testified he was not at work when the harassing telephone calls were made. Beitchman, who resigned as editor in chief after his arrest Oct. 1, told District Justice Susan McEwen he went home sick after working less than a half-hour on March 13, the day of the telephone calls. The newspaper's managing editor, Larry Hudson, testified that he supervised the newspaper's production that day, supporting Beitchman's contention. Beitchman, 44, was accused of calling Henry Malinowski, identifying himself as an assistant attorney general and pressuring Malinowski to drop a lawsuit against Beitchman's brother. Telephone showed the calls were made from the Johnstown newspaper to Malinowski's home and business on March 13, but McEwen said there was no proof Beitchman made them. Chief Deputy District Attorney Ted Fritsch said he was considering refiling charges, using additional evidence, but he declined to elaborate.
DOC.HEAD: Gannett Buys Four Salem-Area Publications
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Nov. 20 approved the sale of four Salem-area newspapers and shopping publications to Gannett Co. Inc. Gannett plans to buy the Stayton Mail, the Silverton Appeal-Tribune, the Mid-Willamette Advertiser and the North Santiam Advertiser, said Frank Crow, owner of the North Santiam Newspapers Inc. Crow took over the papers about 18 months ago from Howard Woodall Jr. and later filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Crow said the newspapers had been profitable but accumulated too much long-term debt due to a succession of sales. He said the two weekly newspapers and the shoppers have a combined circulation of about 18,000. His attorney, Albert Kennedy, said that after debts are settled, the remainder of the sale proceeds will be divided among Crow, Woodall and one other former newspaper owner to settle their combined $1.1 million interest in the publishing company.
DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Publisher Burns Himself
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese newspaper publisher who recently moved from California to Washington burned himself to death on the steps of the Capitol on Nov. 19. Acquaintances said Nguyen Kim Bang, 56, had been distressed about the treatment of his fellow countrymen in Germany and about his own strained ties with a newspaper in California, the Vietnam Daily News of San Jose. He reportedly moved to Washington two months ago to help start a newspaper in northern Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Church Punishes Magazine Execs for Discipline Article, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of an independent Mormon magazine that reported reprimands of church members have been punished themselves, a Salt Lake newspaper said. Temple privileges of Daniel H. Rector, publisher of Sunstone, and Elbert E. Peck, the magazine's editor, were revoked after the article was published in mid-October, The Salt Lake Tribune reported. The magazine story recounted the church's reaction to news accounts about changes in Mormon Church temple ceremonies.
