DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama remains an exile from the land he fled more than 30 years ago. His fight to free his people from Chinese sway continues. A Nobel Peace Prize winner, his only weapon is persuasion. But privately he wonders if there is any hope, or whether there is any future for the role of a Dalai Lama. ---

There is something incongruous in the scene - the Dalai Lama seated robed and cross-legged on a baby blue upholstered easy chair in the Royal Suite of Toronto's Royal York Hotel where reproductions of 18th century European paintings gather dust on the walls. But then, there is also something incongruous about a Buddhist monk leading 6 million Tibetans in a struggle for self-determination in their Himalayan homeland, using kindness as his only weapon against the ruling Chinese. He warmly grasps the hand of his interviewer in both of his, smiling, frequently laughing. He makes self-deprecating jokes or tells humorous stories of his childhood. Obligatorily, he speaks about Chinese politics and violations of human rights in the land he fled in 1959 after an abortive uprising, a land Tibetans say is an independent country under occupation and Beijing says is an integral part of China. But his eyes light up, his whole being comes alive when the subjet changes to peace, to kindness, to human nature, to a world without violence. Some of the restless youths who live at his headquarters in exile at Dharmsala, India, sometimes grow impatient with his methods. ``I always tell them my reasons,'' he says softly, sipping tea. ``Firstly, violence is against human nature. Then, secondly, through violence, although you may achieve something, you may solve some problem, violence always creates a second problem. It may be useful, but the side effect is immense. Then, in our case, if we follow a more violent nature, we may lose many good supporters.'' Peace? What that means depends very much on your definition of the word, says the winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize. On one level, peace may be simply the absence of violence. On another, he says after considerable reflection, it is the absence of fear. ``Since the second world war, during the Cold War, there has been some kind of peace,'' says the maroon- and saffron-robed monk, warming to his subject. ``But that peace was not a genuine peace. That peace was something like the mere absence of war. Bascially, that kind of peace comes from fear. ``Now, today, I think peace is a genuine peace without fear, genuine in the sense of cooperation, or the sense of some kind of security, and working together. That's not the mere absence of war. That's much more positive, much more conceptive. ``Now that (kind of) peace, I have always believed, comes through mental peace, so first peace must be created here, in our minds,'' he says, tapping the sparse, short bristles on his head. ``Then as a reflection of that inner peace, peace atmosphere in the family, peace atmosphere in the community, in the country and on an international level.'' The Dalai Lama was born Lhamo Dhondrub on July 6, 1935 in a small village in northeastern Tibet. At the age of 2, he was, in accordance with tradition, found by a search party of monks and after a series of tests recognized as the reincarnation of his predecessor, the 13th Dalai Lama. He was renamed Jetsun Jamphel Ngawang Lobsang Yeshe Tenzin Gyatso, Holy Lord, Gentle Glory, Eloquent, Compassionate, Learned Defender of the Faith, Ocean of Wisdom.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
TORONTO: of Wisdom.
DOC.TEXT: In 1950, the Chinese Communists attacked and occupied Tibet, forcing the young Dalai Lama to step forward and attempt to deal with Peking. Nine years later, he fled over the mountains on a yak to India, setting up in exile. Much to the dismay of many of his followers, he is not convinced the Dalai Lama, an institution created 600 years ago, has much of a future. ``Some people get the impression that the Dalai Lama institution is an essential element of Buddhism. It is not,'' he says, leaning forward, peering seriously through his tinted glasses. ``Buddhism flourished in Tibet much earlier than the Dalai Lama institution. And also, some people get the idea that the Dalai Lama is something of a symbol for Tibet and without the Dalai Lama Tibet no longer exists or something. That is foolish.'' He says that he is ''just a Buddhist monk, although he readily admits that he is a unifying force for Tibetans. ``But this does not mean that the institution should always remain. It entirely depends on the wishes of the Tibetan people. If they feel the institution should be kept, then it will remain. If the majority of the people feel it doesn't matter, then the institution will cease. In that case, I will be the last Dalai Lama.'' Such talk makes many of his followers nervous. He laughs at their nervousness. Over 10 years between 1978 and 1988, there were a series of communications between the Dalai Lama and the authorities in Beijing, but according to the Tibetan leader, they were only interested in his return. They said he could come back to Tibet with all previous rights and privileges. ``I told them that this is not the case, the problem is 6 million people. It's their rights and their culture. And unless that basic problem is solved, the question of my return is meaningless.'' The Chinese, it seems, have an important sensory organ missing, he says with a belly laugh that echoes across the large sitting room of the hotel suite. ``That is the ear. They always lecture us. Always lecture, lecture, lecture. They never listen to our viewpoint. I think the world community now has to help with some aesthetic surgery to give them some new ears,'' he says, rocking back again with laughter. His peace proposals, first made public in 1987, and refined in 1988, call for less than total independence for Tibet, leaving defense and foreign affairs to the Chinese and all other matters in Tibetan hands. It also would allow a limited number of Chinese troops in Tibet, a regional peace conference, then ``a zone of peace with complete demilitarization.'' ``We're still awaiting a response.'' Much of Tibet's culture already has been destroyed by the Chinese, says the Dalai Lama, and official policy is to dilute Tibet in a sea of Chinese immigration. Time, he says, is running out. ``If the present situation remains another 15 years, then there is no hope. Then Tibetans become a very insignificant community in their own land.'' Nonetheless, he is persistently optimistic. The Beijing regime is very old, he theorizes, and it's only a matter of time. Younger, more reasonable Chinese leaders are on the way. ``The younger generation of Chinese, they themselves are fighting for their rights, for their democracy, for their freedom.'' But he'd rather talk about love and compassion. ``I am always trying to promote compassion and good heart,'' he says, the glow returning to his face. ``Not as a religious ideal, but rather as a humanitarian idea. I believe that little children are born free of any religion, free of any ideology, but not free of compassion. So I believe that compassion and love is the basic human quality.'' ``Hatred is also a human quality, but not the dominant one. The dominant force, in my mind, is compassion.''

DOC.TEXT: The ``Building of Tomorrow'' that Frank Lloyd Wright built 69 years ago has survived the worst of man and nature. But the great architect's legacy may meet its match in Tokyo's land fever. Marked by the horizontal planes and simple wood and mortar of Wright's ``Prairie style,'' the school sits cracked and leaking on a green square of land encroached by high-rises and construction cranes in one of Tokyo's busie sections. The approximately 3,000 square-yard plot owned by Jiyu Gakuen, or Freedom School, is worth at least $230 million dollars, according to the school's president, Gyo Hani. That may prove to be an offer the school can't refuse. The controversy over Myonichikan, or ``Building of Tomorrow,'' points up more than just the dominance of assets over aesthetics in Tokyo's constantly changing skyline, where few traditional structures remain since the fire-bombing of World War II. Architectural landmarks are rare and legal protections weak in a nation with a habit of rebuilding itself from fires, earthquakes and war. In Japan, says Prof. Hiroyuki Suzuki of Tokyo University, artistry bows to function. ``Generally speaking, Japanese love new buildings.'' Wright himself, the father of organic architecture, preached that ``the building should be a natural circumstance of the land.'' But the fields and farmhouses amid which he built Myonichikan in 1921 are no longer there. Today the building is used as a center for craft-making and other activities. Hani insists there is no plan to sell, but says financial security is his first priority as head of Jiyu Gakuen, now a 25-acre campus about 10 miles north. Hani's cousin, Yuko Hani, is seeking to raise the estimated $2 million needed to save Myonichikan. Both are related to the school's founders. ``If Japan is a great economic power, why doesn't it spend money on preserving these cultural assets?'' said Yuko Hani. ``In that sense we certainly can't call ourselves a civilized nation, can we?'' Wright, who died in 1959, designed the building while in Tokyo to supervise the construction of his Imperial Hotel, which was later razed. Along with a private home near Osaka, Myonichikan is the only Wright building left in Japan. Edwin Reischauer, the former U.S. ambassador to Japan who died this year, wrote that Myonichikan ``symbolized Japan's search in the 1920s to become a liberal, innovative nation and a free democratic society.'' Gyo Hani says symbols are nice but with $230 million in land underneath, ``we don't want to commit our posterity to giving up important assets.''

DOC.TEXT: Building prisons is a booming business these days as the nation's prison population swells. But take a look at what modern prisons look like inside and out. They are taking on the appearance of office buildings, and new designs cut in half the number of guards needed to supervise them. ---

The Baker-Miller shade of pink was supposed to have a calming effect on inmates. It did, but not for long. ``It worked for about 15 minutes,'' said Ann Balazs, resident color expert at L. Robert Kimball & Associates, a Pennsylvania design firm. ``After that, they went nuts.'' Picking a wall paint may seem a trifle, but in the growing field of prison design it's often the little things that count. Like where to put the exterior plate-glass windows now used to let in more natural light. In rural settings, waist-high windows work fine. Not so in urban areas, where inmates' temptation to moon passersby proves irresistible. The Ebensburg, Pa., firm founded by Mrs. Balazs' father has learned that lesson and countless others after 12 years designing more than 30 correctional facilities, from federal prisons to county jails. Executives say revenues have risen from $12 million to $26 million in the last five years, and there's no sign of a slowdown. That's because the country's inmate population continues to grow. The number of people behind bars has ballooned from about 500,000 just 10 years ago to nearly 1.1 million, according to the Bureau of Justice Statistics. And the National Council on Crime and Delinquency predicts the figure could reach 2 million by 1995. Prisons and jails built today are a far cry from the ones pictured in old Edward G. Robinson movies. Gone are the drab corridors painted in government green or hospital white. Designers are experimenting with blues, yellows and earth tones to soften the look. Baker-Miller pink failed to make the grade because researchers found its soothing effect only temporary. Given that quality, Mrs. Balazs said it's ideal for holding pens. To make prisons and jails more livable, designers have included such features as air conditioning, upholstery and carpeting. Stainless-steel toilets - once used because they were all but impossible to rip from the floor - are giving way to ceramic fixtures, some of them with seats. Wardens often hold out such amenities as a carrot to inmates who want to graduate to better living quarters within a facility. Even the exteriors have a different look. The bars, barbed wire and blockhouse style of older facilities made them easy to recognize. Modern prisons and jails are built to blend in with the surrounding area. L. Robert Kimball's newest jail, the Hillsborough County Correctional Facility in Manchester, N.H., looks more like an office complex, complete with landscaping. Other facilities have skylights, columns or floor-to-ceiling windows. Architects and wardens alike stress common sense rather than aesthetics is prompting the changes. The overall design strategy aims at reducing tensions and forestalling trouble. ``You used to have 100 inmates in a cellblock that was dark and filthy and not fit to be lived in. That created a very volatile situation,'' said Kevin Drinan, Hillsborough's director of corrections. Drinan contends better living conditions make for better inmates. ``Generally speaking, when you treat people like animals, they act like animals,'' he said. Critics complain the softer style has scant effect on hardened criminals. If anything, they fear it sends the wrong message. ``If prisons are cushy places, no one will mind going there,'' contends Edwin Delattre, who teaches applied ethics at Boston University and recently wrote ``Character and Cops.'' ``The purpose of prisons is to punish. It's unjust if they are too comfortable,'' he said. Like other modern jails, Hillsborough is designed according to the direct-supervision model approved by the National Institute of Corrections. The building is divided into self-contained areas that usually house 48 to 56 inmates. The inmates sleep, shower and dine in those areas, whose cells are arranged around a large day room. ``In the old days, you used to take the inmates to the services. Now, you take the services to the inmates,'' said Czaba Balazs, L. Robert Kimball's chief architect and son-in-law to the firm's founder and president. Because direct-supervision prisons require more space, Balazs says they cost 10 percent to 15 percent more than traditional facilities. But he contends they are less expensive in the long run because their layout limits the movement of inmates and therefore reduces by half the number of guards needed. Proponents of the direct-supervision models say safety is another factor. Because inmates are always within view of their guards, there are fewer fights, according to a study by the National Institute of Corrections. And the safer the environment, the less likely inmates will resort to vandalism or violence in the hope of being separated from others. Moreover, guards in direct-supervision facilities are assigned to the same areas and encouraged to work closely with inmates so they can identify problems before they get out of hand. ``A great part of it depends on the ability of the corrections officer not to be a tough guy but to be a good communicator,'' said Hillsborough's Drinan. ``In many cases, all these inmates need is someone who'll listen to them.'' That hands-on approach combined with design changes can be an effective defense against trouble, including uprisings and riots, Balazs said. ``The environment can have a direct impact on the level of stress. It's no different than you or I getting irritated because of working conditions. But at least we have options,'' he said. ``It's viewed as coddling inmates, but it's really not. The point is, if you make it too tough on them, they're going to make it tough on you.''

DOC.TEXT: La Chanze is a young actress with an exotic name and a dazzling smile who's lighting up the joyful Broadway musical, ``Once on This Island.'' She plays the role of Ti Moune, a peasant girl on an island in the French Antilles. The role requires her to go barefoot and to spend a good deal of time on her knees. ``My feet get pretty beat up,'' La Chanze tells an interviewer in her Booth Theater dressing room after a matinee. ``And my knees! Let me put some cream on my knees. ``It's the floor. When you're on your knees so much, there is muscle to help me from endangering my knees but there's nothing you can do about skin.'' In the play, Ti Moune (the name means orphan), finds a rich young man in his wrecked car, nurses him back to health and falls in love with him. The man, Daniel, played by Jerry Dixon, is enchanted with Ti Moune. But the call of his life among the rich - and lighter skinned - pulls him away. The musical, based on the novel ``My Love, My Love'' by Rosa Guy, got glowing reviews last season at off-Broadway Playwrights Horizons and more raves when it moved to Broadway Oct. 18. La Chanze feels she is a natural for the role of Ti Moune. ``I'm dark skinned and I've always had to deal with the reality of prejudice within and outside my own race,'' she says. In preparation, she spent two weeks living with a family in rural Jamaica. ``They explained the different beliefs they had and the history they'd been told. It was amazing how similar it was to the musical. ``What I do in the show may come across as innocence but it's because I'm trying to portray the Christian faith I have. What motivates Ti Moune is her faith and her love for Daniel.'' Their story in ``Once on This Island'' is told in words, music and dance, like a Caribbean fairy tale or fable. Characters include Erzulie, goddess of love; Asaka, mother of the earth, and Papa Ge, demon of death. La Chanze has one big dance number. ``I feel fortunate to work with someone as brilliant as Graciela Daniele. She did the choreography for my dance and she gave me a lot of room to do steps I enjoyed from my own past experience.'' La Chanze was born in St. Augustine, Fla., the oldest of six girls and three boys. She grew up mainly in Bridgeport, Conn., but moved around often. ``Dancing was my first love,'' she says. ``No matter which city we moved to, my mom had me in something like Pollyann's School of Twirling and Ballet.'' In New Haven, she studied African dance; at Morgan State University in Balitmore, theater; at the Philadelphia College of the Performing Arts, voice and dance. She auditioned in Philadelphia for the summer production of ``Uptown...It's Hot!'' ``When it came to New York,'' she says, ``I had the fever so I stayed here. I was a chorus girl. Maurice Hines was the director, choreographer and star. He heard me sing when one of the female leads was out and he had something written in for me, so I was featured after that.'' She had auditioned for one Broadway show earlier, ``Bubbling Brown Sugar,'' singing ``Hit Me with a Hot Note and Watch Me Bounce'' from ``Duke Ellington's Sophisticated Ladies.'' She says, ``It was my audition song for a very long time.'' She also auditioned for the film ``Tap'' and was told she was too young to play Gregory Hines' love interest. ``After I left `Uptown,' I went into the touring company of `Dreamgirls' - Japan, Europe, Canada, the States. I was cover to the leading woman and sang the parta lot on the road. This is my first leading role where I originated the character.'' She says that when she auditioned for ``Once on This Island'' at an open call her attitude was philosophical. If she got it, fine, if she didn't, it didn't matter. ``Then I got a callback and they gave me the script so I could read one of the scenes. Then I had to have it. I studied with a vocal coach and really worked on the material.'' La Chanze doesn't tell her age ``because of the character in the play. She used to be 16. Somewhere along the line they told me she's 18.'' La Chanze says she was christened with the customary three names. She dropped her first name when she came to New York, her last name after her appearance in ``Dreamgirls.'' It left her with her middle name, La Chanze, which was her maternal grandmother's given name. To those who do not know her first and last names she chooses not to reveal them. She is simply La Chanze. ``Everybody liked it better except my father and my sister Michelle, who wanted everybody to know we were sisters.'' Her father, now living in Kodiak, Alaska, has surprised her by taking up acting. ``He retired from the military in 1982 and got a master's degree in business and started a Ph.D. in management. He owns a computer software company. ``He called and told me he has the lead in `Master Harold... and the Boys.' I had no idea my dad had any interest in acting. He is going to visit me and bring me a tape. He wants to know what I think of his work. He is 46. He has time to pursue an acting career if he wants to. That's hysterical to me.'' La Chanze has an apartment with her cat, P2-78. She left her first cat, Polaris, with her boyfriend when she went on tour. She came back to find he'd given Polaris to the ASPCA. He became an instant ex-boyfriend. The next cat became P2. Somebody in ``Dreamgirls'' thought it should be P2-78 so it was. Her current boyfriend loves P2-78. La Chanze's dressing table holds a crystal paperweight, an opening night gift. She says, ``This represents so much to me. It's from three of my closest friends. I'm Christian and it points straight up and reflects the light. It'll always be with me.''

DOC.TEXT: In flawless English, Edward Woodward combines bluster, bluff and brilliance while he cons his way to finding killers in his new CBS series ``Over My Dead Body.'' Woodward's character, Maxwell Beckett, is often pompous but also a touch nervous that the fraud about his actual Scotland Yard background will be discovered. But he continues the charade in hopes that getting entwined in murder mysteries will revive the inspiration of his writing career. Woodward previously spent four years in New York for ``The Equalizer,'' a series that won him a devoted following. It inspired the publication of a number of newsletters and turned Woodward, now 60 and white-haired, into an unlikely sex symbol. ``Thank God my wife has a sense of humor,'' he says. ``Me, too. I thought it started as a bit of fun, then it got picked up by the magazines. I must say it caused a great deal of mirth among my friends in England.'' The new mystery-comedy is on Friday nights prior to ``Dallas'' in the CBS lineup. Woodward has his character fully defined: ``Maxwell pretends that he was a Scotland Yard detective, but actually he was in the criminal analysis department. It's a lie he has to live with. When we meet him he's moved to America, running out of mystery plots and in the middle of a messy divorce. ``He's irascible, short-fused, inclined to be pompous and feeling guilty about conning people. But he does have a talent for analyzing crime and what makes people tick. He has a terrible writer's block, and it makes him a very prickly individual.'' On the set, Woodward's Becket is trying to intimidate a woman into giving him information about a murder. But he's halted in the middle of his bullying by Jessica Lundy, his co-star. Woodward and Lundy are odd associates - far apart in age but well-matched in using each other in hopes of advancing their separate careers. She has the role of Nikki Page, a newspaper obituary writer. He hopes she'll bring him fresh material, and she sees him as her ticket to the big time. ``Over My Dead Body'' brings the British actor to Los Angeles for his first dramatic work here. He won an Emmy in September as host-narrator of the documentary series ``Remembering World War II.'' He says there are no similarities between Maxwell Beckett of ``Over My Dead Body'' and Robert McCall of ``The Equalizer.'' ``Maxwell is a physical coward,'' he says. ``In every way he's different, except that he does have a good analytical mind.'' Woodward suffered a heart attack three years ago and was reluctant to appear in another one-hour television series. ``I didn't want to do another series. I found the work unbelievably hard,'' he says. But he consented to do ``Over My Dead Body'' because the series would bring him home to England in two years. ``I've slowed down considerably,'' he says. ``I don't work between shows. ``The main problem is that I have a 7-year-old daughter who was in pre-school in New York, school in England and now Los Angeles. It's a great experience for a child to move around, but when she turns 9 I want her to have a consistent education.'' Woodward negotiated a contract that the show will move to England after the first two TV seasons. That will allow his daughter, Emily Beth, to attend school there - while he and his wife, Michele Dotrice, move back into their home in Cornwall. He has three grown children by a previous marriage. ``If we're successful and move to Great Britain I'll twist arms to shoot in Cornwall. But we'll probably stay around London. The story will be that Maxwell moves back home and Nikki follows.'' Woodward also keeps a home in London, where he was born. ``We were bombed three times,'' he says. ``My father was convinced Hitler was personally looking for him. He was injured the last time, and when he got out of the hospital we were evacuated to Cornwall. I learned to love boating there. A month before we came here I bought a 42-foot twin-screw motor yacht to cruise the coast, France and the Channel Islands.'' During his break between ``The Equalizer'' and his new series, Woodward stayed busy playing Sherlock Holmes in England and making ``Mr. Johnson'' in Africa. The movie ``Mr. Johnson'' is due out in January. Like two of his other films, ``Breaker Morant'' and ``King David,'' it was directed by Bruce Beresford. ``The title character is a 17-year-old African,'' he says. ``I'm Sgt. Gollup, who runs a shop in Nigeria in 1926. Mr. Johnson is his clerk. He was left behind by the British Empire and retires in Nigeria. He's a most astonishing bigot. He thinks he's a great gentleman to the African.'' While in school, Woodward had planned to become a journalist, but participation in a series of college productions changed his mind. He studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts. He made his stage debut in London, then joined the Royal Shakespeare Theatre Co. in Stratford-On-Avon. He also performed Shakespeare on tours of India, Australia, South Africa and the Soviet Union. ``The Russians know the plays, but it's interesting to watch the audience hearing Shakespeare in its native tongue for the first time. Shakespeare is played quite differently in Russia. We had three Americans in the company and they were absolutely mobbed by the audience. They were starved for contact with Americans. We Brits said the Americans and the Russians were alike. They each have a passion for their country, love outdoor pursuits and have an enormous involvement with the arts.''

DOC.TEXT: The most delectable movie of the holiday season is a simple little confection from John Hughes about a 10-year-old who's left behind by accident when his parents and multitude of siblings head off for a Christmas vacation in Paris. ``Home Alone'' is endearing, engaging and a lot of fun, once you suspend disbelief and buy into Hughes' idiotic premise. And one main reason for the film's success is Macaulay Culkin, the talented young actor who plays Kevin, the boy who finds paradise in being at home by himself and who gets to defend the castle against all intruders. Child-centered movies are popular with the younger set because they appeal to a sense of adventure, wonderment and just plain getting away from grown-ups. They also find an audience in those adults who are still fortunate enough to have a streak of whimsy in their lives. Some young actors put in such grand performances that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences honored them with Oscar nominations. Only one, Tatum O'Neal ever won, as supporting actress in ``Paper Moon'' in 1973. She was 10. Nominees have included: Jackie Cooper, actor (``Skippy''), 1931; Jodie Foster, supporting actress (``Taxi Driver''), 1976; Quinn Cummings, supporting actress (``Goodbye Girl''), 1977; Justin Henry, supporting actor (``Kramer vs. Kramer''), 1979. Many child-centered movies have made it to video. Here's an alphabetical list of some of what's available: - ``The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'' (1938): Good Mark Twain fun. - ``The Bad News Bears'' (1976): A bunch of foul-mouthed Little Leaguers. The best of the series. The sequels are bad news. - ``The Bicycle Thief'' (1949): Classic Italian drama about a man whose livelihood is threatened when a thief steals his bicycle, and the relationship he has with his son. - ``Black Beauty'' (1946): A little girl searches for her black colt. Will definitely bring a tear or two. - ``The Black Stallion'' (1979): Wonderful movie treatment of children's story about boy stranded on an island with a wild, black horse. - ``Bugsy Malone'' (1976): Look Ma, no grown-ups. Entire cast of kids, starring Jodie Foster, in 1920s send-up. - ``Captains Courageous'' (1937): A spoiled rich kid learns about friendship and life. Stars Spencer Tracey, Lionel Barrymore and Freddie Bartholomew. - ``A Christmas Story'' (1983): Jean Shepard's marvelous memory of Christmas in the 1940s and the ultimate gift, a regulation Red Ryder air rifle. - ``Cinema Paradiso'' (1989): Oscar winner for best foreign film. Concerns the friendship between a little boy and a film projectionist in a small Italian city. - ``David Copperfield'' (1935): Find a children's movie in the 1930s and you find Freddie Bartholomew. He's a marvel in this grand adaptation of Dickens' grand novel. All-star cast includes W.C. Fields, Edna May Oliver and Basil Rathbone. - ``Empire of the Sun'' (1987): A Steven Spielberg epic that loses its poignancy to Spielberg glitz. Based on J.G. Ballard's autobiographical tale of his boyhood experience in a Japanese prison camp during World War II. - ``E.T. - The Extra-Terrestrial'' (1982): Another Spielberg yarn. This time, a young boy takes an alien under his wing. - ``Fanny and Alexander'' (1983): The adventures of two children in Sweden at the turn of the century. Ingmar Bergman at his best. - ``The Fallen Idol'' (1948): A young boy becomes disillusioned with the family butler (Ralph Richardson). - ``The 400 Blows'' (1959): Francois Truffaut's powerful and sad story of a boy's glimpse of reality. - ``The Goonies'' (1985): Some soon-to-be-evicted kids search for hidden teasure and get a spooky adventure in the process. - ``Great Expectations'' (1946): An excellent film version of the Dicken classic about an orphan and his mysterious benefactor. Stars John Mills, Alec Guinness and Valerie Hobson. - ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' (1989): What happens when Murphy's Law meets Daddy the Inventor. Great family fun. - ``Hope and Glory'' (1987): Filmmaker John Boorman's childhood experiences in London during the blitz. - ``The Journey of Natty Gann'' (1985): A street kid rides the rails. - ``Kramer vs. Kramer'' (1979): Robert Benton's Oscar-winning movie about child custody. - ``Mary Poppins'' (1964): ``Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.'' And don't forget the dancing penguins. - ``Miracle on 34th Street'' (1947): Do you believe in Santa Claus? A delightful tale, starring Natalie Wood. - ``My Life as a Dog'' (1987): A charming import from Sweden about a boy's first love. - ``National Velvet'' (1944): Elizabeth Taylor, young and innocent, quiet, pretty and intense. With Mickey Rooney and a fine horse. - ``Paper Moon'' (1973): A con man and his con kid in a delightful story, starring Tatum O'Neal and Ryan O'Neal. - ``Pelle the Conquereor'' (1988): Hard times in Denmark, starring Max von Sydow and Pelle Hvenegaard. - ``Poltergeist'' (1982): What happens when your little girl watches too much television. - ``The Prince and the Pauper'' (1937): Mark Twain's classic about mistaken identity. Stars Billy and Bobby Mauch as young prince of England and a street urchin, and Errol Flynn. Remake in 1978 stars Charlton Heston, George C. Scott and Mark Lester. Both are worthy. - ``Prancer'' (1989): A little girl believes she has discovered one of Santa's reindeer and fights to protect it. - ``The Red Balloon'' (1966): Only 34 minutes of film, but an engaging and warm parable. - ``Salaam Bombay'' (1988): Powerful glimpse of street children in India. - ``Savannah Smiles'' (1982): A 6-year-old runaway teaches a few hoods a thing or two. - ``Sounder'' (1972): A sharecropper and his family. Poignant and well acted by Cicely Tyson, Paul Winfield and Kevin Hooks. - ``A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' (1945): A sentimental portrait of a working class family - in Brooklyn. - ``Tom Brown's School Days'' (1950): Life at a boy's school in Victorian England. - ``Treasure Island'' (1934, 1950, 1990): All three versions of Robert Louis Stevenson's story about a boy's experience with pirates have merit and good casts. Take your pick among Jackie Cooper, Bobby Driscoll and Christian Bale as the kid. - ``Uncle Buck'' (1989): U.B. is in a class all his own. So are the antics of his neices and nephew. Great fun from John Hughes, starring John Candy. - ``Whistle Down the Wind'' (1961): Three children find a murderer and think he's Jesus Christ. A lovely look at innocence and trust. - ``Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory'' (1971): What happens to bad, selfish brats and one nice little kid when they all visit a candy baron's factory. - ``Wizard of Oz'' (1939): Judy and Co. What more can we say? Oh, yeah - and Toto, too. - ``The World of Henry Orient'' (1964): Peter Sellers as lecherous pianist idolized by two adolescent girls. - ``The Yearling'' (1946): A boy and his fawn. - ``Young Sherlock Holmes'' (1985): Spielberg ran out of tricks for this one. Somewhat disappointing, but engaging performances by Nicholas Rowe and Alan Cox as Holmes and Watson as youngsters.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Vol. 3'' (Wilbury) - Traveling Wilburys
The music world's a big joke to the Traveling Wilburys, whose new disc only sounds like it was written and recorded in an afternoon. Don't be fooled. Pride being what it is, this low-key supergroup has made a first-rate followup to their surprise 1988 hit. For all the wink-wink, nudge-nudge antics, the Wilburys are quite serious when it comes to music. In fact, with the exception of Tom Petty, whose solo career is still at its peak - it might behoove George Harrison, Bob Dylan and Jeff Lynne to become full-time Wilburys. That would allow Dylan and Harrison to indulge their senses of humor without worrying about their considerable recorded legacies. Harrison manages to fit the cliche twister, ``she's got a body for business and a head for sin'' into the garage rocker ``She's My Baby.'' Dylan gets the racy line, ``she likes to stick her tongue right down my throat,'' into the same song. The Wilburys don't credit songwriters individually, but it's clear Dylan's contributions loom large. Seemingly offhand songs such as ``If You Belonged to Me'' and the doo-wop style ``Seven Deadly Sins'' are better than anything on his most recent solo album. Harrison's instrumental work is superb, particularly his rocking sitar on the environmentalist ``The Devil's Been Busy,'' and the warped guitar sound on Petty's country romp, ``Poorhouse.'' Lynne, as his recent solo album inadvertently proved, is better suited now as a role player. He plays the widest variety of instruments and his production with Harrison, despite the occasional annoying chirpy background vocals, is fine. ``You Took My Breath Away'' is a worthy tribute to late Wilbury Roy Orbison and the hilarious ``Wilbury Twist,'' a dance anthem for cynical baby boomers, brings this disc to a rocking close. The Wilburys sound like they may be suited to this business. And that's no joke. - By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer. --- ``Uptown'' (Telarc) - Andre Previn with Mundell Lowe and Ray Brown
Great musicians moving into waters that are not really their element often produce tepid ripples of mediocrity. Composer-conductor Andre Previn can adeptly put pen to musical score and ably draw the beauty of Mozart out of a symphony orchestra with the wave of a baton. But can he swing? Can he play to the grayness of an autumn day and the melancholy mood of ``Stormy Weather?'' Better to ask where Previn's talents stop, for the answer to the above is yes. Previn on piano, Mundell Lowe on guitar and Ray Brown on bass form as fine a straight-ahead jazz trio as any in recent memory. Most of the songs on ``Uptown'' are by Harold Arlen or Duke Ellington, and this trio gets to the essence of the music. Any trio has to have a solid backbeat to drive the sound, and Brown is the launch pad for Previn and Lowe. His backing is so solid that both have the freedom to wander as moved. They never wander too far afield, however, and that gives this record a friendly feel. The mood is bright, playful. Previn to Lowe and back, the solos flow. Lowe's caress is soft, but his sound is full. Previn is right on target with the mood of each song, quick to jump on ``It Don't Mean a Thing If You Ain't Got That Swing'' or ``Five O'Clock Whistle,'' and slow to ponder on ``Stormy Weather'' or ``Come Sunday.'' This is the second Telarc jazz recording with Previn; the first featured Brown and guitarist Joe Pass. There's little doubt Previn will ever need to make a living at jazz, but this accomplished musician definitely has a home ``Uptown.'' - By James Reindl, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AN ARTS
Star Watch: Gerard Depardieu as Cyrano
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Roxane in 15th graf, ``Depardieu loves,'' is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Gerard Depardieu is late. He walks quickly into the hotel lobby, apologizes for the delay and hurries off to make a phone call and ditch his suit. A few minutes later, the French actor is seated in a nearly empty restaurant, wearing clothes more to his liking: jeans, T-shirt and a denim windbreaker - all black. His sneakers are white. Depardieu is 6-foot-2, heavy in the torso and light on his feet, like a dancing bear. He has a mustache and straight, dark-blond hair that sweeps across his forehead. His eyes are childlike, sensitive, and his nose is thick, though no match for the one he wears in the title role of his new film, ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' An adaptation of Edmond Rostand's classic love story, ``Cyrano'' begins at a French theater in 1640. Here, too, Depardieu (as Cyrano) is late. The play has already started when a voice is heard shouting, ``King of clowns! Leave the stage - at once!'' Cyrano emerges, pushing his way through the crowd, his long hair and great nose unmistakable. He shouts down the hapless actor on stage and shuts down the performance. ``I've had dreams like that. Bad dreams,'' laughs Depardieu, speaking mostly in English, but keeping a translator on hand. ``I always dream that I am on the stage and Iforget my lines and I start sweeping the floors. I like characters who go too far. In `Cyrano,' what he does is very strong. This man stops the play and puts the character in the street. That's extraordinaire! Encroyable!'' Depardieu was born in 1948 in Chateaureux, part of the region of central France known as the Berri. The third of six children, he was a petty thief at age 8, a dropout at 12 and a runaway at 13. A pyschologist urged him to take drama classes. His first movie came out in 1965, his second six years later. More than 60 have followed, the breakthrough film called, fittingly, ``Going Places'' (``Les Valseuses''). ``Nothing has changed,'' insists Depardieu, who lives near Paris with his wife and two children. ``When I was 12 years old, 8 years old, I was exactly the same way as now. I was always functioning very fast. ``I always wanted to be an actor. I loved the movies. I went to the cinema when I was young and it was magic. I loved going into the theater and sitting in the dark. I would see French `B' movies, also American movies.'' His life on screen has been varied: an imposter in ``Le Retour de Martin Guerre'' (``The Return of Martin Guerre''), a bisexual thief in ``Menage,'' a hunchback in ``Jean de Florette,'' an evil traveling salesman in ``Nathalie Granger.'' He was guillotined in ``Danton,'' murdered in ``Barocco'' and emasculated in ``La Derniere Femme'' (``The Last Woman''). Awards for best actor include the Cesar, the French equivalent to the Academy Award, in 1981 for ``Le Dernier Metro'' (``The Last Metro''); a citation from the National Society of Film Critics in 1984 for ``Danton'' and ``Martin Guerre,'' and honors at the Cannes Film Festival last summer for ``Cyrano.'' ``I'm not interested in people who are happy and everything is great - someone who smiles and is an idiot, who thinks everything's beautiful,'' Depardieu explains, stretching his mouth into a mock-silly grin. ``The most difficult thing is to play a man who is not a gangster or a romantic, who is nothing.'' His voice is a breathless purr at his most intimate moments. It is high-pitched and excitable when he's making a point, and a hoarse bellow whew he's passionate. Depardieu loves everything about films except sitting still, and Cyrano, mighty with the pen and sword, is a man in motion, talking and fighting, pouring his heart out to the beautiful Roxane but putting the words in the mouth of another man. ``When I was young, I was very introverted,'' Depardieu says. ``I didn't need to wear masks; I was a mask. ... I was very good at training to be a boxer but as soon as the competition began I'd lose my nerve. That didn't happen on stage. ``The way Cyrano speaks is magic. I wish I could speak in verse, like he does. All the words he says came directly from the soul. When you're transported by love, you're in a state of grace. It was an easy part to play because I believed in the words of Cyrano.'' Depardieu prepares to leave, making a telephone call, and going through a quick photo session. When he says goodbye, one large hand grips tightly while the three inside fingers from his other hand rest gently above the wrist. It's a bond, a mark until next time. You want to roll up your sleeve and check for imprints. ``I carry my adornments on my soul,'' Cyrano says. ``I do not dress up like a popinjay; but inwardly, I keep my daintiness.'' The actor speaks of his character as a ``tornado,'' a man in love with melodrama who ``expends his energy and feelings without a second thought.'' ``I'm quite like him in this respect,'' Depardieu notes. And then he turns and rushes off, headed for his next appointment, trying not to be late.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Lighting and Set Designer Makes Directing Debut
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Seattle Opera general director Speight Jenkins decided to produce Antonin Dvorak's ``Rusalka,'' he knew whom he wanted as lighting and set designer: Gunther Schneider-Siemssen. There was just one hitch. ``He said, `I won't come unless I am the director,''' Jenkins said. Saying yes meant giving Schneider-Siemssen what is normally the work of three people in his U.S. debut as an opera stage director. For 27 years he was the chief lighting and set designer for the late Berlin Philharmonic conductor Herbert von Karajan. His seven production designs for ``Der Ring des Niebelungen'' were the most by anyone since Richard Wagner compleeed the four-part operatic extravaganza in 1874. Yet his only directing had been in the relative obscurity of South Africa. ``It was a gamble ... a total shot in the dark with one of the most famous people in the business,'' Jenkins said. The gamble paid off in a shimmering joint production by the Seattle Opera and Houston Grand Opera, which is expected to present ``Rusalka'' in its next season. Seattle performances were Oct. 27-Nov. 7. Unlike the movie based on the same Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale, ``The Little Mermaid,'' the opera ends with the death of the prince and the confinement of Rusalka to the dark marshes because she has been tainted by contact with humans. ``On the one hand, I want to bring out the characters, and on the other hand I want to bring out the symbolic and the metaphysical traits,'' Schneider-Siemssen said. ``For example, the chorus in `Rusalka' represents a decadent party in the castle. The one has Parkinson's disease, the other is limping, a third has a pain in the back. ... ``The princess and the dukes and Rusalka are human creatures in contrast to the stiff party.'' Slides hand-painted by Schneider-Siemssen were projected to form the prince's castle, which loomed forebodingly over a stone bridge and moat, and the sky over Rusalka's lake, lined by trees that seem to filter an ethereal moonlight and luminescent sunshine. Spotlights shining through vertical plastic sheets gave the effect of rippling water. Schneider-Siemssen said his goal was always that ``when the curtain opens, you don't only hear the music, you see the music.'' Giving music a visible dimension became his life's work at age 14, he said. Unable to decide between scenery painting and conducting, he went to Clemens Krauss, then general director of the State Opera in Vienna. ``He said, `Don't become a conductor. In the future, we need designers who are able to interpret music optically,''' Schneider-Siemssen recalled. During World War II, he studied scenic painting, theater and related subjects at Munich. His first set design was for a small comedy called ``Angelica.'' For budget reasons he borrowed the furniture from the parlor of his parents' apartment, which soon afterward was bombed in an Allied raid. ``I saved that furniture from the American bombs,'' he said. ``When my parents went to opening night and the curtain opened, they were shocked to see their living room on stage.'' In his first stage contract, at the Landes Theater in Salzburg, money shortages in war-ravaged Europe led him to begin his pioneering use of slides to meld lighting into the set. In 1956, working in Bremen, Germany, he learned that von Karajan had admired his work on a production of Beethoven's ``Fidelio.'' A year and a half later, Schneider-Siemssen arranged an introduction to von Karajan in Salzburg, but it was only in 1962 that their long collaboration began. That year, after laboring over a design proposal for ``Pelleas et Melisande,'' he went to Vienna and found the stage hands were on strike, leaving too little time for set construction. ``So I said to Karajan, `You know, let's not do all this. Let's do it all with light and projections.' ``That gave him the time to do the show,'' Schneider-Siemssen said. ``This was one of the most beautiful productions of Karajan.'' Schneider-Siemssen's first stint as a director was on ``Tristan und Isolde'' in Cape Town, South Africa, in 1983. He later directed ``The Flying Dutchman'' in 1985, ``Die Zauberflote'' in 1985 and ``Fidelio'' this year at Cape Town, Durban, Pretoria and Bloemfontein. ``Of course, the `Fidelio' and the concept of freedom has very much meaning in South Africa,'' he said. ``I have, in the opera house, no apartheid. I have black people and white people in the stage crew, lighting and chorus.'' Today, negotiating for contracts in Austria and Germany, he said he probably should have begun directing 15 years ago. ``I take certain works that are very much of interest to me and that are everything,'' he said. ``I was so busy with the research for the stage and the lighting, I just didn't have the time.'' He spends about seven months a year with his wife, an American, and their four children in a Vienna home where he has his design studio; two months at a summer home in Salzburg for the annual musical festival; and much of the rest of the time at an apartment in New York. ``I fear I have a double marriage,'' he said, ``with stage design, and with my wife.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Have Hall and Oates Become the Alan Aldas of Rock?
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Daryl Hall and John Oates, those enduring peddlers of blue-eyed soul, have given up sex and dancing in favor of sweetness and sincerity. On their new album, anyway. ``Change of Season,'' on the Arista label, is a rebellion against the 1980s and all the decade symbolized, the two said in an interview in their manager's office. The '80s were ``high-tech and high flying, go-go years of getting out there and being aggressive. I thought it was time for a little more sweetness and coming together, bringing out our sensitive side,'' Hall said. ``Ooh Yeah!,'' the duo's last album in 1988, ``was about late '80s kind of things - sex and dancing. This is the opposite of that,'' he said. The new album ``is about change and how people react to change. The unifying lyrical focus is the idea that change occurs and how people react to it resist it, go with it. ... ``I don't look back. I just go,'' Hall said. ``I move straight through things - not without some difficulties occasionally.'' ``I look forward to change,'' said Oates. ``I see things moving, whether they move forward or backward.'' Accompanying the softer image is a softer sound. ``We did a series of unplugged (acoustic) shows last spring,'' Hall said. ``You can play good rock 'n' roll on mandolins. It felt so good we decided to expand on it.'' They'll probably do some of the set acoustically in their upcoming tour. The final track on ``Change of Season'' is the acoustic ``So Close (Unplugged).'' Despite the duo's newly sweet image, the tour will included a lot of that tainted '80s stuff: ``Sra Smile,'' ``Rich Girl,'' ``Private Eyes,'' ``Maneater,'' ``Kiss on my List'' and ``I Can't Go for That.'' The tour will begin in Europe, but Hall and Oates expect to spend most of next year performing in the United States. In concerts this year, they've been performing ``Can't Help Falling in Love With You,'' which they did on ``The Last Temptation of Elvis,'' an album of Elvis Presley hits performed by various artists to benefit the Nordoff Robbins Music Therapy Trust. Most of ``Change of Season'' was recorded in a studio Hall and Oates built in upstate New York. ``It's equal distance between our two homes an hour and a half north of New York City,'' said Oates, who is married and has no children. Hall has a longtime girlfriend. ``It's the first time in over a decade we haven't recorded in New York City,'' Hall says. ``That's another factor in the music. It is not about urban subjects and the sound is not urban. It's a big change for us. ``We didn't try for any one audience with this. We were writing from inside.'' The first single to be released off the new album is ``So Close,'' produced by Danny Kortchmar and Jon Bon Jovi in Los Angeles. ``George Green sent me some lyrics,'' Hall said. ``I adopted the moral and changed the words around a bit. It's about people who started wrong and stay wrong. It's not a pretty story.'' Hall and Oates have been playing for nearly two decades. Their first album came out in 1972; the first they produced themselves was 1980's ``Voices.'' That album ``is the standard we judge ourselves from,'' Hall said. ``It's similar to this album in its purity and simplicity. None of the songs on ``Change of Season'' is written by Hall and Oates together. ``Our apartness is part of our togetherness,'' Hall said. ``We do solo projects or bring in other writers. ``We have telepathic communication. We can do different things and be apart, like we were in 1986, and come back and have taken the same steps and really be thinking the same way.'' ``I think in the process of making music we both kind of know right and wrong for us,'' said Oates.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: The World's Most Dangerous Author
DOC.TEXT: T. Coraghessan Boyle was between acts, just finished with an appearance on ``Late Night With David Letterman'' and getting ready for a reading at Columbia University. A born performer, he fit right in on Letterman, telling jokes about his middle name, crocodiles in Georgia and unsavory food in Japan. The host played it straight and let his guest steal the show. Letterman isn't known for trading barbs with men of letters - imagine one-liners with John Updike about ``Rabbit at Rest'' or Gabriel Garcia Marquez on ``One Hundred Years of Solitude.'' So how did Boyle end up sitting beside him? His appearance is one reason. Boyle doesn't look like a writer. He stands 6-foot-3, his skinny frame covered by a dark gray suit with white speckles and anchored by red high-top sneakers. He has kinky hair, the color of bruised apricots, and a matching beard. And the cover boy of The New York Times book review section doesn't act like a writer, certainly not the kind who spends hours brooding about the future of minimalist novels or the crisis of middle-class relationships in the late 20th century. Just call him, in the Letterman spirit, ``The World's Most Dangerous Author.'' ``I came up from nowhere, looking at TV all day long and thinking writers were snobs,'' Boyle explained in an interview at Manhattan's Algonquin Hotel, where brooding authors are known to congregate. ``But I have the credentials. I have the Ph.D. I have books on the front page of The New York Times. ``I think some writers who don't have the credentials have to prove themselves by acting stuffy. Maybe I've been lucky. I've never been part of the club and I never will and I have no problem with that.'' Seven books and the PEN-Faulkner Prize for fiction in 1988 have settled him only slightly. Boyle is a hard man to pin down. He's a fabulist, a personality, the slippery ``I'' in a hurricane of literary adventures. Read his short stories, ``If the River Was Whisky'' and ``Greasy Lake,'' or his new novel, ``East Is East'' (Viking, $19.95), and you'll find apes, chefs, musicians and the wife of Nikita Khrushchev; the author is distinctly off the pages. None of the characters in ``East Is East'' is based on people he knows. He's never lived in any of the locations. The plot came from a newspaper article he lost long ago. What does T. Coraghessan Boyle, recovered addict of the small screen and other vices, have to do with this wacky tale of Hiro the Japanese sailor, who jumps ship along the coast of Georgia and dodges immigration officials in the Okefenokee Swamp? ``My joke is I wrote a novel about Georgia because I had flown over Georgia several times on my way to Miami. It's easier to write the book if you've seen the place but I don't have to go there like James Michener and dig in. I think fiction is supposed to be an exercise of the imagination. My take is I can do anything I want.'' He was born 42 years ago, his idea of nowhere the town of Peekskill, N.Y., the childhood setting for the author and his television set. The transformation from Tom Boyle, couch potato and daydreamer, to author T. Coraghessan Boyle (the middle name an early work of fiction) began at a creative writing class in college. Boyle calls himself a ``virgin'' to writers' colonies, but he did spend five years at a den of iniquity known as the Iowa Writers Workshop, where Kurt Vonnegut, John Irving, Flannery O'Connor and many others came of age. Boyle expresses his feelings about the company of his peers in ``East Is East,'' which features a colony swarming with pesky authors: --- ``At breakfast, it was thought, artists of a certain temperament required an absolute and meditative silence, broken only perhaps by the discreet tap of a demitasse spoon on the rim of a saucer - in order to make a fruitful transition from the realm of dreams to that exalted state in which the deep stuff of aesthetic response rises to the surface. ``Others, of course, needed just the opposite - conviviality, uproar, crippling gossip, lame jokes and a whiff of the sour morning breath of their fellow artists - to settle brains fevered by dreams of grandeur, conquest and utter annihiliation of their enemies.'' --- ``Of course, I was Olympian and far above all that pettiness,'' Boyle, speaking of his days at Iowa, said with a laugh. ``I know how it feels and I think that's where I'm getting some of my inspiration. I didn't do any politicking and I got everything I wanted from pure virtue, like Mahatma Gandhi.'' ``Descent of Man,'' a collection of stories written for his Ph.D at Iowa, was published in 1979. He followed that with more stories, ``Greasy Lake,'' and a pair of novels, ``Budding Prospects'' and ``Water Music.'' The historical novel ``World's End,'' set in the New York town of ``Peterskill,'' won him the PEN-Faulkner award. For the Columbia reading, Boyle keeps the sneakers and dons a snappy black jacket. This audience will have read his books, but for the author it's still a performance. Boyle sees himself as a crossover artist, straddling talk shows and the Ivy League. ``I do believe the way everything is constructed with television and personality, writers have to go out and grab hold of the attention in some way,'' Boyle said. ``I think I wonder where I fit in exactly, but as far as being on the front page of The New York Times and also be on `David Letterman,' I have no problems with that. I think in this society you have to try to catch and recapture the audience for literature. That's a lot of energy spent for things outside of writing, and that's bad.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Alison Krauss Chose Music Over Roller Derby
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Alison Krauss chose music over roller derby, and the result is a young, bluegrass fiddler-singer shouldering her way into a male-dominated genre. The 19-year-old Krauss is one of just a few women recording the acoustic, mountain-bred music. She's spent three years recording with Rounder Records and has already made a concert tour of the Middle East. But it wasn't that long ago, a few years in fact, that she had to choose between bowing her fiddle or racing on roller skates. ``I was really into roller skating for a long time,'' Krauss recalled in an interview in the office of her booking agent. ``I used to go every Frday and Saturday night. I couldn't decide whether to play the violin or roller skate.'' She chose violin, and subsequently emerged as an independent and gifted instrumentalist with a soprano voice reminiscent of a young Dolly Parton or Emmylou Harris. Though still a teen-ager, she has firm views about bluegrass music and what she will and won't do. Compromises aren't likely. Although she has a recording contract with an independent label, she's not ready to jump to a more prestigious major company. ``We want to play bluegrass music and if somebody signed us, it would be totally something else,'' she said. Major labels today do not sign bluegrass performers because the commercial market for them is weak. ``They would hire a producer, and I'd want to be able to choose somebody myself,'' Krauss said. ``Maybe I'll change my mind later, but really that's not something I'm after right now. I'm playing with four great people (her band, Union Station), and I want to keep doing that.'' She also refuses to play such bluegrass standards as ``Orange Blossom Special,'' ``Rocky Top'' and ``Fox on the Run.'' ``Our goal is to play our own music,'' she said. ``Haven't people heard those songs enough yet?'' Some bluegrass fans might consider such a statement blasphemy. Festival performers are routinely asked to play the standards made famous by Bill Monroe, the Osborne Brothers and others. Krauss grew up in Champaign, Ill., and learned classical violin at age 5. She gravitated to bluegrass music and started winning bluegrass fiddle contests at age 12. Before she was a teen-ager, she began playing at bluegrass festivals in the Midwest. Her current album is ``I've Got That Old Feeling,'' her third, which contains songs focusing on romance and heartbreak. Her past LPs were ``Two Highways'' in 1989 and ``Too Late to Cry'' in 1987. Since she was 10, she has spent much time performing in clubs, places where she was not old enough to legally drink liquor. ``One time, when I was about 13, I was told to go into a room on the break and told to stay there and not even see the bar,'' she said. ``Nobody has ever gotten really rowdy. Sometimes somebody will get really sloshed at the end of the show, but not often.'' Late last year, she and her band spent a month in the Middle East as part of a cultural exchange program sponsored by the U.S. Information Agency. She gave concerts in Israel, Jordan, Pakistan, Syria and Tunisia. ``Our music went over great,'' she said. ``It was a major moment in our lives. We got to see places most people only think about.'' She believes women are breaking into the bluegrass field, which has never had a woman as an established star. ``There's beginning to be singers, fiddlers, banjo players and all-female bands. Bluegrass has been totally male-dominated. It's just something women didn't do.'' She said she's heard other women bluegrass musicians complain about being unwelcome by their male counterparts. ``But I've never had that feeling - that people didn't want me there because I was a woman.'' Her band - a banjo player, guitarist, mandolin player and bass player - performs mostly at nightclubs and some folk festivals. ``The most exciting thing for me is to see people singing the words to your songs while you stand on the stage,'' she said, ``and when people request songs that you do and no one else does.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The ``Grammy Legends Show'' will be taped before a live audience at New York's Royale Theater on Dec. 5. CBS will air the two-hour musical tribute on Dec. 11 at 9:00 p.m. EST. The 1990 Grammy Legends recipients share a total of 46 Grammy Awards among them. Some of the artists who will be included in the special tribute segments dedicated to each Legend are: Stevie Wonder, Richard Marx, Dwigh Yoakam, Smokey Robinson, John Cougar Mellencamp and Oprah Winfrey. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Hugh Masekela, musician, composer and human rights activist, leads a celebration for the 45th Anniversary of the United Nations on Dec. 10 in the UN Delegate's Dining Room. Masekela and his African Orchestra will be sharing their high-spirited music at the gala benefit sponsored by The Friends of the UN, a non-profit, non-governmental organization, in honor of the 45 years of service that the United Nations has provided on behalf of peace, justice and the environment. Masekela began his career over 30 years ago when he became a member of the seminal South African band ``The Jazz Epistles,'' the first black jazz band to record an LP in South Africa. Dec. 10 is also United Nations Human Rights Day, and the event will mark the announcement of the recent UN convention regarding the Rights of the Child.
