DOC.HEAD: Baby Boomers' Group Seeks Political Power Senior Citizens Wield
DOC.TEXT: Karen Meredith has a message for all the baby boomers whose parents told them to buy sensible cars, save money and live within their means: Grow up. Mom and dad were right. Meredith, an accountant inspired to action by the woes of her 30-something clients, believes much of a generatiilt four-room cottage that fits in the back yard. Developer J. Robert Gillette says the cottages are America's answer to Australia's ``granny flats.'' The cottages, which can be hooked to untilities in the main home, sell for about $50,000 or rent for $600 to $700 a month. The relatives are nearby but not crowding the family. Gillette wants the first cottages to be built on the grounds of senior citizens' complexes. Cottage occupants will have more privacy, and pay less, than residents of the complex itself, but still have easy access to social events, meals and services such as laundry. Trial programs in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Texas and California show that what the American Association of Retired People calls the Elder Cottage Housing Opportunity an work. ``It's very cozy,'' Pauline Wessner, 85, said from the ECHO cottage she's lived in for two years near Belvedere, N.J. Wessner's grandson thought of her when the county's Office on Aging announced an ECHO trial program. He had bought the house where she lived for nearly 40 years, and she had moved to an apartment, she said. ``It was too much work for me to mow the grass and everything else.'' ``I live right next door to my grandson now, about 45 feet from his house,'' she said. The county bought the cottage and leases it to her for an amount based on her Social Security income. She has a bedroom, bathroom, parlor and fully equipped kitchen. Probably not more than 100 of the little houses have been set up nationally, said Leah Dobkin of the AARP in Washington. But the AARP has published outlines for developers and local governments of the zoning, parking and other issues the cottages raise. It's better than backing a trailer in, Dobkin said. ``These are specially designed for the elderly, and they meet all housing codes,'' she said. Gillette's cottage plans show ramps for people who don't want to climb stairs, wide doors, bathtub rails, and kitchen sinks minus the usual cabinets underneath that keep wheelchair users at arm's length. Gillette said he'll erect four cottages at the American House Dearborn Heights, Mich., complex by spring. That the cottages are detached is a key for senior citizens like Wessner, who want to live near their families, but not in the same house. ``That wouldn't go,'' Wessner said. ``They have two teen-agers, who like loud music. Grandma's a little too old for that now.'' But the cottage avoids the loneliness of long-distance living. ``My grandson stops in every morning with the newspaper for me. They invite me over, which I appreciate. I go over there on Sunday for coffee and a bun.'' And on holidays, she said, ``We eat together. Unless I'm invited somewhere else.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Indian Aging Advocate Urges Return to Old Values
DOC.TEXT: The old values, from a time when neighbors cared about one another and youngsters respected their elders, must be resurrected or the future will hold little hope for elderly Indians, an advocate says. Curtis Cook, executive director of the Albuquerque-based National Indian Council on Aging Inc., said the growing ranks of Indian elderly make that philosophy even more crucial. ``We're in the midst of an increase in elders and decreasing resources,'' Cook said in a recent luncheon speech to the National Congress of American Indians convention. ``Something has to change.'' The 199O census is expected to show an 83 percent increase in the population of Indian elders since the last count taken a decade ago, he said. ``There's no way that the '90s can have any kind of new federalism or any kind of hope for the future of American Indian elders'' unless the teachings and ways of the past are learned and practiced, Cook said. Cook, a non-Indian who has worked with American Indians for more than 25 years, urged changes in laws and policies and pressed for a commitment among governments and youth to serve older people. Cook criticized the Indian Health Service and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development for what he called policies that hurt elderly Indians. He said HUD will not build homes for Indians over 62, and in some cases will allow only the nuclear family - not grandparents - to live in houses built with federal money. That effectively abolished housing for Indian elderly at a time when statistics show that 23.6 percent live at substandard levels, he said. Cook said the IHS has no specialized geriatric care or research. He criticized the Social Security system for eliminating 17,000 field contact positions in rural areas and the U.S. Bureau of Indian Affairs for not establishing special programs for the elderly. ``This great American society which prides itself on feeding the needy throughout the world ... needs to learn a few things from Indian society, which would say `We will not have enough, but you are a guest here at this table and we will share,''' Cook said. ``This is the Indian term, this is the Indian way.'' Cook said after his talk that society generally holds a misconception that Indians have all their needs met by the federal government. He said Indians, and especially the elderly, have the highest rates of poverty of any ethnic group in the country. The NCAI is the oldest and largest Indian political organization in the United States.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Feisty Bob Watts Still Up in the Air
DOC.TEXT: Bob Watts has flown military cargo planes to China and an orchestra to Canada. He's survived an emergency landing in Bismarck and an unexpected plunge into the Missouri River. He's ornery or kind, depending on whom you talk to. Watts, 73, owns Capital Aviation, with 10 small airplanes and runs it with his wife, Lois. When he's not in the air, you can find Watts in his shop, rebuilding a 1946 Cessna, along with his family - Lois, their 15-year-old dog Klondike and two cats. Klondike has logged more than 3,000 miles in the air. The cats, Midway and Nuisance, have made a few flights by sneaking on board. Watts has flown supplies to the Garrison Dam and to an earthquake scene in West Yellowstone. When conductor Guy Lombardo and his orchestra found their plane had engine trouble, Watts got them to Canada. ``I'll bet I've got shirts and socks in at least a dozen laundromats all over the country from living out of a briefcase,'' he says. But he's had fun. ``I wouldn't want an airline job where I have to fly to Minneapolis to Bismarck and back to Minneapolis and back to Bismarck. I wouldn't do that for all the tea in China,'' he says. Watts was in China during World War II, airlifting military supplies over ``The Hump,'' in the Himalaya Mountains to the Flying Tigers, a group of mercenaries under the command of the United States and its allies. ``On occasion, we had red-ball alerts and we had to go on radio silence,'' he says. ``But the only thing we could really do was head for the clouds, and there were plenty of those. You just keep flying. ``We hauled tent stakes, ketchup, light bulbs, munitions. We moved two cut-up locomotives over the Hump. Later, they were welded back together.'' After the war, he and his brother Jack started Capital Aviation Corp. Jack Watts retired eight years ago. Lois Watts, a home economics teacher for 29 years, became office manager and bookkeeper in 1976. In 1982, Watts was piloting a plane carrying eight people when the landing gear failed and he was forced to bring the plane down in Bismarck on its belly. The landing was smooth; no one was hurt. In 1956, he and a photographer escaped injury when their light plane went into the Missouri River. ``I wasn't watching where I was going,'' Watts recalls. ``I just flew the plane into the water - just like the guy on the street, turns his head to look at a pretty girl and hits a lamppost. I learned to mind the road.'' His biggest obstacle, he says, is the Federal Aviation Administration, which is threatening to take away his license for flying without the proper fuel adjustment valve. Watts and his attorney are fighting the agency. ``If you don't dot all your i's and cross your t's you are subject to severe penalties and fines,'' Watt says. ``People in Washington seem to think a light plane is a rich man's fancy.'' But people like Erwin Kobs of Bismarck, who did maintenance for Watts in the 1950s, think he'll outlast the bureaucrats. ``He's a tough master,'' Kobs said. ``but he's a good pilot. ``Aviation is his life, there's no doubt about that. He's a survivor.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: If You Plan Your Planting, You Can Eat Fresh Longer
DOC.TEXT: Superior taste is the main reason for homegrown vegetables. But identical varieties will ripen around the same time unless the planting is spaced over several weeks. So successive plantings are needed for a continuous, top-quality supply over the longest possible period. For example, in this warm, arid climate, green onions for eating (scallions) develop from onion sets in a few weeks. In late October or early November, I prepare a 4-by-10-foot raised bed and divide it into three equal segments. Sets spaced an inch apart are planted in the first segment. Two weeks later a similar planting goes into segment No. 2. Segment No. 3 is planted two weeks later. By the time the green onions from the first bed have been eaten and replacement sets planted, the second bed is being harvested. This sequence continues until higher temperatures rule out onion planting, usually in late February. Then I put in a warm-season crop such as green peppers, using the same timing. Planting times vary with climates and vegetables, of course, and the process can be this simple or more complex, as desired. To determine plant-succession timing it's necessary to determine the days needed for maturing. There are general guidelines for each vegetable. Beets usually take 60 to 80 days; cauliflower 90 to 100 days; carrots 60 to 100 days; eggplant 70 to 120 days; peppers 90 to 120 days. A reference book will help. More precise is the specific information in seed catalogs or on seed packets. Some varieties of the same vegetables are genetically ready to eat earlier or later than others. While seed sellers take this into account, they also tend to be optimistic. So it's wise to routinely add a week or so to the catalog-packet estimate. Then allow for some plants of the same variety to mature later or before others. After such approximations, and if your beets, say, are supposed to mature in 60 days, plant a third of the seed packet at the recommended time, follow with another third 20 days later, and the final third after another 20 days. The idea is to let nature's growth-regulating system supply vegetables at peak quality over a long period. This works especially well with crops such as lettuce, green onions, carrots, radishes and beets, and is effective with just about everything throughout a growing season. But it won't work for every vegetable, notably zucchini, which seems to produce more than even zucchini lovers, like me, can consume or give away despite careful planning. One friend never plants zucchini, on the theory that neighbors will keep him supplied and he makes them fel great by accepting their surplus. Another friend fills 20-pound grocery bags with zucchini, places them on neighbor's doorsteps, rings the doorbell - and runs. How is peak quality determined? Frequent sampling is effective and simple. Remember that most vegetables taste best when fully developed but before they turn the corner to maturity. Such an idea will bring hoots from commercial growers and from home gardeners who freeze or can their produce. Their need is for everything to be ready for harvest about the same time, for ease of handling. Most seed crops are developed to meet such timing needs. It's a valid position for mass production of food. It's also one reason that so many store-bought vegetables taste so bland. So if taste is your reason for growing vegetables, experiment with successive planting. There is nothing sacred about planting a third of a seed packet at a time. Divide the packet by four or five, or in half, if this works better. Remember, too, that growing seasons seldom are the same from year to year. So adjustments may be needed. As for using sets to produce green onions, purists will insist that scallions, or bunching onions, are best grown from seed designed to produce white, ``bulbless'' onions. This is true. But fresh onions for the table from sets are easy and inexpensive; arrive three weeks or more before those from seeds; and can be planted later in the season. They also are a great way to spark children's interest in gardening. Kids love to push the marble-size sets into the ground and love the almost immediate results. The process also has been known to convert non-gardening adults. If space is limited, the most space-efficient vegetables include beets, broccoli, beans, cabbage, carrots, leaf lettuce, onions, radishes and tomatoes. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Attitude Contributes to Treatment of Older People
DOC.TEXT: Negative attitudes toward the elderly may block their access to the rehabilitation services after accidents, illness or surgery, a study says. The problem of paying for such services represents the greatest barrier to obtaining them, according to the study, released this summer by the American Association of Retired Persons. But it concluded that many older people do not get rehabilitation largely because of their age. ``Many people associate rehabilitation only with younger persons and the possibility of return to work and see no need to provide these services to older people,'' it said. ``Yet rehabilitation can help older people to regain mobility and live independently following a stroke, heart attack, hip fracture or chronic illness.'' Rehabilitation refers to services such as physical, occupational and speech therapy and rehabilitative nursing and the report asserts: ``The provision of rehabilitation services may make the difference between a person who is bedfast and a person who can walk with a walker.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Association Sues State
DOC.TEXT: The debate over how much the state should pay for the cost of caring for nursing home residents has shifted from the Statehouse to the courtroom. Two groups sued this month, alleging the state is not paying enough. The Kansas Health Care Association and the Kansas Association for Homes for the Aging filed the lawsuit in U.S. District Court against the Department of Social and Rehabilitation Services. The groups represent 330 privately owned and non-profit nursing homes in Kansas. ``We have worked extensively at the administrative and legislative branches of government to work out a solution to the rising health care costs of caring for our senior population, but to no avail,'' said Lou Esplund, chairwoman of KAHA. The lawsuit complains that the SRS payment system violates a federal law that requires states to pay ``reasonable and adequate costs'' for nursing home care. Tim Owens, attorney for SRS, declined to comment. John Grace, president of the Kansas Association of homes for the Aging, said federally mandated regulations took effect Oct. 1, requiring that nurses be on duty 24 hours. The state has earmarked $2 million to cover the cost of that regulation and others. But SRS officials estimated the total cost would be $30 million.

The Christmas season began auspiciously for some retailers but poorly for others as consumers, holding tight to their purse strings, shopped cautiously over the Thanksgiving weekend. The big retailers still face a rocky road to Christmas amid the uncertain outlook for consumer spending. Dayton Hudson Corp. was among the retailers plessed by its results. ``We're very encouraged by the start of the season,'' spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said Sunday. But the nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck and Co., had a disappointing weekend. Matthew Howard, Sears' senior vice president for marketing, said Sunday that sales were ``somewhat below our expectations.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal government opened fiscal 1991 with a $31.5 billion deficit in October, the first month of what is expected to be a record year for red ink, the Treasury Department said. The budget gap was 21 percent higher than the $26.1 billion deficit of October 1989. The increase reflects the buildup of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf and the escalation of the savings and loan bailout, officials said Friday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The New York Stock Exchange halted trading for more than 90 minutes because of a power disruption at the nation's largest stock market. The disruption Friday, which NYSE officials called the first in recent memory, shut down the exchange at 9:41 a.m. EST, 11 minutes into the start of trading. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano said the problem was power-related but that the exchange hadn't identified its exact cause. ---

Urging fur wearers to ``donate your dead'' and staging funeral processions for animals, activists around the country attacked the fur industry by taking to the streets on one of the busiest shopping days of the year. From Fifth Avenue in midtown Manhattan to a posh Denver mall to a shopping center in tiny Manchester, N.H., nearly 100 planned demonstrations filled high-fashion shopping spots Friday in what has become an annual ritual. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - If you're singing the blues about the cost of Christmas presents, be thankful your true love isn't asking for the complete catalog of gifts in ``The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' J. Patrick Bradley, that literal-minded chief economist at Provident National Bank, has once again toted up the sales slip for the items listed in the old carol, from a partridge in a pear tree to twelve drummers drumming. This year's total: $15,231.72, up 4.34 percent from last year, he said Friday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Thailand has agreed to legalize the import of American and other foreign cigarettes. In exchange, the government is ending its 18-month investigation of unfair trade charges against the nation. U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills announced the actions Friday. The investigation, which could have led to U.S. trade reprisals against Thailand, was in response to a 1989 petition by the U.S. Cigarette Export Association. --- MILAN, Italy (AP) - Raul Gardini, the chemical tycoon who advocates privatizing Italy's industry, is selling his stake in Enimont and leaving the troubled chemical joint venture to the state-controlled energy group ENI. Gardini, who had long sought to extend his control of Italy's chemical business through a takeover of Enimont, said Thursday he would sell his 40 percent stake for about $2.55 billion to Italy's state energy group. The stock is being sold to Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, also known as ENI. --- MADRID, Spain (AP) - Major carmakers in Spain plan hundreds of layoffs in coming months because of drooping sales. Economists say the moves are a clear signal the nation's economy is slowing down. A spokeswoman for Germany's Volkswagen AG Spanish subsidiary, SEAT SA, said Thursday that the company will cut production by 120 cars a day and lay off 700 temporary workers because of a sharp decline in sales in Spain this year. --- DALLAS (AP) - Francis ``Buddy'' Kemp, president of NCNB Corp., died of brain cancer at his home. He was 50. Kemp had been chairman of NCNB Texas since July 1988 when the Charlotte, N.C., banking company expanded into the state. He had suffered from brain cancer for more than a year before his death Friday. ---

Stock prices declined slightly Friday, turning downward near the close of the quietest session in nearly four years. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 12.13 to 2,527.23, finishing the week with a net loss of 23.02 points. The dollar was mostly higher. Bonds were lower in light trading. Soybean futures prices advanced, petroleum futures were sharply higher, metals posted gains, cattle advanced and pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Biggest Private Companies Double, Forbes Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The largest private U.S. companies' sales have doubled since 1985, due in large part to a dramatic rise in the number of leveraged buyouts, Forbes magazine reports. But despite the huge shift as publicly-held companies turn private, Minneapolis-based Cargill, a commodities marketer, maintained a firm grip on the number one spot for the sixth straight year of the Forbes annual ranking, with revenues of $44 billion last year. As companies continued to move up in the ranks in sales, one prominent private-company billionaire - Donald Trump - dropped off the ``Forbes 400'' list of the richest Americans, as his recent financial woes have dramatically diminished his net worth. Among companies, Cargill's total sales were nearly triple the sales of second-ranked Wichita, Kan.-based Koch Industries, a petroleum, natural gas and chemicals firm with an estimated $17.2 billion in sales. All told, the Forbes list of top private firms in the Dec. 10 edition showed that sales of the biggest 400 companies increased from $340 billion when the list was first started in 1985 to $609 billion last year. In 1989 the figure totaled $592 billion. Helping to boost the jump in sales, 120 of those firms have been taken private in leveraged buyouts, including such giants as R.H. Macy, RJR Nabisco, Trans World Airlines and the parents of Revlon and Northwest Airlines. Forbes reported that 48 of the 400 largest companies are based in New York -more than any other city. Chicago remains in second place on the ``Forbes 400'' list with 25 companies, followed by Dallas with 21 companies and Los Angeles with nine. Detroit, Houston and San Francisco share fifth place with seven firms each. The top state for private firms is New York with 65 companies. However, California moved up fast in the ranks, in second place with 42 companies up from seven last year. Texas is in third place with 39 firms, followed by Illinois with 29 and Florida with 20.

DOC.HEAD: Heseltine Would Bring the Biggest Changes, Economists Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Of the three contenders to succeed Margaret Thatcher as prime minister, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine would bring in the biggest economic changes, analysts say. But no matter who wins, economists say, no drastic changes such as big tax hikes or renationalizing industries are in sight. That's because Heseltine and the other two challengers, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, are capitalist Conservative Party members with ``impeccable Thatcherite credentials,'' as one economist put it. All three candidates have stressed that they want to build on Mrs. Thatcher's accomplishments, while suggesting they envision a gentler, kinder Britain. ``The differences between them are much more style than substance,'' said George Hodgson, an analyst at the London investment firm Warburg Securities. Paul Turnbull, an economist with Smith New Court PLC, said, ``The outlook for the U.K. economy is not radically different whoever is in power.'' Any of the three would continue current economic policy of high interest rates to fight 10.9 percent inflation, although the winner is expected to quickly cut the 14 percent base lending rate by a half or full percentage point to gain popularity. The winner will have little control over the current, downward course of the economy, partly because Britain has joined Europe's exchange rate mechanism, the economists said. That limits the government's ability to change interest rates very much because the pound must fluctuate within a narrow band. The new Conservative Party leader's policies are also bound to be influenced by the necessity to contest the socialist Labor Party in a national election by mid-1992. Heseltine, 57, is a flamboyant and ambitious self-made publishing millionaire who has patiently waited his opportunity since he walked out of Mrs. Thatcher's cabinet in 1986. He won enough votes from Conservative party members in a ballot last week to force a second ballot this coming Tuesday, prompting Mrs. Thatcher to resign. Major and Hurd then stepped forward together in a friendly challenge to Heseltine. Also self-made, the 47-year-old Major is a poor acrobat's son who climbed up from welfare recipient to banker to the top of his party. His campaign promotes the creation of a classless meritocracy in Britain. Hurd, 60, was educated at Eton and Cambridge and was a career diplomat before entering politics. He has been in the Cabinet since 1984 but has never been involved with economic issues. The most notable difference among the challengers is that Heseltine believes in government solutions to industrial problems. Major and Hurd emphasize free markets, although Hurd is regarded as the more liberal Tory of the two. ``Heseltine would try to make the management of the U.K. economy similar in style to what he thinks happened in Japan and Germany, where the government takes a much more interventionist line in trying to achieve certain strategic aims in industry,'' said David Kern, chief economist at National Westminster Bank. This has raised fears in the financial markets that he would strap companies with obligations and increase public spending, which would undermine the country's budget surplus and raise interest rates. However, Kern added, ``I'm not so sure in practice there will be that much difference.'' The economists also said Heseltine would go furthest on the two promises all the candidates have made: to embrace European union more enthusiastically than Mrs. Thatcher did, and to take another look at the highly unpopular per-capita community charge, or ``poll tax.'' However, Kern noted that whoever the winner is, ``Britain's tense relationship with Europe won't become a great love affair.'' Hodgson said all the contenders ``have got immaculate Thatcherite credentials. They are all fully committed to privatization. They're all fully committed to lowering tax rates as quickly as possible and as is prudent,'' Hodgson said. ``You may say that Thatcher may have gone but the fundamental commitment of the Conservative Party to widen individual choice (by shrinking government) remains theirs,'' Hodgson said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Matsushita Near Agreement on Purchase of MCA
DOC.TEXT: The entertainment giant MCA Inc. was near a decision on a buyout offer valued at more than $6.5 billion from Japan's Matshushita Electric Industrial Co., published reports said today. The Wall Street Journal said negotiations between the two companies concluded late Sunday and that the MCA board was preparing to approve the transaction. The Journal said the offer on the table was valued at about $6.8 billion, including $66 a share in cash and $5 a share in stock in MCA's New York-area television station, WWOR-TV. Federal rules prohibit a foreign company from owning a broadcast station. The New York Times said in today's editions that talks were continuing Sunday night on a buyout at $71 or $72 a share including cash and stock in the TV station. That would put the total value of the deal at around $6.7 billion. Calls were placed to spokesman for both companies today, but they were not immediately returned. If a deal were reached, MCA would be the second Hollywood studio to be acquired by a Japanese company in little more than a year and the fourth major American studio to be controlled by a foreign-based owner. MCA's competitor, Sony Corp. of Japan, agreed in September 1989 to aquire Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for about $5 billion including assumed debt. Two other major Hollywood studios are owned by foreign companies. Twentieth Century Fox is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd., based in Australia, and Italy's Pathe Communications Corp. recently completed a $1.3 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Inc. MCA is a major producer of movies such as ``Jaws,'' television shows such as ``Murder, She Wrote'' and records by Sheena Easton, Bobby Brown and Tiffany. Matshusita is a major consumer and industrial electronics manufacturer, whose brands include include Pansasonic, Technics and Quasar. It reportedly has been interested in an entertainment company to complement its line of entertainment hardware such as televisions, stereos and videocassette recorders. Talks between MCA and Matshushita were first disclosed in late September, and it was reported they were discussing a price of $80 to $90 a share. The discussions reportedly intensified in the past week. MCA, based in Universal City, Calif., earned $191 million on revenue of $3.4 billion last year. Matsushita earned $1.48 billion on sales of $37.8 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Ube, Marubeni Begin Plastics Venture In London
DOC.TEXT: Ube Industries Ltd., a Japanese maker of chemicals, cement and machinery, established a joint venture with Britain's Marubeni Corp. to provide plastic composites to users in Europe such as automakers and producers of office automation equipment, the Japanese companies announced Monday. The joint venture, European Technological Composites Ltd., is capitalized at 2 million pounds, or $3.9 million, with Ube Industries holding a 70 percent stake. Marubeni holds the remainder. The joint venture aims to build its own plant in the U.K., which is expected to produce plastic composites such as polypropylene composites beginning April 1992. Combined output at the new plant is seen at around 6,000 metric tons in the initial year, an official at Ube Industries said. Ube Industries and Marubeni established a joint plastic venture in Nashville, Tenn., in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Matsushita Buys MCA in Biggest Japanese Purchase of U.S. Company
PRECEDE New York
DOC.TEXT: In the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. said today it was buying MCA Inc., owner of Universal Studios, for $6.06 billion. Matsushita, a $27 billion giant known for such brand names as Panasonic, Quasar and Technics, is Japan's biggest manufacturer of consumer electronics equipment. By buying the maker of such box office hits as ``Jaws'' and ``Back to the Future,'' Matsushita seemed to be trying to keep pace with archrival Sony Corp., which bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion a year ago, analysts said. Universal is the fourth Hollywood studio to come under foreign control. The deal seems likely to exacerbate some fears in the United States that too many major U.S. companies are falling under Japanese control. Under the agreement, Matsushita is to start a cash tender offer of $66 a share for MCA's common stock by Nov. 30. MCA chairman and chief executive officer, Lew Wasserman, 77, stands to earn about $330 million from the deal. Wasserman had personal holdings of 5 million MCA shares, or 7 percent, and controlled an additional 6 million through trusts and charities. ``Matsushita is a great international company,'' Wasserman said. ``This combination assures the structural integrity of MCA and its worldwide operation. MCA will continue to operate under its own name and will be run by its existing management.'' The purchase, which followed two months of intense, sometimes frustrating negotiations, is seen as Matsushita's attempt to dominate the growing alliance of technological hardware and entertainment industries. ``Software and hardware have been developing simultaneously - they are like wheels of the same car,'' Akio Tanii, Matsushita's president, said at company headquarters in Osaka. ``We intend that excellent works made by MCA will be distributed all over the world through a variety of media.'' Analysts say Matsushita will now have a ready stock of high-profile movie and television programming to use for its high definition television, considered the next generation in home entertainment.

The stock market declined broadly today, faced with resurgent oil prices and higher interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 24.51 points to 2,502.72 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 233 up, 747 down and 416 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 17.71 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The price of crude oil for January delivery jumped about $2 a barrel, to near $34 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said the oil market heated up on word of a U.S. push for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of military force if Iraq doesn't withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 1. The same circumstances helped send bond prices lower and interest rates higher in the credit markets. Losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down { at 112[; Boeing, down ~ at 43}; General Electric, down ~ at 52}; Philip Morris, down ] at 47}, and General Motors, down { at 36~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.46 to 170.93. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .73 at 295.17. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 12.13 to 2,527.23, finishing the week with a net loss of 23.02 points. Declining issues nosed out advances on the NYSE, with 643 up, 681 down and 556 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 63.35 million shares, the lowest total in almost four years, against 140.66 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Up Sharply In Anticipation of U.N. Resolution on Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices soared about $2 per barrel on the futures market early today, as traders speculated the United Nations was about to authorize the use of force to push Iraq out of Kuwait. ``It's rocking and rolling in here this morning,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``The big news is the U.S. is said to be seeking a Jan. 1 deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal.'' U.S. officials said they plan ask the U.N. Security Council this week to approve a resolution that would authorize the use of military force against Iraq if Saddam Hussein does not pull his troops out of Kuwait by the first of the year. Iraq said it would not get out of Kuwait, which it occupied during August. Oil traders responded by bidding up the price of crude oil by almost $2 per barrel at the opening of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``Traders are looking for the resolution to be approved,'' Tagler said. While a U.N. resolution would not be an act of war, he said, the possibility that it will be approved leads oil traders to believe war in the Persian Gulf is now more likely. By late morning, light sweet crude was up $2.05 at $33.95 on contracts for delivery in January. Contracts for delivery in later months were all sharply higher. As crude futures shot up, contracts of delivery of refined petroleum products were also on the rise. Home heating oil jumped 6.04 cents to 94.70 per gallon on contracts for delivery in December, with later contract months all moving up by more than 5 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was up 5.35 cents at 87.75 cents a gallon on contracts for December delivery. Later contracts months all moved higher. ``Products are just tracking the crude up,'' said Christian Gohler, a broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Natural gas, meanwhile, was up 4.5 cents at $2.665 per 1,000 cubic feet on contracts for delivery in January. Later contract months were also higher. Crude's rise today was its second big jump in a row. During Friday's trading session, contracts for January delivery rose $2.27 a barrel. The session before that, crude moved up 72 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Block Increase In `Baby' Bell Access Rates
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a Texas telephone company that accused one of the so-called baby Bell phone companies of trying to drive it out of business. The court, without comment, refused to block Southwestern Bell from increasing access rates charged to the Texas company from $5,000 to about $77,000 a month. The Texas firm, DFW Metro Line Services, offers customers a flat rate for calls between Dallas and Fort Worth. DFW uses telephone lines leased from Southwestern Bell. The regional Bell company told DFW in June 1989 it must pay about $77,000 a month to lease the lines. Southwestern Bell said it had been charging DFW only $5,000 a month in the mistaken beief that DFW provided its customers with a paging service only. But DFW said Southwestern's real motive was to drive the Texas company out of business and eliminate a competitor. A federal judge refused DFW's request for an order that would bar Southwestern from increasing the access rates pending the outcome of DFW's lawsuit against the baby Bell company. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May also refused to issue an injunction blocking the rate increase. The appeals court said DFW failed to show it would suffer irreparable injury from the rate hike. The appeals court said that if DFW loses customers or even is forced out of business, it ultimately still could prevail in its suit against Southwestern and recover any losses it suffered. ``The lost goodwill of a business operated over a short period of time is usually compensable in money damages,'' the appeals court said. DFW has been in business since 1988. The case is DFW Metro Line Services vs. Southwestern Bell, 90-670.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Gain On Hopes For Soviet Sales
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices were modestly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after an opening surge linked to perceptions that a U.S.-Soviet grain deal is near. Wheat futures were fractionally lower; corn futures were slightly higher. Soviet grain-buying officials were visiting Washington today and were expected to discuss with government representatives the possibility of receiving export credits and striking a new long-term grain agreement. Dan Cekander, grains analyst with the Chicago trading company Rodman & Renshaw Inc., said a new grain agreement is not likely until the Soviets buy the 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and 1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat that remain under an existing grain pact. Cekander said strength in international vegetable oil markets also helped boost soybean prices. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.48\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent higher with December at $2.22} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $1.07 a bushel; and soybeans were 2 cents to 4 cents higher with January at $5.84\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, paced by sharp losses in the pork complex. Live cattle were .35 cent lower to .30 cent higher with December at 79.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .32 cent lower with January at 87.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .70 cent to 1.25 cents lower with December at 52.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.8 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with February at 69.40 cents a pound. Cattle futures rose while pork futures fell on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Jumps by 72 to Rebound After Two Weeks of Declines
DOC.TEXT: After two weeks of declines, the number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rebounded by 72 this week to bring the total to 1,175 nationwide, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. ``Some of that clearly is improvement of the weather that had been bad for the past two weeks, particularly in Oklahoma,'' said Ike Kerridge, a vice president at the toolmaker which keeps the count. ``But it also relates to the seasonal upturn expected during the last quarter of the year.'' The number of rigs had fallen by 41 rigs over the past two weeks, following heavy rains in the Oklahoma area. A year ago this week, the number of working rigs was 1,037. Kerridge said he could not forecast changes for the count, but believed it would grow in December because drillers will be using any remaining funds in calendar-year budgets. ``I still expect to see a rig count around 1,250 in December, but whether that will be at the beginning of the month or the middle or the end, I can't say,'' Kerridge said. ``The weather and the random movement of rigs that can effect it makes it impossible to predict on a week-by-week basis.'' Decreases in the previous weeks came on the heels of a milestone earlier in the month when the number of working rigs reached 1,144 - a high figure not seen since Dec. 28, 1987. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count - the widely watched index of drilling activity - since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Texas led the major oil producing states for the week, by adding 23 rigs to the count, followed by Oklahoma, whose count increased by 16, and Louisiana, which added 11 rigs. Other major oil producing states reporting increases for the week include California, up by nine; Wyoming, adding eight; Colorado, adding six; Kansas, which increased by four; New Mexico, up by three; and Michigan and North Dakota, which each added a rig. Ohio was the only major oil producing state to report a loss for the week, dropping by one. The count in Pennsylvania remained unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Freezing Half of Businesses' Accounts
DOC.TEXT: The government today proposed freezing 50 percent of the bank accounts of state-owned businesses by Saturday in an effort to cut the national budget deficit, Tass reported. The national defense budget also would drop by 10 percent and other Soviet agencies would take cuts of up to 30 percent under the 1991 national budget proposed to the legislature, the official news agency said. Finance Minister Victor Pavlov also said the nation's gross national product in the first nine months of 1990 dropped by 13 billion rubles, or $23.4 billion at the official rate, from the previous year, according to Tass. The government last month had said GNP for the period dropped 1.5 percent. The report was one of the most comprehensive yet on the state of the national economy. But a flourishing black market, critical shortages of most basic consumers goods and economic rebellion by many of the 15 Soviet republics made it difficult to determine how the final budget would shape up. Tass said the government budget was being divided for the first time into national and republic levels. It put the national government's share of the budget at 261 billion rubles, slightly less than half the total. The proposal on bank accounts, if approved, would be the first large sell-off of shares in state-owned businesses in Soviet history and a significant step in a massive scheme to denationalize state-owned industries. The proposal amounts to a drastic, last-ditch effort to cut the enormous Soviet budget deficit before the end of the year. The deficit stood last year at about 120 billion rubles. Pavlov told lawmakers that officials projected that this year's national deficit would be 56 billion rubles, or about $100 billion, out of a budget of 508 billion rubles, $915 billion. It was not clear if the figures included the spending freeze. The proposal would allow employees to receive the frozen funds only in the form of stock shares in their companies. Tass said the government would freeze 50 billion to 60 billion rubles, $90 billion $108 billion, of state-owned businesses' accounts - half of their total deposits - that the enterprises fail to use before Saturday. But the resources may be transferred to work collectives to buy shares in the enterprises. The news agency said the moratorium would be temporary, but did not say how long it would last. It was not clear whether employees would hold the stock in their own names or as a group. As part of the attempt to slash the budget deficit, 1991 foreign aid will be cut to one-quarter of this year's level, Tass said. A number of Communist countries, such as Cuba, have relied heavily on Soviet subsidies and are likely to be hit hard by the cutbacks. The defense budget is to drop to 64 billion rubles, $115 billion, next year, Tass said. That would be roughly 40 percent of the proposed national budget. The Soviet government bureaucracy faces a 30 percent budget cut, Tass reported. No other details were offered and it was unclear which government agencies would be hit hardest.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Buys MCA in Biggest Japanese Purchase of U.S. Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 new grafs to CLARIFY that deal values MCA at nearly $6.6 billion, including value of stock in television station, also updates stock price. Picks up 10th graf pvs: MCA chairman ... Also SUBS 19th graf pvs to CLARIFY that Pathe is Italian-controlled. Picks up 20th graf pvs Japanese companies ...
DOC.TEXT: In the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. company, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. said today it would buy MCA Inc., owner of Universal Studios, in a deal worth $6.6 billion. Matsushita, a $37.8 billion giant known for such brand names as Panasonic, Quasar and Technics, is Japan's biggest manufacturer of consumer electronics equipment. By buying the maker of such box office hits as ``Jaws'' and ``Back to the Future,'' Matsushita seemed to be trying to keep pace with archrival Sony Corp., which bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion a year ago, analysts said. Universal is the fourth Hollywood studio to come under foreign control. The deal seems likely to exacerbate some fears in the United States that too many major U.S. companies are falling under Japanese control. Under the agreement, Matsushita is to start a cash tender offer of $66 a share for MCA's about 92.8 million shares of common stock by Nov. 30. MCA shareholders will also get stock in a television station that cannot be sold to Matsushita because federal rules prohibit foreign-based companies from owning U.S. broadcast stations. The deal calls for MCA shareholders to get one share in a new company that will own MCA's New York-area television station, WWOR, for every five shares of MCA stock they own just before the tender offer is completed. Company officials have estimated the new shares will be worth about $5 for every share of MCA stock. Adding that to the $66 per share in cash brings the per-share value to $71, or nearly $6.6 billion, for MCA's fully diluted shares. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, MCA was the most actively traded issue, slipping 25 cents a share by late morning to $65.12{. MCA chairman and chief executive officer, Lew Wasserman, 77, stands to earn about $355 million from the deal based on his personal holdings alone of about 5 million MCA shares, or 7 percent. In addition, he controls an additional 6 million through trusts and charities. ``Matsushita is a great international company,'' Wasserman said. ``This combination assures the structural integrity of MCA and its worldwide operation. MCA will continue to operate under its own name and will be run by its existing management.'' The purchase, which followed two months of intense, sometimes frustrating negotiations, is seen as Matsushita's attempt to dominate the growing alliance of technological hardware and entertainment industries. ``Software and hardware have been developing simultaneously - they are like wheels of the same car,'' Akio Tanii, Matsushita's president, said at company headquarters in Osaka. ``We intend that excellent works made by MCA will be distributed all over the world through a variety of media.'' Analysts say Matsushita will now have a ready stock of high-profile movie and television programming to use for its high definition television, considered the next generation in home entertainment. ``Matsushita has been behind Sony in audio-visual and entertainment fields in the last couple of years,'' said Takatoshi Yamamoto of the investment firm Morgan Stanley. ``By acquiring MCA, Matsushita can obtain movie, record, broadcast and publishing industries all at once. ``Looking at the long-term effect of the deal, it will benefit Matsushita in producing and marketing HDTV, the competition for which is expected to intensify in the mid-1990s,'' he said. But in an atmosphere of trade friction between the United States and Japan -not to mention the potential of a further downturn in the U.S. economy - Matsushita is taking a big risk, analysts say. ``The biggest problem is the negative image f Japanese buying up everything in the U.S.,'' said Rodney Harada, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. ``One of the biggest reasons I was surprised by the deal was because Matsushita has always been careful to improve its image before.'' In addition to the Japanese purchases, 20th Century Fox is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., based in Australia, and Italian-controlled Pathe Communications Corp. recently completed a $1.3 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Inc. Japanese companies have caught most of the U.S. criticism, however, after making other high-profile purchases such as Rockefeller Center and the Pebble Beach golf club. But Matsushita, one of the world's leading manufacturers of industrial equipment and semiconductors, may have considered the deal a risk it couldn't refuse. Japanese consumer electronics companies have been looking to Hollywood to revitalize a flagging market for consumer video products and expand their control over the lucrative home entertainment market. Purchases of film libraries, for instance, allow them to release old movies and television shows in videotape format. ``People don't watch electrons and pixels,'' Steven Ross, chairman of another entertainment industry hybrid, Time-Warner Inc., said in a recent speech. ``They watch movies and programs. ... New technologies are still-born without software to animate them.'' Sony also purchased CBS Records, for example, and successfully used it in the 1980s to launch the compact disc as a format. Nonetheless, several analysts said the much-touted ``natural'' linkup between hardware manufacturers and movie, video and TV entertainment companies is still an unproven strategy. For one thing, digitalizing older movies and TV programs for HDTV is very expensive. ``It looks like they're doing it and trying to figure out strategy afterward,'' said Mike Jeremy, an analyst in Tokyo for Baring Securities. In Japan, Matsushita is jokingly called ``Maneshita,'' or ``copycat,'' for its custom of introducing products only after its competitors have tested the market for them. But some people envision a future of integrated home entertainment consoles that would include HDTV, a personal computer, stereo and other gadgetry. And that future may accrue to the company with the most prominent image, analysts said. ``Sony has a strong image. People in most countries would automatically know what a Walkman is,'' said Jeremy. ``Matsushita has Panasonic, Quasar and Technics, but they need to rationalize themselves into one image.'' Apart from Universal Pictures, which also produced such hits as ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' MCA's holdings include a robust television division featuring winners like ``Murder, She Wrote'' and ``Quantum Leap.'' MCA Records carries the popular teen vocalist Tiffany, as well as the sultry star Sheena Easton. MCA, which earned $191 million last year on revenues of $3.4 billion, also owns a book publishing division, theme parks and real estate. Matsushita earned $1.48 billion on sales of $37.8 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: The World's Greatest Mystery
DOC.TEXT: From a can of beans to a new car to a $100,000 variable rate mortgage, it's nearly impossible these days to find out in advance how much cash you'll be paying out. It may get worse. With recession threatening and consumer confidence low, so many merchants are cutting prices that the slash mark in advertisements is almost as common as the dollar sign. There are regular prices, discount prices, former prices, today-only prices, sale prices, cash-only prices, credit card prices, special prices, one-time-only prices and prices with discounts and rebates. Mix in sales taxes and cents-off and dollars-off coupons, and maybe figure in the specials of the day at the grocery store, and the arithmetic defies your ability to determine the total bill. Should you plan ahead and do the calculations in advance, you might then find prices changed by the time you get to the store. Quick price changes are easy on high-volume items, and electronic computers make it all the easier. Price confusion has long been the bane of the frequent traveler, who is confronted with so many airline rates - and exceptions by day of week or week of year - that agents become addled and can't figure their own commission. Car rental contracts may add mystery to the trip, and hotel room charges, including local taxes, can make a mockery of so-called quick checkout services. Skip the car rental and take a cab? Sure, and try to decipher the rate card. Perhaps you buy a car instead. By law, prices are posted on new car sales, but rare is the person who can predict to the penny what the total will be. If a trade-in is involved, a Nobel laureate might shy from the challenge. So you stay home. Nobody says you have to buy; you can communicate by telephone instead. Yes, but your telephone bills might be too involved to communicate with you. Well, you can read, too, and as your peruse your magazine you pull out a card offering a big discount off the newsstand price. Meanwhile, you spot an ad for the latest bestseller novel: ``Published price $19.95. Our price $16.54.'' In this day and age, of course, you can also communicate by facsimile or computer, but to get into that modern mode you must first own one or the other. You search the ads, and you read: ``Under $799,'' and ``From $499 up.'' This is a free-market economy at work, the biggest in the world, and you might argue that a variety of prices and frequent price changes reflect intense competition. But there are those who are convinced it is meant to confuse. How in the name of rationality, they ask, did automobile prices, to cite one example out of thousands, get way up there after years of refunds, rebates, dealer discounts, and desperate salesmen giving up part of their commissions? How, they ask, do consumer prices rise at 5 percent a year if almost everyone is slashing away like a bushwacker in the jungle, and most of the rest are boasting that theirs are everyday low prices? There is a mystery here, and a challenge to those would seek the answers. It is important to us all, somewhere on the scale between those other great unknowns, such as where the lost socks go and what's out there in space.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Kill Florida Affirmative Action Program
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to end an affirmative action program aimed at awarding more public works contracts to businesses run by minorities and women. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by companies that said the Tampa, Fla.-area program is unconstitutional because it condones reverse discrimination against white men. The affirmative action program was adopted in 1984 by Hillsborough County, which set a goal of awarding 25 percent of the value of all annual construction contracts to businesses owned by women and minorities. The program, in effect, calls for officials to favor contractors who have lined up companies run by minorities and women as subcontractors. If the contractor submitting the low bid on a project has met the county's affirmative action goals, that company is likely to win the contract. But the low bidder may lose if it fails to convince officials it has at least made a good-faith effort to meet those goals. In other cases affecting businesses, the court: -Rejected a challenge to the seizure by U.S. Customs agents of some 2,700 allegedly obscene magazines that were shipped from Cleveland and denied entry into Canada. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that the magazines could be treated as imports from a foreign country once they were headed back to Cleveland. -Refused to kill two fair-housing lawsuits that stem from newspaper real estate advertisements showing only white models posing as homeowners. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that forces developers of a Virginia condominium community to defend themselves against allegations they violated the Fair Housing Act. -Rejected an appeal by a Texas telephone company that accused one of the ``Baby Bell'' local phone companies of trying to drive it out of business. The court, without comment, refused to block Southwestern Bell from increasing access rates charged to the Texas company from $5,000 to about $77,000 a month. In the Florida affirmative action case, after a group of white-owned construction companies sued to overturn the program, a federal judge ruled it was unconstitutional and barred the county from enforcing it. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled the judge last August and reinstated the program, saying that at least on its face, it does not violate the Constitution's equal-protection guarantees. The appeals court sent the suit back for a trial at which the white-owned companies will have a chance to prove their allegations. The court said the Hillsborough plan appears to be significantly different from a so-called set-aside program adopted by Richmond, Va., that was overturned by the Supreme Court last year. The Richmond plan established a quota that required 30 percent of the value of annual public works contracts to be awarded to minority businesses. In striking down that plan, the high court said local governments must narrowly tailor affirmative action plans to remedy proven past bias. The appeals court said Hillsborough County acted only after a six-year, wholly voluntary plan failed to do enough to help minorities and women in the building industry. ``Unlike Richmond, Hillsborough County decided to implement its law based on statistics indicating that there was discrimination specifically in the construction business commissioned by the county,'' the appeals court said. It noted that the county shunned rigid quotas and only adopted flexible goals for awarding contracts to minorities and women.

DOC.HEAD: Production Cuts Also Hit Canadian Auto Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers said 12,600 employees in Canada will be laid off temporarily on top of the 38,800 U.S. employees being furloughed due to sagging North American sales. Ford Motor Co. said that starting Monday, 1,600 workers at Ford of Canada's Oakville, Ontario, truck plant would be laid off for two weeks and 1,150 workers at its two V-8 engine plants in Windsor, Ontario, would begin a one-week layoff. Ford said 700 people at its Essex V-6 engine plant in Windsor would be laid off for one week starting Dec. 10. The company's glass plant in Niagara Falls, Ontario, laid off 350 employees Monday, with 150 scheduled to return next Monday and the remainder to stay off for another week. Ford of Canada spokesman Jim Hartford said the layoffs were due to slumping sales in Canada and in the United States, where 80 percent of the company's Canadian production goes. General Motors of Canada announced layoffs of 7,000 employees in Ontario and Quebec last week, also citing slow sales. Chrysler Canada extended a Nov. 19 layoff of 1,800 workers at its van plant in Windsor through the first week of December. The pinch will be eased for employees by Canadian Auto Workers union contract agreements that provide laid-off workers with up to 95 percent of base pay during shutdowns. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler said the 38,000 U.S. layoffs, also aimed at cutting production to match slow demand, began at Thanksgiving and would run through Dec. 7 at 14 assembly plants in eight states.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slide as Hopes for USSR Sales Fade
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell moderately Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fading hopes for new sales of U.S. crops to the Soviet Union. DOC.HEAD: Heller CEO Tapped to Lead USF&G
DOC.TEXT: Norman P. Blake Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Heller International Corp., was named on Monday as chairman, president and chief executive officer of USF&G Corp. Blake, 49, has been the head of Chicago-based Heller since 1984. He succeeds Jack Moseley, who took early retirement earlier this month. USF&G is a diversified financial services company based in Baltimore. It sells property and casualty and life insurance, as well as financial services. The company recently slashed its dividend and embarked on a $75 million cost-cutting program earlier this month after losing $15 million in the third quarter. USF&G said it would cut costs by reducing staff at all levels. ``USF&G is an industry leader with a strong national franchise and a proud winning tradition,'' Blake said. ``The insurance sector, like the entire financial services industry, is entering an era of change that will require energy and creativity to meet competitive challenges.'' At Heller International, a wholly-owned subsidiary of The Fuji Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, Blake led a strong turnaround in profitability. He also worked at General Electric Credit Corp. as executive vice president financing operations, and from 1974 to 1976 was president of TOP Inc., a Detroit-based provider of insurance services.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Allows Whooping-Cough Suit to Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs at end on claims deadlines. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to shield a whooping cough vaccine manufacturer from a lawsuit that said company negligence caused brain damage in an inoculated infant. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories to stop the suit. Michelle Graham was given the vaccine in 1980 when she was a few months old. Soon after, she was diagnosed as suffering from severe brain damage that causes retardation. The Grahams, who sued Wyeth in Kansas and have since moved to Cabool, Mo., said the New York City-based company was negligent. The vaccine is used to immunize children against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. Charles and Tammy Graham said the vaccine component against pertussis, or whooping cough, was responsible for their daughter's brain damage. A federal jury's $15 million award to the Grahams was overturned by the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last June. But the appeals court, while saying the trial judge improperly excluded evidence that could help the drug company, refused to kill the suit. Wyeth said such suits should be precluded because its vaccine is licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The company argued that letting the Grahams sue has the effect of making state laws supreme over federal law in violation of the Constitution. Kansas laws on personal injury claims govern the outcome of the suit, even though it would be tried in federal court in that state. Congress recently extended the deadline to file claims under the National Vaccine Injury Act, which provides some compensation for those injured by vaccines. The deadline for those injured on or before Oct. 1, 1988, was extended from Oct. 1, 1990, to Jan. 31, 1991. But failure to file by the deadline does not bar the Grahams or anyone else frm suing for damages.

DOC.HEAD: Wood Products Company Expects No Better Than Break-Even Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Boise Cascade Corp. said Monday it expects to break even financially during the final three months of 1990. Officials at the wood products company said a weakening market for paper, pulp and corrugated containers, expansion costs and higher interest rates will reduce Boise Cascade's profitability. In a statement, the corporation predicted ``results for the fourth quarter of 1990 to be close to break-even'' compared with earnings of 27 cents per share in the third quarter. A break-even quarter would leave the company with just over $70 million in net income for 1990. That compares to $267.6 million in 1989, $289.1 million in 1988 and $183 million in 1987. In its earnings forecast, the company cited further weakening in some markets, high interest rates and modernization expenses at its mills in Rumford, Maine, and International Falls, Minn. It also said its building products segment has been operating at a loss since September because of high wood costs, sluggish demand and declining prices. Boise-Cascade has been on a cost-efficiency drive since undergoing severe economic stress in the early 1980s while gradually shifting its emphasis away from building products to paper and paper products.

DOC.HEAD: Iran In Accord To Buy Oil Products From Arab Gulf States
DOC.TEXT: Iran has reached agreement on direct purchases of petroleum products from several Arab states in the Persian Gulf, an official of the National Iranian Oil Co. said Monday. The company, which imports about 200,000 barrels a day of gas oil and kerosene, will now buy quantities of thse products directly from refineries in Bahrain, Qatar and Abu Dhabi, the official said. In the past, many Gulf states banned the sale of oil products to Iran because of their political support for Iraq during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait as dramatically reversed that political situation, and the Arab states are now actively courting Iran.

Stock prices bounced back from a broad early decline to finish with a small gain today. Prices fell at the outset as oil prices rose sharply and interest rates climbed. But the pressure on both bonds and stocks let up as the session progressed. The price of crude oil for January delivery climbed about $1 a barrel, to just under $33 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said the oil market heated up on word of a U.S. push for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of military force if Iraq doesn't withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 1. Interest rates on long-term Treasury bonds, which climbed to about 8.50 percent in the early going, fell back to near 8.41 percent by the close, down slightly from where they stood at the end of last week.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Better Prepared This Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Despite a looming recession, Alan Markus began the Christmas season at his Lazarus department store without the financial worries that dogged the company a year ago. Christmas 1989 fell three weeks before an avalanche of junk bond debt forced Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. to seek bankruptcy court protection for Lazarus, Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and seven other department store chains. But the Lazarus that Markus manages a block away from Federated and Allied headquarters can already see the difference a year makes. In 1989, ``we experienced some situations where we had difficulty receiving merchandise, whereas this year that's not a problem,'' Markus said in an interview recently. As they undergo Chapter 11 reorganization, Federated and Allied, subsidiaries of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., have back some of the stability and confidence they lacked at the start of last year's Christmas shopping season. Under bankruptcy law, their current suppliers are guaranteed payment. And while the retailers have undertaken a series of cost-cutting steps, other storeowners are now being forced to make the same moves to protect themselves from the current slump in consumer spending. To cut costs, the Federated and Allied chains have centralized their credit operations, cut back their executive staff and set up committees to plan merchandise buying. Their bankruptcy court status also let them end an expensive lease in New York. ``If there is a plus to our being in reorganization, it's that we have already taken those steps,'' Federated and Allied spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Janet Mangano, an industry analyst for Jessup, Josephthal & Co., said of the Campeau units, ``They're probably one of the best-positioned (retailers) because they were pretty much faced with the worst kind of environment - excluding a recession - in 1990.'' ``They changed their merchandise mix and got their shop in order,'' she said. Federated and Allied sought protection from their creditors on Jan. 15, citing $7.7 billion in debts, much of it from the high-priced junk bonds Campeau issued to buy the retailing giants. Retailers across the country - Federated and Allied included - are faced with a sharp drop-off in consumer spending this Christmas season. Retail sales, already sluggish because of the weakening economy, stalled in the summer after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices higher and left consumers with little extra money to go shopping with. Department stores were particularly hard-hit as customers cut out buying non-essentials such as clothing, furniture and home appliances - the core of their business. The Federated and Allied chains - which also include Maas Brothers, Bon Marche, Abraham & Straus, Rich's-Goldsmith's, Burdine's and Stern's - reported $680 million in sales in October, below expectations. Some of the stores, including the 40 Bon Marche branches in the Northwest, reported a good start to the Christmas shopping season. However, how well the retailers ultimately do during the holidays won't be known until after Dec. 25. Ms. Sanger said the companies have not altered their prediction, made in October, that they will emerge from bankruptcy next year. The forecast was based on the belief that a recession in the retail business would last through most of the year, she said. ``It's fair to say we would be more concerned if this were the year we were emerging from reorganization, because ... we would be facing more difficulties,'' she said. At the Lazarus in Cincinnati, Markus said he was prepared for customers to spend less money this year. ``I think our merchandise content is better this year and focused on strong key items ... identified as good sellers for the Christmas season,'' Markus said. ``We hope to come close to meeting last year's figures,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: last week.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 30 points at its morning low, closed with a 5.94 gain at 2,533.17. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 10 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 788 up, 716 down and 471 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 131.54 million shares, against Friday's four-year low of 63.35 million. The NYSE's composite index rose .57 to 172.96.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Won't Keep Yosemite Concession
With AM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Yosemite Park & Curry Co. will be sold to ``a qualified American buyer'' when Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. completes its acquisition of MCA Inc., officials said Monday. The park concession has been a small but controversial division of MCA, which Matsushita has offered to acquire in a deal worth $6.6 billion. Matsushita, one of Japan's largest consumer electronics manufacturers, will spin the concession off to blunt criticism over a Japanese company operating a national park concession. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan has indicated he would oppose a foreign company playing a major role at Yosemite or other parks. A press release said Matsushita will sell the concession ``to be responsive to environmental and other concerns that have been raised.'' The concession will be sold within a year after Matsushita's acquisition of MCA is completed, the press release added. ``Prior to the sale, Yosemite Park and Curry will be held in escrow and operated by its existing management and board,'' said John Poimiroo, the concession's vice president for communications. He explained that Yosemite Park & Curry Co. currently has a board of directors separate from MCA's. Between the time the sale of MCA becomes final and Matsushita sells Curry, the concession's income will be donated to the National Park Foundation to benefit Yosemite and other national parks, Poimiroo said. Whoever buys the concession will have to seek renewal of its contract with the National Park Service in 1993. Renewal may not be gained easily because MCA has been criticized for paying too little in its current agreement, and one other bidder already has surfaced. A group of environmentalists have formed the non-profit Yosemite Restoration Trust to try to win the concession business which includes restaurants, stores, transportation and lodging. David Curry began the concession in 1899, nine years after the park was founded. The present company was formed in 1925 and purchased by MCA in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Says More than 5,700 Schools Signed Up for Channel One
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications said Monday that more than 5,700 schools have signed contracts for its commercially sponsored Channel One news show for teens, and expects to reach its goal of 8,600 schools by next June. Chairman Christopher Whittle said all of the service's available commercial time has been either sold or optioned for sale to 13 different advertisers for the January-June period. Ed Winter, the Whittle executive overseeing the Channel One project, told reporters at a news briefing that Channel One should generate $65 million in gross revenue this school year, during which the number of schools under contract rose from about 600 in October 1989 to its November total of 5,718. He said revenues should rise to $110 million in the 1991-92 school year, which would be the first at which the service operated for an entire year with its full complement of schools. Winter said that is more than four times the $25 million Cable News Network generated in its third year and more than triple the $37 million that ESPN produced in its third year in operation. ESPN and CNN are among the biggest cable TV networks in the United States. The Channel One service has been widely criticized by national education groups for bringing paid advertising into the classroom, when children are required by law to be in school and must sit and watch. Each 12-minute show includes two minutes of paid commercials for products such as breath mints, candy bars, movies and toothpaste. Whittle transmits the show to schools by satellite overnight each night. The Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company equips every participating school with videocassette recorders and TV monitors for every classroom that the schools can keep as long as they show the program, with ads, daily to all their students. The producers of the program say schools would not have access to the equipment were it not for the money generated for it from commercials. The schools signed to date are in every state except Hawaii, Alaska, Maine, Rhode Island and Nevada. Whittle told reporters that once Channel One reaches 8,000 schools, it will begin to exhaust its budget for equipment and will have to sign up more advertisers to pay for the additional TVs and VCRs. He said Channel One won't increase the amount of advertising it carries per show, but may cut back on how often each advertiser appears and may cut out its donation of free time for public service messages such as anti-drug ads. Advertisers are currently charged at a rate of $150,000 for a 30-second commercial reaching an audience of 6 million teens. Whittle says that rate compares favorably with those available for reaching teens on other TV shows. For next school year, Whittle said he hopes to use the Channel One system to make available up to five special programs that may include advertising or be available on a pay-per-view basis to schools that wish to show them. He said topics for the specials could include a 30-minute program on a space shot, for instance, or shows related to academic courses. In addition, he said Channel One will consider leasing its transmission system to other program producers for after-school events like a rock concert, a sports show or meetings by various groups. Participating schools will not be obligated to use such programs. ``We don't make the decision on whether these programs will be aired. The schools make the decision on whether to air it,'' he said. Whittle said he doesn't expect the revenue generated from such programs will ever exceed 15 percent of the revenue generated for Channel One.

Prices fell at the outset as oil prices rose sharply and interest rates climbed. But the pressure on both bonds and stocks let up as the session progressed. The price of crude oil for January delivery climbed about $1 a barrel, to just under $33 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said the oil market heated up on word of a U.S. push for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of military force if Iraq doesn't withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 1. Interest rates on long-term Treasury bonds, which climbed to about 8.50 percent in the early going, fell back to near 8.41 percent by the close, down slightly from where they stood at the end of last week. Wall Streeters are expecting a challenge of sorts to the recent bond-market rally later this week, when the government reports on the gross national product for the third quarter of the year. Economists are looking for the data to show an increase at an annual rate of 2.1 percent or 2.2 percent, after adjustment for inflation, up from an earlier estimate of 1.8 percent. Boise Cascade, which estimated fourth-quarter results near the breakeven point, dropped ] to 23{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $5.93 billion, or 0.20 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .57 to 172.96. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.54 to 371.25, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.41 at 316.51.
