DOC.HEAD: U.S. Might Step Up Export Subsidies, Yeutter Says
DOC.TEXT: The United States may boost subsidies of its agricultural exports should international trade talks fail to reduce foreign trade barriers, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Monday. The final round of the talks is scheduled next week in Brussels, and the chances of reaching an agreement to cut agricultural subsidies worldwide is ``very slim,'' Yeutter said. Yeutter has refused to say how the United States would retaliate against European countries if they refuse to agree to subsidy cuts the United States wants. ``What I've indicated persistently and consistently in recent months ... is that we'll protect our own interests. The (European) Community can draw its own conclusions as to what that means, and we're not going to telescope what that means,'' Yeutter said. However, the 1990 farm bill authorizes Congress to increase U.S. export subsidies to $1 billion a year to counter foreign farm supports. About $425 million is budgeted for 1991. ``We're pleased that authorization is there because it may become essential,'' Yeutter said during a question-and-answer session with reporters. EC countries spend 20 times as much as the United States on export subsidies, Yeutter said. ``That's just an intolerable situation.'' The Bush administration proposed eliminating 75 percent of current domestic farm supports and import barriers and reducing export subsidies by 90 percent. The EC has offered to trim 30 percent of 1986 support levels. The farm issue is considered key to completion of the current round of global trade talks, which involve 105 nations under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The administration has made GATT reform a top priority in the belief that lowering trade barriers offers the best chance of expanding U.S. exports of agricultural products and other goods and services. Dairy producers, for example, need new markets overseas because domestic consumption is reaching its limit, Yeutter said. He defended the market orientation of the 1990 farm bill, saying it would benefit farmers whose planting practices were restricted by government policy. The five-year farm bill now awaiting President Bush's signature gives farmers the option of planting what they choose on 15 percent of the acreage that is normally reserved for subsidized crops. Another provision would pay farmers to idle wheat acreage and plant sunflowers and other oilseeds that many farmers have quit growing in recent years. ``If we believe in markets we should be favorably disposed to these provisions,'' Yeutter said. ``If we don't believe in markets we should move to the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises on Gulf Jitters, Gold Also Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced moderately against most major currencies Monday, boosted by growing concerns about the Middle East. Gold prices moved moderately higher. Analysts said the foreign exchange markets were ``Middle East-driven,'' with traders focused on the Bush administration's attempts to win support for a proposed U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing military force to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. Investors tend to view the dollar as a relatively safe haven during times of political uncertainty overseas. Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for Bank of New York Co., said other currencies - in particular the German mark - were also beneficiaries of fears about war. The mark declined against the dollar, but gained against other currencies. The dollar closed at 1.4870 marks in New York, up from 1.4860 on Friday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.4920 German marks, up from 1.4860. The U.S. currency rose as far as 1.4948 marks in New York but then fell back, leaving traders skeptical about the dollar's chances for holding on to its gains. Meanwhile, the yen suffered as war speculation raised questions about the Japanese economy. The counrry is heavily dependent on the Middle East for its energy needs, importing 99 percent of the oil it uses. The dollar jumped to 129.05 yen in New York from late Friday's 127.10. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.95 yen, up 0.82 yen from Thursday's close of 127.13 yen. There was no trading in Tokyo on Friday because of a holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 128.75 yen. The dollar turned in a mixed performance against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.96895 in New York from late Friday's $1.9668. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.9655 from $1.9670 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.2620 Swiss francs, up from 1.2600; 5.0130 French francs, up from 5.0115; 1,116.125 Italian lire, up from 1,115.50; and 1.16075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16015. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4920 German marks, up from 1.4860; 1.2680 Swiss francs, up from 1.2583; 5.0300 French francs, up from 5.0075; 1.6823 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6760; 1,118.75 Italian lire, up from 1,115.00; and 1.1596 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1592. Gold rose in New York, picking up $2.40 to close at $386.10 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $386.15, up $2.40. In London earlier, gold rose to a late bid price of $387.00 a troy ounce from $383.75 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $386.50 from $383.25 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $7.10 an ounce to close at $386.35. Silver prices also rose, with the metal gaining 2.3 cents to close at $4.149 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. In London, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.18 a troy ounce from Friday's $4.15.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Fall As Hopes For Soviet Sales Dim
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell broadly Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fading hopes for new sales of U.S. crops to the Soviet Union. On other commodity markets, pork futures plunged; cattle futures were mostly higher; oil futures surged; and precious metals advanced. In Chicago, wheat futures settled 4 cents to 6 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.43{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3} cents lower with December at $2.18} a bushel; oats were 3\ cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.04{ a bushel; soybeans were 2} cents to 5{ cents lower with January at $5.76{ a bushel. Monday's losses erased most of the gains the grain and soybean markets posted late last week. Selling accelerated after Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the Bush administration still insists the Soviet Union formally liberalize its emigration policies before it can be eligible for export credit guarantees. Yeutter's statement dashed hopes that a meeting Monday between Agriculture Department representatives and Soviet officials would lead to a new grain sales. ``I think there was a feeling that with political compromise over the Soviet stand in the Persian Gulf situation, the United States would compromise on food credit,'' said William Biedermann, research director with the Chicago-area commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Gerald Zusel, a vice president in the grain-trading division of E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc., said Moscow has relaxed emigration restrictions unofficially. The impasse over grain sales to the Soviets is ``like a bad game'' in which U.S. farmers are the losers because slack export sales mean low prices, he said. ``The administration is saying no change in export policy, no credit. The Russians are saying no credit, we ain't buying,'' Zusel said. Pork futures crashed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by limit losses in the pork-belly market that reflected perceptions that high prices are stifling retail bacon demand. The market got another dose of bearish news after the close when the USDA released a monthly report that showed a much higher-than-expected supply of frozen pork bellies. The government reported there were 5.5 million pounds of bellies in the nation's commercial freezers on Oct. 31. Although it was the second-lowest Oct. 31 stocks figure on record, the number was far above the average trade estimate of 4.7 million pounds. Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Inc., said the market likely will fall further in the near term, ``but the bottom line is we still need to put more bellies into storage.'' Cattle prices firmed as the discount of futures to cash prices stimulated buying interest on the futures market. Live cattle futures were .10 cent to .50 cent higher with December at 78.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .45 cent higher with January at 88.22 cents a pound; live hogs were .72 cent to 1.43 cents lower with December at 52.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.8 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with February at 69.40 cents a pound. Oil futures jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange as escalating tensions in the Persian Gulf standoff prompted new buying. Among the factors contributing to war fears were a warning from Mikhail Gorbachev that Iraq's aggression against Kuwait would be punished, a call-up of U.S. combat reserves from four states, and movement toward a United Nations resolution authorizing force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Light, sweet crude oil futures finished 2 cents to $1.56 higher with January at $32.95 a barrel; heating oil was 2.07 cents to 3.96 cents higher with December at 92.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.8 cents to 2.5 cents higher with December at 84.2 cents a gallon. Precious metal futures followed the oil markets higher. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled $2.20 to $2.40 higher with November at $386.10 a troy ounce; silver was 2.2 cents to 2.6 cents higher with December at $4.152 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Hughes Aircraft to Open Electronic Components Plant in Spain
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s Hughes Aircraft subsidiary said Monday it has set up a company in Spain to supply the expanding commercial and industrial markets for electric components in Europe. Hughes said the move will be accompanied by expanded marketing efforts in Europe, and other new factories are being considered. Hughes Microelectronics Europa Espana SA will be built on nine acres of land in a new industrial park in Malaga, a Mediterranean seaport that hopes to become a center of technology. By 1994, it will employ 400 workers, all Spanish and about a quarter of them engineers, Hughes Aircraft said. The Spanish operation is a subsidiary of Hughes' Microelectronics Europa Ltd. in Scotland, which is part of Hughes' Torrance-based Industrial Electronics Group.

DOC.HEAD: Microwave Corp., AT&T In Joint Radio Products Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS second graf to DELETE reference to ``over the air.''
DOC.TEXT: Microwave Corp. and AT&T have entered into an agreement to develop advanced microwave radio products for use in phone networks and private radio systems, the companies said Monday. The two will develop digital radio products that will use a new industry standard to send signals through the fiber-optic cables increasingly used in telephone networks. The new standard is based on a technology called synchronous digital hierarchy transmission. ``Technology which evolves from this joint development effort will be available to both companies for future products,'' the announcement said. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Both companies will market the new radio products, with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. concentrating on high-capacity applications and Digital Microwave on low- to medium-capacity uses. Microwave Corp. has had an association with AT&T since 1985. Under it, AT&T sells Microwave products under the AT&T brand.

DOC.HEAD: Hitachi Demonstrates Computer That Mimics Brain
DOC.TEXT: Hitachi Ltd. demonstrated a computer Monday that mimics the learning and problem-solving capabilities of the human brain, and said the machine is the fastest of its type. The Japanese computer maker said its so-called neural computer can carry out 2.3 billion operations per second, the highest performance ever for such a machine. Hitachi demonstrated its computer at a technology fair it put on for reporters and financial analysts. The machine contains 1,152 ``neurons,'' the electronic devices that act as processors in neural computers. Conventional computers need to be given an exact list of instructions for carrying out a job, but a neural machine can figure out how to perform a task based on the information given it. Neural computers also can reconize patterns. However, neural machines are poor at numerical calculations, the forte of conventional computers. Hitachi said its machine would be useful for programs such as signature recognition and predicting stock prices, tasks that usually would require the power of a large and expensive supercomputers using conventional technology. Though Hitachi's machine is an experimental model, a production version could be available in Japan in as little as two years, said Shojiro Asai, deputy director of Hitachi's main research center. He said production models would take the form of an attachment to conventional computer workstations.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Begins Shipping Advanced Microprocessor
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. has begun shipping large quantities of its most advanced computer microprocessor after a lengthy delay, the company said Monday. The chip, unveiled almost two years ago, can execute 20 million instructions per second. It combines functions that require up to 50 chips in most computers. But flaws have plagued the chip, called the 68040, causing several production delays since it was announced in March 1989. The announcement beat arch rival Intel Corp.'s unveiling of its advanced 80486 chip by about a month. Intel got its chip on the market last year. Murray Goldman, senior vice president of Motorola's Microprocessor and Memory Technologies Group, blamed the delays on the chip's complexity. It packs 1.2 million transistors and is among the fastest chips made. The company used the delays to design a chip faster, cheaper and smaller than its rivals, Goldman said. ``It has hurt us that I'm late with the 040,'' Goldman said. ``I paid a price for doing this. Now, my competitors are going to pay a price.'' Motorola switched production of the chip at its plant in Austin, Texas, on Nov. 16 and began shipping several hundred chips last week. The company hopes to hit peak production of 1,000 chips a week by January, said Jim Reinhart, marketing manager for the chip line. Microprocessors act as the brains, or central processors, of personal computers. Apple Computer Inc. and Hewlett-Packard Co. lead 36 computer system and board manufacturers intending to use the 68040 in future products, Motorola said. But one analyst believes the delays in achieving full production doomed the microprocessor group. This is the latest in a long string of similar announcements, said Rick Whittington, semiconductor analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. ``They went out and ballyhooed this thing a year and a half ago as the next coming of the Lord, and we've been waiting for it,'' Whittington said. ``Now it's here, we hope, and it's a good thing. If not, you could pretty well sign that group's death warrant. As it is, they get a reprieve, but the patient has problems.'' Jay Samstag, vice president and computer analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago, disagreed. ``It's a lead part, and I'm sure there's other business that comes along with it, but you have to put that in perspective. They have a very large product line,'' Samstag said. Motorola stock closed at $53 Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from Friday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Editors: Disregard f0245, AM-Time-Paramount, which moved inadvertantly on these circuits. The story is outdated. ^The AP
BHA Aviation Withdraws Offer For Eastern Airlines' Florida Commuter
DOC.TEXT: An investor group announced Monday it has withdrawn its bid to buy Eastern Airlines' Florida and Bahamas commuter subsidiary, Bar Harbor Airways. Jack E. Robinson, a principal of the Miami-based investor group, BHA Aviation Inc., said the investors and Eastern agreed on the price, but weren't able to settle on certain contractual provisions. Until recently, Robinson was the president of Bar Harbor, which operates as Eastern Express. Eastern asked for bids on the commuter airline earlier this fall. ``What you've got is a very unique situation. I left Bar Harbor at end of October, found investors, and we made our bid in early November to Eastern,'' Robinson said from New York in a telephone interview. ``Our bid was chosen from among several others as the most attractive, and we proceeded to negotiations.'' There was no immediate comment from financially-ailing Eastern, which plans to return to bankruptcy court in New York on Dec. 3 in hopes of receiving its second $15 million infusion of operating capital in three weeks. Calls to Eastern's corporate offices Monday were not returned. Robinson refused to specify what contractual provisions snagged the BHA offer. Bar Harbor has 184 scheduled daily flights serving 20 cities in Florida and the Bahamas. It is Florida's largest commuter airline, with hubs in Miami and Tampa.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Electronics Giant Gobbles `Jaws' Maker MCA in Hollywood Megadeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 3rd graf pvs, The purchase ..., to UPDATE with Geffen reaction; PICK UP 4th graf pvs, But the ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA5,LA6,NY20
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc., one of America's most precious entertainment gems, will be acquired by Japanese business giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. in a $6.6 billion deal that firmly establishes Japan's presence in Hollywood moviemaking. Even at that huge price tag - the largest ever for a Japanese purchase of a U.S. company - the deal announced Monday was mildly disappointing to investors who had been anticipating the purchase since it was first rumored in September. The purchase, which includes Universal Studios, figures out to about $71 per MCA share. The takeover-starved market had been hoping for something closer to $90. ``I would be happier if it was more, sure. But I'm very happy with the price,'' said David Geffen, MCA's largest single shareholder and head of Geffen Records, an MCA subsidiary. Geffen received his stock when MCA bought his record company last year. The deal will bring Geffen more than $700 million. But the buyout accomplishes an objective for Matsushita, which needed the entertainment ``software'' of MCA to complement its electronics ``hardware.'' The combination mirrors one struck by Sony Corp., which bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion a year ago. With MCA in its fold, Matsushita will try to compete more effectively against its archrival Sony and shake its image as a copycat exploiting the technological advances of other companies. Matsushita is Japan's largest electronics company and is familiar to American consumers through brand names such as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. MCA, which began 65 years ago as a booking agent for jazz bands, has grown to become a colossus of films (``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future''), records (Reba McEntire, Elton John, Guns N' Roses, Bobby Brown, George Strait) and television (``Murder, She Wrote,'' ``Major Dad''). Its Florida and California theme parks are exceeded only by Disney's. ``Software and hardware have been developing simultaneously - they are like wheels of the same car,'' Akio Tanii, Matsushita's president, said at company headquarters in Osaka, Japan. ``We intend that excellent works made by MCA will be distributed all over the world through a variety of media.'' Big foreign investments in Hollywood have become a regular occurrence since Rupert Murdoch's Australia-based News Corp. bought 20th Century Fox in 1985. Just this month, MGM-UA Communication Co. was purchased by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications for $1.3 billion. Disney said last month it was launching a partnership to raise at least $600 million from Japanese investors to make movies. Until the MCA deal, Sony's acquisition of Columbia was the largest Japanese purchase of a U.S. business. Sony also owns CBS Records. The merged Matsushita and MCA will yield a far larger company. Their combined revenues in 1990 will be $51 billion, according to the Value Line Investment Survey. That compares with $27 billion for Sony-Columbia, and $11 billion for the largest studio-based U.S. conglomerate, Time-Warner Inc. ``This agreement ... will create synergies that neither company could achieve alone,'' said MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman, who is widely regarded as a leader and mediator for all of Hollywood, not just MCA. MCA President Sidney Sheinberg said the decision to sell MCA was difficult, but a ``nothing short of a duty'' to shareholders and employees given the globalization of the marketplace. ``They have indicated their respect for our autonomy and corporate culture,'' Sheinberg said. Despite those assurances, the acquisition seems certain to provide fuel for critics of Japanese investment in the United States, like the Columbia deal and the recent purchases of real estate trophies such as Rockefeller Center in New York City and Pebble Beach in California. Matsushita is barred by federal law from owning one key MCA property, WWOR-TV in the New York area. That station will be spun off into a separate company with MCA's current shareholders owning its stock. Addressing another sore point, Matsushita said MCA's Curry Co. subsidiary, which operates restaurants, hotels and other services in Yosemite National Park, will be sold within a year. Curry is a tiny though highly profitable fragment of MCA's business. The idea of it being Japanese-owned produced harsh criticism. Complaints go much further. The record producing and composing legend Quincy Jones, expressing the private fears of many in Hollywood, said recently that foreigners are being allowed to buy America's legacy. In addition, Jewish groups have protested Matsushita's honoring of the Arab-sponsored boycott of Israel. ``Matsushita's discriminatory policies are not only reprehensible on ethical grounds but contradict the bedrock principle of free and open trade between nations,'' the World Jewish Congress said in a statement Monday. Most independent observers say Matsushita knows it is foolish to meddle with an American success that has never been duplicated abroad. They believe it will follow the lead of Sony, which has lavished hundreds of millions of dollars on megastars like Michael Jackson and megaproducers like Peter Guber and Jon Peters, while adopting a generally hands-off style toward management of its U.S. entertainment holdings. ``It doesn't help them to interfere in the creative process and interfere in the quality of the product for some philosophical, political or other purpose,'' said Jeff Logsdon, an entertainment analyst with Siedler Amdec Securities Inc. MCA stockholders will receive $66 per share in cash from Matsushita, except for the 5 million shares held by Wasserman, who will get an equivalent amount in preferred stock in a newly organized Matsushita subsidiary for his shares. The MCA chief had sought to avoid having to pay taxes on a cash deal. In addition, MCA shareholders will receive new stock in WWOR, which is worth about $5 per share of their MCA common stock. There are about 92.8 million shares of MCA common stock outstanding on a fully diluted basis, making the deal worth nearly $6.6 billion. MCA officials originally had hoped for better, but fears about debt-laden deals in a sluggish economy made credit tight and investors wary worldwide. The disappointment was evident in trading of MCA shares Monday, which dropped 25 cents to $65.12{ while leading the most active list of New York Stock Exchange issues.
